title: Applying Machine Learning To Detect Abnormal Vibrations Through Cutting Force And Vibration Acceleration During External Turning
authors: Quang Ngoc The Ho, Tan Phat Nguyen, Duc Quyen Nguyen, Ngoc Phan Nguyen, Toan Phat Le, Thanh Trung Do
abstract: Turning is one of the most widely used metal machining processes, in which the occurrence of vibration is unavoidable. Excessive vibration can result in dimensional inaccuracies and deterioration of surface quality. This study presents the design and development of a cost-effective device capable of detecting excessive vibration by measuring acceleration and cutting force signals directly from the turning tool holder during external cylindrical turning. Based on the acquired sensor data, two machine learning models - LSTM and ResNet18 - were implemented to identify abnormal vibration patterns. The experimental results demonstrated that the proposed models achieved a detection accuracy of up to 98% in identifying excessive vibrations. Owing to its low-cost hardware and high detection performance, the proposed system holds significant potential for practical deployment in industrial machining environments.

title: Finite Element and Power Electronics Co-Design of A 12 V Permanent Magnet Motor for Electric Power Steering Applications
authors: I Wayan Adiyasa, Kurniawan Sigit Wahyudi, Ninda Kurniadi, Fajrin Sidiq Muzaffarul Zaman, Agus Widyianto, Mohamad Heerwan Bin Peeie
abstract: This study presents a finite element analysis and power electronics co-design for a 12 V low-voltage permanent magnet motor (PMSM) applied to an Electric Power Steering (EPS) system. Finite element method (FEM) analysis is used to evaluate the electromagnetic characteristics, including cogging torque, torque-speed, core losses, and back-EMF distribution. The motor is able to maintain a torque of $2,046 \mathrm{~N}. \mathrm{m}$ at a speed of 1378.49 rpm with a cogging torque fluctuation of only 87.1 mNm. The system efficiency is recorded at 83.82% with an input power of 352.36 W and an output power of 295.36 W. Integration of power electronics simulations shows the circuit’s ability to maintain stable motor torque, with copper losses fluctuating in the range of $40-50 \mathrm{~W}$. The co-design approach can meet the EPS requirements in terms of efficiency, electromagnetic performance, and thermal reliability.

title: A ZVS-PWM Three-Phase DC/AC Converter
authors: Chien-Ming Wang, I-Hsiang Wang, Yu-Zhe Lee, Tzu-Yuan Lan
abstract: This paper presents a ZVS-PWM three-phase DC/AC converter which is composed of two capacitors, six power switches, three resonant tanks, and three output filters. It can be seen as a combination of three independent half-bridge ZVS-PWM DC/AC converters. They operate independently but 120 degrees out of phase with each other. Each of them uses its own resonant tank to generate its own high-frequency resonant voltage waveforms and then combines them to form its own sinewave output voltage waveform with lower high frequency harmonics. The resonant tanks also provide ZVS function on all power switches. The switch loss and EMI of proposed converter is lower. The presented DC/AC converter uses the three-phase sinusoidal pulse width modulation (SPWM) control technique to regulate system dynamic characteristic. This paper designs and makes a 2000 W ZVS-PWM three-phase DC/AC converter to verify circuit performance.

title: A Basic Study on Feedback Control of Conducted EMI in a Three-Phase Inverter Using Digital Active Gate Drive
authors: Shimon Shigetomi, Katsuhiro Hata, Hidemine Obara
abstract: Previous methods with a conventional gate driver often suffer from a trade-off between EMI and switching losses. This paper proposes a real-time feedback control method using a digital active gate drive (DAGD) to overcome this trade-off in a three-phase inverter system. The proposed system monitors conducted EMI in the $\mathbf{5 -3 0 ~ M H z}$ range using a LISN and spectrum analyzer and automatically adjusts the gate drive strength to maintain the EMI level at a predefined target. The experimental results demonstrated that the EMI level successfully converged to the two different target values during continuous operation, regardless of the initial settings. This effective EMI tracking enables reduced switching losses by avoiding EMI over-suppression.

title: Design of Leakage Inductance in Toroidal Transformers Using Magnetic-Material Filament
authors: Jinxing Zhou, Koji Orikawa
abstract: This paper presents a design method for the primary leakage inductance of toroidal transformers for pulse power supplies. The transformer employs printed circuit boards (PCBs) for the windings, and the leakage inductance is adjusted by varying the spacer height between the primary and secondary windings. A total-permeance-based formula was derived and validated with prototypes. Measurement results showed a linear spacer-inductance relationship with less than 10% error. When the space between the primary winding and secondary winding is only the air, a 21% slope deviation was observed with increased spacer height, due to copper-foil leakage flux. Inserting a magnetic-material filament into part of the air gap reduced the slope error to 3%. This modification also enabled the target inductance to be achieved with a 34% lower spacer height, facilitating miniaturization for high-frequency pulse power transformers.

title: Development of a GaN-Based Multiphase Synchronous Rectification Buck Converter
authors: Mei-Fang Wang, Wei Chang, Yen-Rung Lin, Cheng-Hao Weng, Tzung-Lin Lee
abstract: This paper proposes a four-phase synchronous rectification buck converter based on gallium nitride (GaN) power devices, achieving both high efficiency and high-power density. The system adopts synchronous rectification to reduce conduction and switching losses, while employing multiphase interleaving to distribute current, suppress ripple, and alleviate capacitor stress. Compared with conventional multi-phase buck converters, this work introduces a modified duty-offset method for current sharing control, which replaces the conventional algorithm, shortens computation time, and improves system stability. In addition, a Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller is implemented to enhance dynamic response at high frequencies. Experimental results show that the proposed converter achieves a peak efficiency of 96.657% at an output power of 432 W, confirming both the feasibility and the distinct advantages of the proposed method for high-current, high-efficiency applications.

title: Seamless Transition Switching Control Technique Between DCM and CCM for Four-Switch Buck-Boost DC-DC Converters
authors: Yen-Shin Lai, Yu-Hao Su, Si-Yu Lai
abstract: A new seamless transition switching control technique between CCM and DCM for four-switch buck-boost converter is proposed in this paper to significantly improve light-load efficiency. This proposed seamless transition switching control technique does not require the additional zero-crossing detector for the judgement of DCM and CCM. An on-line calculation method which is simple is proposed, instead. This approach reduces conduction losses under light-loads, thereby improving the light-load efficiency. The circuit specifications include an input voltage of 96 V, an output voltage range of 70 V to 150 V, and a rated power of 1 kW. Experimental results demonstrate a peak efficiency of 98.97%.

title: Primary-Side Current Based SR Control for High Voltage and High Frequency Cascoded Dual Half-Bridge Resonant Converter
authors: Pin-Hao Haung, Tsorng-Juu Liang, Kai-Hui Chen, Ching-Ya Chien, Ching-Ya Chien
abstract: In the paper, the cascoded dual-half-bridge (CDHB) resonant converter is implemented with the GaN power devices for high-input voltage applications because the voltage stress on power switches is reduced. Since power devices of the CDHB resonant converter can be operated with soft-switching, the system efficiency is increased and therefore increasing the switching frequency and the power density of the converter. In this paper, the primary-side current is detected to generate the control signal of the secondary-side synchronous rectifiers, reducing conduction losses. Finally, an experimental prototype of the CDHB resonant converter with the presented primaryside based synchronous rectification control method is implemented. The input voltage range is 740 V to 840 V, the output voltage is 15 V, the rated power is 105 W, and the series resonant frequency is designed at 1 MHz. At the input voltage of 800 V and the current output of 4.2 A condition, the highest efficiency is achieved at 94%.

title: Spectroscopic and Morphological Characterization of Dust Deposition Effects on Bifacial PV String Performance After Two-Year Field Exposure in Tropical Climate
authors: Md. Imamul Islam, Mohammadreza Lak, Mohd Shawal Jadin, Ahmed Al Mansur, Sahel Solemanifard
abstract: Bifacial photovoltaic (PV) systems are increasingly deployed in open-field environments, where dust deposition is a critical factor influencing long-term performance and durability. This study investigates the performance of bifacial PV technology after two years of operation using a combination of electrical characterization, morphological analysis, and spectroscopic evaluation. Two strings of 28 series-connected bifacial modules were tested using the Solmetric PV Analyzer. Under similar irradiance conditions ($851-858 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$) and module temperatures ($\sim 39^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$), the strings exhibited performance ratios of $89.7 \%$ and $89.1 \%$ with fill factors of 0.75 and 0.74. Analysis of accumulated dust using SEM-EDS revealed predominantly silica-based particles $\left(69.5 \% \mathrm{SiO}_{2}, 8.9 \% \mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)$, which directly impact light transmission. UV-VIS-NIR spectroscopy showed $42.6 \%$ reflectance at $\boldsymbol{\sim} \mathbf{8 5 7} \mathbf{n m}$, critically affecting the spectral response of the silicon cells. Despite this dust accumulation, both strings maintained relatively high voltage ratios (0.81) and current ratios ($0.92-0.93$), with measured power outputs of $\sim 10.9 \mathrm{~kW}$ ($90 \%$ of predicted values). The angular, irregular dust particles observed via SEM microscopy suggest non-uniform deposition patterns that partially explain the minimal degradation in electrical performance despite the challenging tropical environment. These findings highlight how dust particle size, composition, and spectral filtering synergistically contribute to performance degradation. The integration of electrical and material diagnostics offers a comprehensive approach for assessing dust-induced losses and guiding maintenance or mitigation strategies for bifacial PV systems under long-term outdoor exposure.

title: Edge Computing Offloading Method for UAV-Based Intelligent Maritime Networks
authors: Wenxiao Zhang, Zonghui Wu, Lingyi Chen, Peng Jin, Lei Han, Xin Su
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Network nodes in marine information systems exhibit significant strong heterogeneity, which introduces complex and high-dimensional constraints for optimizing task offloading in marine mobile edge computing (MEC). Additionally, the diverse and complex maritime application scenarios may lead to computational task overload in localized areas of marine networks. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a UAV relay-assisted maritime task offloading edge computing method. Innovatively, a hierarchical classification method for marine network nodes is constructed based on multi-scale heterogeneous feature attributes. Combined with deep reinforcement learning (DRL), an efficient task offloading optimization strategy for marine MEC is designed to enhance the efficiency and reliability of edge computing task offloading in marine environments.

title: Light-guided multi-branch cooperative low-light enhancement network
authors: Yi Wang, Xuan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: In real-world environments, insufficient lighting and other environmental factors often result in images with dull colors and a range of quality issues, which severely affect both visual perception and subsequent image processing tasks. To address this problem, this paper propose an illumination-guided multi-branch low-light enhancement network, termed LMCnet. The core components of LMCnet include explicit illumination enhancement guided by illumination priors, a lightweight multi-head window self-attention module, which together significantly reduce computational overhead. Experimental results on public datasets demonstrate that LMCnet can effectively enhance image brightness and restore image information.

title: Hybrid BiLSTM–LSTM Models for Adaptive Hotel Occupancy Forecasting: A Case Study from an SME Hotel in Salatiga
authors: Li-Hua Li, Martin Setyawan
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: This study explores the use of AI-driven forecasting techniques to address occupancy prediction challenges in small and medium-sized (SME) hotels. A real-world case of Oemah Djari Hotel Syariah (ODHS), a locally owned SME hotel in Salatiga City, Indonesia, is used. Since Salatiga city is an increasingly competitive landscape shaped by rapid growth in tourism and manufacturing, the ODHS hotel faces high volatility in occupancy rates and short booking lead times, making traditional forecasting approaches inadequate. To tackle this, we propose a hybrid deep learning model combining Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM) networks to predict daily occupancy over a 60-day horizon. The proposed model demonstrates high predictive accuracy with low error metrics (MAPE, SMAPE, MSLE) and a strong R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score. The findings confirm the potential of AI-based forecasting models to enhance strategic decision-making in SME hotels.

title: Attention-enhanced Gating for Mixture of Expert LLM
authors: Na Gao, Boqian Fu, Xiuheng Liao, Ziang Wu, Tao Liu, Chunhua Su
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Transformer-based MoE models have become mainstream in large language models (LLMs). The core design of the Transformer architecture is the attention mechanism that each input token will calculate the attention values with others. The Mixture of Experts (MoE)-based LLMs was proposed to replace the dense layer in the Transformer with a gate function and several sparsely activated small experts. This design saves the inference cost since only part of the experts are used. However, existing MoE works only use the data features as the input of the gate function; the importance information of attention value is ignored. In this paper, we propose an attention-enhanced mixture of experts (AMoE), a novel transformer-based MoE model. Specifically, we propose a new gate with an integrated attention mechanism, which improves the model’s performance. We conduct comprehensive experiments to support the effectiveness of our proposals.

title: A Methodological Review of Advances in Deep Learning-Based Methods for SSVEP Classification
authors: Shakil Hossan, Md. Khademul Islam Molla, Shabbir Mahmood, Mahboob Qaosar, Abu Saleh Musa Miah, Najmul Hassan, Jie Huang, Jungpil Shin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs) play a key role in EEG-based Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs). They offer a high information transfer rate (ITR), require little user training, and resist noise. Recently, many studies have focused on developing SSVEP-based EEG classification systems using CNNs, RNNs, Transformers, and hybrid structures. These evaluations usually center on accuracy, ITR, and generalization across different subjects. Some researchers have tried to study this area, but the review papers available usually have a limited viewpoint. They usually emphasize inputs, architectures, or classifications and overlook important performance measures such as accuracy, ITR, and generalization ability. Furthermore, many of these papers are outdated and do not account for recent advancements from 2022 to 2025. They provide general categories without a detailed analysis of methods or architecture. To address these gaps, we present a new survey that includes SSVEP-based EEG classification studies published between 2020 and 2025. This survey focuses on explainable AI (XAI) approaches. Our review looks at current methods and highlights key challenges. These challenges include data efficiency, practical use in the real world, and the development of solutions that don’t require calibration. We also discuss future research directions. We emphasize the need to improve hybrid models, domain adaptation, and interpretable AI to boost both performance and trust in SSVEP-based BCIs.

title: Postural Stability in Pilots Under Simulated Mild Hypoxia
authors: Lenka Hanakova, Boris Oniscenko, Jan Weiss, Vladimir Socha
abstract: Hypoxia represents a significant concern in aviation safety. Numerous studies have examined its impact on cognitive performance and other aspects of human functioning, but only a limited number have addressed its effects on balance, which involves multisensory integration and contributes to postural stability. A PRISMA-based literature search confirmed that evidence in this area remains scarce. Consequently, an experimental study was conducted to investigate the influence of hypoxic conditions on postural stability in pilots. Eleven licensed pilots were exposed to normobaric hypoxia, induced by breathing a reduced-oxygen gas mixture at ambient pressure, simulating an altitude of $4572 \mathrm{~m}(15000 \mathrm{ft})$. The experiment involved two simulated flights under normoxic and hypoxic conditions, while postural stability was assessed before, between, and after the flights using a balance board. Several parameters derived from center of pressure (COP) displacement in both one- and two-dimensional analyses were evaluated. Data were analyzed using repeated-measures ANOVA (rANOVA) followed by post-hoc testing.The results did not reveal consistent statistically significant effects of hypoxia on postural stability. Significant differences were observed only in mediolateral parameters (SD-ML and ROM-ML) when aggregated across sensory conditions, but no effects were found when conditions were examined individually. Within the limitations of the small sample size, single simulated altitude, and short exposure duration, the study concludes that acute mild hypoxia at $4572 \mathrm{~m}(15000 \mathrm{ft})$ does not measurably impair basic postural stability in pilots.

title: Analysis of the Difference in Production Parameters Between Low-Cost and High-Cost 3D Printers
authors: Ivana Koláriková, Volodymyr Tymofiiv, Michal Hovanec, Samer Al-Rabeei
abstract: This study presents a comparative evaluation of production parameters between a low-cost and a high-cost fused deposition modeling (FDM) 3D printer. The theoretical part outlines the role of additive manufacturing (AM) in industrial and domestic contexts, with a focus on FDM/FFF technology and its most frequently used materials. The experimental section investigates differences between the affordable Prusa i3 MK2 printer and the industrial-grade Fortus 450 mc, using a wrist brace model as a test geometry. The model was processed in Stratasys Insight (for the Fortus) and Ultimaker Cura (for the Prusa) software environments. Quantitative parameters such as printing time, material consumption, energy usage, and production cost were systematically compared for three print orientations. Derived indicators-including relative cost, energy efficiency, and material utilization ratios-were calculated to identify key trends. The results demonstrate the contrasting performance and economic profiles of both printers, offering practical insights for users selecting between consumer-level and industrial FDM systems.

title: Regulatory Framework of EASA, European Strategies, and Practical Applications of Artificial Intelligence in Aviation
authors: Tatiana Gajduskova, Edina Jencova, Adam Turac, Diana Majorska, Karolina Hreskova, Gabriel Galgoci
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is becoming an important tool in modern aviation; however, its implementation is associated with unique challenges arising from the safety-critical environment. The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) is systematically developing a regulatory framework that reflects the non-deterministic nature of AI, the limited explainability of models, and the need for so-called continuous assurance throughout the entire system lifecycle. This article analyzes the concept of AI levels, the forthcoming regulatory system Part-AI, its linkage with the EU AI Act, and the strategic objectives defined in the EASA AI Roadmap 2.0. At the same time, it presents selected examples of practical AI applications from the Fly AI Report (2020) and other studies, confirming benefits in areas such as predictive maintenance, flight trajectory management, airport operations, and enhancement of passenger experience. The discussion highlights the need to align technological innovation with regulatory requirements on trustworthiness, explainability, and safety, emphasizing the importance of coordination between EASA, European institutions, and industry. In conclusion, it is argued that the introduction of AI in aviation is feasible only through a gradual, transparent, and rigorously monitored process that maintains the balance between innovation and public trust.

title: Network Slicing for Dynamic DMZ and Federated Learning in Operational Technology Environment
authors: Brian G. Rodiles Delgado, Brian E. Casio Iracheta, Alejandro X. Solano, Mario D. Martinez, Deepak K. Tosh, Christian Servin
abstract: Industrial Control Systems (ICS) and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) environments are essential to modern infrastructure, facing challenges in ensuring low-latency, high-throughput communication while mitigating cyber threats. The collection of network and process information is crucial for ensuring operational security and efficiency in these environments. However, resource constraints in Operational Technology (OT) environments make it difficult to implement traditional solutions. While Demilitarized Zones (DMZs) are useful for isolating and securing critical systems, orchestrating them is time and resource-consuming. Moreover, the use of network slicing to orchestrate a dynamic DMZ along with a Federated Learning (FL)-ready OT environment remains underexplored. This paper presents an integrated framework combining Federated Learning (FL), network slicing, and a dynamically provisioned DMZ to enable real-time monitoring and enhanced cybersecurity without disrupting operations. Leveraging digital twin technology and Kubernetes Network Functions (KNFs), the architecture supports predictive analytics, anomaly detection, and Industry 4.0 requirements. Performance evaluations validate the proposed architecture’s efficiency in throughput, deployment speed, and learning accuracy, establishing a robust foundation for future ICS automation and data-driven decision-making.

title: Stress Testing of Infrastructure Networks and System Order
authors: Davis C. Loose, Megan C. Marcellin, Igor Linkov, Gigi Pavur, Luke H. Hogewood, Michael A. Deegan, James H. Lambert
abstract: Resilience of critical infrastructure emerges from cascading failures that traverse both sector-level and asset-level interdependencies. This paper introduces a framework for assessing resilience using a hybrid network graph of infrastructure systems that merges critical sectors with individual assets and employs scenario-based node removals to mimic cascading disruptions. Critical sectors are identified using eigenvector centrality and PageRank, while Spearman’s rank correlation quantifies disruption to system order under different scenarios, ranging from sector-wide outages to targeted asset failures. The framework is applied to the watershed of an industrial region and its dam network, linked to thirteen abstract critical infrastructure sectors. The method reveals large systemic influence of the Energy sector and identifies high-impact assets. By integrating sector–asset couplings with customizable disruptive scenarios, the framework enables resilience assessments that capture both systemic and localized vulnerabilities. The innovation is to join stress testing of infrastructure networks with system order. The results provide decision-makers with clear indicators for prioritizing mitigation investments and refining contingency plans to enhance the robustness of interdependent infrastructure.

title:
Event-triggered Control Scheme for (Q, S, R) -γ-dissipative and H
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Performance of Switched Time Delay Systems by Switching on Sampling Input and Signal
authors: Hao-Chin Chang, Chang-Hua Lien, Ker-Wei Yu, Hung-Chin Li, Sundarapandian Vaidyanathan, Cheng-Ruei Yu
abstract: The scheme of improved event-triggered control (IETC) is proposed to enrich the resource for network communication of perturbed switched interval delay models. The rule and control of switching is proffered by LMI method to achieve the robust mixed achievement of switched delay model. The developed IETC scheme is also applicable to the switched delay model operating in the presence of any signals. Delay and sampling with interval sense are applied instead of fixed and pointwise condition. A matrix presentation method is employed to establish the contributions. An example is presented to show our main control result on switched time-delay model.

title: Intercomparison of reflectometric and interferometric GNSS-R altimetry in the presence of direct multipath
authors: Hongmei Li, Xuebao Hong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: In the presence of direct multipath, a conventional Global Navigation Satellite System reflectometer (GNSS-R) can measure water level in a either reflectometric or interferometric way. This paper reports an initial intercomparison between these two implementations of GNSS-R altimetry using the GPS L1 C/A raw signals from a stationary experiment. The phase delay and signal power of the reflected signal are analyzed to determine the antenna heights in the way of reflectometry and interferometry, respectively. Altimetry results are shown; the mean absolute error (MAE) and root mean square error (RMSE) of reflectometric retrievals are 1.193 m and 1.433 m, while those of interferometric retrievals are 0.045 m and 0.080 m. With quality control further applied to the phase and power observables, the MAE and RMSE of reflectometric retrievals are 0.377 m and 0.470 m, and those of interferometric retrievals are 0.056 m and 0.082 m. These results indicate that interferometry performs better in terms of altimetry accuracy than reflectometry, and quality control could be applied to improve the accuracy of reflectometric altimetry when the reflected signal is interfered by a direct multipath.

title: Development of Flexible and Biodegradable Paper-Based Wheatstone Bridge Strain Gauge for Low-Cost Sensing Applications
authors: Amit Kumar Goyal, Neha Gupta, Ajay Kumar, Rajesh Mahadeva
abstract: In this manuscript, a paper-based flexible strain gauge has been proposed using standard office paper and everyday graphite pencil. Detailed Analysis and characterization of several design parameters and sensor configurations have been investigated experimentally, such as the width and length of the electrodes and pencil graphite content. Additionally, sensor topologies such as the Wheatstone bridge configuration have been investigated to achieve a highly sensitive strain gauge device. A full Wheatstone bridge configuration has been chosen based on the optimized design parameters. The fabricated structure demonstrated promising results with great sensitivity, high stability, and a wide uniform range from maximum tension to maximum compression. The proposed Full Wheatstone device allows environmental compensation and exhibits a very high gauge factor (GF) of 40.2 for tensile strain and 34.4 for compressive strain for a deflection range of -30 mm to 30 mm. The proposed full, pencil-drawn Wheatstone bridge configuration is cost-effective and easy to fabricate with high sensitivity at 130 mV/V, spanning the entire range of the device. This enables compatibility with standard electronic readout platforms, including microcontrollers, for biomedical sensing, machine–human interfaces, and strain-sensing applications.

title: On the Regularization and Linearization of the Microwave Inverse Scattering Problem Using Subwavelength-Focused Fields
authors: Brendon C. Besler, Elise C. Fear
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This communication investigates the use of subwavelength-focused incident fields to reduce the ill-posedness of the microwave inverse scattering problem by decreasing the smoothness of the scattering kernel, while also localizing the fields to reduce multiple scattering and linearize the problem. In the ideal case of a point-like incident field it is demonstrated that the inverse problem becomes well-posed. Improved imaging results are demonstrated using more realistic subwavelength-focused incident fields compared to conventional approaches. Conventional regularization and nonlinear inversion techniques are used. The impact of the full width at half-maximum and sidelobe level of the subwavelength-focused incident field on image accuracy are investigated to assess the feasibility of using subwavelength-focused fields for quantitative imaging.

title: Theory and Network Modeling of Mechanically Reconfigurable Magnetoinductive Waveguides
authors: Samuel J. Coogle, Brian Prejean, Asimina Kiourti
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper introduces a new class of mechanically reconfigurable magnetoinductive waveguides (mrMIWs). Through careful design, mrMIWs can be used to realize sensors that monitor an object’s size for several biomedical and structural health applications, while overcoming limitations in the state-of-the-art. First, the theory of mrMIWs is presented, followed by a novel network analysis for first-order, finite-length mrMIWs that allows for rapid design and analysis. The resulting model provides the most accurate analytical prediction of the behavior of real mrMIWs, such as passband ripples, to date. Notably, the adaptability of the model empowers the introduction and accurate modeling of parasitic magnetic coupling, a herein proposed phenomenon wherein the direct magnetic coupling between the transmitting and receiving loops overpowers the magnetoinductive propagation. Figures of merit are then introduced to quantify the performance of mrMIWs as sensors, followed by a study of various possible deformations for mrMIWs. Overall, this paper makes advances in mrMIW theory, empowers rapid design of first-order mrMIWs, and develops the theoretical framework required for the development of sensors based on mrMIWs.

title: A Novel Wasserstein Color Transfer Variational Framework on Fabric Images
authors: Xuyuan Zhang, Chen Xu, Yu Han, George Baciu, Weiqiang Zhang
abstract: Color transfer on fabric images has become a prevalent computer-aided tool in the fashion design and textile industry, enabling the automatic generation of simulated recolored images available for computer previews. Many existing variational methods are sourced with color palettes due to their ease to use; however, these approaches are often limited by practical inefficiencies, primarily arising from their reliance on cost-intensive iterative calculations. Moreover, the presence of color bleeding and distortion frequently degenerates the visual quality of their recolored fabric images. In this paper, we propose a novel color transfer variational framework on fabric images that consists of three modules: (1) image decomposition, (2) image segmentation, and (3) image recoloring. The first module constructs a variational Wasserstein optimization to generate independent reflectance and shading images, utilizing outputs from the intrinsic image decomposition network OS-Net for efficient modeling and initialization. Building on the piecewise constant approximation of the reflectance image, the second module formulates a variational model to partition the reflectance image into multiple regions of interest, represented by fuzzy membership functions. For image recoloring, color transfer results are produced by reintegrating the shading image with the recolored reflectance image, modified according to the given color palette. Experiment results demonstrate that, compared to classical fabric color transfer variational methods and recent learning-based approaches, our framework significantly enhances operational efficiency and achieves superior color transfer performance. It effectively eliminates unexpected color bleeding and distortion while preserving the original geometric structures and intricate fabric details in recolored images.

title: Parameter Optimization of Quantum Key Distribution in Quantum-Classical WDM-SDM Coexistence Systems
authors: Yaoxian Gao, Yongmei Sun, Yuefeng Ji
abstract: In quantum-classical coexistence systems, classical noise and system loss can significantly affect the performance of quantum key distribution (QKD), while the fixed-parameter QKD (FPQ) cannot adapt to varying conditions. In this paper, we propose a local search algorithm (LSA) for QKD to optimize the parameters in wavelength division multiplexing (WDM) and space division multiplexing (SDM) systems. Simulation results show that LSA can achieve 99.9% performance of the exhaustive search algorithm, while significantly reducing computational complexity. Moreover, LSA improves QKD performance by 31.9% over standard single mode fiber and 24.5% over multicore fiber in quantum-classical coexistence systems.

title: Lighter: A Lightweight Full-Information and Dual-Guide Network for Remote Sensing Image Change Detection
authors: Yuan Wang, Sixian Chan, Guoyu Yang, Jian Tao, Tianyang Dong, Xiaolong Zhou, Xiaoqin Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote Sensing (RS) Change Detection (CD), a technique focused on identifying surface alterations from bi-temporal images, holds substantial significance for various applications, such as land management and disaster surveillance. In the last decade, deep learning-based CD methods have advanced rapidly. However, recognizing sporadic distributional changes over time in complex scenes remains a significant challenge. However, many existing solutions rely on large model capacities and high computational costs, yet still fail to incorporate sufficient semantic information for accurately recognizing complex real changes. To tackle this challenge, a lightweight full-information and dual-guide network (Lighter) for RSCD is presented. Specifically, we design a lightweight full-information mingling module (FIMM) that emphasizes the injection of multi-perspective information during the feature interaction. This approach leverages rich semantics as cues to reason about diverse changes. Furthermore, we propose a lightweight dual-guide difference capture module (DDCM), which utilizes the unique information of each guide to teach each other thereby reducing the interference of pseudo-variations. Extensive experiments on four datasets demonstrate that our lightweight architecture achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance with only 1.10M parameters and 2.01G FLOPs. The code will be released upon publication.

title: SI-Mamba: High-Resolution Sea Ice Recognition via RB-NDI Guided State Space Model
authors: Wenjun Hong, Zhanchao Huang, Yongke Yang, Luping You, Junchao Cai, Jiajun Zhou, Weiwang Guan, Hua Su
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Sea ice recognition is of great significance for reflecting climate change and ensuring ship navigation safety. In recent years, many deep learning-based methods have been proposed and applied to the segmentation and recognition of sea ice regions. However, existing deep learning models often struggle to effectively capture the subtle spectral differences between sea ice and seawater, as well as the large-scale spatial dependencies in high-resolution remote sensing images, resulting in limited segmentation accuracy in areas with ambiguous ice-water boundaries. This paper proposes a red-blue normalized difference index (RB-NDI) guided state space model approach for sea ice segmentation, termed SI-Mamba. In the proposed SI-Mamba, the Index-Guided Collaborative Enhancement (IGCE) module employs an RB-NDI index-guided state space model (SSM) mechanism to overcome the limitations in explicit modeling of spectral features, achieving efficient modeling of long-range spatial dependencies in sea ice distribution. Furthermore, the designed Dynamic Boundary Focus Loss (DBFL) function adjusts the model's expressive capability in edge-sensitive regions through collaborative optimization between the main segmentation head and the index-assisted head. Experiments on multiple generated sea ice datasets demonstrate that the proposed SI-Mamba achieves improved performance in sea ice segmentation and identification in optical remote sensing images. It significantly enhances the accuracy of ice-water boundary recognition and generalization capability in complex scenarios, offering a novel and effective solution for remote sensing based sea ice recognition.

title: Universal Approach to the Performance Analysis of Multi-Carrier Communication Systems over Fading Channels Based on the Concept of Effective SNR
authors: Miguel López-Benítez
abstract: The analytical performance evaluation of multi-carrier communication systems is inherently complex, as the overall system performance depends on the distinct Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) levels experienced by each sub-carrier due to the frequency-selective nature of the propagation channel. In this context, this work provides novel analytical results for the performance evaluation of multi-carrier systems over fading channels based on the concept of effective SNR, which collapses all per-subcarrier SNRs into a single equivalent SNR that provides the same performance as the full multi-carrier system. A universal model for the statistics of the effective SNR based on analytically tractable expressions and valid for any fading scenario is presented, which can be particularised to specific fading scenarios through the selection of two constant parameters. The proposed modelling approach is exploited to derive novel mathematical expressions that enable a simple, versatile and universal analysis of the performance of multi-carrier systems over fading channels.

title: Deadbeat Control of Dual Active Bridge Converters With Adaptive Noise Resistance Ability
authors: Dehao Kong, Tianxu Cao, Ralph Kennel, Marcelo Lobo Heldwein
abstract: Although deadbeat control offers excellent dynamic performance for dual active bridge (DAB) converters with relatively simple computations, it is sensitive to sampling noise, which degrades system performance and even leads to instability. Existing approaches based on digital filters induce higher computational burden and alter the system pole locations affecting the inherent characteristics of deadbeat-controlled DABs. Therefore, this letter proposes a novel deadbeat control method with adaptive noise resistance ability for DABs. Instead of digital filters, an adaptive attenuation coefficient is used to efficiently and adaptively mitigate the impact of noises, using a simple structure. Combing with the compensation term derived from the system model, it introduces no steady-state error and preserves the original closed-loop pole locations, thereby maximally retaining the essential features of deadbeat control. Experimental results verify the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method.

title: Discharge Signal Detection Based on NV-Center Quantum Magnetometry
authors: Xuelei Wang, Chao Gu, Mengzhao Zhu, Jian Wang, Xucheng Wang
abstract: A quantum sensing monitoring method for discharge signals is proposed based on magnetic field perturbation perception with diamond NV centers (Nitrogen-Vacancy Centers). First, a quantum sensing system integrating optical excitation, microwave drive, and fluorescence signal acquisition was constructed. The quantum state response patterns of NV centers under static and transient magnetic fields were systematically verified by assembling a high-concentration ensemble of NV-center diamond sensing units and an opto-electronically integrated probe combined with excitation sources: permanent magnet constant magnetic field and pulsed current discharge. Experimental results indicate that greater the local magnetic flux density gradient of the probe, or the more uneven the magnetic field distribution, makes it easier to induce the obvious splitting of NV color center energy level. In the absence of external fields, the ODMR spectrum exhibits two shallow resonance peaks. As external magnetic field perturbations intensify, peak depth significantly increases, characterizing enhanced Zeeman splitting of the ground state levels. Simultaneously, despite the time-varying nature of the electromagnetic field induced by pulsed current discharges, the quantum probe stably captures locally perturbed magnetic fields generated by the discharges. The constructed NV-center-based quantum sensing system demonstrates outstanding sensitivity and stability in both static and transient magnetic field detection. This article provides a feasible pathway and technical foundation for quantum monitoring of transient electromagnetic fields during partial discharges in electrical equipment.

title: Equation-Based Design Methodology for Switched-Capacitor Converter Topologies
authors: Seokwon Choi, Dam Yun, Jung-Ik Ha
abstract: Switched-capacitor (SC) converters are increasingly adopted for their high volumetric power density. However, a comprehensive approach to the systematic synthesis of SC converter topologies remains insufficiently developed. This study presents an equation-based design framework that explicitly represents the dc bias conditions and component interconnections through symbolic topological equations. These equations capture the fundamental principles of SC converter operation, including Kirchhoff's circuit laws and charge balance conditions. Additionally, a set of design constraints is defined to ensure a unique and deterministic solution for charge variables. Building on this foundation, a structured synthesis procedure is presented to generate arbitrary SC converters that achieve specified voltage conversion ratios. The methodology is demonstrated through detailed derivations of a conventional 4:1 Dickson topology and a modified 3:1 FCML topology. As a practical application of the design procedure, three distinct 6:1 converter topologies are developed. One configuration is implemented as a 48V-to-8 V converter prototype, which achieves a peak efficiency of 98.19% and exhibits high-load performance approximately equal to that of the conventional Dickson converter while reducing the volume of passive components by 50%. The experimental results confirm the theoretical validity and practical utility of the proposed analytical framework.

title: Tree-shaped Recursive Network: Rethinking Directional Features in Lightweight Single Image Super Resolution
authors: He Jiang, Fudi Yi, Rui Zhang, Mujtaba Asad, Peijie Wang, Ting Yu, Deqiang Cheng
abstract: Single Image Super Resolution (SISR) is a post-processing technology for Internet of Things (IoT) devices that reduces bandwidth usage and improves communication efficiency. While most SISR models perform similarly on images with simple textures, their differences become more pronounced when handling complex directional textures, which are challenging to reconstruct. In view of this, we propose a Tree Recursive Network (TRN) for SISR that utilizes a tree-shaped topology and a non-local coordinate attention mechanism to capture global directional textures. First, a binary tree residual block is introduced to preserve the attention and residual features without increasing the number of parameters. Second, a non-local coordinate attention mechanism is applied to integrate non-local and directional features to effectively capture global information while reducing computational complexity. Third, a directional attention fusion technique that integrates attention and residual features is presented. Extensive experimental results show that TRN outperforms other models in terms of evaluation metrics such as PSNR and SSIM. Notably, on the ×2 Urban100 dataset, the PSNR of TRN is 0.24 dB higher than that of the popular model CFIN, which highlights its potential and usefulness.

title: An IoE-Powered Framework for Adaptive Energy-Security Trade-Off in IoT
authors: Mattia Giovanni Spina, Azzedine Boukerche, Floriano De Rango
abstract: The Internet of Energy (IoE) is emerging as a key enabler for integrated energy and security management in resource-constrained IoT environments. This convergence offers new opportunities for intelligent and sustainable energy and security operations. However, the inherent computational and energy limitations of IoT devices, combined with the complexity of security configurations, often lead to the neglect of protection mechanisms. The lack of lightweight, adaptable solutions makes standardized security protocols – such as Transport Layer Security (TLS) and Datagram TLS (DTLS) – unsuitable for large, heterogeneous deployments. Their static and rigid nature causes excessive overhead and limits adaptability under dynamic network conditions. To address these challenges, this article introduces an IoE-enabled architectural vision that tightly integrates energy and security management. In this architecture the IoE Controller (IoE-C) is introduced. It operates as an orchestration layer, leveraging data from energy and security monitoring platforms to dynamically adapt tailored security measures on IoT constrained devices. The Energy and Security aware Index (ESaI) is proposed as a composite metric to evaluate and guide the security-energy trade-off. The proposed paradigm generalizes the concept of dynamic and lightweight security across widely adopted IoT protocols, such as MQTT and CoAP. Evaluation results demonstrate improvements in device lifetime and energy efficiency compared to traditional TLS/DTLS-based solutions, while preserving adequate security guarantees. The framework outlines a scalable and sustainable path for secure IoT deployments in 6G and future energy-intelligent infrastructures.

title: MGSANet: A Multiscale Graph Spatial Alignment Network for Weakly Aligned RGB-Thermal Object Detection_supp1-3647051.pdf
authors: Muhammad Waqas
abstract: The current mainstream research on color-thermal (i.e., RGB-T) object detection assumes that the RGB and thermal images are strictly aligned. However, in practical situations, due to the insufficient spatiotemporal synchronization, stereo disparity of the camera in the installation position, and the errors in the image pairs registration process, the position of the same objects in RGB and thermal images are not completely overlapped. The position shift can cause distortion, trailing, and blurring issues during the image fusion process, leading to a decrease in model detection accuracy. To address this challenge, we propose a novel multiscale graph spatial alignment network (MGSANet), which can effectively alleviate the negative effects of cross-modal image misalignment. Specifically, we represent the feature maps extracted from RGB and thermal images by backbone network as a graph structure, and use graph attention network (GAT) to model the spatial position deviation relationship. Furthermore, considering the multiscale characteristics of the objects, we represent the feature maps with multiscale graphs. We then align RGB and thermal feature maps in a potential feature space according to the learned deviation relationship for object detection. In addition, considering the scarcity of RGB-T datasets from the perspective of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), and to verify the object detection performance on different platforms, we construct an RGB-T object detection dataset collected by the UAV platform, named KUSTDrone. We conducted experiments on datasets collected by vehicle and UAV platforms respectively. Experimental results demonstrate that MGSANet outperforms the competitive methods for weakly aligned RGB-T object detection. The dataset will be accessible at https://github.com/KustTeamWQW/KUSTDrone with a license, and the code will also be accessible at https://github.com/KustTeamWQW/MGSANet.

title: Distributed Optimization in Multilayer Networks via Tensor-Laplacian Dynamics
authors: Christian D. Rodríguez-Camargo, Andrés F. Urquijo-Rodríguez, Eduardo Mojica-Nava
abstract: Multilayer networks provide a more advanced and comprehensive framework for modeling real-world systems compared to traditional single-layer and multiplex networks. Unlike single-layer models, multilayer networks have multiple interacting layers, each with unique topological features. In this article, we generalize previously developed results for distributed optimization in multiplex networks to the more general case of multilayer networks by employing a tensor formalism to represent multilayer networks and their tensor-Laplacian diffusion dynamics. Although multiplex networks are a special case of multilayer networks, where each layer has the same number of replica nodes connected one-to-one, this generalized framework removes the need for replica nodes, allowing variability in both topology and number of nodes across layers. This approach provides a fully generalized structure for distributed optimization in multilayer networks and enables more complex interlayer connections. We derive the multilayer combinatorial Laplacian tensor and extend the distributed gradient descent algorithm. We provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence of algorithms. Numerical examples validate our approach, and we explore the impact of heterogeneous layer topologies and complex interlayer dynamics on consensus time, underscoring their implications for real-world multilayer systems.

title: FAS-RIS for V2X: Unlocking Realistic Performance Analysis with Finite Elements
authors: Tuo Wu, Xiazhi Lai, Kangda Zhi, Maged Elkashlan, Naofal Al-Dhahir, Matthew C. Valenti, Fumiyuki Adachi
abstract: The synergy of fluid antenna systems (FAS) and reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) promises robust vehicle-to-everything (V2X) links, yet most analyses invoke the central limit theorem (CLT) and thus fail to capture practical, finite-size deployments. This paper develops a realistic and tractable framework for FAS–RIS systems with a finite number of elements. We approximate the cascaded end-to-end gain via a Gamma distribution using moment matching, model spatial dependence across FAS ports with a block-correlation structure, and derive an accurate, closed-form approximation for the outage probability using Gauss–Chebyshev quadrature. Extensive simulations show that the proposed Gamma-based analysis markedly outperforms CLT-based baselines-especially for small numbers of RIS elements and ports-while converging to them as the array grows. The results provide actionable guidance for V2X design and dimensioning under practical constraints on RIS size, FAS aperture, and channel correlation.

title: Low Divergence Angle Extended-Cavity Single-Mode VCSEL Based on Dielectric DBR mirror
authors: Tongxin Wang, Pingping Qiu, Hengjie Zhou, Qiuhua Wang, Chaowei Si, Shuanglin Yue, Sheng Zhang, Qiang Kan
abstract: We present a vertical cavity surface emitting laser (VCSEL) employing the extended-cavity structure and dielectric film reflector, with a 4.5 μm oxide aperture diameter. The laser operates in fundamental transverse mode with side-mode suppression ratio (SMSR) exceeding 30 dB at 1090 nm. The divergence angle is limited to only 4°, attributed to increased diffraction loss for high-order transverse modes and a larger mode field size facilitated by the extended-cavity. The top reflector comprises sputtered dielectric distributed Bragg reflector, while current spreading and partial reflectivity are facilitated by 3 pairs of p-doped DBRs. The device demonstrates a low thermal resistance of 1.3 K/mW and exhibits robust temperature stability. The combination of stable single-mode performance, minimal divergence angle, and low thermal resistance establish this VCSEL design as a promising candidate for high-performance single-mode VCSELs suitable for applications in atomic sensing and high-precision metrology.

title: Multi-step, Multi-scale Traffic Flow Time Series Forecasting
authors: Axel Schaffland, Julius Schöning
abstract: Accurate traffic flow forecasting is critical for urban mobility management. Nonetheless, existing methods often face challenges in multi-step prediction scenarios over extended time horizons. We present a novel multi-scale traffic flow forecasting framework using graph neural networks, which are capable of predicting traffic patterns of up to three days ahead at varying temporal resolutions. We extend Spatiotemporal Self-Supervised Learning with methods to integrate multi-scale data processing, combining high-resolution scale with low-resolution scales to balance computational efficiency and accuracy. We leverage our own dataset, comprising static network topology and dynamic sensor data, and demonstrate that synthetic adjacency matrices can replace handcrafted ones without significantly sacrificing performance, streamlining the preprocessing. Key innovations include a scale-space representation for temporal data and a network architecture adapted to non-uniform time series. Further, our results show that preprocessing significantly enhances forecasting accuracy while multi-step prediction achieves comparable accuracy results to single-step benchmarks. Our framework’s ability to handle extended forecasting horizons with reduced computational overhead highlights its practicality for real-world application, such as adaptive traffic control and logistics planning. This work advances spatial-temporal forecasting by addressing hardware constraints through multi-scale representations and lays the groundwork for future extensions incorporating multimodal data and expert knowledge.

title: Augmented DFA-Enhanced Photonic Reservoir Computing for IMDD Equalization
authors: Yixian Dong, Mao He, Wentao Lv, Xihua Zou, Wei Pan, Lianshan Yan
abstract: We propose a microring-resonator–based reservoir-computing (MRR-RC) architecture integrated with an augmented direct feedback alignment (aDFA) scheme. The aDFA implements adaptive mask updating to better match the encoded input to the physical reservoir, thereby reducing mask-induced randomness and more effectively exciting the device nonlinearities. We evaluate the architecture by numerical simulation for intensity-modulation/direct-detection (IMDD) optical links. In a 25-km IMDD scenario the aDFA-augmented MRR-RC improves receiver sensitivity by 1.8 dBm relative to the non-adaptive baseline. These results indicate that the proposed aDFA-augmented MRR-RC is a promising, compact, and energy-efficient candidate for equalization in short-reach optical transmission systems.

title: Evaluating Range of Motion of Two Prominent Neck Support Devices for Daily Activities_supp1-3647266.mp4
authors: Haohan Zhang
abstract: Neck muscle weakness causes the inability to raise and move the head, leading to fatigue, neck pain, and a “head-on-chest” posture (dropped head syndrome) in severe cases, which significantly affects quality of life. Static neck collars are the current standard of care. However, these collars are passive, which cannot restore the head-neck movement necessary for daily tasks. Emerging robotic devices like powered neck exoskeletons were developed to enable head-neck movements. Previous laboratory tests showed improved patients’ ability to follow prescribed trajectories; however, the ability to assist with daily tasks of such a robotic device remains unknown. In this paper, the functional range of motion allowed by a state-of-the-art powered neck exoskeleton was compared to a clinic-standard static neck collar in healthy adults performing simulated daily tasks wearing these devices. Results showed a greater head range of motion and consequently less compensatory torso movements while wearing the neck exoskeleton in its transparent mode. Participants rated the neck exoskeleton more favorably than the static collar in terms of comfort and ability to perform the tasks. Results also revealed the range of motion limits of the current neck exoskeleton for these daily tasks. These results provided justifications for using neck exoskeletons to restore daily functions and offered critical insights into future refinement of this technology to enable head range of motion for critical daily activities.

title: Analysis, Design, and Demonstration for Rotation-type Experimental System of Dynamic Wireless Power Transfer
authors: Takachika Hatano, Ryosuke Ota, Daiki Satou, Hiroyasu Kobayashi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Vehicular Technology
abstract: Experiments on dynamic wireless power transfer (DWPT) for electric vehicles (EVs) typically require vast testing grounds and significant costs, making them difficult to implement. As a solution, experimental systems utilizing rotational motion for DWPT have been proposed. However, few such systems have been developed and their design methods and fundamental characteristics remain unclear. This paper presents the construction of a rotation-type experimental system for DWPT and discusses its design methodology and basic characteristics. In developing the prototype, mechanical stability was verified through simulations analyzing stress and critical rotational speed of the rotating components. A sector-shaped transmitter coil, suitable for this system, was designed and analyzed using electromagnetic field simulations, confirming similar characteristics to conventional linear-rail-based systems. Furthermore, the effects of misalignment between transmitter and receiver coils and the electrical characteristics of slip rings and brushes were evaluated. Finally, power transfer characteristics were validated through experiments at a linear velocity equivalent of 40 km/h and 3.3 kW power transfer.

title: A Risk Identification and Prediction Model for Intelligent Driving Under Multi-Vehicle Interactions in Mountain Tunnel Environments
authors: Xiaoyu Cai, Minghua Zhang, Cailin Lei, Ling Jin, Bo Peng
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Accurate driving risk prediction is essential for preventing traffic accidents, particularly in complex mountain tunnel environments where conventional assessment methods often fall short. This study presents a novel approach for quantifying and predicting driving risk under multi-vehicle interactions scenarios. A weighted comprehensive risk matrix is constructed by integrating Time-to-Collision (TTC) and Interaction Strength (IS), taking into account the behavior of surrounding vehicles. Arisk representation framework centered on the ego vehicle and a multi-level risk classification scheme are proposed. To capture the spatial and temporal dynamics of driving risk, a hybrid deep learning model is proposed, combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory networks (LSTM), and Attention mechanisms. The model was validated using real-world trajectory data from six mountain tunnels in Chongqing, China. The model achieved prediction accuracies of 83% in car-following and 76% in lane-changing scenarios, outperforming traditional methods. The proposed model significantly enhances the identification and prediction of abnormal driving behaviors under highly interaction conditions, offering a valuable tool to improve intelligent driving safety in mountain tunnels.

title: Generative AI Driven Task-Oriented Adaptive Semantic Communications
authors: Yuzhou Fu, Wenchi Cheng, Jingqing Wang, Liuguo Yin, Wei Zhang
abstract: Task-Oriented Semantic Communication (TOSC) has been regarded as a promising communication framework, serving for various Artificial Intelligence (AI) task driven applications. The existing TOSC frameworks focus on extracting the full semantic features of source data and learning low-dimensional channel inputs to transmit them within limited bandwidth resources. Although transmitting full semantic features can preserve the integrity of data meaning, this approach does not attain the performance threshold of the TOSC. In this paper, we propose a Task-oriented Adaptive Semantic Communication (TasCom) framework to effectively facilitate the inference of different AI tasks. Based on the Generative AI (GAI) techniques, we first propose a Joint Source-Channel Coding (JSCC) that which only extracts and fuses task-related semantic features, and then transmits them to achieve efficient task-oriented semantic transmission. Then, we propose a generative training algorithm to train the proposed JSCC for optimal performance. Furthermore, an Adaptive Coding Controller (ACC) is proposed to find the optimal coding scheme for the proposed JSCC, which allows the semantic features with significant contributions to the task inference to preferentially occupy limited bandwidth resources for wireless transmission. The simulation results show that the proposed TasCom outperforms the existing TOSC and traditional codec schemes on the object detection and instance segmentation tasks under all considered channel conditions.

title: Energy-Efficient Resource Allocation for Multi-Gateway LoRa Networks via Graph-Enhanced Attention Learning
authors: Ziqi Lin, Jinming Li, Hai Chen, Di Zhang, Shimin Gong, Bo Gu
abstract: Long-range (LoRa) technology has emerged as a promising solution for Internet of Things applications due to its low power consumption and long communication range. However, its pure ALOHA-based MAC layer leads to severe packet collisions as the network scale expands, significantly degrading the system energy efficiency (EE). While careful allocation of transmission parameters such as channel (CH), transmission power (TP), and spreading factor (SF) could mitigate this issue, the complex interference patterns in multi-gateway scenarios and the time-consuming nature of EE evaluation pose significant challenges. Therefore, we propose an analytical model to calculate the system EE while fully considering the impacts of multiple gateways, duty cycling, quasi-orthogonal SFs and capture effects. Based on this model, we formulate a joint CH, SF, and TP allocation problem to optimize the system EE. To solve this NP-hard optimization problem, we decompose it into CH assignment and SF/TP assignment subproblems. A two-phase optimization framework is then designed. In the first phase, a matching-based algorithm is designed for CH assignment. In the second phase, a multi-agent reinforcement learning approach that incorporates a two-stage attention mechanism and graph convolutional networks is proposed for SF/TP assignment, which effectively captures and weights inter-ED interactions in multi-gateway scenarios. Simulation results indicate that the proposed approach well-suited for complex multi-GW LoRa network topologies and outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms.

title: Quantum-Assisted Barrier Sequential Quadratic Programming for Nonlinear Optimal Control
authors: Nahid Binandeh Dehaghani, Rafal Wisniewski, A. Pedro Aguiar
abstract: We propose a quantum-assisted framework for solving constrained finite-horizon nonlinear optimal control problems using a barrier Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP) approach. A quantum subroutine is incorporated to efficiently solve the Schur complement step using block-encoding and Quantum Singular Value Transformation techniques. We formally analyze the time complexity and convergence behavior under the cumulative effect of quantum errors, establishing local input-to-state stability and convergence to a neighborhood of the stationary point, with explicit error bounds in terms of the barrier parameter and quantum solver accuracy. The proposed framework enables computational complexity to scale polylogarithmically with the system dimension demonstrating the potential of quantum algorithms to enhance classical optimization routines in nonlinear control applications.
