title: Improving Transient Response of LLC Converters via Frequency-Domain Pole-Canceling Compensation
authors: Dohong Lee, Younghoon Cho, Bonggook Kim
abstract: This paper presents a variable-frequency voltage control scheme for LLC resonant converters to enhance transient response without compromising stability. A simplified second-order small-signal model is derived and validated for accurate control-oriented analysis. Based on this model, a polecanceling compensator is proposed to enable higher crossover frequency and improved gain margin. The proposed compensator is compared with a conventional PI compensator in terms of bandwidth, gain/phase margins, and transient performance. Simulation results confirm that the proposed method achieves significantly faster settling time and eliminates high-frequency ringing, demonstrating improved dynamic performance.

title: Predicting Corrosive Sulfur Value in Transformer Oil Using a Long-Short-Term Memory (LSTM)-Based Time-Series Classification Approach
authors: Rahmat Fitriadi, Tumiran, Syukron Abu Ishaq Alfarozi
abstract: Continuous operation of the transformer will result in a decline in the quality of the transformer’s insulating oil. One of the parameters that can be used as an indicator of the decline in transformer oil quality is the increase in the content of corrosive sulfur compounds, where this condition is a significant factor contributing to internal transformer damage. This study aims to develop a model to predict future values for the corrosive sulfur categories in transformer oil using long-term historical test data (2010-2023). The Long-Short-Term Memory (LSTM) algorithm was developed and systematically compared with a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), Random Forest (RF), and Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (SARIMA) model to evaluate their ability to model temporal degradation behavior. The experimental results showed that the LSTM model achieved the highest performance, with an accuracy of 0.83 and an F1 score of 0.83, outperforming GRU (0.67), RF (0.15) and SARIMA (0.54). The LSTM achieved the highest accuracy (0.83) and the F1 score (0.83), confirming its ability to capture long-term dependencies. Unlike previous studies that focused on dissolved gas analysis (DGA), this work introduces the first LSTM-based framework that uses ASTM D130 data to forecast transformer oil corrosion.

title: Bayesian Optimized LSTM-MFPC Controller for Microgrid Frequency Regulation
authors: Ying-Yi Hong, Francisco I. Alano, Yih-Der Lee, Jheng-Lun Jiang
abstract: Due to the growing demand for renewable energy, sources such as solar and wind power are increasingly integrated into microgrids. However, the intermittent nature of renewable generation and its dependence on inverter-based interfaces pose significant challenges for microgrid frequency control strategies. This paper proposes a novel Long Short-term Memory (LSTM)-based Model-Free Predictive Control (LSTM-MFPC) scheme that explicitly considers both the lookback window and prediction horizon in its design. The proposed controller is employed to regulate microgrid frequency under sudden irradiance fluctuations, which lead to abrupt changes in photovoltaic (PV) output. The method is validated using a Controller-Hardware-in-the-Loop (CHIL) simulation implemented on an OPAL-RT real-time digital simulator in conjunction with a Jetson edge device. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms conventional controllers, such as PI controllers, traditional Model Predictive Controllers (MPCs), and basic multilayer perceptron-based MFPCs (MLP-MFPCs).

title: Design of Long Range, High Power, High Efficiency Miniature Coils for MHz Band WPT
authors: Natsuki Sugiura, Kan Akatsu
abstract: To address the high burial costs associated with Electric Vehicle (EV) Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) systems, this study initially considered a compact, capacitor-less MHz-band self-resonant two-layer coil. This coil, employing copper foil to reduce the skin effect, demonstrated high-efficiency, high-power transmission. However, its thickness due to the two-layer construction disturbs mountability to the vehicle body. Therefore, this work further compares the two-layer design with a planar coil configuration, aiming to maintain high performance while improving suitability for vehicle integration, specifically by evaluating coil area, thickness, and achievable transmission distance.

title: A Design of Fuzzy Logic Controller Application to Modern Gantry Crane
authors: Nhan H. Nguyen, Chuong L. Vo, Huynh Quang Duy, Thien M. Tran
abstract: This study presents a comparative analysis of two popular control strategies as Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) and Fuzzy Logic Controllers (FLC), applied to a modern gantry crane system. The modern gantry crane exhibits nonlinear dynamics and significant load oscillations during motion, which pose challenges for precise positioning and operational safety. The objective is to evaluate the effectiveness of both control approaches in reducing pendulum oscillations, minimizing settling time, and improving overall system response. A dynamic model of a modern crane system is developed and simulated by using MATLAB/Simulink environment, incorporating test scenarios such as target position changes and external disturbances. Simulation results indicate that the FLC with the Mamdani-Sugeno technique offers superior performance under nonlinear and uncertain conditions, while the PID controller performs effectively in stable, deterministic environments. This study provides insights into selecting appropriate control strategies for modern crane system design.

title: Feature Selection in Boosting Modeling for Survey Data Using a Statistical Inference Approach
authors: Alan Prahutama, Fariz Budi Arafat, Budi Warsito
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Feature selection is an important part of machine learning for obtaining optimal model performance. Statistically, feature or variable selection produces a parsimonious/simple model but with optimal performance. Feature selection in ML can be performed using logistic regression, among other methods. Statistically, logistic regression for survey data with complex designs differs from naïve logistic regression, in which data are assumed to be randomly sampled. This study models the classification of poor households using the 2023 Susenas data, comprising 341,082 households and 28 features. The methods used were boosting methods (Gradient Boosting, LightGBM, CatBoost, and XGBoost). The results indicate a class imbalance that must be addressed. In this study, SMOTE was used to address this issue. The results of the statistical testing (Kruskal-Wallis test) showed significant differences between SMOTE and non-SMOTE in the boosting model. Additionally, feature selection yielded different results compared to non-feature selection. LightGBM, CatBoost, and XGBoost outperformed Gradient Boosting in classifying poor households in Indonesia. Overall, the F1-score in the Boosting model was 0.779 with feature selection.

title: Agile Combat Support – Second-Level Logistic Support of Air Forces
authors: Pavla Davidová, Zbyšek Korecki, Tomáš Hoika
abstract: The Czech Air Force (CAF) is building a second level of logistic support with the aim of achieving the ability to deploy and operate air forces outside of permanent bases. Given the expected complexity of future operational environments, the leadership of the CAF was prompted to consider several adaptive bases (AB) concepts. From this perspective, the second level of logistic support can be characterized as tactical support for helicopter operation and maintenance under field conditions, carried out by the mobile logistic support battalion of the air force, which provides maintenance, repairs, replenishment, inventory management, and technical documentation. The aim of this article is to analyze and propose the structure of a Fuel and Lubricant Service Point (FLSP) within a Forward Arming and Refueling Point (FARP). The article demonstrates that the effective organization of FARP/FLSP, including personnel, equipment, and procedures, is a key prerequisite for the modern operational capabilities of the air force in the field.

title: Privacy-Preserving “Right to Be Forgotten” in Configurable Blockchain Tokenization: A Cryptographic Audit Framework
authors: Pierre Ghaly, Harald Gjermundrød, Ioanna Dionysiou
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Blockchain tokenization ecosystems face significant challenges in complying with privacy regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), particularly the “Right to Be Forgotten” mandate. The immutable nature of blockchain conflicts with the requirement for data deletion, creating a fundamental tension between technological capabilities and regulatory compliance. This paper presents a novel cryptographic audit framework for implementing GDPR-compliant data erasure in configurable tokenization systems. Our approach leverages cryptographic key destruction, zero-knowledge proofs for audit trails, and automated smart contract mechanisms to achieve practical data deletion while preserving blockchain immutability. The framework introduces a triple-layer architecture separating on-chain and off-chain references from off-chain sensitive data, enabling verifiable data erasure through cryptographic “shredding” techniques. We demonstrate the framework’s effectiveness through detailed algorithms and present a proof of concept comprehensive audit mechanism that generates cryptographic proofs of successful data deletion without revealing sensitive information. Our solution addresses critical gaps in current blockchain privacy implementations and provides a practical pathway for regulatory compliance in tokenization ecosystems.

title: Input-Output Model and Algorithms for Supply Chain and Import Savings Analysis
authors: Nahuel Guaita, Silvio Guaita
abstract: This paper leverages an Input-Output methodology to develop an algorithmic framework designed to address supply chain challenges that arise when domestic production is expanded—particularly in the context of recent U.S. policies aimed at achieving energy independence and dominance. Beyond analyzing historical trends, the proposed tool generates forward-looking metrics that support strategic decision-making. Additionally, it introduces two indicators— MS1 and MS2—that quantify the effectiveness of import substitution efforts over time and in response to changes in output. These metrics are embedded within a broader algorithm that integrates macroeconomic data, sectoral interdependencies, and trade dynamics to assess the feasibility and impact of industrial policy interventions. By doing so, the tool not only evaluates past performance but also enables scenario-based forecasting and investment planning.Our contribution is twofold. First, we propose a systematic methodology to categorize industrial sectors into four strategic roles: boosters, non-boosters, strategical pivots, and non-strategical pivots. This classification enables the identification of key sectors that are critical to the supply chains of other industries and the whole industrial sector. Second, we apply this framework to construct an ordinal vector of industrial sectors that highlights leverage points for strengthening domestic energy production and reducing reliance on imported components.By integrating policy analysis, input-output modeling, and techno-economic evaluation, This approach provides policymakers and industry stakeholders with a robust, data-driven foundation for designing strategies that strengthen domestic supply chains, reduce reliance on foreign inputs, and align with national energy security objectives.

title: Semiconductor Supply Chain Synthetic Data Generation Using Knowledge Graphs
authors: Matthew C. Gunn, Davis C. Loose, Megan E. Gunn, Negin Moghadasi, Thomas L. Polmateer, Zachary A. Collier, Igor Linkov, James H. Lambert
abstract: Semiconductors are essential to a variety of applications ranging from consumer goods to military systems. Their decentralized supply chains are particularly vulnerable to disruptions including from technology innovations, tampering/counterfeits, natural hazards, geopolitical conflicts, surges of supply/demand, tariffs, and regulations. Simulation and forecast models can help improve the resilience of the supply chains, though the scarcity of observational or experimental data is a challenge for modelers. This paper introduces a procedure for generating synthetic data using a knowledge graph for a synthetic dataset. Two AI-assisted experiments are illustrated to compare approaches with respect to resource utilization and amenability to validation. The results are used to reflect on best practices for generating synthetic data in this topic.

title: Hybrid Protection Against UWB Pulses Based on a Meander Line and a Gas Discharge Tube
authors: Georgiy Y. Kim, Konstantin P. Malygin, Yevgeniy S. Zhechev, Alexander V. Nosov
abstract: This paper presents a detailed analysis of the influence of exposure duration on the protective characteristics of a gas discharge tube (GDT) using SPICE model simulation and experimental testing. Based on the analysis results, we optimized the SPICE model to provide clearer results and formulated the conditions for the timely triggering of the GDT. Two different types of exposure and two meander line (ML)-based structures were considered. It was demonstrated how the first pulse from the output of the lines primes the GDT for triggering, with subsequent pulses being suppressed by the device. Despite the fact that in this case the first pulse (which primes the GDT) propagates further and is not attenuated, its amplitude is still lower than that of the original pulse. This is important for reducing the heating of sensitive elements in radio-electronic equipment. In this scenario, the maximum ultra-wideband (UWB) pulse attenuation in structures 1 and 2 was 25 and 44 times, respectively. Additionally, we considered the case where the GDT was connected at the input of the line and found that this connection is preferable for maximum UWB pulse suppression. Specifically, the maximum UWB pulse attenuation in structures 1 and 2 was 102 and 143 times, respectively. As a result, the attenuation of UWB pulses at the output of the ML with the GDT was increased, compared to the ML alone.

title: Forget Me Not: Fighting Local Overfitting With Knowledge Fusion and Distillation
authors: Uri Stern, Eli Corn, Daphna Weinshall
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Overfitting in deep neural networks occurs less frequently than expected. This is a puzzling observation, as theory predicts that greater model capacity should eventually lead to overfitting – yet this is rarely seen in practice. But what if overfitting does occur, not globally, but in specific sub-regions of the data space? In this work, we introduce a novel score that measures the forgetting rate of deep models on validation data, capturing what we term local overfitting: a performance degradation confined to certain regions of the input space. We demonstrate that local overfitting can arise even without conventional overfitting, and is closely linked to the double descent phenomenon. Building on these insights, we introduce a two-stage approach that leverages the training history of a single model to recover and retain forgotten knowledge: first, by aggregating checkpoints into an ensemble, and then by distilling it into a single model of the original size, thus enhancing performance without added inference cost. Extensive experiments across multiple datasets, modern architectures, and training regimes validate the effectiveness of our approach. Notably, in the presence of label noise, our method – Knowledge Fusion followed by Knowledge Distillation – outperforms both the original model and independently trained ensembles, achieving a rare win-win scenario: reduced training and inference complexity.

title: A general and robust active fire detection method using Sentinel-2 and Landsat shortwave infrared measurements_supp1-3647717.docx
authors: Minghui Tao
abstract: Accurate detection of active fires (AF) is crucial for improving estimates of biomass burning emissions and environmental management. Satellite remote sensing at shortwave infrared (SWIR) bands with 10-30m spatial resolution has a great potential in identifying the numerous small active fires missed by fire-monitoring systems using coarse spatial resolution data, but is challenging due to heterogeneous backgrounds and multiple interferences. By combing enhanced threshold method and abundant prior information, we developed a generalized and robust fire detection algorithm using the daytime Sentinel-2 SWIR observations over complex surfaces in China. To discriminate with high reflecting surface targets such as rooftop and solar panels, more thresholds with visible and SWIR bands along with land cover datasets are utilized. Moreover, industrial thermal anomalies are excluded by time series satellite images. Validations of Sentinel-2 AF detection through visual inspection show very low commission rates (<1-3%) over selected regions of the world. Since burnt areas in fire boundaries with higher temperature than backgrounds were taken as AFs, the average omission rates increase to ~3-4%. A maximum omission rate of ~7-8% occurs in African grassland, which has a short burning time. Despite consistent spatial patterns, 1 km MODIS and 375 m VIIRS detections performed in the medium infrared bands missed more than 90% of Sentinel-2 AFs. With the flexible framework, our method also has robust performance in similar Landsat 8/9 SWIR observations. By combing Sentinel-2 2B/2C and Landsat 8/9 observations, our reliable AF detection at fine scales (20-30 m) can provide a significant supplement for the biomass burning emission estimation with a temporal resolution of 2-3 days.

title: Track and Enclose a Target of Mobile Robot With Motion and Field of View Constraints: An Event-Triggered Control Strategy
authors: Yu Wen, Yue Yang, Jiangshuai Huang, Shaoxin Sun, Xiaojie Su
abstract: This article presents a robust control strategy for formation enclosing and tracking of a dynamic target by a group of two-wheeled mobile robots under network control. Reference trajectories are designed to enable the robots to encircle and follow the target while meeting motion and field-of-view constraints. An event-triggered nonsingular terminal sliding mode controller is then proposed, where a specific class of scalar functions defines a novel sliding surface that ensures finite-time convergence in the presence of matched disturbances and avoids singularity. An event-triggered mechanism determines control signal transmissions and is adapted to handle communication delays, ensuring closed-loop stability while reducing communication load. The proposed method is validated through experiments on a multi-robot triangular formation tracking task, demonstrating its applicability and effectiveness in practical networked scenarios.

title: Single-Mode ZBLAN Optical Fiber Couplers: Minimizing Losses and Devitrification
authors: Gebrehiwot Tesfay Zeweldi, Tina Lam, Mark Andrews, Martin Rochette
abstract: Single-mode ZBLAN optical fiber couplers with coupling ratios as high as 50%/50% are demonstrated. Thanks to a controlled argon atmosphere during tapering, low-loss single-mode couplers are fabricated with excess losses of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< $</tex-math></inline-formula>0.75 dB in the spectral range of 1500 nm - 2680 nm, and their broadband transmission is characterized. Tapers fabricated under an argon atmosphere are compared with those fabricated under ambient air, revealing differences in transmission loss and surface texture. Combinations of scanning electron microscopy, energy-dispersive spectroscopy, and x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, coupled with XPS depth profiling, assign different roles to the implication of fluorine surface diffusion and reactions with adventitious oxygen, water, and carbonaceous deposits. A common denominator revealed by XPS is the interruption of the metastable ZrF<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{4}$</tex-math></inline-formula> network caused by elevated temperature processing. It is concluded that introducing a neutral blanket of inert gas to the fiber drawing oven yields optical fiber couplers with substantially reduced transmission losses.

title: Q Cells in Wireless Networks
authors: Martin Haenggi
abstract: For a given set of transmitters such as cellular base stations or WiFi access points, is it possible to analytically characterize the set of locations that are “covered” in the sense that users at these locations experience a certain minimum quality of service? In this paper, we affirmatively answer this question, by providing explicit simple outer bounds and estimates for the coverage manifold. The key geometric elements of our analytical method are the Q cells, defined as the intersections of a small number of disks. The Q cell of a transmitter is an outer bound to the service region of the transmitter, and, in turn, the union of Q cells is an outer bound to the coverage manifold. In infinite networks, connections to the meta distribution of the signal-to-interference ratio allow for a scaling of the Q cells to obtain accurate estimates of the coverage manifold.

title: Edge-Guided Shallow and Contextual Deep Feature Learning via Bidirectional Attention for Salient Object Detection in Optical Remote Sensing Images
authors: Samra Kanwal, Nazar Waheed, Bushra Rashid, Nayef Alqahtani, Ali Alqahtani
abstract: Salient object detection from optical remote sensing images seeks to detect and segment out objects that stand out visually by mimicking human interpretation. Accurately detecting salient objects in remote sensing imagery is hindered by the broad variability in object appearances and background complexity. Despite recent advancements, there exist two major challenges. Firstly, it remains unclear how to fuse shallow features with deep features optimally. Secondly, defining an optimal strategy for multi-scale feature processing is crucial, as patterns can vary significantly across different levels. We introduce a novel bidirectional attention mechanism to tackle these challenges. Our framework features: (1) a Parallel Convolution-Channel Attention (PCCA) module that boosts edge representation and highlights salient feature channels, and (2) a Holistic Reverse Attention (HRA) module that preserves crucial details in high-level features. Coupled with a multiscale progressive decoder, our method enables precise feature integration. Extensive evaluation on benchmark datasets demonstrates the superiority of our proposed model compared with 17 state-of-the-art (SOTA) models, achieving a significant 11.57% reduction in Mean Absolute Error and setting a new state-of-the-art on S-measure with a 0.4% improvement.

title: Reducing Latency by Eliminating CSIT Feedback: FDD Downlink MIMO Transmission for Internet-of-Things Communications
authors: Juntaek Han, Namhyun Kim, Jeonghun Park
abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for low-latency frequency division duplex (FDD) multi-input multi-output (MIMO) transmission with Internet of Things (IoT) communications. Our key idea is eliminating feedback associated with downlink channel state information at the transmitter (CSIT) acquisition. Instead, we propose to reconstruct downlink CSIT from uplink reference signals by exploiting the frequency invariance property of channel parameters. Nonetheless, the frequency disparity between the uplink and downlink makes it impossible to get perfect downlink CSIT, resulting in substantial interference. To address this, we formulate a max-min fairness problem and propose a rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA)-aided efficient precoding method. In particular, to fully harness the potential benefits of RSMA, we propose a method that approximates the error covariance matrix and incorporates it into the precoder optimization process. This approach effectively accounts for the impact of imperfect CSIT, enabling the design of a robust precoder that efficiently handles CSIT inaccuracies. Simulation results demonstrate that our framework outperforms other baseline methods in terms of the minimum spectral efficiency when no direct CSI feedback is used. Moreover, we show that our framework significantly reduces communication latency compared to conventional CSI feedback-based methods, underscoring its effectiveness in enhancing latency performance for IoT communications.

title: Synthesis of Sparse Antenna Arrays Using Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models
authors: Jiapeng Zhang, Zihan Zhang, Hui Li
abstract: Designing sparse arrays with fewer antenna elements and lower peak sidelobe level (PSLL) is critical and challenging for antenna arrays in terminal devices in Internet of Things (IoT) systems. This article presents a deep learning method based on denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) for synthesizing sparse arrays. With predefined constraints such as aperture size, number of elements, and minimum element spacing, a training dataset that enables the proposed DDPM is generated to directly learn the distribution characteristics of these sparse arrays. To simplify the network architecture, the backbone network U-Net is replaced by a multilayer perceptron (MLP). In addition, an innovative conditional generation strategy is introduced to enhance the training accuracy, categorizing the training data into diverse cross-conditional labels based on PSLL and sparse ratio. During the training process, two separate regression networks are employed to predict the sparse ratio and the PSLL, and a Pareto-optimal weighting scheme (PWS) is designed to address the trade-off between them. Examples of two planar sparse arrays and a conformal sparse array demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed DDPM-based method, highlighting its superiority in reducing PSLL and increasing sparse ratio, reducing inference time compared with the existing methods.

title: A 5.9 GHz Sezawa SAW Acoustic Delay Line Based on Al 0.6 Sc 0.4 N-on-Sapphire with Propagation Q -factor of 3,044
authors: Chin-Yu Chang, Xiaolei Tong, Pedram Yousefian, Ella Klein, Xingyu Du, Roy H. Olsson
abstract: In this work, we demonstrate a high-performance surface acoustic wave (SAW) delay line based on a Scandium alloyed aluminum nitride (AlScN)-on-sapphire platform operating at 5.9 GHz with an exceptionally high acoustic propagation Q-factor. An 800 nm AlScN thin film with 40% scandium alloying concentration was deposited on a thick sapphire substrate to achieve strong acoustic energy confinement and large electromechanical coupling, thereby minimizing the insertion loss (IL) and propagation loss (PL) of the acoustic delay line (ADL). The proposed ADL was designed to operate in the Sezawa mode using a Single-Phase Unidirectional Transducer (SPUDT) electrode configuration for better unidirectionality. The fabricated ADLs with different delay lengths, after conjugate matching, exhibited delay times spanning 13 to 214 ns and IL ranging from 7.6 to 18.3 dB. The extracted PL reached as low as 9.2 dB/mm at 5.9 GHz, with a group velocity (vg) of around 5,779 m/s. Based on these results, the proposed ADLs exhibit a high acoustic propagation Q-factor of 3,044. These findings highlight the potential of AlScN-on-sapphire platforms for high operational frequency, low-loss SAW ADL devices in advanced RF applications.

title: A Novel Long Short-Term Complementary Memory Network Based on Temporal Distribution Matching for Soft Sensing in Industrial Processes
authors: Kaiji Liao, Xudong Shi, Lin Sui, William Holderbaum, Weili Xiong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: With the development of industrial intelligence, deep learning-based soft sensors are widely used in complex industrial systems to estimate key quality variables in real-time, with long short-term memory (LSTM) networks excelling in nonlinear dynamic modeling. However, conventional LSTM networks face the challenge of redundant memory weight allocation, which hinders efficient capture of critical temporal dependencies. Moreover, the probability distribution of industrial process variables often exhibits dynamic temporal shifts, significantly deteriorating model generalization performance. In this study, a novel long short-term complementary memory network based on temporal distribution matching (TDM-LSTCM) is proposed for product quality prediction in industrial processes. First, a novel memory update rate gate is designed based on LSTM to obtain adaptive update rate factors for different time steps, regulating the information flow rate. Second, the memory update rate gate is embedded into the input and forget gates, leading to the development of a complementary input-forget regulation gate structure to optimize the cell state update mechanism. Furthermore, the TDM algorithm is incorporated into the training process through a dual-stage optimization strategy. During the distribution characterization stage, the training dataset is partitioned into distinct periods with the most pronounced distributional discrepancies. In the distribution matching stage, cross-period discrepancies in hidden states are minimized to facilitate the extraction of common information. Finally, the proposed methodology is validated through a penicillin fermentation process and flue gas desulfurization system. Experimental results demonstrate that the developed approach outperforms other modeling methods, showcasing its promising application potential.

title: DRACO: Data Replication and Collection Framework for Enhanced Data Availability and Robustness in IoT Networks
authors: Waleed Bin Qaim, Öznur OÖzkasap, Rabia Qadar, Moncef Gabbouj
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) bridges the gap between the physical and digital worlds, enabling seamless interaction with real-world objects via the Internet. However, IoT systems face significant challenges in ensuring efficient data generation, collection, and management, particularly due to the resource-constrained and unreliable nature of connected devices, which can lead to data loss. This paper presents DRACO (Data Replication and Collection), a framework that integrates a distributed hop-by-hop data replication approach with a routing-free mobile sink-based data collection strategy. DRACO enhances data availability, optimizes replica placement, and ensures efficient data retrieval even under node failures and varying network densities. Extensive ns-3 simulations demonstrate that DRACO outperforms state-of-the-art techniques, improving data availability by up to 15% and 34%, and replica creation by up to 18% and 40%, compared to greedy and random replication techniques, respectively. DRACO also ensures efficient data dissemination through optimized replica distribution and achieves superior data collection efficiency under varying node densities and failure scenarios as compared to commonly used uncontrolled sink mobility approaches namely random walk and self-avoiding random walk. By addressing key IoT data management challenges, DRACO offers a scalable and resilient solution well-suited for emerging use cases including industrial IoT device monitoring, smart city environmental sensing, agricultural IoT data collection, and disaster response networks, where maintaining data availability under device failures or intermittent connectivity is critical.

title: User Preference-Aware Deep Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Objective Optimal EV Charging Control
authors: Kyoungjin Kim, Qin Yang, Sang-Jo Yoo
abstract: his paper presents a deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based electric vehicle (EV) charging control framework that dynamically optimizes the supplied voltage and current in response to real-time battery states, environmental conditions, and user preferences. Unlike conventional model-based controllers, the proposed method learns optimal charging strategies through interaction with a virtualized electro-thermal environment, enabling adaptability to nonlinear battery dynamics and stochastic user behavior. The charging problem is formulated as a constrained Markov decision process, and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) is employed to learn adaptive control strategies. A hybrid two-stage learning structure is designed, combining indirect reinforcement learning in simulation for safe policy acquisition and direct learning for real-world adaptability. A multi-objective reward function is developed to reflect user-specific trade-offs among charging efficiency, charging time, and target SoC achievement, while safety constraints are embedded through penalty terms. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed DRL controller achieves faster convergence, improved charging efficiency, and stronger constraint satisfaction compared to the conventional constant current – constant voltage (CC–CV) and model predictive control (MPC) benchmarks.

title: D-Axis Inductance Measurement Considering Cross-Coupling Interference Using Low-Speed Sensorless Control of SynRM
authors: Yuto Yamamori, Hiroto Yoshida, Mutuwo Tomita, Masaru Hasegawa, Shinji Doki
abstract: Synchronous reluctance motors (SynRMs), which are characterized by the absence of permanent magnets and rotor windings, have garnered significant attention in recent years. A notable characteristic of SynRMs is the substantial variation in the inductances $L_{d}$ and $L_{q}$ along the d and q axes, which is influenced by magnetic saturation and the current flowing through each axis. Furthermore, cross-coupling interference occurs, where $L_{d}$ varies with the q-axis current, and $L_{q}$ varies with the d-axis current. Therefore, errors in motor parameters owing to variations in $L_{d}$ and $L_{q}$ influence the position sensorless control. To address these challenges, we propose a novel position sensorless control technique that leverages a SynRM model to estimate the high-frequency extended EMF generated by superposing high-frequency currents at low speeds. In this approach, when the circular superposition method, which superimposes high-frequency currents on both the d and q axes, is employed, the position estimation error converges even if a significant discrepancy exists between the actual and set values of $L_{q}$ of the SynRM model. By implementing this method and calibrating $L_{d}$ within the SynRM model to ensure convergence of the position estimation error, $L_{d}$ can be measured regardless of the variation in $L_{q}$. This paper presents experimental results that demonstrate the efficacy of this approach. In this study, we leverage this advantage to demonstrate that our method for measuring $L_{d}$, while considering cross-coupling interference yields highly valuable experimental results.

title: Realization of All-Device ZVS at Light Load Operations in DAB Converters Using SPS-Based Partial Power Canceling Modulation
authors: Yota Suzuki, Cheng Huang, Takanori Isobe
abstract: This paper proposes an improved SPS-based modulation for Dual Active Bridge (DAB) converters. The method achieves zero-voltage switching (ZVS) across all switching transitions, even under light-load and no-load conditions. It is achieved by introducing a zero-power transfer period within the SPS waveform, during which power transfer is actively canceled. It enables to reduce the net transferred power while maintaining a constant repetitive frequency. This method does not change the magnetic flux and field in the transformer from that by the conventional single phase shift (SPS); therefore, audible acoustic noise from the transformer core, it can be a problem when the load is varying periodically, can potentially be suppressed. The effectiveness of the proposed method was experimentally verified using a 3.3 kW DAB converter with 3.3 kV SiC-MOSFETs.

title: Variation-Aware Circuit Simulation of Parallel-Connected SiC MOSFETs Based on Individual Device Modeling
authors: Kazuki Matsumoto, Taiki Nishioka, Hajime Takayama, Jun Furuta, Kazutoshi Kobayashi, Michihiro Shintani
abstract: Silicon carbide (SiC) MOSFETs exhibit significant device-to-device variation, which cannot be accurately simulated using the SPICE models provided by manufacturers. This paper presents a variation-aware circuit simulation framework based on individual device modeling. The proposed method is applied to two commercial SiC MOSFETs with parametric variations, whose device parameters are extracted from measured switching waveforms and implemented into a SPICE simulation of the parallel connection of the two devices. Transient analyses under double-pulse test conditions successfully reproduce the current imbalance in experiments, with rise time and fall time showing good agreement between simulation and measurement (errors within 0.9-5.2 %). Furthermore, the simulation environment enables the evaluation of countermeasures using an active gate driver with individually tuned waveforms. The agreement between simulation and measurement validates the effectiveness of the proposed method. This variation-aware simulation methodology facilitates earlystage evaluation of imbalance mitigation techniques. It contributes to design quality of high-power SiC-based converter circuits.

title: Study of SiC and Cascoded GaN Power Switches Adopted in Boost and Full-Bridge Resonant Converters
authors: Wen-Cheng Chu, Tsorng-Juu Liang, Kai-Hui Chen, Ching-Ya Chien, Pei-Wen Li
abstract: In this paper, SiC and cascoded GaN power devices are practically applied to boost converters and fullbridge resonant converters for investigating their characteristics under hard switching and soft switching, respectively. A boost converter is then implemented with the following specifications an input voltage 300 V, an output voltage 600 V, a rated power 2 kW, and switching frequency 200 kHz. A full-bridge resonant converter specified with an input voltage 600 V, an output voltage of 200 V, a rated power of 2 kW, and resonant frequency of 300 kHz is implemented. The characteristics of SiC and cascoded GaN power devices operating in hard and soft switching are then discussed. Experimental results show that the full-load efficiencies of the hard switching boost converter using SiC and cascoded GaN power devices are $97.9 \%$ and $98.2 \%$, respectively, while the fullload efficiencies of the soft switching full-bridge resonant converter are $94.7 \%$ and $95.2 \%$ with SiC and cascoded GaN power devices, respectively.

title: Analysis of Service Engineer Profession Models
authors: V. A. Marenko, A. E. Lozhnikov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The professional competencies of a service engineer job directly influences on economics, in particular on reducing financial losses related to equipment downtime. For various sectors of the economy, it may result in technical insecurity of the country in general. The problem also includes service providers, ensuring strategic development priority of the country. The aspects enumerated above prove the actual urgency and relevance of the problem chosen for research. The aim of the research is to investigate the content of a service engineer job with the help of cognitive modeling using the agricultural and industrial complex as a case study. It includes building a cognitive model and its analysis to identify functionally important factors using simulation modeling. Methods: to realize the aim the development of cognitive model variants has been built in the form of sign graphs, the vertices of which being the concepts of a subject field (factors) and the curves being the causal relations between them. The estimate of factor interactions is made with the help of simplicial analysis and simulation experiment series. The results of the research show that the set of factors influencing on the job of a service engineer such as “resource planning”, “economic thinking”, “readiness to learn”, experience”, “remoteness of service centers” are functionally important for this profession. These factors recognized by the experts should be considered by management administrations when making managerial decisions.

title: The Knowledge Cosmos: An Immersive Platform for Interdisciplinary Research Discovery
authors: Alec McGail, Rifaa Tajani, Nikita Sridhar, Jiabao Li
abstract: As the volume of scientific literature continues to expand exponentially, traditional research tools struggle to keep pace—often reinforcing disciplinary silos and limiting opportunities for discovery. The Knowledge Cosmos re-imagines research exploration through an interactive, 3D visualization platform that treats science not as a static repository, but as a navigable universe. By spatializing 17 million academic papers based on semantic similarity, the platform enables users to explore the structure of knowledge intuitively, uncover interdisciplinary connections, and identify underexplored intellectual gaps.Drawing on the principles of play, immersion, and serendipity, The Knowledge Cosmos democratizes the bird’s eye view of research and encourages curiosity-driven inquiry across a wide range of users including students, educators, independent thinkers, and lifelong learners. This paper outlines the conceptual foundations, design, and technological infrastructure of the platform, shares insights from preliminary usability testing, and discusses future directions to scale its potential as a catalyst for interdisciplinary exploration and knowledge creation.

title: Marketing Preferences for Paid versus Free Digital Platforms and AI-powered Tools in Aviation English Language Learning
authors: Róbert Rozenberg, Anna Cekanová, Miroslava Semancíková, Daniela Cekanová, Michaela Bugnová
abstract: The aviation industry depends on precise communication between pilots and air traffic controllers (ATCOs), making listening and speaking skills crucial for safety and efficiency. With the growth of digital platforms, e-learning has become one of the core methods for developing aviation English proficiency along with traditional classroom-based learning. This study explores new trends and complementary research in e-learning methodologies for developing language skills to student pilots, ATCOs, aircraft mechanics and other aviation related professions based on survey data collected from the 110 students of the Faculty of Aeronautics of Technical University of Košice. At the same time, the study examines the marketing dimension of online language education by analyzing a follow up survey on students’ preferences for digital platforms offering paid or free versions of online courses. Results highlight both the pedagogical and market-driven factors shaping the future of aviation English training influenced by emerging technology.

title: Attitude synchronization and position consensus for a multi-agent autonomous system
authors: Stephen Kimathi, Bertalan Beszédes, Abdallah Benhamida
abstract: This paper presents a formulation for the simultaneous solution to the attitude and position control for a multiagent formation coordination, based on dual quaternion and graph theory techniques. The agents in the formation system are represented using dual quaternion parameterized kinematics in the configuration space, such that a control strategy is designed to achieve the simultaneous attitude synchronization and position consensus to a target reference trajectory. The control strategy is formulated based on a distributed leader follower formation architecture, with a static configuration modelled using graph theory. The goal of the formation system is to ensure the convergence and tracking of attitude trajectory of the leader agent by the followers agents, while maintaining a preset desired formation shape between the agents. Numerical simulations have been presented using four homogeneous rigid bodies, to validate the effectiveness of the proposed control configuration in the consensus based formation acquisition and maintenance.

title: Payment-failure times for random Lightning paths
authors: Taki E.M. Abedesselam, Fabio Giacomelli, Francesco Pasquale, Michele Salvi
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: We study a random process over graphs inspired by the way payments are executed in the Lightning Network, the main layer-two solution on top of Bitcoin. We first prove almost tight upper and lower bounds on the time it takes for a payment failure to occur, as a function of the number of nodes and the edge capacities, when the underlying graph is complete. Then, we show how such a random process is related to the edge-betweenness centrality measure and we prove upper and lower bounds for arbitrary graphs as a function of edge-betweenness and capacity. Finally, we validate our theoretical results by running extensive simulations over some classes of graphs, including snapshots of the real Lightning Network.

title: Research on 5G Network Testbed for Industrial Control Requirements
authors: Wen Tan, Lu Yin, Shi Dong, Ying Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Closed-loop control systems impose stringent requirements on network latency and jitter. Traditional industrial Ethernet and fieldbus technologies can achieve deterministic transmission through dedicated protocols, yet wireless communication still faces instability in industrial scenarios. Although 5G networks possess potential advantages in low latency and high reliability, their performance in industrial closed-loop control has not been systematically validated. To address this gap, this paper designs and implements a 5G network test platform tailored for industrial closed-loop control. The platform is constructed based on an end-edge-cloud collaborative architecture, ensuring consistency between the plant and actual industrial processes. On this platform, a digital twin model is integrated with the control system and 5G network to conduct closed-loop control experiments over 5G transmission, followed by a comparative analysis of the network’s impact on control performance. The results demonstrate that the proposed platform can effectively replicate industrial control processes, providing a verification method for assessing the applicability of 5G networks in closed-loop control. Furthermore, it establishes an experimental foundation for future network protocol optimization and industrial adoption.

title: Reinforcement Learning With Self-Aligning Torque for Autonomous Driving Agents on Low-Friction Surfaces
authors: Riku Oyama, Yuichi Okuyama, Kenta Hosoya, Yoichi Tomioka, Nobuyoshi Asai, Jungpil Shin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: In our research, we propose the reinforcement learning method considering self-aligning torque for improving driving stability of autonomous driving agents on low-friction road surfaces. While prior reinforcement learning studies for autonomous driving did not consider self-aligning torque, we explicitly introduce it as an additional observation signal. We employed the Soft Actor-Critic(SAC) algorithm for learning and conducted evaluation experiments on the Donkey Simulator under six different conditions, combining the with or without self-aligning torque, the the with or without steering angle observation, and the output format for force or angle. Agents with self-aligning torque consistently achieved faster lap times across all conditions compared to agents without it. This demonstrates their contribution to stability and performance. This study suggests potential applicability not only in simulators but also for future real-world autonomous driving on low-friction surfaces.

title: Preserving Sovereignty and Privacy for Personalization: Designing a Federated Recommendation System for Data Spaces
authors: Haya Halimeh, Philipp zur Heiden
abstract: Data spaces have become a strategic pillar of Europe's digital agenda, enabling sovereign, legally compliant data sharing within decentralized ecosystems. As data space initiatives evolve, personalized recommendations are increasingly recognized as key use cases. However, traditional recommendation approaches typically rely on centralized aggregation of user behavior data-directly conflicting with the core ethos of data spaces: sovereignty, privacy, and trust. Federated recommendation systems offer a promising alternative by training models locally and exchanging only intermediate parameters to build a global model. Despite this potential, the integration of federated recommendation techniques and data space architectures remains largely underexplored in research and practice. This paper addresses this gap by designing and evaluating a prototype of a federated recommendation system specifically tailored for data spaces and compliant with their underlying infrastructure. Our findings highlight the viability of developing privacy-preserving, collaborative recommendation systems within data spaces, and contribute to the broader adoption of AI across these emerging ecosystems.

title: A Current Sensing Method with Enhanced Immunity to Reference Ground Disturbance
authors: En-Chi Kang, Yaow-Ming Chen
abstract: This paper proposes a current sensing method by using the Enhanced Capture (eCAP) which is a function of the microcontroller. The proposed sensing method detects the rising and falling edges of the pulse signal, computes its duty ratio, and subsequently decodes the signal to reconstruct the actual sensed current. It has a better noise immunity than using the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC), which is easily affected by noise. The proposed sensing method can get more precise feedback value when the reference ground of microcontroller is interfered. This paper introduces the operation of the eCAP module and provides a detailed description of the sensing circuit design process. Additionally, the method for reconstructing the actual current from the signals obtained by the eCAP is presented. Simulation results obtained from the PLECS software and experimental results using the Texas Instruments LAUNCHXL-F28379D as the microcontroller are presented for validation. Finally, a histogram is used to compare the accuracy of the proposed sensing method and the ADC sensing method.

title: An intelligent AR content generation mechanism based on agentic AI
authors: Vasiliki Chrysikou, Anthony Karageorgos, Vassilis C. Gerogiannis, Georgios Ntalos
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: As Augmented Reality (AR) technologies continue to evolve, the demand for intelligent and context-aware content generation is rapidly increasing. The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into AR workflows opens new possibilities for dynamic, responsive, and personalized virtual experiences. This paper introduces an innovative framework for AR content generation driven by agentic AI. The proposed mechanism enables intelligent agents to dynamically generate, and call 3D AR content based on real-world contextual requirements. Specifically, the system focuses on using AI-driven modules to automatically generate AR content and efficiently deliver it through intelligent agents, exploring the broader potential of AR generation in industry. As a case study, we examine a scenario in the sustainable furniture manufacturing sector. Specifically, we present an AI agent-based system that assists a furniture manufacturing company calculating the estimated carbon storage based on the type and quantity of wood materials used. The system supports informed decision-making by linking 3D object construction with environmental impact data, dynamically rendered through AR.
