title: Descriptor: Enhancing Conversations for the Hearing Impaired in the 9th Computational Hearing in Multisource Environments Challenge (CHiME9 ECHI)
authors: ROBERT SUTHERLAND, JASON CLARKE, HEND ELGHAZALY, THOMAS KUEBERT, MARKO LUGGER, STEFAN PETRAUSCH, JUAN AZCARRETA ORTIZ, BUYE XU, STEFAN GOETZE, JON BARKER
abstract: This paper presents a dataset for Enhancing Conversations for the Hearing Impaired (ECHI). This is a publicly available dataset comprised of recordings of four-party conversations in a noisy, cafeteria-style environment, close-talk reference speech signals, clean voice samples from the participants and motion tracking data. This dataset was created to be used as part of the Computational Hearing in Multisource Environments (CHiME) 9 Challenge, Task 2 (ECHI), which aims at developing systems to extract and enhance speech from the conversation partners, i.e. removing the background noise using audio from microphone signals of hearing aids or Project Aria smart glasses. This dataset can be used to both train and evaluate the performance of neural-network or signal-processing-based speech enhancement algorithms, and it was created due to the lack of datasets of conversational speech in noisy environments with clean reference audio. Groups of four people were seated around a table, surrounded by loudspeakers which played interfering speech, cafeteria-style sounds and ambient background noise. Participants were instructed to have conversations guided by provided conversation prompts. Each participant also recorded a reading of the first paragraph of the rainbow passage as a clean sample of their voice, which may be used by a speech enhancement system to extract their speech from the noisy mixture. This dataset contains 29 hours of audio from 194 participants.

title: Seabed Sediment Classification Based on Multibeam Data Using a Multifeature Fusion Algorithm
authors: Hongda Guan, Yixiong Zhang, Jingjing Bao, Chengqiang Wu, Wenyan Hong, Huiying Li
abstract: The seabed sediment serves as a critical indicator of seabed conditions, and its accurate classification is essential for rapid assessment of the seabed environment. In this article, we propose a novel multifeature fusion algorithm based on bathymetry and backscatter intensity data acquired by a multibeam bathymetry system. To address the challenge of the limited availability of labeled samples, a sample enhancement algorithm is proposed to effectively expand the data set while preserving sample consistency. To improve the feature expression ability of single-source data, we extract various texture features from the backscatter intensity data using the gray-level co-occurrence matrix, while different topographic features are derived from the bathymetry data. Given the high dimensionality and redundancy of these features, the random forest algorithm is employed to quantify feature importance, and a feature selection method is proposed based on importance ranking. Experimental results demonstrate that the selected feature combination achieves higher classification accuracy and stronger feature expression ability. By integrating the sample enhancement and multifeature fusion algorithms, the random forest model attains a classification accuracy of 96.73% on real data. This work establishes a viable framework for seabed sediment classification by leveraging the sample enhancement and multifeature fusion.

title: A Wideband D-band Microbump Antenna with Self-packaged Design
authors: Junming Ding, Wangwen Xu, Yue Ping Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: This article presents a wideband, efficiency enhanced, slot-coupled microbump antenna featuring a self-packaged design for D-band applications. The proposed architecture employs substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) technology with slot feeding, fabricated using the standard printed circuit board (PCB) process. It is seamlessly integrated into a silicon wafer through advanced heterogeneous integration technique to facilitate accurate antenna measurement. A benzocyclobutene (BCB)-based coplanar waveguide with ground (CPWG) to PCB-based SIW transition is designed to ensure effective interconnection and probe measurement. The microbump operates in a quasi-TM₁₀ mode, while the slot resonates in a half-wavelength mode, with both modes closely aligned in frequency and exhibiting strong mutual coupling. Furthermore, the dual microbumps act as electric dipoles, coupling with the slot’s magnetic response to form a hybrid configuration that significantly enhances bandwidth. Remarkably, the design achieves high performance despite utilizing cost-effective but lossy FR-4 substrate, which is typically suboptimal for millimeter-wave (mmWave) applications. Compared to conventional slot antenna, the proposed design exhibits significant improvements: impedance bandwidth increases from 5.9% to 42.8%, radiation efficiency from 57.8% to 71.6%, and maximum realized gain from 4.95 dBi to 8.54 dBi. These advancements make the antenna an excellent candidate for highly integrated antenna-in-package (AiP) solutions on FR-4 substrate.

title: A Low-Complexity Neural Equalizer for Nonlinear Compensation in Photonics-Assisted Terahertz Wireless Links Beyond 500 GHz
authors: Liang Zhao, Yanyi Wang, Dongju Du, Yingxiong Song, Zhengxuan Li, Nan Ye, Qianwu Zhang, Junjie Zhang, Min Zhu, Jiao Zhang, Mingxu Wang, Jianjun Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Terahertz Science and Technology
abstract: Photonics-assisted terahertz (THz) communication beyond 500 GHz has emerged as a key enabler for future 6 G wireless networks, but faces critical signal impairments such as phase noise, inter-symbol interference (ISI), and nonlinear distortion caused by optoelectronic devices. The deep convolutional neural network (Deep-CNN) equalizers have been utilized at the receiver digital signal processing to mitigate signal impairments. However, traditional Deep-CNN equalizers face the issue of high computational complexity. Thus, we propose and demonstrate a low-complexity nonlinear equalizer CNN-biGRU-Attention-pruning (CNN-biGRU-A-P) for a THz wireless communication beyond 500 GHz. We introduce <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {L}_{1}$</tex-math></inline-formula> -structured pruning, knowledge distillation and the AdamW optimizer into the model to significantly reduce computational complexity and parameter count, while keeping the accuracy degradation within 3%. The experimental results demonstrate that, compared to the traditional Deep-CNN, the proposed CNN-biGRU-A-P reduces computational complexity by 96.8% and achieves a gain in receiver sensitivity of 0.5–0.8dB. Meanwhile, the number of parameters of CNN-biGRU-A-P is reduced by 93.2% compared to the traditional Deep-CNN. The proposed CNN-biGRU-A-P nonlinear equalizer maintains high performance while significantly reducing computational complexity, thereby offering an efficient approach to mitigating nonlinear impairments in THz wireless communication systems.

title: Digital Twin-Guided Soft Sensor With Dual Spatial Attention for CO Concentration Prediction under Limited Labels
authors: Yupeng Xing, Fenghu Liang, Xindong Wang, Xiangyu Cao, Dongya Zhao
abstract: Hydrocarbon steam reforming (HSR) is widely employed in refineries for hydrogen production, where carbon monoxide (CO) concentration serves as a critical indicator of carbon emission intensity. However, accurately estimating CO concentration in real time remains a challenge due to the limited labeled data and poor data quality. To address these issues, a digital twin-guided soft sensor with dual spatial attention (DTDSA) is proposed. Firstly, a digital twin model is developed to produce pseudo-labels by mechanism simulator, alleviating the shortage of labeled data while embedding domain knowledge to guide subsequent feature extraction. Secondly, a novel dual spatial attention stacked quality-autoencoder (DSA-SQAE) model is proposed to dynamically capture critical features, thereby improving robustness against poor data quality. Specifically, an input spatial attention layer is designed to extract informative features across layers, while a gated spatial attention layer is incorporated to capture multi-level features and model complex spatial dependencies. Furthermore, a real-virtual-supervised training strategy is incorporated to enhance the extraction of critical features from both real and simulated data. Finally, experimental results from a real HSR case demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves CO concentration prediction accuracy.

title: Multi-Channel Sparse Bayesian Learning With GAMP Integration for Bearing Fault Diagnosis
authors: Zheng Cao, Jisheng Dai, Weichao Xu, Chunqi Chang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Industrial Electronics
abstract: Data collected from multiple sensors contains rich fault information for bearing fault diagnosis. However, it is difficult to leverage these joint information due to the following reasons: (1) signals from different channels often have asynchronous sampling lengths, which can greatly hinder subsequent processing; (2) unpaired frequency transformations can lead to significant algorithmic degradation; and (3) handling multi-channel data simultaneously can be quite time-consuming. To solve above three challenges, in this paper, we newly propose a multi-channel sparse Bayesian learning (SBL) based approach for bearing fault diagnosis. The key innovations are: (1) extend the existing sparse frequency learning model into multi-channel form, accommodating variable-length signals across different channels; (2) identify the fault frequencies from the signal envelopes without any frequency transformations by leveraging the common sparsity of the fault frequencies-of-interest in the frequency domain; and (3) construct a real-valued data model with a special unitary matrix, and integrate the generalized approximate message passing (GAMP) method into the Bayesian framework to enhance the fault detection performance while reducing computational complexity. Since the message passing has the property of element-wise operation and can provide exact marginal posteriors, the proposed method can achieve state-of-the-art performance with low-complexity. Both simulation and real datasets can demonstrate it.

title: Data Disclosure for Heterogeneous Privacy Profile
authors: Ke Chao, Shengling Wang, Weicheng Wang, Shaoyong Guo, Xiuzhen Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: The crux of data disclosure lies in the meticulous quantification and judicious trade-off between privacy leakage and utility. Firstly, the measurement of privacy leakage is the premise of sensitive data compliance disclosure. Existing solutions are mainly based on the qualitative perspective and the group perspective, which are unable to quantitatively measure the risk of individual privacy leakage. Secondly, in terms of balancing privacy leakage and utility, existing solutions overlook uninformed disclosure scenarios. In such scenarios, the two-dimensional privacy-utility game will be reduced to the optimization of a single parameter of mutual information. To address the aforementioned drawbacks, this paper proposes a data disclosure mechanism tailored for heterogeneous privacy profiles. Specifically, we decouple the multilevel privacy leakage through mutual information. By respectively addressing the informed and uninformed disclosure, we achieve the optimization of the joint potential energy surface of privacy and utility, breaking through the dilemma of excessive protection and utility collapse in data disclosure. On this basis, we conduct a comprehensive discussion on the two data disclosure strategies, namely introducing disturbance and linear obfuscation. The results of extensive simulations verify the effectiveness of the proposed mechanism. Finally, our work shows that balancing privacy and utility in data disclosure is unfeasible with disturbance-introducing strategies. In contrast, using linear obfuscation strategies can achieve such a balance, and the optimal approach is the disclosure scheme that minimizes the data disclosure loss.

title: Finite-Time Adaptive Control of Genetic Regulatory Networks with Mixed Delays and Disturbances: A Comparison Approach
authors: Rui Wang, Kui Ding, Xiaotai Wu, Kiabo Shi, Quanxin Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: This brief studies the finite-time control problem for a class of complex genetic regulatory networks (GRNs) with mixed time delays, actuator faults, and random disturbances. Firstly, different from existing Lyapunov-based methods, we propose a novel comparison principle approach to stability analysis, which avoids the construction of complex Lyapunov functionals. Secondly, by designing a fractional-power adaptive fault-tolerant controller, we achieve online compensation for actuator faults and suppression of disturbances without requiring prior knowledge of their bounds. Meanwhile, theoretical analysis shows that under relaxed conditions time delays need only be bounded, not differentiable, the closed-loop system states converge to zero exactly within a finite time T. Finally, simulations validate the effectiveness and superiority of the method.

title: PEGSYS: A Portable and Easy-to-Operate Smart Screening and Grading System for Glaucoma
authors: Zhike Han, Zeheng Ye, Wangchao Wu, Chaoyang Hong, Shuiguang Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Glaucoma, a leading cause of irreversible blindness, remains challenging to diagnose due to its asymptomatic progression. Traditional diagnostic methods require high-resolution fundus imaging and specialized expertise, limiting their feasibility for widespread screening, particularly in resource-limited areas, such as rural regions and remote mountainous areas in China. To address this issue, we propose U-Net-Segformer, a glaucoma screening framework designed to enhance segmentation accuracy for low-quality images and mitigate performance degradation across datasets. The model achieved Dice coefficients of 91.01% and 97.50% for optic cup (OC) segmentation and 89.39% and 96.50% for optic disc (OD) segmentation on the Drishti-GS and REFUGE datasets, with absolute cup-to-disc ratio errors of 3.13% and 3.76%, respectively. By integrating U-Net-Segformer with portable fundus imaging devices and cloud-based AI analysis, we developed an intelligent, mobile glaucoma screening system capable of real-time diagnosis. The system features a user-friendly mobile terminal that enables fundus image capture anywhere, with cloud-based processing for real-time screening results. This approach addresses the shortage of glaucoma screening resources in primary care and remote areas. Extensive evaluations on public and self-collected datasets from partner hospitals demonstrated a 94% accuracy rate, confirming the system’s effectiveness and clinical applicability.

title: Graph Convolutional Network Based Multimodal Uncertainty Fusion for Human Activity Recognition
authors: Zhili Shi, Yilin Dong, Tianyun Zhu, Lei Cao
abstract: Human Activity Recognition (HAR) is a cornerstone of precision health, enabling personalized health management through the continuous monitoring of daily activities and behavioral patterns. Many existing HAR methods prioritize advancing feature extraction architectures while often overlooking the detrimental impact of inherent data noise. This oversight can compromise feature integrity and, consequently, degrade recognition accuracy. To address this limitation, we introduce the Multimodal Uncertainty Fusion Network (MUFNet), a novel framework that integrates skeleton and RGB data streams. A key innovation of MUFNet is the Feature Uncertainty Enhancement Module (FUEM), which models feature reliability by learning a class-aligned Gaussian distribution. This allows the model to stochastically identify and amplify robust feature channels, thereby enhancing feature resilience to noise. Concurrently, a Dynamic Temporal Convolution (DTC) module employs learnable continuous offsets to adeptly capture actions of varying temporal dynamics, including those that are rapid or irregular. Our approach fuses features from multiple skeleton modalities (3D joint, 3D bone, and 2D joint) with spatiotemporal region-of-interest (ST-ROI) features extracted from RGB frames, where the latter is guided by the 2D skeleton structure. Comprehensive evaluations on three public multimodal HAR benchmarks— NTU RGB+D 60, NTU RGB+D 120, and Northwestern-UCLA—validate the superiority of MUFNet. Our model consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving accuracies of 95.6% (X-Sub) / 98.9% (X-View) on NTU RGB+D 60, 91.3% (X-Sub) / 92.9% (X-Set) on NTU RGB+D 120, and 95.3% on Northwestern-UCLA. The source code is available at: https://github.com/ShiZhiLi7/MUFNet.

title: Graph Neural Network-Based Prediction of Rural Social Structures in the Digital Economy
authors: Huiting Liu
abstract: The digital economy is profoundly reshaping rural societies, leading to new patterns of interaction, organization, and development. Predicting rural social structures under this transformation requires methods capable of modeling complex relational data. In this work, we propose a Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based framework for rural social structure prediction. Our method constructs heterogeneous graphs where individuals, households, and organizations are represented as nodes, and their economic, social, and digital interactions are represented as edges. We design a relation-aware message passing mechanism to integrate multi-source attributes, including demographic features, communication records, and digital economy participation. Furthermore, a temporal extension is introduced to capture the evolving dynamics of rural communities over time. To validate our approach, we conduct experiments on real-world rural datasets collected from multiple provinces, consisting of household survey data, mobile communication logs, and e-commerce activity. Experimental results show that our method achieves significant improvements over traditional baselines such as logistic regression, random forests, and standard GNN variants. Specifically, the proposed model reaches an average overall prediction accuracy of 92.3%. These results demonstrate that our framework effectively captures both structural dependencies and temporal dynamics, offering new insights into rural social structure analysis and providing technical support for digital inclusion and rural governance strategies.

title: Navigation in Virtual Reality Floor Mazes: Added Cognitive Demand and its Effects on Gait and Balance in Parkinson’s Disease
authors: Jiawei Chen, Vedika P. Basavatia, Kimberly T. Kwei, Sunil K. Agrawal
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Along with motor dysfunction, people with Parkinson’s Disease (PD) often develop cognitive dysfunction, linked to the gait abnormality - freezing of gait (FOG). Spatial navigation in Virtual Reality Floor Mazes (VR-FM) provides a unique framework for studying the effects of cognitive load on walking, with the ability to manipulate the complexity of the cognitive load. In addition, mazes include turns which simulate indoor home environments that people with PD frequently traverse in their daily life. This study is aimed to examine the effects of increasing cognitive load, applied with VR-FM, on motor performance in PD subjects with and without FOG. This is particularly important in understanding Parkinson’s Disease, as cognitive decline is a strong contributor to morbidity and mortality as the disease progresses and may be a contributing factor to FOG. Fourteen subjects with PD, including eight who exhibited FOG, completed VR-FM under three conditions: (i) Control mazes where the path to the goal is displayed, (ii) Easy mazes with two or less decision points, (iii) Hard mazes, with more than two decision points. In comparison to non-freezers, freezers took fewer spin steps, shorter and slower strides, and reduced medial-lateral sway of the center of mass. These deficits became worse with maze difficulty, accompanied by further degradation in balance measured by margin of stability. Increased cognitive load imposed by the VR-FM led to gait deterioration and a prioritization for balance in both freezers and non-freezers. This supports the use of VR-FM as a tool to investigate motor-cognitive interplay in PD. Freezers exhibit more pronounced deterioration in gait and balance in VR-FM. Hence, VR-FM can serve as a potential tool to characterize and identify freezers.

title: Towards Understanding Generalization and Stability Gaps Between Centralized and Decentralized Federated Learning
authors: Yan Sun, Li Shen, Dacheng Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: As two mainstream frameworks in federated learning (FL), both centralized and decentralized approaches have shown great application value in practical scenarios. However, existing studies do not provide sufficient evidence and clear guidance for analysis of which performs better in the FL community. Although decentralized methods have been proven to approach the comparable convergence of centralized with less communication, their test performance always falls short of expectations in empirical studies. To comprehensively and fairly compare their efficiency gaps in FL, in this paper, we explore their stability and generalization efficiency. Specifically, we prove that on the general smooth non-convex objectives, 1) centralized FL (CFL) always generalizes better than decentralized FL (DFL); 2) CFL achieves the best performance via adopting partial participation instead of full participation; and, 3) there is a necessary requirement for the topology in DFL to avoid performance collapse as the training scale increases. We also conduct extensive experiments on several common setups in FL to validate that our theoretical analysis is consistent with experimental phenomena and contextually valid in several general and practical scenarios.

title: Novel Nearshore Bathymetric Method Based on Adaptive Bandwidth Mean Shift Filtering Using ICESat-2 Data
authors: Yifu Chen, Liqin Zhou, Yuan Le, Haichao Guo, Huhai Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The Ice, Cloud, and Land Elevation Satellite 2 (ICESat-2), equipped with the Advanced Topographic Laser Altimeter System (ATLAS) system, uses a 532 nm laser to measure global surface elevations and enable spaceborne nearshore bathymetry. The main challenge in ATLAS-based bathymetry is accurately distinguishing water-surface and seafloor photons from diverse environmental datasets. This is particularly difficult due to the strong attenuation of laser signals in water, contamination from sun glint and subsurface backscattering, and the sparse distribution of bottom-return photons in turbid coastal waters. To address this issue, this study proposes a novel bathymetric method based on the adaptive-bandwidth mean shift filtering method (AMFM). This method adaptively determines bandwidth parameters via k-nearest neighbors to identify surface/seafloor photon clustering centers, reconstructs wave and seabed topography using B-splines for automatic photon extraction, and performs refraction correction to ensure bathymetric accuracy. The bathymetric results were highly accurate, with slope, coefficient of determination (R2), and root mean square error (RMSE) values reaching 0.98, 0.98, and 0.47 m, respectively. AMFM achieved high accuracy and full adaptivity photon filtering for ATLAS dataset. The shift bandwidth can adaptively change based on the data distribution to adjust the cluster shape and quantity, which is robust for detecting noise and outliers. Additionally, numerous experiments were performed with various ATLAS datasets covering areas around the South China Sea, Atlantic Ocean, and Pacific Ocean. This method, which includes curve fitting in postprocessing, is suitable for photon datasets with various spatial distributions and densities. Finally, based on the methods’ ability to search for the cluster center and detect local density maxima, photon datasets can be separated into several intervals in the along-track direction to achieve segment handling. Using multithreading technology, AMFM achieved high calculation efficiency and adaptively detected signal photons, thereby providing a powerful solution for processing massive amounts of ATLAS data.

title: Lossy Parallel Visualization of Large-Scale Volume Data with Error-Bounded Image Compositing
authors: Yongfeng Qiu, Yuxiao Li, Xin Liang, Yafan Huang, Guanpeng Li, Sheng Di, Franck Cappello, Hanqi Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th Symposium on Large Data Analysis and Visualization (LDAV)
abstract: We present a novel use of error-bounded lossy compression to accelerate distributed parallel volume rendering, which involves blending many semi-transparent images rendered by distributed processes, a procedure known as parallel image compositing. Specifically, we improve the widely adopted binary-swap algorithm by compressing intermediate images with strict pixel-wise error bounds. We propose a per-pixel error-bound model tailored to each communication request in the binary-swap algorithm to control the compositing error. We derive a per-round error bound based on the color and opacity of each intermediate pixel during compositing. Our algorithm also uses a dynamic strategy that balances compression and communication cost, deciding whether to compress based on network latency, bandwidth, and compressor performance. Our method significantly improves the frame rate for in situ rendering, demonstrating notable performance improvements in frame rate. We evaluate our algorithm through an end-to-end GPU-based parallel volume rendering pipeline using a GPU-accelerated renderer and compressor, integrated with CUDA-aware MPI. We demonstrate scalability with up to 512 GPUs on the Perlmutter supercomputer.

title: Trajectory Optimization and Resource Scheduling for NOMA-URLLC Integrated UAV-Assisted Autonomous Vehicular Networks
authors: Jiamei Chen, Yansong Wang, Yutong Zhang, Yufeng Li, Yupeng Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: This paper proposes a trajectory optimization and resource allocation scheme for Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access-Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communications (NOMA-URLLC)-enabled UAV-assisted autonomous driving systems, aiming to fulfill the stringent communication requirements in high-mobility scenarios. To address this challenge, we introduce the Shared Neural Network-Based Multi-Agent Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (S-MATD3) algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing baseline algorithms in terms of convergence speed, stability, trajectory planning, and overall throughput performance.

title: Star centroid estimation and parameter calibration for 3CMOS star sensor
authors: Yanzhao Niu, Xinguo Wei, Jian Li, Xiangyu Bi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: 3CMOS imaging can effectively obtain color ratio information of stars, thereby providing novel observation data for improving the performance of star sensors. A critical requirement for star sensors using 3CMOS is the provision of precise star positional estimates, it is the foundation to realize the attitude measurement. To address this issue, the star imaging mode for this configuration star sensor is initially described. Building upon this model, we establish a method for precise star centroid estimation. Furthermore, a method for calibrating this star sensor’ parameters is proposed. Finally, field attitude measurement experiments are conduct to examine the proposed method.

title: Switching-Resistant and Load-Balanced SFC Deployment in LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Tianhao Liu, Xin Li, Chenyu Zhao, Xuhao Yan, Yongjun Zhang, Shanguo Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: This paper proposes a switching-resistant and load- balanced service function chain (SFC) deployment (SRLB-SFCD) scheme in LEO satellite networks (LSNs) to reduce the SFC deployment strategy switching count caused by satellite-to-ground link (SGL) handovers while achieving network load balancing. Simulation results demonstrate the flexibility and superiority of SRLB-SFCD.

title: Aircraft vulnerability assessment method for HEMP based on antenna coupling, cable coupling, electromagnetic window coupling simulation
authors: Tao Zhang, Yulin Feng, Qiang Hou, Ning Dong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: The vulnerability assessment of electromagnetic pulse is an important design factor to ensure the safety of aircraft flight and enhance the survivability of aircraft in complex electromagnetic environment. In the United States and Europe, a perfect evaluation standard and test system have been established, and a system-level evaluation method based on electromagnetic topology theory and multi-physical field coupling simulation technology have been developed. In this paper, a robust electromagnetic pulse vulnerability assessment method based on front and rear door coupling simulation is presented. Firstly, antenna coupling, cable coupling and slot window coupling are modeled, and the time-domain electromagnetic simulation is carried out according to the standard HEMP radiation.

title: Interference Mechanism Analysis of UWB EMP on UAV Image Sensor
authors: Yansong Li, Yazhou Chen, Min Zhao, Xiaolu Zhang, Yan Shen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: UAV has flicker and image distortion effects under ultra-wideband electromagnetic pulse (UWB EMP) irradiation. CMOS image sensor (CIS) is used in the camera of the UAV. To investigate the influence laws and interference mechanisms of UWB EMP on the CIS, a 2D pixel unit model is established using Silvaco TCAD. Simulations with varying EMP amplitudes and ramp times are conducted at different coupling nodes to analyze photoelectron concentration changes in the photosensitive region. Results show: 1) Direct coupling into the photosensitive region most significantly affects peak photoelectron concentration; 2) EMP injection through Floating Diffusion (FD) and Transfer Gate (TG) nodes has negligible effect; 3) For EMP coupled through Reset (RS) and Power Supply (VDD) nodes, peak photoelectron concentration decreases with longer pulse ramp times but increases with higher pulse amplitudes. Electromagnetic shielding measures implemented on the CMOS camera to enhance its anti-interference capability in complex electromagnetic environments.

title: Research on Electric Aircraft Inspection System
authors: Guoqing Zhou, Yuhao Li, Xinyue Fan, Weiping Zhao, Jun Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: With the technological innovations and industrial upgrades in the global electric aviation sector, the research, development, and commercialization of electric aircraft are accelerating. Against this backdrop, the technical framework for electric aircraft is becoming increasingly mature. However, technological breakthroughs and operational safety issues have emerged as key factors constraining further development. As a core component influencing flight safety and efficiency in electric aircraft, propellers are gaining increasing importance in ground testing procedures. Thanks to the high-precision development of sensor technology and the continuous progress of computers in signal processing, data storage, and intelligent analysis, intelligent testing solutions based on virtual instrumentation technology have become a trend in industry development. Therefore, this paper proposes a testing system based on LabVIEW upper-level computers and data acquisition cards, aiming to achieve efficient collection and precise processing of electric aircraft ground data.

title: Estimate the fast changing correction values in the Beidou satellite-based augmentation messages based on LSTM
authors: Haizhen Zhang, Longwei Xu, Zhongwang Wu, Yaxin Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: The fast changing correction number (PRC) in the Beidou Satellite Based Augmentation System (BDSBAS) is a key parameter for improving positioning accuracy, but its current linear extrapolation model is difficult to capture nonlinear dynamic characteristics in low broadcast frequency scenarios, resulting in error accumulation. In response to this issue, this paper proposes a fast changing correction estimation method based on Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) network, which dynamically models the short-term fluctuation pattern of satellite clock bias through gating mechanism. The experiment used BDSBAS measured data from the 333rd and 334th days of 2024 (B1C frequency point, PRN 1 to 32 satellites) to simulate extreme scenarios where the broadcast frequency was compressed from 6s to 60s, and compared the performance of LSTM and linear extrapolation models. The results show that the root mean square error (RMSE) of the LSTM model is 0.0314m, which is better than the linear model (0.1527m). The research has verified the high-precision prediction ability of LSTM in low-frequency broadcast scenarios, providing technical support for BDSBAS to integrate authentication messages and optimize message architecture, and helping to improve the autonomous controllability and service security of the Beidou Navigation System.

title: Android-Based Graphical User Interface for Motion Control and Environment Visualization of the TIAGO Base Mobile Robot
authors: R. R. Garipov, R. Safin, T. G Tsoy, H. Kuo-Hsien
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This paper presents a developed Android application for motion control and environmental visualization of the TIAGO Base mobile robot operating under the Robot Operating System (ROS). The application provides two-way data exchange with the robot via the rosbridge protocol, which allows teleoperation, setting navigation targets, and obtaining visual information about an environment in real time. Control modes with virtual joysticks, display of a terrain map and lidar data, as well as interactive setting and control of navigation targets are implemented. Additionally, a function of saving the current state of the map with a route and targets in the form of images on a mobile device is provided. The developed solution expands the possibilities of human interaction with mobile robots and can be used in educational, research and applied tasks of autonomous navigation.

title: Software for Assessing Error Correction Ptrotocols in Quantum Communications
authors: Nikita Repnkiov, Vladimir Faerman
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This article addresses the development of quantum communication methods in the context of emerging quantum computing threats and emphasizes the importance of key reconciliation in quantum communication systems. The study focuses on the CASCADE protocol and the design of a software prototype intended for research and educational purposes. A parallel error-correction algorithm based on the actor model was implemented, improving the efficiency of key reconciliation and reducing the amount of exchanged data. Evaluation of the prototype revealed limitations, including the computational cost of message passing, complexity of error handling, and code redundancy due to iterative development. Experimental results confirmed the correct implementation of the core CASCADE algorithms and informed the design of future improvements. Proposed enhancements include redesigning the system architecture, developing interfaces for exporting intermediate data, defining the communication channel as a separate component, and expanding tools for systematic verification and comparative analysis of blind keyreconciliation methods.

title: Analysis of changes in predispositions and skills for people applying for a Commercial Pilot License
authors: Matej Ščerba, Robert Wieszala, Jacek Mendala, Naqibullah Daneshjo, Maja Foryciarz, Jozef Mário Jusko
abstract: Civil aviation has been transformed by rapid technological change, expanding traffic volumes, and the pervasive use of digital systems in both cockpits and training environments. This paper analyses how these developments have shifted the competency profile of civil pilots from physical endurance toward psychomotor and cognitive performance, IT literacy, and teamwork. Building on a literature-informed background (cockpit automation, airport infrastructure, training system evolution) and an empirical survey of 138 ATPL(A) trainees and 17 flight instructors, we quantify current strengths and gaps. Results show strong theoretical and flightplanning skills but systemic deficits in crew cooperation, emotional stability, independence, and professional communication. We discuss implications for curriculum design (KSA100 (Knowledge, Skills, Attitudes)), scenario-based training, English proficiency, VR/AI (Virtual Reality / artificial intelligence) integration, and cybersecurity hygiene) and outline actionable recommendations to better align training outcomes with modern cockpit demands.

title: The Dichotomy of the Skies: An Analysis of European UAS Integration, Regulatory Transposition, and Civil-Military Interoperability
authors: Nofal Kattan, Marek Košuda, Miroslav Kelemen, Volodymyr Polishchuk
abstract: This article provides a comprehensive analysis of the transposition of European Union (EU) and NATO frameworks for Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) into Slovak national legislation. It examines the dual regulatory structures established by the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) for civil operations and NATO for military applications, alongside the U-space digital traffic management concept. The central finding reveals a paradox in Slovakia: while formally compliant with EU and NATO mandates, the country exhibits a significant substantive deficit characterized by institutional underperformance, a lack of technical infrastructure, and regulatory “gold-plating.” Through a systematic, multidimensional gap analysis benchmarking Slovakia against its European peers, the study identifies critical shortcomings across legal, institutional, and technical domains. Furthermore, it addresses the strategic challenge of civil-military interoperability, dissecting doctrinal asymmetries and identifying “performance equivalence” as a key pathway for integrating military systems into civil airspace. The article concludes with policy recommendations, arguing that achieving Europe’s strategic vision for a competitive and secure drone sector requires moving beyond formal compliance to genuine functional integration.

title: The Impact of Multi-Frequency GNSS Receivers on the Reduction of Ionospheric Error
authors: Andrej Novák, Tomasz Lusiak, Jan Zýka, Alena Novák Sedláčková, Sahir Deniz Özdemirci
abstract: This article explores the impact of multi-frequency GNSS receivers on mitigating ionospheric errors in satellite-based positioning. The study begins by discussing the architecture, signal structures, and measurement techniques of GNSS systems, focusing on the influence of the ionosphere on signal propagation. The study highlights the precise ionospheric correction strategies in this case PPP-RTK, that enable rapid convergence and centimetre level accuracy without heavy reliance on infrastructure. A comparative analysis of different ionospheric modelling strategies reveals that factors such as geographic location, network density, and modelling methodology play a critical role in positioning accuracy. The results further indicate that achieving fully consistent comparisons across studies remains challenging due to variations in temporal and spatial conditions under which the experiments were conducted.

title: Cloud-Based Digital Twin for Real – Time Battery Thermal Management Using Nonlinear Model Predictive Control
authors: Josh Rawlinson, Kaibo Li, Truong Quang Dinh
abstract: Battery Thermal Management (BTM) is essential to the safety, performance and longevity of battery systems. Traditional systems often rely on fixed parameter models and are restricted by onboard computational resources, limiting adaptability to the non-linear characteristics of batteries. This paper develops a cloud-based digital twin for real – time BTM, enabling online estimation of the battery’s internal resistance to support a Nonlinear Model Predictive Controller (NLMPC) in a hardware–in–the–loop environment. The accuracy of internal resistance in the NLPMC’s prediction model is critical to its performance in thermal management, however online calibration adds significant computational overhead. Parameter estimation in the cloud offloads computational burden on embedded hardware and a scalable infrastructure for future development. The system integrates a dSPACE MicroAutoBox II and network gateway for the connection to an external cloud service with Controller Area Network (CAN). Experimental results demonstrate stable bi – directional communication and sub – second cloud latency, confirming feasibility for adaptive control in an embedded BTM system.

title: A Fast Terminal Sliding Mode Control for 6-degree-of-freedom cable-driven manipulator
authors: Tran Buu Thach Nguyen, Xuan Tra Nguyen, Kyoung Kwan Ahn
abstract: This paper proposes a Fast Terminal Sliding Mode Control (FTSMC) strategy for a 6-degree-of-freedom (6DOF) cable-driven (CD) manipulator operating under lumped uncertainties including external disturbances and dynamic model inaccuracies. The FTSMC-based proposed control law is designed to enhance disturbance rejection and uncertainty compensation capabilities, thereby ensuring high-precision position tracking. Furthermore, it can guarantee rapid convergence of the system states to a small neighborhood of the origin in finite time. Under the proposed approach, the stability of the closed-loop system is theoretically guaranteed through mathematical proof based on the Lyapunov theorem. Finally, the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed approach are demonstrated through comparative simulations under different operating scenarios.

title: High Precision Control for Electro-Hydraulic Actuator System with Recursive Terminal Back-stepping Sliding Mode
authors: Hung Le Nguyen, Van Du Phan, Anh Duc Pham, Kyoung Kwan Ahn
abstract: In this paper, a recursive terminal back-stepping sliding-mode (RTBS) controller is proposed to provide a high-precision and high-speed performance for the Electro-hydraulic Actuator (EHA) system. For the controller, a terminal sliding manifold with an integral sliding function is integrated into the traditional back-stepping control strategy in a recursive structure that the sliding surface reaches the stable point successfully and robustly and remains stable under varies disturbances and uncertainties. The system’s stability, proved by Lyapunov theory, guarantees the robustness of the proposed controller when applying on such high-order system. The effectiveness of the controller is then verified via numbers of simulations in comparison to the conventional back-stepping sliding mode control framework which shows a significant improvement in the control accuracy of tracking errors and the ability of ignoring system disturbances.

title: Voltage Stability of Multi-Infeed VSC HVDC System – a Review
authors: Siti Rahmah Wati, Roni Irnawan, M. Isnaeni Bambang Setyonegoro
abstract: A multi-infeed VSC HVDC system, which integrates multiple nearby VSC HVDC links, presents new challenges regarding voltage stability, especially in weak AC networks. The dynamic interactions among converters, whether in pure VSC configurations or hybrid systems including LCC, present significant challenges in voltage regulation, necessitating the implementation of more adaptive and responsive control strategies. This article identifies numerous factors influencing voltage stability, along with control strategies implemented to maintain system reliability. Additionally, this article discusses the challenges faced and the proposed solution approaches in recent research, particularly within the context of multi-infeed VSC systems. The findings of this study are expected to make a significant contribution to the development of a more stable and efficient electrical power system, alongside the increased integration of renewable energy.

title: Design Criteria for a Wide Input/Output Range LLC Converter Using Topological Reconfigurations
authors: Takashi Ohno, Guillaume Lefevre, Guillaume Regnat, Davide Barlini, Hiroki Watanabe, Jun-Ichi Itoh
abstract: This paper proposes a circuit design methodology for an LLC converter capable of a wide input and output voltage range. By utilizing the full-bridge and the halfbridge switching configurations, the proposed converter achieves a $19 \%$ reduction in transformer volume and a $65 \%$ reduction in resonance inductor volume compared to a conventional full-bridge LLC converter. The converter maintains zero-voltage switching under all operation voltages and load conditions, using the proposed design methodology. Finally, the FB/HB LLC converter demonstrated a maximum efficiency of 94.2%.

title: Design and Implementation of Paralleled Three-Phase Three-Level Inverters using Virtual Resistance Droop Control
authors: Laskar Pamungkas, Yu-Chen Chang, Chieh-Fu Chen, Huang-Jen Chiu, Jing-Yuan Lin, Peter J. Huang
abstract: This research presents the design and hardware implementation of a digitally controlled three-phase, three-level inverter parallel system with redundancy. The system employs the virtual resistance droop control method for parallel operation, which enables proportional load sharing according to inverter capacities without requiring a dedicated instantaneous communication. The T-type three-level topology is adopted, offering advantages such as reduced component count, high efficiency, and lower output voltage total harmonic distortion (THD). For modulation method, a variant of carrier-based PWM (CBPWM) is utilized. Compared with the space vector PWM (SVPWM), CBPWM offers simpler implementation since it does not require space vector position determination, while still achieving high voltage utilization. To validate the proposed approach, two 6 kW inverters were developed and tested, confirming feasibility of the design.

title: Independent Power Control of Three-Level Inverter for Dual-DC-Sources with Common Negative Bus
authors: Pawin Lothong, Surapong Suwankawin, Somboon Sangwongwanich
abstract: This paper presents a power control strategy for a dual-input DC source using a three-level T-type inverter with a common negative bus. Traditional multi-source inverter systems typically require two-stage power conversion and employ Space Vector Pulse Width Modulation for power flow control, which is often complex and computationally intensive. To eliminate the complexity, a three-phase, threelevel dual-port inverter is proposed, allowing two independent DC sources to connect and enabling single-stage power conversion using a common negative bus. A Carrier-Based Pulse Width Modulation technique is adopted to simplify modulation and facilitate directional power regulation. The power-sharing ratio between two DC sources can be precisely adjusted through this method. The proposed concept is validated through both simulation and Hardware-in-the-Loop testing.

title: Implementation of a Three-Phase LLC Resonant Converter with Phase-Shedding Control
authors: Yao-Chun Tung, Gwo-Jen Chiou, Yuk-Hang Wong, Jeng-Yue Chen, Fuh-Shyang Juang
abstract: With the growing demand for distributed energy resources and high-efficiency power conversion, robust and stable power electronic converter architectures have become increasingly critical for the development of modern power grid systems. This paper proposes a three-phase LLC resonant converter with integrated phase-shedding control to address key issues in conventional LLC converters, such as large output current ripple and poor efficiency under light-load conditions. The proposed converter is comprehensively designed, simulated, and experimentally implemented. The proposed three-phase LLC resonant converter with phase-shedding control operates at input voltage of 400 V, within output voltage range of 280 V to 410 V, and a maximum output power of 2000 W. According to experimental results, the converter maintains an efficiency above 90% across the full load range, with a peak efficiency reaching 97.38%, The novelty of this work lies in the implementation of the controlled high-impedance interval, which fundamentally enables reliable and efficient phase-shedding operation.

title: Resilience Oriented Optimization of Distributed Energy Storage in Networked Microgrids
authors: Chandan Chaudhary, Mohammed Benidris, Joydeep Mitra
abstract: Power systems face increasing vulnerability to highimpact, low-frequency extreme weather events that cause spatially and temporally distributed infrastructure damage, challenging traditional resilience strategies. While existing literature extensively examines microgrid resilience under static failure scenarios, limited research addresses the dynamic coordination of distributed energy storage systems (DESS) across networked microgrids during evolving damage and recovery conditions. This study proposes a comprehensive resilience-oriented optimization framework that integrates tornado event modeling with multitimescale mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) for coordinated DESS operation in networked microgrids. The framework employs a rolling-horizon approach to capture real-time damage progression, asynchronous component repairs, and renewable generation uncertainty, enabling adaptive storage coordination strategies that minimize load curtailment while preserving critical reserves. Monte Carlo simulations demonstrate that the proposed coordinated DESS operation enhances critical load continuity, reduces system-wide curtailment, and accelerates recovery trajectories under diverse tornado scenarios. The framework provides a scalable platform for resilience-enhanced planning in distribution networks facing escalating climate-induced disruptions.

title: A Miniaturized High-Power Ultra-wideband Electromagnetic Power Source System Design and Experiment
authors: Jin Qin, Wenxu Yao, Pei Li, Juncheng Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: To achieve the miniaturization of high-power ultra-wideband microwave microwave power sources, an integrated design scheme composed of a low-profile high-power tightly coupled radiating antenna with a coaxial wideband high-power microwave microwave power source was adopted. Theoretical simulations and prototype testing were conducted on the performance indicators of the array antenna and wideband microwave power source. Key challenges such as high-power insulation at room temperature, impedance matching of the pulse-forming line, and the generation of picosecond-level ultra-narrow steepened pulses were addressed. A prototype of the microwave power source system was developed. Field calibration and irradiation test results indicate that a pulse front width of 220 ps, a maximum repetition frequency of 100 Hz, a system weight of 71 kg, and a radiation field strength of 358 kV and a corresponding output power is about 1.4GW. The system can effectively induce soft kills on target objects, operates stably over long periods, and maintains excellent airtightness.

title: Customer Satisfaction Analysis of Data Packages Among Students Toward Telecommunication Service Providers in Timor-Leste Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Marcelino Caetano Noronha, Hindriyanto Dwi Purnomo, Danny Manongga, Hendry, Iwan Setyawan
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Among students in East Timor, the internet is very important, making data packages a key factor in choosing a telecommunications provider. The purpose of this research is to evaluate student satisfaction with data packages using logistic regression and KNN algorithms for comparison of the two algorithms. A total of 812 data were collected through questionnaires both manually and digitally via Google Forms. The areas where the data was obtained are located in the eastern part of Manatuto district, the central part of Dili district, Aileu, and the western part of Liquisa district. Data processing was carried out with preprocessing, normalization, and label encoding as a response to missing data to ensure model robustness and data consistency. Logistic regression is used for classification of client satisfaction levels and successfully achieved the highest accuracy of 96.34%. In comparison, the KNN algorithm achieved an accuracy of 79.27%, which is why logistic regression has higher accuracy than KNN. This evaluation highlights that internet speed, service reliability, and affordable pricing for students, where internet speed shows a reliable correlation. The model’s capability can also be well produced and minimizes overfitting. The results of this study provide important lessons for telecommunications service providers and can improve the offerings from service providers to meet the digital needs of students in Timor-Leste. This research also utilizes machine learning algorithms to support the importance of data and information for telecommunications clients in Timor-Leste

title: Comparative Analysis of Carrier-Based Modulation Methods for Dual-Parallel Three-Level T-Type Inverters
authors: Mohammadreza Lak, Sahel Solemanifard
abstract: The increasing global demand for energy has brought greater attention to high-power electronic inverters. This trend has spurred the development of dual-parallel threelevel T-type inverters (3LTIs) configuration. The control of dual-parallel 3LTIs can be effectively performed using synchronous, interleaved, and integrated pulse width modulation (PWM) techniques. Although many studies have been conducted on these techniques’ space vector modulation version, less attention has been paid to the carrier-based version, which is practically superior. This paper presents carrier-based implementation of the aforementioned techniques. Besides, it compares their performance regarding output power quality, control complexity, circulating current, and common mode voltage variation. The simulation results reveal considerable technical aspects to consider in the dualparallel configuration.

title: Quantitative Assessment of A Priori and Experimental Distinguishing of Single Defects in Dynamic Systems
authors: Sergey V. Shalobanov, Sergey S. Shalobanov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This paper examines an approach to analyzing a diagnostic model for distinguishing single parametric defects in continuous dynamic objects, based on a parametric sensitivity model. A methodology for analyzing the a priori and experimental distinguishability of single parametric defects is proposed. Good agreement between the a priori and actual distinguishability values for single parametric defects was found when using various input signals. All computational experiments and modeling were performed using specialized software packages created in the Scilab dynamic modeling environment and custom-developed software tools.

title: Neural Network-Based Segmentation of 4D In Situ Tomographic Data for Inhomogeneous Porous Materials
authors: Ksenia Spiridonova, Kirill Akifyev, Danil Farkhutdinov, Evgeni Magid
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: A study of inhomogeneous samples’ internal structure under external loads is crucial for analyzing the mechanical properties and morphology of a real product. X-ray computed tomography is a widespread method for non-destructive control. In this research, cubic samples with an internal closed ellipsoidal pore were investigated. Samples were manufactured using fused deposition modeling. Then all samples were loaded using a 4D in situ XCT device. A U-Net convolutional neural network was used for the samples’ segmentation. A qualitative analysis of the segmentation results using this method shows high performance, but additional metrics are needed for a deeper assessment.

title: Air Traffic Control Room Design in the Context of Actual Operator Requirements
authors: Petr Adolf Skřehot, Slavomíra Vargová, Denisa Charvátová
abstract: This article examines the ergonomic design of air traffic control workstations with regard to both international standards and the actual needs of operators. It identifies key ergonomic factors that affect safety, performance, and reliability, and discusses approaches for their evaluation under real operational conditions. The MEHOD method, developed in the Czech Republic, was applied in a technical supervision room at Válav Havel Airport in Prague as part of the research. The findings demonstrate a potential improvement of overall ergaticity (Ebd) from 0.88 to 0.96 after proposed design modifications, with the most significant gains observed in workstation and display criteria. These results underscore the importance of integrating ergonomic principles already at the stage of layout planning and technical design, while also highlighting the limitations of existing standards in the context of evolving human needs and working conditions.

title: Automated Risk Management Mechanisms in DeFi Lending Protocols: A Crosschain Comparative Analysis of Aave and Compound
authors: Erum Iftikhar, Wei Wei, John Cartlidge
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Blockchain-based decentralised lending is a rapidly growing and evolving alternative to traditional lending, but it poses new risks. To mitigate these risks, lending protocols have integrated automated risk management tools into their smart contracts. However, the effectiveness of the latest risk management features introduced in the most recent versions of these lending protocols is understudied. To close this gap, we use a panel regression fixed effects model to empirically analyse the cross-version (v2 and v3) and cross-chain (L1 and L2) effectiveness of liquidation mechanisms, measured through TVL and total revenue as proxies for performance of the two most popular lending protocols, Aave and Compound, during the period Jan 2021 to Dec 2024. Our analysis reveals that liquidation events in v3 of both protocols lead to an increase in total value locked and total revenue, with stronger impact on the L2 blockchain compared to L1. In contrast, liquidations in v2 have an insignificant impact, which indicates that the most recent v3 protocols have better risk management than the earlier v2 protocols. We also show that L1 blockchains are the preferred choice among large investors for their robust liquidity and ecosystem depth, while L2 blockchains are more popular among retail investors for their lower fees and faster execution.

title: Automatic Cross-chain Protocol Pausing with Real-time Conformance Checking
authors: Bruno Mateus, André Augusto, Rafael Belchior, André Vasconcelos, Miguel Correia
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: The proliferation of diverse blockchain networks has intensified the demand for interoperability, but cross-chain bridges introduce significant security risks. This paper proposes a protocol protection framework for early incident detection and containment through a runtime transactions conformance checking pipeline. Deviations from expected behavior trigger a pausing mechanism, halting operations to prevent incorrect state propagation across blockchains. Our evaluation shows that anomalies can be detected and cross-chain asset transfers paused in less than 10 seconds, reducing attack exposure and preventing cascading failures. The results highlight how automated pausing is a critical safeguard for securing interoperability infrastructures and strengthening cross-chain ecosystems.

title: Integrated Metrics for System Performance, Attributes, and Critical Threats for Resilience Analysis
authors: Raquel L. Valdez, Thushara Gunda, Stephen B. Ferencz, Nicole D. Jackson
abstract: Critical infrastructure systems are increasingly vulnerable to a range of threats. However, resilience assessments often fall short of capturing the complexity of multi-sector dynamics and the cascading impacts of these disruptions. To address this gap, this paper introduces an approach for Integrated Metrics for system Performance, Attributes, and Critical Threats (IMPACT). The IMPACT framework provides a structured method for resilience analysis by integrating three core components: (1) threat representations, which characterize chronic and acute threats by their origin and occurrence patterns; (2) system attributes, which assess inherent system qualities from a multi-sector dimension (e.g., built infrastructure, environmental, regional dynamics); and (3) performance outcomes, which capture cascading effects and recovery interdependencies across multiple sectors. In addition to explicitly representing multiple dimensions of import, the IMPACT framework enables integration of both traditional and multi-disciplinary metrics to advance resilience insights. Using a case study of the Colorado River Basin in Texas, we demonstrate the value of the IMPACT framework for revealing insights about the frequency and persistence of a drought-related threat as well as system attributes of water rights and sectoral demands that contribute to variations in water shortages, ultimately influencing the overall performance of the system. Additional work is needed to evaluate the utility of the IMPACT framework to other critical infrastructure systems, especially across regions and compounded threats. By linking threats, attributes, and outcomes, the IMPACT framework supports a more holistic understanding of risk and resilience in critical infrastructure systems across sectors.

title: Fortifying the Metaverse: Security, Privacy, and Trust in In-Network Computing
authors: Nadine Y. Fares, Manar Jammal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: The rapid evolution of the Metaverse has introduced new paradigms in digital interaction, integrating in-network computing to enhance real-time processing, scalability, and immersive experiences. However, this shift also presents critical security, privacy, and trust challenges that traditional security models struggle to address. This paper explores the vulnerabilities associated with in-network computing in the Metaverse, including identity spoofing, data integrity threats, and regulatory gaps, and proposes a multi-layered security framework to mitigate these risks. The findings of this study provide a foundation for developing secure in-network computing strategies in virtual environments while advocating for legal and policy frameworks that uphold user rights and data protection.

title: Design and Implementation of a Totem-Pole Power Factor Corrector
authors: Xian-Kai Wu, Zong-Zhen Yang, Yu-Chi h Huang, Ming-Zhe Chi, Yi-Hua Liu
abstract: Bridgeless totem-pole power factor correction (PFC) is increasingly adopted to improve front-end efficiency, yet practical deployment is challenged by input-current spikes at line zero crossings and sensitivity to sampling misalignment that elevates total harmonic distortion (THD). This work presents a digitally controlled, continuous-conduction-mode (CCM) totem-pole PFC rated at 600 W with an online adjustable dc-bus setpoint of $\mathbf{3 8 0} \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{4 3 0 ~ V}$ to better accommodate downstream dc-dc efficiency optimization. Implemented on a TMS320F280049C DSP, the controller realizes a firmware-level zero-crossing soft-start sequence and co-aligns half-cycle interrupt triggers with the ADC sampling instant, augmented by duty-cycle feedforward. A detailed operating principle and hardware architecture are provided, and experimental results confirm improved input-current THD and power factor (PF) across the load range; the minimum measured THD is 2.27%, and PF remains above 0.99 for loads exceeding 30%.

title: Techno-Economic Evaluation and Optimal Sizing of an Islanded Hybrid Microgrid Using Various Dispatch Strategies: A Case Study on Sebira Island
authors: Ricky Ardian Pratama, Fransisco Danang Wijaya, Yohan Fajar Sidik
abstract: Sebira Island is one of the outermost small islands within the administrative region of DKI Jakarta and it remains unconnected to the main electricity grid due to the absence of an undersea cable. Limited electricity availability, high operational costs of fossil fuel consumption and geographical constraints highlight the urgent need for a more efficient and sustainable energy system. This study aims to evaluate and optimize the configuration of Sebira Island’s hybrid microgrid by comparing three energy dispatch strategies: Load Following (LF), Cycle Charging (CC) and Combined Dispatch (CD). The analysis is based on several key indicators, including Net Present Cost (NPC), Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE), annual carbon emissions, operation and maintenance (O&M) costs and land requirements for each strategy. The results indicate that the CD strategy delivers the most optimal performance, achieving the lowest NPC and LCOE at ${\$}$4,777,391 and ${\$}$0.219/kWh respectively, along with the lowest annual carbon emissions of $608,049 \mathrm{~kg}$. However, the CD strategy requires an additional land area of $1,972.42 \mathrm{~m}^{2}$, which exceeds the available space of only $776 \mathrm{~m}^{2}$. In contrast, the CC and LF strategies remain within the land constraints but offer slightly lower energy and economic efficiency. Therefore, while CD is the most technically and environmentally favorable strategy, its implementation would require additional solutions such as rooftop PV installations, multi-tier panel mounting systems or land expansion. This study is expected to serve as a valuable reference for the development of hybrid microgrid systems in other island or remote regions of Indonesia that face similar challenges in achieving reliable, environmentally friendly and sustainable energy access.

title: On-Site Electric Motor Health Monitoring: from Condition Assessment to Predictive Maintenance
authors: Chen-Pei Yi, I-Haur Tsai, Shih-Chin Yang
abstract: This paper proposes an innovative predictive maintenance (PdM) framework integrating sensor design with state estimation techniques to effectively monitor condition changes in AC motors during operation. In this research, the data acquisition and state observer are conducted using the data acquisition box (AQbox), a low-cost external data acquisition device developed by the NTU Motor Tech Lab. To verify the practical applicability of this framework in industrial environments, four AQboxes have been installed on cooling circulation AC pump motors at Pacific Electric Wire & Cable Co. (PEWC) to test the feasibility of state estimation within the PdM system. This paper presents and analyzes torque anomaly data observed during monitoring. Based on these data characteristics, a robust two-step triggering recursive least squares (RLS) method is developed to predict optimal maintenance timing, effectively addressing data growth and instability while lack of system degradation data. The AQbox will continue to collect field data to form a database for further developing neural network-based diagnostic methods using these electrical signal waveform anomalies.

title: Miller Plateau Voltage Sensor Circuit Integrated Into Gate Driver IC for Physics-Based Load Current Estimation
authors: Taro Takamori, Yen-Yun Huang, Yaogan Liang, Michihiro Ide, Po-Hung Chen, Makoto Takamiya
abstract: This paper proposes a Miller plateau voltage sensor circuit integrated into a gate driver IC for estimating the load current $I_{\mathrm{L}}$ in IGBT without requiring high-bandwidth measurement equipment. The proposed sensor circuit operates with the momentary high-Z gate driving (MHZGD) method, which sets the gate current $I_{\mathrm{G}}$ to zero during the Miller plateau period. This eliminates voltage drops across gate resistors, enabling accurate, temperature-compensated sensing of the gate voltage $V_{\mathrm{GE}}$, which correlates with $I_{\mathrm{L}}$. A track-and-hold circuit captures the Miller plateau voltage as a DC signal, suitable for digitization using a low-speed analog-to-digital converter. A physics-based polynomial fitting model using the known junction temperature $T_{\mathrm{J}}$ allows accurate $I_{\mathrm{L}}$ estimation with only ten calibration points. The proposed sensor circuit integrated into gate driver IC is fabricated using a $\mathbf{1 8 0}-\mathbf{n m}$ BCD process, achieving a compact IC chip size of $2.0 \mathrm{~mm} \times 2.5 \mathrm{~mm}$, with the sensor circuit occupying only $\mathbf{7 0 0} \mu \mathbf{m} \times \mathbf{5 0 0} \mu \mathbf{m}$. Experimental validation through 600 V double-pulse tests using a $1,200 \mathrm{~V}$, 100 A IGBT module confirms $I_{\mathrm{L}}$ estimation from 10 A to 80 A at $T_{\mathrm{J}}$ ranges from $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $\mathbf{1 2 5}^{\circ} \mathbf{C}$, with an estimation error of up to 8.27 A.
