title: Investigating the Impact of Fault Handling Models on Reliability Indices of Digital Substation
authors: Rizwan Rafique Syed, Hans Kristian Høidalen
abstract: IEC61850-based fully Digital Substations (DS) are already in service. Power system engineers use traditional methods to conduct reliability analysis of these systems. The involvement of communication architecture and its inherent nature, however, demands a holistic approach that should encompass both structural and performance analysis of this system to yield more accurate results. This work proposes and develops the functional model for seven DSAS architectures along with Fault/Error Handling Model (FEHM), and conducts the combined reliability analysis with the primary system (CB-and-half scheme). The analysis is carried out utilizing both Monte Carlo and analytical approaches. The results show that, firstly, the impact of the automated switching is significant in improving the substation reliability indices as compared to manual switching. Secondly, the developed models only affect the substation reliability indices when the secondary system failure modes are included. Finally, the sensitivity analysis showed the usefulness of the FEH model and revealed its significant impact on reliability indices of substation at higher repair times.

title: Design and Small-Signal Stability Analysis of Grid-Forming Inverter Based on Generalized Fractional-Order Virtual Synchronous Generator Control
authors: Peng Zhang, Wenjuan Du, H. F. Wang
abstract: Virtual synchronous generator (VSG) control may lead to active power oscillations under insufficient damping. Although various feedback control-based methods have been proposed to address this issue, they often degrade the inherent inertial response of the VSG. In this paper, fractional-order control is introduced into the VSG, providing additional degrees of freedom, which leads to the formulation of three fractional-order VSG (FOVSG) control strategies. The active power and frequency dynamic performances of these FOVSG schemes are analyzed and compared, and then proposes a generalized FOVSG (GFOVSG) control. By appropriately designing the GFOVSG, controllable active power dynamics can be achieved while significantly enhancing the system's inertial response. To evaluate the impact of GFOVSG on the small-signal stability of the grid-connected system, a stability analysis method is developed based on the fractional-order small-signal model of the system, and the small-signal stability criterion is derived. Compared to the VSG, grid-forming inverters with the GFOVSG can maintain small-signal stability under stronger grid conditions. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by simulation and experimental results.

title: Wideband and Wide-Angle Radar Cross Section Reduction of Slot Antenna for Stealth Applications
authors: Surbhi Arora, Jayanta Mukherjee
publish: IEEE Journal on Miniaturization for Air and Space Systems
abstract: This research presents a novel hybrid method to minimize the radar cross-section (RCS) of a compact slot antenna operating over 5.1-9.9 GHz. The combination of metal reduction and Characteristic Mode Analysis (CMA) enables the effective suppression of scattering modes, achieved by carefully analyzing and manipulating modal currents. This technique achieves an RCS reduction of up to 8.6 dB across a broad frequency range of 1-20 GHz (181%), including both in-band and out-of-band frequencies, under normal incidence of linearly polarized (LP) waves. Moreover, it demonstrates RCS reductions of up to 6 dB over an approximate frequency range of 2-20 GHz for varying incidence angles of LP waves. Additionally, RCS reductions of up to 5 dB are attained across the 3-20 GHz frequency range for both normal and obliquely incident circularly polarized (CP) waves. Notably, the RCS reduction achieved is robust and insensitive to polarization and angle variations, thereby ensuring a consistent performance enhancement, while preserving the antenna’s inherent radiation capabilities. To validate the design, a prototype was developed and tested, yielding measured results that closely match the simulated data, confirming the effectiveness of this hybrid technique.

title: Profit Maximization of Distribution Network Stakeholders Facilitating EV Demands with Adaptive Demand Side Management Policies
authors: Manoj Saha, Siddhartha Sankar Thakur, Aniruddha Bhattacharya, Bishwajit Dey
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Industry Applications
abstract: The rapid integration of electric vehicle (EV) infrastructure, particularly EV charging stations (EVCS) and battery swapping stations (BSS), has introduced new challenges to modern distribution networks due to dynamic and uncertain load profiles. This paper proposes a comprehensive profit maximization framework aimed at improving economic outcomes for three key stakeholder groups: EVCS operators, BSS operators, and distribution network consumers. The model integrates demand-side management strategies such as load shifting and load curtailment to mitigate undesirable load fluctuations while enhancing operational efficiency. A hybrid metaheuristic optimization technique combining Differential Evolution with Prairie Dog Optimization is used to solve the multi-entity coordination problem. Extensive simulation studies are carried out on a 118-bus radial distribution network under six different case studies. Results indicate that simultaneous profit maximization across all stakeholders yields superior economic performance compared to individual optimization. The proposed framework achieves up to 18.7% higher total profit. Specifically, EVCS operators, BSS operators, and demand-side participants benefit from profit improvements of 21.9%, 24.2%, 49.9%, and 2.5%, respectively, highlighting the economic viability of the proposed coordinated approach across all six operational cases.

title: Model Predictive Current Control for Three-Phase Three-Level Inverters Based on Harmonic Current Extraction
authors: Junhao Lu, Yong Yang, Yichen Jiang, Aiming Ji, Mingdi Fan, Hanguang Peng, Yong Tang, Garcia Cristian, Jose Rodriguez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Predictive Control of Electrical Drives and Power Electronics (PRECEDE)
abstract: In this paper, a model predictive current control (MPCC) scheme utilizing harmonic current extraction techniques is proposed for three-phase three-level T-type inverters. The harmonics of output current decrease significantly by adding the current harmonics as one of the control objectives to the cost function. Meanwhile, the reasonable distribution of redundant small voltage can realize the automatic balance of neutral point voltage without the need to design the weighting factor of the neutral point potential, thus simplifying the control process and improving the portability of the algorithm. In order to confirm the feasibility of the proposed MPCC and show its enhanced effectiveness over conventional method, comparative simulation experiments are presented.

title: Optimization of Solder Paste Printing Process Parameters Using Central Composite Design and RSM: A Case Study on Minimizing Cycle Time
authors: Thi Cam Duyen Doan, Minh Tai Le
abstract: This study proposes a structured optimization framework for solder paste printing in Surface Mount Technology (SMT) by combining Multi-Criteria Decision Making (MCDM) and Response Surface Methodology (RSM). The Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) was first used to screen ten candidate parameters, identifying print speed, print pressure, and separation speed as key factors. A Central Composite Design (CCD) with 51 experimental runs was conducted, and a second-order regression model was built using Design-Expert software. ANOVA confirmed the model’s significance (p < 0.0001), with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.9989. Print pressure emerged as the most influential factor. The optimized settings - 74.7 mm/s print speed, 15.5 kgf (≈ 152 N) print pressure, and 9 mm/s separation speed—resulted in a predicted cycle time of 19.1 seconds. This hybrid AHP–RSM approach offers a reliable, data-driven method for improving SMT productivity.

title: Integral Sliding Mode Control for Autonomous UAV Tracking of Moving Targets via a Vision-Based Algorithm on the PX4 Platform
authors: Tran Minh Quang, Ha Le Nhu Ngoc Thanh
abstract: This paper presents an Integral Sliding Mode control (ISMC) algorithm for real-time tracking of a moving ground target using a hexa-rotor unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) and a vison-based technique via a virtual system on the PX4-platform. The main control objective is to minimize the horizontal tracking error while maintaining a constant flight altitude. Firstly, a moving target’s position is acquired from a virtual vision camera based on image processing techniques, and the measurement noise is attenuated by a Kalman Filter (KF). In addition, the target’s velocity and acceleration are also estimated in real-time by using a classical KF. Based on these approximated values, an Integral SMC algorithm is constructed to guarantee a small horizontal position tracking error. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, Software-In-The-Loop simulation (SITL) are conducted and compared with a classical Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller. The flight simulation environment is configured on the PX4 platform, in which the virtual hexacopter UAV is equipped with a downward-facing gimbaled monocular camera to ensure that the relative position of the moving target is continuous observation. Simulation results demonstrated that the ISMC consistently outperforms the PID controller in terms of tracking precision, robustness, and responsiveness under identical testing conditions.

title: Enhancement of Small Object Detection Algorithms in UAV-Based Aerial Imagery
authors: Wen Ge, Xiaofeng Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: UAV-captured images present unique challenges for object detection, including dense small objects, large scale variations, and frequent occlusions. To address these issues, we propose PFE-YOLO, an improved YOLO-based algorithm featuring three key enhancements: (1) a PPA module with multi-branch fusion and attention mechanisms replacing residual structures in C3k2 to boost small object feature extraction; (2) a Focus Feature-enhanced neck network for improved multi-scale feature fusion; and (3) an Efficient-Head detector for reduced computational complexity. The improved algorithm demonstrates significant accuracy enhancement compared to the baseline method. This study provides an efficient solution for small object detection from UAV perspectives, exhibiting high practical application value.

title: EDRA: An Enhanced Divine Religions Algorithm for Multi-UAVs Path Planning
authors: Lin Zhao, Jun Cai, Wei Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: For the multi-UAVs path planning problem, this work proposes an enhanced divine religions algorithm called EDRA, by combining the divine religions algorithm with the linear search operator, a novel search mechanism to balance exploration and exploitation. The experiments were carried out on the CEC2017 benchmark set and multi-UAVs path planning scenarios to verify the effectiveness of EDRA. The results reveal that EDRA attains an equilibrium between exploration and exploitation, enhancing both the convergence rate and output quality. EDRA is effective for the multi-UAVs path planning challenge.

title: CKF-Based Sensorless Control for Dual Three-Phase PMSM in Electric Aircraft Drive Systems*
authors: Hao Wu, Xiuhong Jiang, Yong Deng, Miao Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Dual Three-Phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (DTP-PMSM), owing to their high redundancy and strong fault tolerance, hold significant application value in aerospace propulsion systems. To address the vulnerability of mechanical position sensors to extreme environmental disturbances in high-reliability electric aircraft drive systems, this paper proposes a sensorless fused control strategy based on the Cubature Kalman Filter (CKF) for DTP-PMSM. By establishing a nonlinear mathematical model of the DTP-PMSM in the rotating d-q reference frame, the CKF algorithm is employed to perform multi-source state fusion estimation of motor current and voltage signals, enabling high-precision dynamic observation of rotor position and speed. The proposed method is validated on the MATLAB/Simulink simulation platform under flight actuator load characteristics and strong disturbance conditions. The results demonstrate that, compared to conventional Sliding Mode Observer (SMO) approaches, the proposed CKF-based strategy achieves superior tracking accuracy in rotor angle estimation and significantly reduced speed fluctuation rates under conditions of abrupt speed changes, load variations, and simulated vibration disturbances. This research contributes a lightweight, fault-tolerant, and sensorless intelligent drive solution for aerospace electromechanical actuation systems, enhancing reliability in extreme operational environments.

title: Fusion algorithm for UAV moving target tracking and obstacle avoidance based on enhanced transformer
authors: Tianji Zheng, Mingze Yuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) that conduct tasks of moving target tracking and obstacle avoidance in dynamic and complex environments have become a hot research area in intelligent flight control, and there are still many challenges regarding how to integrate these tasks while also ensuring real-time performance and accuracy. In this paper, we propose an enhanced Transformer UAV motion target tracking and obstacle avoidance fusion algorithm (ETFA), which is deeply optimized on the basis of traditional vision Transformer architecture to achieve the collaborative scheduling of the perception of target behavior and the safety of the flight path. The model proposed in the paper mainly includes three core modules. (1) The Spatiotemporal Attention Encoder (STAE) is used to extract motion features in a continuous frame and construct a dynamic target representation. (2) The Dual-Path Cross-Fusion Module (DPCFM) enables in-depth communication between the target tracking path and environmental obstacle information, thereby enhancing the model's task adaptability. (3) The Adaptive Risk-Aware Planning Decoder (ARPD) employs attention heat maps and obstacle prediction results to generate feasible and safe flight trajectories. ETFA uses a fusion loss function in the training phase that incorporates target tracking accuracy, path smoothness, and obstacle avoidance safety. From experimental results, the ETFA algorithm provides significant advantages in target tracking accuracy, obstacle-avoidance success rates, and planning efficiency.

title: Enhancing Intrusion Detection in Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) with Optimized Lightweight Deep Learning Models
authors: Edy Kristianto, Elvin Justin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: The development of the Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) has brought significant security challenges, particularly concerning cyberattacks that threaten the integrity and privacy of medical data. Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) have become essential for identifying and preventing such attacks. However, implementing IDS in an IoMT environment requires a lightweight approach due to the resource limitations of IoMT gateways or edge devices. This research aims to develop an intrusion detection system for the IoMT using basic deep learning models. A tuned algorithm modification was used to create a lightweight model, ensuring that these models could operate optimally on resource-constrained devices. The dataset used in this study encompasses various types of attacks relevant to the IoMT. The model performance was evaluated based on metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score, and ROC AUC. The results indicate that the Fully Connected Deep Neural Network (FCDNN) model combined with focal loss delivers the highest accuracy, 94.6%, while maintaining a model size of less than 256 KB, making it an effective solution for intrusion detection within the IoMT. This study contributes to the development of reliable and efficient security systems for IoMT and promotes the application of deep learning technology in resource-constrained environments.

title: Ontology-Driven Deep Learning Generation Using Natural Language Style Representations
authors: Incheon Paik, Zheqi Shen
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Deep learning (DL) has achieved remarkable progress across various fields, yet designing customized DL architectures remains complex and labor-intensive. While AutoML frameworks assist with model selection and hyperparameter tuning, they lack mechanisms to integrate structured domain knowledge. To overcome this limitation, we propose an ontology-driven approach that enables Large Language Models (LLMs) to reason over structured knowledge and dynamically generate DL architectures. Traditional ontology systems rely on XML formats and rule-based engines, which hinder adaptability and compatibility with modern AI tools. Our approach transforms ontological concepts—such as classes, properties, and rules—into structured natural language, allowing LLMs to process and infer directly from them. This enables intuitive understanding and flexible reasoning without the need for external inference engines. We develop a prototype system that uses LLMs for DL architecture generation guided by ontology-based reasoning. Experimental results demonstrate improved adaptability and reduced reliance on specialized tools. Furthermore, we incorporate a Few-Shot Learning mechanism to enhance LLMs’ capability to interpret and apply ontology rules effectively. This research bridges the gap between structured knowledge representation and natural language-based reasoning, contributing to the development of autonomous and intelligent DL systems capable of domain-specific optimization.

title: QA Generator Framework for Chatbot Dataset Using NLP Methods with T5 and BERT Models
authors: Andreas Matthew, Endah Kristiani, Chao-Tung Yang, Fredicia, Benisius Anu
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: The development of artificial intelligence (AI), such as chatbots in the academic field, relies on large and high-quality datasets. Manually creating these datasets is time-consuming, resource-intensive, and delays AI deployment. To address this, we propose an automated dataset generation framework using Natural Language Processing (NLP) and transformer-based models. This research uses pretrained large language models (LLM), specifically T5 and BERT, to extract meaningful information from academic PDF documents, particularly two-column structured papers, and generate question-answer (QA) pairs as chatbot datasets. The proposed framework includes a text extraction, preprocessing, and QA generator; the pair will then be evaluated using three metrics: confidence score, BERTScore, and F1-Token. Unlike prior works that primarily target comprehension benchmarks dataset and task-based such as SQuAD or UnifiedQA, our framework accelerates the creation of datasets for chatbots, reduces the need for human effort, and guarantees the maintenance of high-quality and relevant datasets by directly processing unstructured academic PDFs with a nocel of dual-model strategy where T5 is used for question generation, and BERT is used for answer extraction to answer the generated question, with a built-in filtering mechanic and an adaptive parameter adjustment strategy that dynamically tunes parameters to maintain semantic diversity and reduce redundancy while ensuring semantic quality. Experimental results shows that the framework consistently produces QA pairs with high semantic value and both BERTscore and confidence score having high scores indicating a strong performance, demonstrating the viability of the framework as a scalable tool for automated dataset creation for chatbots.

title: Can Business Process Modeling Support Legal Decision-Making in Practice?
authors: Melissa Zorzanelli Costa, Daniel Dummer de Souza, Renata Silva Souza Guizzardi, João Paulo A. Almeida
abstract: Despite the various potential benefits of diagrammatic representations in the legal domain, empirical evidence of their suitability for use by legal professionals is still scarce. In this paper, we address this gap specifically for BPMN models representing a complex and highly specialized procedure in the Brazilian legal system. We assess whether the model can be used by legal professionals to guide decision making correctly. We further investigate whether the process model is perceived to be easy to use, useful and whether there is an intention to use the artifact, following the guidelines of the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM).

title: Strategic Decision Quality in Digital Transformation Projects: a Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise Case Study
authors: Lars Eberhardt
abstract: This article examines how strategic decisions can influence the outcomes of digital transformation in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Using the example of a German SME, its development is tracked over a three-year period during which elements of Spetzler's Decision Quality Framework were introduced. The study focuses on five specific areas in which decisions played a central role: Data Access, Use of Camera-Based Recognition, Object Tracking, Structural Reasoning, and Warehouse Space Optimization. Based on these use cases, the impact of the project was evaluated using a retrospective joint-assessment based on Spetzler's six dimensions. The results show that the SME was able to improve its decision-making practices in a meaningful way. Although the results are based on a single case, they indicate the potential of evaluating the decision quality in an early stage of Digital transformation. The article is one of the first practical investigations into how ex-ante decision quality methods can be applied in SMEs undergoing digital transformation.

title: Time Series Matching Based on Comparison of Corresponding Graphs
authors: S. N. Chukanov, A. G. Belik, V. N. Tsyganenko
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This paper examines the comparison of time series of a set of concepts based on the formation of weighted directed graphs of the mutual influences of time series concepts on each other. The graph vertices correspond to the concepts, and the weighted arcs correspond to the values of the influence of one concept on another. The graph structure can be characterized using the spectrum of the eigenvalues of the graph’s Laplace matrix, which corresponds to the heat equation. For this purpose, a heat kernel matrix is formed; the time derivative of the heat kernel matrix is determined by the Laplace matrix. The coefficients of the Taylor series expansion of the heat content of the heat kernel can be used to represent the graph structure. The paper presents relations for determining the Mahalanobis distance between feature vectors (heat kernel invariants) which can be used for pattern recognition. The topicality of the problem is to increase the uniqueness of identification when recognizing time series by taking into account both the spectrum of eigenvalues of the Laplace matrix of the graph and the eigenvectors. The goal of this paper is to explore the possibility of using the coefficients of the power series expansion of the heat content of the constructed graph as feature vectors – characteristics of the graph’s properties. The novelty of the methods presented in this paper lies in the fact that, unlike the spectral embedding method, it explores the possibility of comparing graphs (images) based on the Mahalanobis distance between invariants constructed from the thermal content decomposition coefficients. An algorithm for minimizing the Mahalanobis distance between graph vertices is proposed, based on learning the Mahalanobis matrix.By comparing graphs corresponding to time series of a set of concepts, it is possible to compare time series.

title: Testing of the Ultrasonic Range Finder of the Mobile Sensor Unit in Windy Conditions
authors: Jozef Novotňák, Zoltán Szőke, Róbert Bréda, Peter Gašparovič, Eduard Dolný
abstract: The paper presents the testing of an ultrasonic sensor mounted on a mobile sensor unit. It describes the issues of the monitoring unit itself, and deals in detail with testing the MB7383 ultrasonic sensor in various conditions - the accuracy and reliability of detection when used on a mobile sensor unit indoors with various shapes of reflecting surfaces and also outdoors with deteriorated environmental conditions, especially wind gusts and their impact on the reliability and accuracy of object detection. Testing and simulation of outdoor conditions took place in a wind tunnel.

title: Accident Prediction Models and Human Factor Analysis in Aviation: A Systematic Review of Emerging Approaches
authors: Slavomíra Vargová, Petr Adolf Skrehot, Tomáš Zeman, Jan Strohmand
abstract: This paper presents a systematic review of emerging methodologies in aviation accident prediction and human factor analysis. Following the PRISMA 2020 guidelines, a total of 22 studies were included, covering probabilistic models, machine learning approaches, human factor frameworks, and ergonomic modeling. Bayesian networks and probabilistic methods were shown to provide structured reasoning but remain data dependent. Machine learning offers scalability and predictive capacity, yet suffers from transparency and regulatory acceptance issues. Human factor frameworks, such as HFACS, STAMP, and FRMS, provide indispensable contextual insight but lack predictive precision. Ergonomic and performance modeling bridges the gap between human capabilities and system design but remains underintegrated into predictive analytics. The review concludes that hybrid approaches combining data-driven methods with human factor frameworks represent the most promising direction for proactive aviation safety.

title: Conthereum: Concurrent Ethereum Optimized Transaction Scheduling for Multi-Core Execution
authors: Atefeh Zareh Chahoki, Maurice Herlihy, Marco Roveri
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Conthereum is a concurrent Ethereum solution for intra-block parallel transaction execution, enabling validators to utilize multi-core infrastructure and transform the sequential execution model of Ethereum into a parallel one. This shift significantly increases throughput and transactions per second (TPS), while ensuring conflict-free execution in both proposer and attestor modes and preserving execution order consistency in the attestor. At the heart of Conthereum is a novel, lightweight, high-performance scheduler inspired by the Flexible Job Shop Scheduling Problem (FJSS). We propose a custom greedy heuristic algorithm, along with its efficient implementation, that solves this formulation effectively and decisively outperforms existing scheduling methods in finding suboptimal solutions that satisfy the constraints, achieve minimal makespan, and maximize speedup in parallel execution. Additionally, Conthereum includes an offline phase that equips its real-time scheduler with a conflict analysis repository obtained through static analysis of smart contracts, identifying potentially conflicting functions using a pessimistic approach. Building on this novel scheduler and extensive conflict data, Conthereum outperforms existing concurrent intra-block solutions. Empirical evaluations show nearlinear throughput gains with increasing computational power on standard 8-core machines. Although scalability deviates from linear at higher core counts and increased transaction conflicts, as theoretically expected, Conthereum still significantly improves upon the current Ethereum sequential execution model and outperforms existing intra-block concurrent solutions across a wide range of conditions.

title: Demo: Verify, Don’t Trust: Open-Source AI Is Not Enough
authors: Vid Keršič, Marjan Heričko, Muhamed Turkanović
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly used in critical domains, yet models are often executed by third par-ties-making open-source access alone insufficient for establishing trust in results. We propose a design for an AI model registry that provides the foundation for verifiability of the execution by supporting the full model lifecycle, from model registration to inference validation. Our implementation leverages Ethereum, IPFS, and two verification approaches: zero-knowledge machine learning (ZKML), and optimistic ML (OPML) via dispute resolution. The system enables users to confirm both the identity of the model and the correctness of its execution, enhancing trust in open-source AI.

title: DSM Implementation and Regulation: A Case Study on Policy, Tariff, and Verification Challenges in the GCC Smart Grid
authors: Ameni Boumaiza, Furkan Ahmad, Muneera Al-Qahtani, Sa’d Shannak, Antonio Sanfilippo
abstract: This paper outlines a roadmap for harmonizing Demand-Side Management across the GCC, tackling challenges of regulatory fragmentation, rising peak demand, and limited coordination. It reviews current DSM frameworks, identifies key structural gaps, and incorporates a techno-economic analysis using peak load reduction metrics, cost-benefit evaluations, and load-shifting simulations. Based on these insights, the paper recommends standardized M&V protocols, aligned tariff structures, enhanced consumer engagement tools, and a regional coordination mechanism under the GCC Interconnection Authority to support effective, economically viable DSM implementation.

title: Feedback Linearization Controller Design for a Hexacopter UAV: Theory and Experiments
authors: Le Anh Phi, Pham Quoc Khanh, Ha Le Nhu Ngoc Thanh
abstract: This paper presents a theoretical formulation and real implementation of the Feedback Linearization (FBL) control algorithm for a hexacopter unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) to improve the tracking performance of the control system in both attitude and position. The traditional Proportional–Integral–Derivative (PID) controller is widely used for linear systems due to its simplicity and straightforward gain tuning. However, for nonlinear models, the control performance of the classical PID algorithm faces serious limitations in terms of stability, especially for underactuated systems like UAVs. The Feedback Linearization controller is a well-known technique that relies on a mathematical model to achieve full input–output linearization, thereby enhancing tracking precision and reducing errors. The structure of the entire control system can be separated into two parts. First, a low-level controller is developed for attitude stabilization by controlling the rotational speeds of multiple rotors. Another part is a high-level controller responsible for driving the horizontal position to the desired value. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, Hardware-in-the-Loop (HITL) simulation and real implementation on the Pixhawk 6C flight controller, combined with the PX4 platform, are conducted and compared with the classical PID controller. The results from both simulation and real experiments demonstrated the superior performance of the Feedback Linearization controller compared to conventional control methods.

title: Interferometric Fiber-Optic Temperature Sensor Based on the Optical Multiharmonic Vernier Effect
authors: Wei-Hsuan Huang, Quoc-Thinh Dinh, Ching Lee, Thi-Thu-Hien Pham, Cheng-Yang Liu
abstract: A dual Fabry–Pérot interferometer system based on the optical Vernier effect is proposed for high-resolution temperature sensing. By introducing a slight cavity length detuning between the sensing and reference interferometers, a long-period envelope is generated, which effectively amplifies spectral shifts resulting from temperature variations. Numerical simulations and experimental results consistently confirm that an increase in temperature induces a distinct blue shift in the interference spectrum, primarily due to the combined effects of thermal expansion and the thermo-optic response of air within the cavity. To quantify this temperature dependence, the peak wavelengths of the second-order upper envelope were extracted at multiple temperature conditions and fitted using linear regression. The analysis shows a consistent wavelength shift of approximately one fringe per 10 degrees Celsius, with a coefficient of determination as high as 0.9701, indicating excellent linearity. These results demonstrate the feasibility, stability, and precision of the proposed system based on the optical Vernier effect for accurate temperature monitoring. Its compact configuration makes it a promising candidate for advanced fiber-optic sensing applications.

title: Tides of Memory: Digital Echoes of Netizen Remembrance
authors: Lingyu Peng, Chang Ge, Liying Long, Xin Li, Xiao Hu, Pengda Lu, Qingchuan Li, Jiangyue Wu
abstract: This artwork presents an interdisciplinary interaction installation that visualizes collective online mourning behavior in China. By focusing on commemorative content posted on Sina Weibo following the deaths of seven prominent Chinese authors, the artwork employs data scraping, natural language processing, and 3D modeling to transform fragmented textual expressions into immersive digital monuments. Through the analysis of word frequencies, topic models, and user engagement metrics, the system constructs a semantic-visual landscape that reflects both authorial legacies and collective memory. This research contributes to the fields of digital humanities, visualization design, and digital memorial architecture by proposing a novel approach for preserving and reactivating collective memory in the digital age.

title: Bringing LoRa Downlink to Backscatter Devices
authors: Han Wang, Yihang Song, Qianhe Meng, Chong Zhang, Songfan Li, Shuwei Wu, Ruizhe Zhang, Li Lu
abstract: Recent advances in backscatter communication have exhibited great advantages on uplink, both in power consumption and communication performance. However, their downlink tends to lag far behind due to stringent on-device power constraints. This paper presents Sisyphus, a novel communication paradigm designed to empower backscatter devices with LoRa downlink. To achieve this, we propose a novel receiver design for passive coherent demodulation of LoRa. In this design, we creatively couple LoRa’s down-conversion with de-chirping (dc2), leveraging the processing gain brought by chirp spread spectrum (CSS) modulation to boost communication range without the need for additional power supply. Moreover, we exploit the cyclical time-frequency feature intrinsic to LoRa for demodulation, and a low-power analog-digital signal processing circuit with negligible power is devised to replace the existing power-intensive sampling and costly digital computation. We prototype Sisyphus for proof-of-concept, and comprehensive experimental results demonstrate that Sisyphus can achieve significant power savings compared to legacy LoRa receiver while retaining the anti-interference ability of legacy LoRa. We envision that the design of Sisyphus can unlock the potential for broader applications of LoRa-based backscatter devices.

title: Normative Hiking Exertion Pattern Modeling from GPS Data using Log-Normal Distribution for Enhancing Mountain Trekker Safety
authors: Tajim Md. Niamat Ullah Akhund, Yojiro Mori
abstract: For safety monitoring, early anomaly detection, and trail difficulty assessment is essential to model physical exertion during hiking. In this work, a metric that combines horizontal and vertical physical effort obtained from GPS data is introduced called hypotenuse velocity (VH). The main hypothesis is that the distribution of VH values over time can be statistically modeled to describe normative hiking patterns and reflects the underlying exertion dynamics of hikers. GPS data from nine mountain trails in Japan including two solo hikes and seven group hikes (teams of five to ten people each) were collected in order to verify this theory. Nine potential statistical models were compared to the VH distribution of each trail. Akaike information criterion and mean squared error were used to quantify goodness-of-fit. The log-normal distribution consistently produced the lowest AIC and MSE values across all trails, demonstrating both its theoretical and empirical suitability for describing the dynamics of skewed exertion. The ideal log-normal parameter ranges that describe typical hiking behavior were found through brute-force simulations using hundred million samples per trail. The framework’s potential for anomaly detection was demonstrated by the deviations from these ranges observed in trails with self-reported discomfort. The suggested system offers scalable applicability for health-conscious trail monitoring and early-warning systems in natural settings because it is lightweight, GPS-based, and sensor-minimal.

title: On the Secrecy-Sensing Optimization of RIS-assisted Full-Duplex Integrated Sensing and Communication Network
authors: Elmehdi Illi, Ahmad Bazzi, Marwa Qaraqe, Ali Ghrayeb
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) has recently emerged as a viable technique for establishing sensing and communication using the same resources. Nonetheless, the operation of ISAC networks is often challenged by the absence of a direct link between the sensing node and the targets, and by the risk of disclosing confidential data to malicious targets when using the same signal for both tasks. In this paper, a robust reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-aided scheme for securing a full-duplex (FD) ISAC network is proposed. The considered network consists of uplink and downlink users served in FD through a multi-antenna dual-functional radar communication base station (BS), which employs co-located multi-antenna communication-radar arrays to detect multiple malicious targets while preserving communication secrecy in their presence. Additionally, the BS utilizes an optimized artificial noise (AN) that serves to disrupt the malicious targets’ reception and increase the sensing illumination power. By optimally designing the RIS phase shifts, transmit beamforming matrix, AN covariance matrix, and uplink users’ transmit power and combining vectors using an alternating optimization-based algorithm, the network’s sensing performance is maximized under secrecy and total power constraints. Numerical results present the proposed scheme’s efficacy, particularly when a direct link between the BS and the various nodes/targets is absent.

title: Energy Efficiency Analysis of Active RIS-enhanced Wireless Network under Power-Sum Constraint
authors: Jingdie Xin, Yan Wang, Feng Shu, Feng Zhao, Yifan Zhao, Hao Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: Recently, as a green wireless technology, active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) attracts numerous research activities due to its amplifying ability to combat the double-fading effect compared to passive one. How about its energy efficiency (EE) over passive one? Below, the EE of active RIS-aided wireless network in Rayleigh fading channels is analyzed. Using the law of large numbers, EE is derived as a function of five factors: power allocation factor, the number (N) of RIS elements, the total power, the noise variances at RIS and at user. To assess each factor’s impact, the simple EE function for the concerning factor is given with others fixed. To evaluate the impact of N on EE, we establish an equation with the EE of active RIS equaling that of passive one, and three methods, bisection, Newton’s method, and simulated annealing, are designed to find the roots of this equation. Simulation results show that as N tends to medium-scale or large-scale, the asymptotic performance formula is consistent with the exact EE expression well. As N varies from small-scale to large-scale, the active RIS intersects passive one at some point (N0 ≈ 210). When N < N0, active RIS performs better than passive one in terms of EE. Otherwise, there is a converse conclusion.

title: Enhanced Aperture Efficiency in a Parabolic Cylindrical CATR via Decoupled Diffraction Control
authors: Ke Yang, Zhengpeng Wang, Wei Fan
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: To overcome the challenge of balancing high performance with low manufacturing cost in large-aperture compact antenna test range (CATR) systems, this letter proposes and validates a novel linear array feed parabolic cylindrical CATR based on a dimension-separation diffraction control strategy. This strategy decouples the complex two-dimensional edge diffraction problem into two independent one-dimensional problems. In the vertical dimension, passive suppression of edge diffraction is achieved by designing mechanical serrations on the upper and lower edges of the reflector. In the horizontal dimension, this letter proposes an active diffraction cancellation algorithm that controls the quiet zone ripple caused by the straight-cut edges by optimizing the complex excitations of the feed array, eliminating the need for physical serrations. This design concept ensures a high-quality quiet zone, characterized by peak-to-peak amplitude and phase variations of less than 1 dB and 10°, respectively. Simultaneously, it simplifies the reflector manufacturing process and significantly improves aperture efficiency. The proposed CATR demonstrates an exceptional aperture efficiency of up to 91% at 10 GHz. Even at a lower frequency of 2.6 GHz, despite more pronounced diffraction effects from a smaller electrical aperture, it maintains an efficiency of 78.5%. This significantly outperforms both traditional CATR (50%) and fully-serrated edge designs with tapering excitation (67.5%).

title: High Sensitivity Evanescent Field-Based Micro-Resonator Using Porous Cladding for Sensing Applications in the Visible Range
authors: Pauline Girault, Laurent Oyhenart, Théo Rouanet, Simon Joly, Guillaume Beaudin, Jean-françois Bryche, Michael Canva, Paul G. Charette, Laurent Bechou
abstract: In this work, we fabricate and study a sensitive polymer-based optical sensor for visible range detection in water environment. The studied transducer is a micro-resonator relying on the interaction between the evanescent wave and the aqueous medium to measure the medium refractive index change. The micro-resonator consists of a waveguide with PMMA polymer as the core layer and porous silica as the lower cladding layer to significantly enhance the evanescent field ratio and sensitivity. The first results show a very good resonator quality factor of around 2.10<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{4}$</tex-math></inline-formula> and a sensitivity of 255nm/RIU at 760nm for aqueous solutions with glucose at different concentrations. These state-of-the-art results obtained in the visible range demonstrate that a polymer-based sensor with a porous cladding appears as a promising platform for evanescent field-based sensing in the visible range without any surface chemical functionalization in an aqueous medium.

title: PowerMamba: A Deep State Space Model and Comprehensive Benchmark for Time Series Prediction in Electric Power Systems
authors: Ali Menati, Fatemeh Doudi, Dileep Kalathil, Le Xie
abstract: The electric power sector is undergoing substantial transformations due to the rising electrification of demand, enhanced integration of renewable energy resources, and the emergence of new technologies. These changes are rendering the electric grid more volatile and unpredictable, making it more challenging to maintain reliable operations. In order to address these issues, advanced time series prediction models are needed for closing the gap between the forecasted and actual grid outcomes. In this paper, we introduce a multivariate time series prediction model that combines traditional state space models with deep learning methods to simultaneously capture and predict the underlying dynamics of multiple time series. Additionally, we design a time series processing module that incorporates high resolution external forecasts into sequence-to-sequence prediction models, achieving this with negligible increases in size and no loss of accuracy. We also release an extended dataset spanning five years of load, electricity price, ancillary service price, and renewable generation. To complement this dataset, we provide an open-access toolbox that includes our proposed model, the dataset itself, and several state-of-the-art prediction models, thereby creating a unified framework for benchmarking advanced machine learning approaches. Our findings indicate that the proposed model outperforms existing models across various prediction tasks, improving state-of-the-art prediction error by an average of 7% and decreasing model parameters by 43%. The code is available at https://github.com/alimenati/PowerMamba

title: SynC: Synergistic Boosting of Structure and Representation for Deep Graph Clustering
authors: Shifei Ding, Benyu Wu, Xiao Xu, Ling Ding, Xindong Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Employing graph neural networks (GNNs) for graph clustering has shown promising results in deep graph clustering (DGC). However, existing methods disregard the reciprocal relationship between representation learning and structure augmentation: the more homogeneous the graph, the more cohesive the node representations; the more cohesive the node representations, the more reliable the structure augmentation becomes. Moreover, the generalization ability of existing GNN-based models on the low homophily graph is relatively poor. To this end, we propose a graph clustering framework named synergistic deep graph clustering network (<monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SynC</monospace>). <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SynC</monospace> employs a transform input graph autoencoder (TIGAE) to obtain high-quality embeddings via mitigating the representation collapse issue of GAE for guiding structure augmentation. Then, we recapture neighborhood representations on the refined graph to obtain clustering-friendly embeddings and conduct self-supervised clustering. Notably, these two stages share weights, resulting in synergistic boosting while significantly reducing the number of model parameters. Additionally, we introduce a structure fine-tuning (SF) strategy to improve the model’s generalization on the low homophily graph. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SynC</monospace>. The code is released at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Marigoldwu/SynC</uri>.

title: A Minor Multifault Cooperative Diagnosis Method for Lithium-Ion Power Batteries Based on Multi-Information Fusion
authors: Xin Gu, Chenghui Zhang, Hao Geng, Jinglun Li, Yan Li, Fangyuan Bi, Zhihao Chen, Yunlong Shang
abstract: Fault diagnosis is a key technology to ensure the safe operation of power batteries. However, batteries minor faults are characterized by diverse triggers and coupled features, which are easily covered by noise. Early diagnosis of minor faults is extremely challenging. The traditional threshold method is difficult to determine the optimal threshold, which cannot diagnose minor faults. Therefore, a minor multifault cooperative diagnosis framework based on multi-information fusion is proposed. On the one hand, the variance generalized S-transform is presented to detect minor faults. Further, internal short circuits, external short circuits, and poor contact faults are distinguished based on the voltage pseudo-variance and temperature rise. On the other hand, the variable scale distance integral distance and voltage spectrum integration method are invented to diagnose self-discharge faults and sensor faults, respectively. The equivalent internal resistance approach is used to detect inconsistent faults. The experimental results demonstrate that the presented approach achieves a 98.5% fault detection rate and a 97.7% detection accuracy rate. The detection results of different types of batteries faults and simultaneous faults of diverse cells prove the robustness of the proposed technology.

title: A Reliable Monitoring of Livestock Location and Geo-Fencing Application
authors: Mohammad Reza Nosouhi, Keshav Sood, Robin Doss, Gang Li, Zubair Baig, Anandakumaran Sellathurai, Anjali Kaushik
abstract: Trustworthy livestock monitoring is essential for improving farm management and minimizing economic loss caused by animal displacement or theft. We propose an intelligent livestock location monitoring and geo-fencing framework using Deep Autoencoder (DAE) model ensuring data integrity and system trustworthiness. The framework classifies anomalies as either sensor faults or compromised nodes based on the Moran’s I spatial autocorrelation index by quantifying spatial inconsistency among neighboring nodes. The results confirm the framework’s effectiveness and practical potential for reliable livestock monitoring and geo-fencing in smart farming environments.

title: A Novel Online Operation Mode Recognition Strategy of LLC Resonant Converter
authors: Jian Wang, Taotao Ge, Jie Chen
abstract: The time-domain analysis is a widely used method for characterizing LLC converters, where the operating modes (OpMods) of an LLC converter can be categorized into distinct types based on combinations of resonant circuit states within a switching period. Each OpMod requires a dedicated model for analysis, and failure to correctly identify these OpMods may lead to reduced model accuracy. Traditionally, boundaries between OpMods involving discontinuous conduction mode (DCM) are considered to lack analytical expressions describing the relationships among switching frequency, voltage gain, and load. In this paper, analytical expressions for the boundaries of all common OpMods are derived by extracting the magnetizing inductor voltage at OpMod boundary as critical features and integrating Kirchhoff's Voltage Law. As a theoretical analytical solution, this method exhibits no errors in OpMod boundaries compared to simulation results. Based on this, a novel online OpMod recognition strategy is proposed, which can be seamlessly integrated into existing control systems and design frameworks. Experiment result confirm the effectiveness of proposed approach.

title: Finding Informative Skyline Results over Incomplete Data with Threshold-based Bucket Skyline Algorithm
authors: Zhang Xiaowei, Hamidah Ibrahim, Fatimah Sidi, Siti Nurulain Mohd Rum, Mudathir Ahmed Mohamud
abstract: Skyline queries which return objects that are not dominated by any other objects, have been integrated into various real-world database applications. However, the presence of incomplete data in databases, may lead into cyclic dominance relation that none of the objects are considered as skylines, while the transitive dominance property may no longer hold. Although, these issues have received great attention, most of the existing skyline algorithms typically ignore the quality of the returned skyline results, thereby limiting the insights they offer. In this paper, a Threshold-based Bucket Skyline Algorithm (TBSA) is proposed with the aim to derive informative skyline results, i.e. results that are not too few and with low missing rate. TBSA organises the objects in the database into a two-layer structure, namely: bucket and cluster, to ensure only dominant objects are retained for further skyline analysis. Meanwhile, to minimise the tuning iterations, a threshold prediction model is constructed that identifies in advanced the subspaces to be excluded from the skyline computation. Extensive experiments have been carried out on the synthetic and real datasets and the results show that TBSA outperforms the previous approach with respect to the number of iterations, pairwise comparisons, skyline results, informative skyline results, and processing time.

title: Simplified and Generalized BV-VTEAM Model for Bipolar Memristors and Its Application in Digital Logic Circuit Design
authors: Le Ngoc Thanh, Nguyen Van Minh, To Thanh Trung Truc, Dang Anh Minh, Vo Minh Huan
abstract: Memristors have been employed in the design of integrated memory, logic gates, analog circuits, and neuromorphic systems. Their non-volatile nature, high integration density, and compatibility with CMOS technology have been widely documented in numerous studies. Existing research has compared the operational characteristics of various memristor models, including linear, nonlinear, current-controlled threshold adaptive models, and voltage-controlled adaptive models. However, many of these traditional models are either too domain-specific or physically complex, which limits their practical simulation efficiency. In response to the need for a simple, general-purpose, and fast-simulating model in EDA flows, this study proposes an BV-VTEAM which is advanced version of the V-VTEAM model for bipolar memristors. The new model maintains a balance between simplicity and accuracy. In the BV-VTEAM model, the internal state variable represents the memristor's conductivity level. This dynamic variable evolves over time based on the applied stimulus. The state update is performed using a manual integration method, where the time step is automatically selected based on the nearest absolute timestamps in both the growth and decay phases. The bounded function is applied to ensure that internal state variable remains within physical limits. Additionally, the output current is regulated by a maximum threshold using a soft-bounded approach to avoid Zero Jacobian issues, thus improving numerical stability. The operation conditions are analyzed in various dynamic parameters in terms of supply voltage, operating frequency, maximum current, time constant, and nonlinearity exponent This BV-VTEAM model is further utilized to design digital logic circuits, including AND, OR, and flip-flops, laying the groundwork for constructing more complex digital systems based on memristive components.

title: A Localization-Enhanced Adaptive Multi-level Feature Fusion Network for Remote Sensing Scene Classification
authors: Qingyang Guan, Chulin Wang, Nanxi Zhao, Mengxing Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Remote sensing image classification is a prominent topic in remote sensing, where both local detail information and global context information are crucial for remote sensing image classification. However, most networks focus only on the last layer of high-level feature extraction, ignoring the precise localization information in the shallow features. Moreover, only simple addition operations are used in feature fusion, resulting in semantic gaps. To solve this problem, in this paper, we propose an adaptive multilevel feature fusion network (LEAMFF-Net) based on localization enhancement, designing a multiscale context interaction module (MSCIM) to enhance the extraction of multiscale features by using inflated convolution, and finally, a localization enhancement module (LEM) is designed to enhance feature localization. It fuses multilevel features via a multiscale adaptive feature fusion (AMFF) module. Moreover, it transfers accurate shallow-level localization information to higher-level representations, enabling the network to focus on key features. Comprehensive experiments are conducted on three widely used remote sensing datasets. The proposed model outperforms most state-of-the-art methods.

title: Research on the Control System of Electric Variable Pitch Propellers
authors: Weiping Zhao, Shengwen Shu, Hongxu Guan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: With the advancement of electric technology, electric pitch systems have started to dominate aircraft design, gradually replacing traditional hydraulic pitch systems. The development of electric aircraft is expected to become a key step for the aviation industry to achieve sustainable development<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[1]</sup>. This paper takes the electric pitch propeller control system as the research object, innovatively designs the hardware and software of the electric pitch propeller control system, and conducts a detailed research, analysis, and experimental testing on its performance. The emergence of electric aircraft has overturned traditional aircraft design concepts, starting from the principles of safety, convenience, environmental friendliness, and high energy efficiency, driving innovation in the field of aerospace engineering. Through continuous optimization of the overall design of electric aircraft, they have become one of the key models for development in the global aviation industry in recent years, representing the direction of advanced technology.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[2]</sup>

title: On-State Resistance Measurement Circuit Under Galvanic Isolation Constraints
authors: Junho Shin, Jong-Won Shin, Suwoong Eo, Dae-Un Sung, Hyun-Woo Jung, Sanghyun Moon
abstract: An increase in the on-state resistance ($\boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{D} \boldsymbol{U} \boldsymbol{T}}$) of power semiconductor devices serves as an indicator for estimating their remaining useful life (RUL). Resistance Rdut is generally calculated by measuring the on-state voltage across the power semiconductors and dividing it by the conduction current. In isolated converters, the need for galvanic isolation between the on-state voltage measurement circuit (OVMC) and the controller presents a key design challenge: the high bandwidth (BW) required for the measurement conflicts with the limited BW of the signal isolator. This paper presents a novel circuit that overcomes this limitation by incorporating a sample-and-hold stage before the isolator. This method preserves the on-state voltage as a DC-level signal, allowing it to be accurately transmitted through a low-BW isolator. The proposed method was experimentally validated on a $1-\mathrm{kW}, 400 \mathrm{~V}$-to- 14 V activeclamp forward-flyback converter prototype, achieving an onstate resistance measurement with approximately 90% accuracy.

title: CT-CLNet: A CNN-Transformer Contrastive Learning Framework for Remote Sensing Scene Classification
authors: Qingyang Guan, Mengxing Yang, Chulin Wang, Chongjin Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: In the field of remote sensing image processing, the task of remote sensing image classification is the core foundation for many subsequent applications. With the development of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Transformer, the classification accuracy has significantly improved. However, due to the complexity and diversity of remote sensing scenes, as well as the faster rate of frequency and spatial resolution changes, remote sensing scene classification still faces greater challenges. According to recent studies, CNNs have efficient performance in local feature extraction, but still have deficiencies in global feature perception. In this paper, we propose a contrastive learning model CNN-Transformer Contrastive Learning Framework (CT-CLNet) for remote sensing image classification task. which combines the advantages of CNN and Swin Transformer, and realizes the effective interaction between local and global information through the bi-directional attention cross-fertilization module. For the potential semantic prediction differences between CNN and Transformer, the model is trained by combining the classification loss and the contrastive learning loss through the contrastive learning approach, which further strengthens the feature representation capability and robustness of the model. The experimental results on three remote sensing classification datasets, UC land and NWPU, show that CT-CLNet exhibits obvious advantages in classification accuracy, robustness, and generalization ability.

title: Multi-Class Parkinson’s Disease Detection Based on Finger Tapping Using Attention-Enhanced CNN-BiLSTM
authors: Abu Saleh Musa Miah, Md Maruf Al Hossain, Najmul Hassan, Yuichi Okuyama, Jungpil Shin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Accurate evaluation of Parkinson’s disease (PD) severity is essential for effective clinical management and intervention development. Despite the proposal of several gesture-based PD recognition systems, including those using the finger-tapping task to assess Parkinsonian symptoms, their performance remains unsatisfactory. In this study, we present a multi-class PD detection system based on finger-tapping, using an attention-enhanced CNN-BiLSTM framework combined with handcrafted feature extraction and deep learning techniques. In the procedure, we used an existing dataset of finger-tapping videos to extract temporal, frequency, and amplitude-based features from wrist and hand movements using their formulas. These handcrafted features were then processed through our attention-enhanced CNN-BiLSTM model, a hybrid deep learning framework that integrates CNN, BiLSTM, and attention mechanisms to classify PD severity into multiple levels. The features first pass through a Conv1D-MaxPooling block to capture local spatial dependencies, followed by processing through a BiLSTM layer to model the temporal dynamics of the motion. An attention mechanism is applied to emphasize the most informative temporal features, which are then refined by a second BiLSTM layer. The CNN-derived features and attention-enhanced BiLSTM outputs are concatenated, followed by dense and dropout layers, before being passed through a softmax classifier to predict the PD severity level. Our model demonstrated strong performance in distinguishing between the five severity classes, showcasing the effectiveness of combining spatial-temporal representations with attention mechanisms for automated PD severity detection. This approach offers a promising non-invasive tool to assist clinicians in monitoring PD progression and making informed treatment decisions.linicians in monitoring PD progression and making informed treatment decisions.

title: Gate-Voltage-Dependent Input Capacitance Partitioning for Accurate Modeling of Trench-Gate SiC MOSFETs
authors: Taiki Nishioka, Kazuki Matsumoto, Hajime Takayama, Jun Furuta, Kazutoshi Kobayashi, Michihiro Shintani
abstract: This paper presents a dynamic input-capacitance model for trench-gate silicon carbide (SiC) MOSFETs that accounts for voltage-dependent partitioning between gate-tosource ($C_{\mathrm{gs}}$) and gate-to-drain ($C_{\mathrm{gd}}$) capacitances. In contrast to conventional planar-based models with static partition boundaries, the proposed model introduces a dynamically varying boundary governed by instantaneous changes of gatesource voltage $V_{\mathrm{gs}}$ and gate-drain voltage $V_{\mathrm{gd}}$. The model is developed based on transient electric field behavior extracted from technology computer-aided design (TCAD) simulations, which reveal time-dependent shifts in the internal gate oxide field boundary during switching transitions. Experimental validation is conducted using gate charge measurements obtained from a double-pulse tester (DPT) with model fitting performed across a two-dimensional voltage space. Compared to the conventional static-boundary model, the proposed model improves accuracy, reducing the relative error against the measurements. Furthermore, it successfully captures the voltage dependence of $C_{\mathrm{gs}}$, thereby offering enhanced physical fidelity for circuit simulations and circuit design involving trench-gate SiC MOSFETs.

title: Neural Network Simulation of a Residential Building for a Data-Driven Thermal Consumption
authors: Oleg V. Stukach, Ivan A. Ershov, Nadezhda A. Dvurechenskaya
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The growing complexity of urban infrastructure increased the efficiency of heat supply, which must be ensured by the efficient and sustainable operation of supply organizations. Overspending of heating energy or decrease in thermal comfort follows to decrease of control quality. Systemically, the heat consumption of residential buildings on a whole city is a set of time series characterized by correlations not only with the outside temperature, but also a lot of building characteristics. Optimization of the temperature mode in the heating system is proposed to solve this problem. The model of heat consumption in a multi-storey building was designed using Long Short-Term Memory simulation. High accuracy of series reproduction has been achieved. The model is based on the characteristics of the building and meteorological factors as the temperature of the outside air. The data-driven model has been verified by commercial heat metering database. The results show the possibility and necessity of design a neural network weather-dependent regulator. Also it may be serve a basis for justifying housing renovation programs, as well as plans of the thermal energy supply organizations management.

title: Environmental and Economic Analysis of Sustainable Aviation Fuels in the Context of Circular Economy: A Case Study
authors: Alica Tobisova, Robert Rozenberg, Adam Turac, Miroslav Bohac
abstract: The aviation industry is facing increasing pressure to reduce its environmental impact, making the transition to a circular economy a strategic priority. This article examines the application of circular economy principles in aviation, with a particular focus on the potential of sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) to reduce CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions. A detailed case study of a commercial flight from Bratislava (LZIB) to Doha (OTHH) on a Boeing 737-800 aircraft is presented. The analysis evaluates the environmental and economic impacts of replacing conventional Jet A-1 fuel with various types of SAF, produced using technologies such as HEFA, FT-SPK, ATJ, and SIP from different feedstocks. Scenarios with SAF blends of $10 \%$, 30%, $50 \%$, and a hypothetical $100 \%$ are compared. The results indicate that while all SAF variants reduce emissions, the overall life-cycle carbon footprint and costs vary significantly depending on the production technology and feedstock used. The findings suggest that SAF produced from waste materials, particularly through the HEFA and FT-SPK production pathways, offer the most promising balance between environmental benefits and economic viability. This study highlights the crucial role of feedstock selection and policy support in accelerating the decarbonization of the aviation sector.

title: Use of Polymer Material-PETG in Environments with Chemical De-Icing Agents
authors: Petr Kalvoda, David Demydenko
abstract: The article focuses on the application of additive manufacturing technologies for producing components made of Polyethylene Terephthalate (PETG) material intended for ground-based airfield equipment used in airport maintenance. The aim of the study was to analyze and select suitable materials for additive manufacturing of spare parts, with particular emphasis on their mechanical properties and resistance to commonly used chemical de-icing agents. The study includes experimental testing of tensile and flexural properties as well as hardness of the selected materials after significant exposure to chemical de-icing substances such as Clearway 1 and Urea.

title: Programmable Governance for Group-Controlled Decentralized Identifiers
authors: Carlo Segat, Sandro Rodriguez Garzon, Axel Küpper
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) is a paradigm for digital identity management that offers privacy and flexibility advantages. A key technology in SSI is Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) and their associated metadata, DID Documents (DDOs). DDOs contain crucial verification material such as the public keys of the entity identified by the DID (i.e., the DID subject) and are often anchored on a distributed ledger to ensure security and availability. Long-lived DIDs must support updates (e.g., key rotation). Ideally, only the DID subject should authorize DDO updates. However, in practice, update capabilities may be shared or delegated. While the DID specification acknowledges such scenarios, it does not define how updates should be authorized when multiple entities jointly control a DID (i.e., group control). This article examines the implementation of an on-chain, trustless mechanism enabling DID controllers under group control to program their governance rules. The main research question is the following: Can a technical mechanism be developed to orchestrate on-chain group control of a DDO in a ledger-agnostic and adaptable manner?

title: An Assessment Framework to Offline Functionality in Central Bank Digital Currencies
authors: Vladyslav Nekriach, Panagiotis Michalopoulos, Cyrus Minwalla, Andreas Veneris
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: The emergence of blockchain technology has reshaped the financial sector, leading to the introduction of new financial products and services. In parallel, central banks worldwide are investigating the possibility of issuing central bank digital currency (CBDC) and the potential use of blockchain as a foundational technology. Of particular interest is offline functionality, where transactions can be completed even if neither party is connected to the ledger at the time of transaction. Such offline functionality carries unique opportunities for countries and policy makers, but also comes with a new set of risks. Proposed herein is an assessment framework as a critical modeling tool towards risk evaluation. The framework is broadly applicable to blockchain-based solutions that support multiple off-chain transactions prior to synchronization. Urban and rural environments were modeled to demonstrate the model’s fidelity and flexibility. A test offline digital currency solution was evaluated via threat level experiments to ascertain the prototype’s resilience to varying levels of malicious activity. Results illustrate how various parameter configurations affect resilience to malicious activity and information propagation, demonstrating the effectiveness of the framework in providing valuable insights for the design of offline currency systems.

title: Towards Next Generation Domain Services: A Committee based Privacy Scheme leveraging Move on IOTA
authors: Antonino Iaria, Mirko Zichichi, Vittorio Ghini, Stefano Ferretti
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: The inherent complexity of cryptographic addresses in Web3 ecosystems poses significant usability problems. Decentralized Domain Services attempt to solve this challenge yet, in the meantime, jeopardize users’ pseudo-anonymity. This paper investigates the design and implementation of a decentralized naming system leveraging IOTA’s Move smart contract framework. We analyze the system architecture and provide a comparative evaluation against established domain name services such as ENS, SuiNS, SolanaNS, and Avvy, highlighting the unique advantages and limitations of our proposed solution. Moreover, we introduce a novel committee-bridge architecture managing off-chain hashed name storage, enabling selective disclosure of domain information while maintaining low computational overhead. We also present results from an evaluation that assesses the functioning and the performance of the system, which confirm the viability of the proposal.
