title: Decentralized Dynamic Self-Triggered Control for Cascaded Switched CSTRs via ESN-Based Dual Heuristic Programming
authors: Huaguang Zhang, Zhousheng Chu, Chong Liu, Shuhang Yu
abstract: This article proposes a dynamic self-triggered (DST) control strategy and a switching signal for a cascaded switched continuous stirred tank reactor (CSTR) system subject to asymmetric input constraints. First, the switched subsystems are established, and an improved nonquadratic performance function (PF) is designed, enabling the decentralized constrained switched control problem (CP) to be decomposed into a set of unconstrained optimal switched CPs for the individual subsystems. To reduce communication and computational burdens while eliminating the need for dedicated trigger-monitoring hardware, a dynamic self-triggering mechanism is incorporated into the controller. Subsequently, the DST Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation associated with the transformed optimal switched CP is derived. To circumvent repeated trial-and-error and ease the selection of activation functions, a dual heuristic programming method utilizing echo state networks (ESNs) is adopted to approximate the PF. According to the Lyapunov theorem, the output weights of the ESN and the states of the closed-loop switched subsystems are proven to be uniformly ultimately bounded. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed DST control strategy and switching signals is validated on a cascaded switched CSTR system comprising three reactors.

title: Generalized NOMA-ARQ with Round-Robin IIC for IoT Systems
authors: Meshari Alshehri, Emad Alsusa, Mahmoud Alaaeldin, Arafat Al-Dweik
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Vehicular Technology
abstract: This paper investigates the performance of non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) integrated with automatic repeat request (ARQ) for point-to-point Internet of Things (IoT) wireless backhaul links. The proposed framework is generalized accommodate an arbitrary number of users, incorporates round–robin (RR) scheduling, and use iterative interference cancellation (IIC) with chase combining (CC) to enhance fair power allocation while reducing the packet drop rate (PDR). The results reveal that NOMA-ARQ with IIC significantly outperforms conventional orthogonal multiple access (OMA) in various scenarios. The signal-to-noise (SNR) gain in PDR performance is particularly evident in moderate to high SNR conditions, ranging from 13 to 35 dB, and for scenarios involving three users with multiple transmission attempts. The proposed approach demonstrates up to a threefold increase in system throughput compared to OMA, highlighting its potential for enhancing backhaul performance in dense IoT deployments. These findings highlight the potential of IIC-assisted ARQ-NOMA to address the requirements for spectrum efficiency and data reliability effectively.

title: Hybrid Cloud-Edge-Vehicle Collaborative Task Offloading in VEC Based on Reinforcement Learning and Game Theory
authors: Feiyan Guo, Xiaoqing Luo, Xingshu Liu
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Vehicular Technology
abstract: With the rapid advancement of autonomous driving technologies, Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) networks are recognized as pivotal in enhancing the efficiency and safety of intelligent transportation systems. However, the highly dynamic and mobile nature of V2X environments poses considerable challenges for task offloading, particularly in achieving low delay, high energy efficiency and task success rate maximization. To address these issues, this study introduces the Dynamic Task Offloading Framework (DTOF) and the Hybrid Integrated Offloading Algorithm (HIOA). The DTOF incorporates dynamic task segmentation with cross-layer resource allocation, thereby improving adaptability under high mobility conditions, with vehicle speeds ranging from 20 to 120km/h. The HIOA integrates deep reinforcement learning (DRL) with game-theoretic methods to achieve near-optimal multi-objective optimization, encompassing delay minimization and energy efficiency improvement across vehicle densities of 30 to 80 vehicles/km2. Specifically designed to satisfy the delay requirement for Level 4 and beyond autonomous driving, the HIOA ensures both low delay and energy efficiency. Hybrid simulations combining SUMO traffic modeling and a 5G New Radio (NR) channel model demonstrate that the HIOA achieves superior performance compared to existing approaches. Under typical operating conditions, it reduces service access delay by 25%,lowers energy consumption by 18% and elevates task success rate by 30%. Moreover, the HIOA maintains robust performance under peak traffic scenarios (80 vehicles/km2) and amid infrastructure impairments (30% RSU failure rate). This work substantially augments the efficiency and adaptability of V2X, establishing a solid groundwork for further development of autonomous driving technologies. Future research will investigate federated learning for cross-domain collaboration and refine the integration of game-theoretic and DRL mechanisms to further reduce computational complexity.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Bending Eavesdropping Detection in Optical Communications Using a Physics-Informed Convolutional Network
authors: Wenshuai Qin, Xiaoxue Gong, Weigang Hou, Lu Gan, Lei Guo
abstract: This paper proposes a physics-informed convolutional network (PICN) scheme to detect bending eavesdropping attacks in dual-polarization coherent optical communication systems. We present a theoretical model for optical signal transmission under bending eavesdropping, analyzing the impact of bending eavesdropping on fiber physical characteristics such as dispersion and nonlinear effect. These physical characteristics are embedded into a convolutional neural network (CNN) to construct PICN, which automatically captures subtle variations of the signal features under bending eavesdropping. To validate the effectiveness of the scheme, we first develop an eavesdropping experimental platform in an 80-km 168 Gbps dual-polarization quadrature phase shift keying (QPSK) coherent optical communication system. Polarization data are then collected under normal transmission, 10.8 mm and 15 mm bending radius. Finally, the detection performance of four classifiers including PICN, random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), and K-nearest neighbor (KNN) are evaluated at single and mixed bending radii. Experimental results demonstrate that PICN achieves detection accuracies of 100%, 98.53%, and 99.02% under 10.8 mm, 15 mm, and mixed bending radii, respectively. Our work provides novel theoretical foundations and innovative perspectives for bending eavesdropping detection in optical fiber communication systems.

title: Search Me in the Dark: Access Pattern-Hidden Range Query over Encrypted Spatial Data
authors: Yinbin Miao, Xin Wang, Guijuan Wang, Yibing Wang, Kaifa Zheng, Xinghua Li, Zhiquan Liu, Rebert H. Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: With the widespread use of encrypted spatial data, many range query schemes emerge to address potential security risks caused by access pattern leakage. However, most existing schemes rely on a dual-server model to hide access patterns and often involve complex spatial relation judgments during range comparisons, leading to low query efficiency. To address these issues, we propose a novel Fast and Access Hidden Range Query (FAHRQ) scheme. First, we introduce an efficient range membership verification technique based on Bloom filters and Lagrange interpolation function, combine homomorphic encryption to ensure the confidentiality of spatial data and the computational flexibility of related operations, and realize the access pattern hidden under single server. Then, we construct an index using R-tree and employ Bloom filters and prefix 0-1 encoding to accelerate the minimum bounding rectangle intersection judgment, enabling secure and efficient range queries over encrypted spatial data while maintaining retrieval accuracy. Finally, we give a formal security analysis to show that our scheme achieves access pattern hidden while protecting data security, and conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate that our scheme improves query efficiency by 5 – 7× compared to existing schemes.

title: iAudit: Towards Efficient Pixel-Level Dynamic Image Auditing in Decentralized Storage
authors: Haiyang Yu, Yinglong Gao, Shen Su, Zhen Yang, Yuwen Chen, Shui Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Decentralized storage auditing approaches are designed to ensure data security in dishonest decentralized storage providers. However, the need for data updates introduces new challenges to the design of decentralized storage auditing approaches. Existing approaches can support dynamic auditing for updated files. Unfortunately, they can only deal with block-level updating, which is counter-intuitive and requires conversion from semantic changes to binary changes. Furthermore, existing dynamic auditing approaches require the recalculation of auxiliary auditing information (e.g., auditing authenticators) in data owners, which imposes unnecessary additional burdens on data owners, particularly those with constrained resources in decentralized storage environments. In this paper, we focus on image files and propose iAudit, an efficient pixel-level dynamic image auditing approach in decentralized storage. We first design a novel image authenticator with image pixels for efficient dynamic auditing, which combines convolution operations and polynomial commitment in authenticator construction. Additionally, we build an owner-free dynamic mechanism in dynamic decentralized storage auditing approach by utilizing zero-knowledge proof techniques. In this way, the dynamic operation overheads incurred by auditing can be completely eliminated from the data owners. A prototype of iAudit is implemented, and extensive experimental results demonstrate that iAudit outperforms state-of-the-art works, achieving over a 210× speedup for data owner in dynamic update phase.

title: Too Little Fit, Too Much Demand: A Task–Technology Perspective on Sustainability in Engineering Management_supp2-3646967.docx
authors: Maja Due Kadenic
abstract: The increasing regulatory demands for sustainability pose a significant challenge for engineering management in aligning corporate strategies with practical implementation. This paper investigates how multinational organizations operationalize sustainability directives, focusing on the integration of environmental product declarations within engineering practices and information systems. Employing a 13-month ethnographic case study within the global product lifecycle management (PLM) unit of a large multinational enterprise, we apply task–technology fit (TTF) theory to evaluate the effectiveness of current digital infrastructures, including PLM, enterprise resource planning, and product configuration systems. Our findings highlight a critical misalignment between regulatory sustainability requirements and technological capabilities. Engineering managers often rely on manual processes, because of fragmented data systems and limited automation, resulting in inefficiencies and compliance risks. Sustainability is predominantly defined through customer-driven performance metrics focused on resource efficiency at the deployment stage. It is also shaped by multiple institutional logics, where sales follow a market logic, corporate leadership a reputational or ESG logic, and engineering a technical logic. These differences fragment efforts and limit integration. The study achieved a high level of rigor through methodological triangulation of interviews, observations, documents, and system access, combined with insider–outsider researcher roles and reflexive analysis. We recommend improving interoperability and automation of digital systems to streamline sustainability reporting and compliance, and encourage closer alignment among corporate strategy, technological infrastructure, and engineering practices. This study contributes to the literature by showing why integration challenges persist despite regulatory imperatives and underscores the need for strategic investment in integrated technological solutions.

title: Endpoint Localization of Faint Streak-like Objects in Single-Frame Star Images
authors: Yong Han, Desheng Wen, Jie Li, Zhangchi Qiao, Xin Wei, Tuochi Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Endpoint localization of faint streak-like objects is an important component of space situational awareness. In this study, a correlation-based endpoint localization is proposed. It is composed of coarse localization and fine localization. The mathematical model of correlation is derived and verified, and it is used to select the optimal reference image of endpoints in different localization stages and conditions. Meanwhile, a correlation-coefficient-weighted centroid mapping is proposed to achieve the fine location. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior localization accuracy for faint streak-like objects in single-frame star images while maintaining practical computational efficiency, and maintains robust performance for a peak SNR ≥ 2. Furthermore, validation on real star images confirms the method’s validity and expected performance in practical operation.

title: A Remaining Useful Life Prediction Method of Wet Friction Component Based on Data-model Interactive Framework
authors: Jianpeng Wu, Ao Ding, Pengpeng Li, Heyan Li, Liyong Wang, Shuai Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The reliability of wet clutches is critical to the efficient operation of heavy equipment, as the lifespan of the wet friction component directly impacts the clutch’s stable performance. To accurately predict the remaining useful life (RUL) of wet friction components and to address the overfitting and poor robustness often observed in single models, this study proposes an innovative framework that integrates a neural network with a Wiener process model, thereby establishing a novel data–model interaction architecture. The framework gathers multidimensional degradation data from accelerated life tests and uses Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) to derive a composite health index. Subsequently, the composite health index is modeled using the Wiener Degradation Process (Wiener) to estimate the RUL. An objective function based on the prediction error is then defined, and the Adam algorithm adjusts the framework parameters dynamically to minimize this function and improve the RUL prediction accuracy. The prediction results suggest that the mean relative error (MRE) of this model is only 4.47%, confirming its accuracy. This method provides a more reliable RUL prediction solution for wet friction component based on artificial intelligence.

title: Ferroelectric Memcapacitor on SOI for High Capacitive Ratio by Mechanism of Depletion Capacitance Modulation Toward Dimension Scaling Down
authors: Z.-F. Lou, B.-R. Chen, A. Aich, J.-H. Chen, S. T. Chang, S. Maikap, Pin Su, M. H. Lee
abstract: A C<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">HCS</sub>/C<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">LCS</sub> ratio of 500× for a ferroelectric capacitive memory (FCM) with an SOI substrate has been demonstrated as an ideal synaptic operation achievement. This ratio is a crucial parameter in FCM as it indicates the ability of the memory to store and retrieve data reliably. The modulated depletion region could be expanded laterally due to the spatial restriction in the vertical direction by the SOI to reduce C<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">LCS</sub>; moreover, a low-voltage-based saturation capacitance of double Hf<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1-x</sub>Zr<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> (DHZO) further enhanced C<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">HCS</sub>. For DHZO-SOI FCMs, the outstanding nondestructive read operation (NDRO) was experimentally exhibited with >10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">9</sup> cycles by both devices and readout schemes, α<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">P</sub>/α<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</sub> = -0.25 / +1.55 for synapse. The proposed technique is simulated with a remaining ratio of 73× for pillar FCM scaling to 20nm, a promising concept that benefits the dimension scaling pathway.

title: HUGSIM: A Real-Time, Photo-Realistic and Closed-Loop Simulator for Autonomous Driving
authors: Hongyu Zhou, Longzhong Lin, Jiabao Wang, Yichong Lu, Dongfeng Bai, Bingbing Liu, Yue Wang, Andreas Geiger, Yiyi Liao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: In the past few decades, autonomous driving algorithms have made significant progress in perception, planning, and control. However, evaluating individual components does not fully reflect the performance of entire systems, highlighting the need for more holistic assessment methods. This motivates the development of HUGSIM, a closed-loop, photo-realistic, and real-time simulator for evaluating autonomous driving algorithms. We achieve this by lifting captured 2D RGB images into the 3D space via 3D Gaussian Splatting, improving the rendering quality for closed-loop scenarios, and building the closed-loop environment. In terms of rendering, we tackle challenges of novel view synthesis in closed-loop scenarios, including viewpoint extrapolation and 360-degree vehicle rendering. Beyond novel view synthesis, HUGSIM further enables the full closed simulation loop, dynamically updating the ego and actor states and observations based on control commands. Moreover, HUGSIM offers a comprehensive benchmark across more than 70 sequences from KITTI-360, Waymo, nuScenes, and PandaSet, along with over 400 varying scenarios, providing a fair and realistic evaluation platform for existing autonomous driving algorithms. HUGSIM not only serves as an intuitive evaluation benchmark but also unlocks the potential for fine-tuning autonomous driving algorithms in a photorealistic closed-loop setting.

title: Federated Explainable AI for Privacy-Preserving Cardiovascular Disease Detection Using Wearable Devices
authors: Saad Alammar, Hamad Aldawsari, Abdullah AlSahly, Khalid A. AlGhamdi, Muhammad Attique Khan
abstract: Consumer electronics such as smartwatches, fitness trackers, and IoT-enabled medical devices are at the forefront of next-generation connected healthcare systems when integrated with Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI). These consumer electronics provide transparent, reliable, and patient-centric healthcare when integrated with XAI. Current approaches use centralized AI models that violate data privacy, are non-interpretable, and do not inspire trust in patients. Black-box decision-making further reduces clinical adoption and personalization of interventions in healthcare. In response to these issues, this paper presents a Federated Explainable AI (FedXAI) framework wherein health data is retained on consumer devices and only model updates are shared for collaborative learning. Explainability makes sure that both patients and clinicians understand how AI predictions have been made. The proposed methodology is described for early detection and monitoring of cardiovascular disease using data generated from wearable consumer electronics. Interpretable alerts about irregular heart activity help achieve timely interventions, enhance patient engagement, and support clinical decision-making. Results show FedXAI as an enhancement over existing methods in terms of diagnostic accuracy while keeping data private and increasing trust in an AI-driven healthcare system; thus, it becomes a potential foundation toward future connected healthcare solutions.

title: FluoEcoli-Instance: A High-Content Fluorescence Microscopy Dataset and CBAM-Enhanced Hybrid Task Cascade for E. coli Instance Segmentation
authors: Son T. Huynh, Hai X. Nguyen, Dat Q. Duong, Tien K. Nguyen, Nhi K. P. Nguyen, Hoang Tran Le Nguyen, Phuong N. Vu, Nghi P. G. Nguyen, Khoi D. Vu, Hoa Q. N. Ho, Tuan-Anh Tran, Stephen Baker, Binh T. Nguyen
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) has become a global health crisis, creating an urgent need for rapid and accurate bacterial identification to guide appropriate antibiotic therapy. Automated segmentation of bacteria in microscopic images enables quantitative analysis of cellular morphology and spatial patterns, offering valuable cues for early species recognition. Such image-based insights can accelerate diagnostic decisions and promote rational antibiotic use, ultimately mitigating the impact of AMR. Hence, we present a significantly expanded dataset of E. coli fluorescence images, extending that of Dat et al. [1] with additional samples and refined annotations to better support bacterial segmentation research. We extensively re-examine several popular segmentation models using standardised COCO metrics ($mAP$, $mAP_{0.50}$, $mAP_{0.75}$, $mAP_{\rm{small}}$) and find that methods originally designed for semantic segmentation struggling with instance-level tasks. On the other hand, two-stage detectors, especially Cascade Mask R-CNN [2] and its Hybrid Task Cascade (HTC) [3] variant, perform best when paired with modern backbone networks. In particular, our framework introduces a novel synergy between the ConvNeXtV2-Tiny backbone and the HTC architecture, enhanced by the CBAM [4] attention mechanism (reduction ratio of eight), to achieve superior feature refinement and instance delineation. This configuration sets a new performance benchmark, achieving $mAP_{0.50} = 0.940$, $mAP_{0.75} = 0.882$, $mAP_{\rm{small}} = 0.788$, and $mAP_{0.50:0.95} = 0.787$, and directly supports the development of data-driven, clinically relevant microbial analysis systems that can guide evidence-based and timely antimicrobial treatment strategies.

title: W-band Circularly Polarized Antenna Array with Dual Split Rings and Hexagonal Lattices for Satellite Communication
authors: Changhee Lee, Jin Myeong Heo, Gangil Byun
abstract: This paper proposes a W-band circularly polarized (CP) antenna array utilizing dual split rings and hexagonal lattices for satellite communication (SatCom). The dual split rings are sequentially stacked on top of a multilayer printed circuit board (PCB) and are aperture-coupled by a feeding ring. The magnitude and phase of the induced currents in the dual rings are independently controlled by adjusting the line width and rotation angle to achieve optimal AR performance, while the radius and split gap of the rings determine the resonant frequency. This enables greater flexibility in PCB-based W-band CP antenna design against manufacturing constraints. The feeding ring is excited by a center via post within a hexagonal lattice. The rotational symmetry of this feeding structure facilitates symmetric beam patterns, required for two-dimensional beam steering in SatCom. In addition, via fence surrounding the center via post mitigates mutual coupling caused by surfacewaves. The effectiveness of the proposed design approach is demonstrated by a full-wave numerical simulation and validated through fabrication and measurement. The fabricated 4 × 8 antenna array exhibits VSWR < 2 over 15 GHz (85−100 GHz), a 3-dB axial ratio bandwidth of 2.8 GHz (89.7−92.5 GHz), and a peak right-hand circular polarization gain of 15.7 dBic at 92 GHz. The fabricated array shows beam steering capabilities of ±60° with scan loss up to 4.5 dB at 92 GHz.

title: An iterative algorithm to estimate state of health in Li-ion batteries
authors: Ana Caetano Bochini, Alain Segundo Potts
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries are essential for clean energy technologies, but their performance degrades over time. Accurately estimating their state of health (SoH) as a key indicator of their degradation is crucial for battery management, especially in electric vehicles and battery energy storage systems. There are many studies focused on SoH estimation, from the simplest least squares regression to more sophisticated ones based on data-driven techniques and neural networks. However, higher accuracy means higher complexity and, generally, higher execution time. In this sense, this paper presents an iterative algorithm that estimates the SoH using a cyclic least squares approach. The robustness of the algorithm is mainly based on an iterative process developed for the calculation of the state of charge, performed through the least squares calculation. The algorithm is improved by the use of an optimized extended Kalman filter to estimate the battery parameters and states. The method is tested under various operational conditions, presenting satisfactory results.

title: A Configurable Multi-Purpose Automotive Signal Simulator for ECU Testing and Diagnostic Education
authors: Nguyen Dang Bui Chi, Phat Nguyen Dang Tan, Nhan Nguyen Tam, Tri Dinh Quoc, Quang T.D. Pham, Hung Dinh Nguyen
abstract: This paper details the design and development of a configurable, multi-purpose signal simulation platform for Hardware-In-the-Loop (HIL) testing and diagnostics of automotive Electronic Control Units (ECUs). The system generates a comprehensive suite of high-fidelity signals essential for engine management, including emulating digital crankshaft and camshaft position signals, as well as various analog sensor inputs such as coolant temperature and throttle position. Furthermore, the simulator provides Pulse-Width Modulated (PWM) outputs for the functional testing of actuators like fuel injectors and integrates CAN bus communication to evaluate dashboard instrumentation, offering a holistic approach to ECU verification. Engineered to be compact, portable, and cost-effective, this platform provides an efficient and accessible tool for hands-on diagnostic education and ECU functional testing without requiring a physical engine, bridging the gap between theoretical principles and practical application. (Abstract)

title: A Tool Environment for Relational Database Design
authors: S.V. Zykin, A.A. Zharkikh
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The theory of relational database design is currently well developed and widely known. Moreover, there is a significant number of database structuring tools. The most popular ones are MySQL Workbench, Lucidchart, Micro, Oracle Designer, etc. All these tools involve the use of the theory but do not contribute to it in any way since the design process begins with the formation of database tables and the method of obtaining these tables is ignored. This article aims to solve this problem. The addition of algorithms forming correct relational database relationships to the tool environment will improve the quality of the designer’s work. In the article, the theory is supplemented with modern results and methodological recommendations that contribute to the correct application of the theory in practice.

title: Dynamics of a Gyrostat in a Variable Force Field
authors: Z. V. Morina
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This paper investigates the attitude dynamics of a gyrostat-type spacecraft in a variable gravitational field arising during motion along elliptical orbits, including highly eccentric ones. A mathematical model is developed that takes into account structural asymmetry, an internal rotor, and the displacement of mass centers. A comparison of the system behavior in circular and elliptical orbits is performed. Numerical simulations in Wolfram Mathematica confirm the loss of equilibrium stability with increasing eccentricity. The study is aimed at solving applied problems of analysis and synthesis of attitude control systems for gyrostat-type spacecraft under real operational conditions.

title: Tracking and Localization of an Acoustic Source in the Observed Area Using a Webcam
authors: Jozef Galanda, Michal Hovanec, Samer Al-Rabeei, Edina Jenčová, Gabriel Feketi
abstract: This paper deals with the issue of locating noise sources in an observed area using Eye Tracking technology with a web camera. People tend to automatically move their gaze towards the perceived source of sound; therefore, gaze measurement can be used to quickly, easily, and accurately quantify the ability to locate sound. Eye Tracking is practically applicable to solving this problem. The authors present the implementation of a system for real-time eye detection and gaze tracking, head movement compensation by tracking facial reference points, and signal filtering using the Kalman filter. To demonstrate its usability, an application of solution was created to test the reaction time of the tracked object from the moment the sound source is detected, with three testing modes and a comprehensive data collection system. Based on the measured results, the authors identify the limitations of the implementation and propose possibilities for further development of the implemented system. The findings of this work can be used to improve training programs, improve vehicle control, support economic evaluations of aircraft noise impacts, and raise aviation safety standards in future research.

title: Implementation of the GBAS system as a prospect for increasing the accessibility of regional airports
authors: Diana Majorska, Peter Dzurovcin, Peter Korba, Radoslav Catlos
abstract: This paper investigates the implementation of the Ground-Based Augmentation System (GBAS) at regional airports as a modern alternative to the Instrument Landing System (ILS). The study addresses the growing need to improve safety, capacity, and operational efficiency in line with Performance-Based Navigation (PBN) principles. Using a comparative analysis of ILS, GBAS, and SBAS systems, the research evaluates the technical, economic, and environmental benefits of GBAS, with emphasis on GAST-C and GAST-D service types enabling CAT II/III approaches. A structured implementation framework tailored to regional airports is proposed, reflecting their spatial and economic constraints. The results confirm that GBAS offers substantial improvements in accuracy, cost-effectiveness, and environmental sustainability, making it a key enabler of performance-based and sustainable regional aviation infrastructure.

title: A Quantitative Analysis of the Legacy ATM Financial Model
authors: Marek Košuda, Michaela Stessl, Michaela Stessl, Nofal Kattan
abstract: This paper provides a quantitative analysis of the legacy financial model governing European Air Navigation Service Providers (ANSPs) to establish an empirical baseline for the transition towards a Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA). The research problem centers on the model’s inherent economic characteristics, particularly its cost inelasticity and risk allocation mechanisms, which are poorly understood in a quantitative sense. The methodology involves constructing a mathematical financial model based on the European performance and charging scheme. This model is calibrated and validated using six years (2018-2023) of detailed financial and operational data from a representative national provider, LPS SR of Slovakia. The results of a 7-year simulation (2018-2024) quantify the ANSP’s financial performance, revealing a massive loss in 2020 followed by a sharp, regulation-driven return to profitability in 2022. The discussion analyzes these findings, concluding that the legacy system is defined by regulatory resilience, where financial risk from demand shocks is transferred directly to airspace users, rather than being absorbed by the provider. This analysis demonstrates that a shift to an SOA is not merely a technical change but a fundamental economic transition from a regulated cost-recovery utility to a market-based system where service providers must assume full financial risk.

title: Utilization of Progressive Technologies for Aircraft
authors: Mathias Jouvenat, Mathias Jouvenat, Branislav Rácek, Maroš Divok, Martin Venceľ
abstract: This paper deals with the application of modern digital technologies in the process of initial aircraft concept design. It provides an overview of the individual steps in the conceptualization process, using XFLR5 software, which is intended for aerodynamic modelling and analysis. The main objective of this paper was to develop a concept design for a light aircraft inspired by the recreational aircraft Cessna 172, with a perspective toward utilizing sustainable energy sources for its propulsion system. As part of this process, various aerofoils and planforms were analysed and compared to optimize flight performance and ensure adequate energy efficiency of the proposed aircraft.

title: Geometric Motion-Based Approach to UAV Detection and Localization
authors: Robert Dianovský, Pavol Pecho, Andrej Novák, Ján Rostáš
abstract: The increasing prevalence of small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has created a challenge for airspace security. Existing counter-UAV (CUAS) solutions frequently rely on radar, radio-frequency detection and optical systems, which are often constrained by computationally intensive classifiers. This paper introduces a geometric motion-based algorithm for aerial object detection and localization that avoids reliance on appearance features or machine learning. The method detects motion pixels in video frames, projects them into threedimensional rays using camera calibration data, and estimates object position by intersecting rays from multiple viewpoints. A proof-of-concept experiment was conducted with low-cost commercially available hardware. Tests with a fixed-wing UAV of 1.8 m wingspan confirmed the ability of the system to reconstruct three-dimensional flight trajectories. Additional observations of avian targets and a passenger airplane at cruising altitude illustrated both the generality of the method and its limitations. The results demonstrate that even with low-cost hardware and lightweight computation, geometric motion-based approaches can contribute to UAV detection and airspace awareness.

title: Demo: “DappTweet” A Solution to Use Twitter/X from MetaMask Wallet
authors: Seyed Ahmadreza Abtahi, Reza Abtahi, Bruno Rodrigues, Burkhard Stiller
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: This demo paper presents DappTweet, a Web3 app that lets any blockchain address send posts and direct messages on Twitter/X via a MetaMask wallet using an addressproven posting workflow. A relay account publishes on the user’s behalf and embeds the sender’s address and the transaction hash for public verification. The prototype implements three flows: public post, private message, and verification.

title: Study on Parallel Accelerated Computation of Planetary Orbit Motion
authors: Xuanji Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: The simulation of asteroid orbits requires high-precision numerical integration methods for accuracy. To improve computational efficiency, parallel computing strategies can be introduced during the numerical solution process. In this study, the fourth-order Runge-Kutta method is employed as the numerical integrator, and asteroid orbit simulations are implemented in C++. Three strategies are tested and compared: serial computation, OpenMP parallelism, and MPI parallelism. The efficiency of the GPU parallel strategy is also explored. The experimental results demonstrate that parallel computing significantly reduces runtime compared to serial execution, with OpenMP achieving better performance than MPI. Furthermore, the GPU exhibits a significantly higher speedup than CPU-based parallelism.

title: MSDA-UNet: Multi-Scale Dynamic Attention UNet for Remote Sensing Image Denoising
authors: Qingyang Guan, Chongjin Yang, Bo Shang, Guangze Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Remote sensing images often suffer from low resolution, complex textures, and the presence of multi-scale targets, posing significant challenges for effective denoising. To address these issues, this paper proposes an enhanced denoising network based on the U-Net architecture, termed MSDA-UNet. Firstly, a Bidirectional Cross Attention Module (BiCrossGroup) is introduced to capture global geometric structures and long-range semantic dependencies by leveraging bidirectional spatial perception in both horizontal and vertical directions, combined with a cross-group attention mechanism. Secondly, a Multi-scale Enhancement Module (MEM) is designed, which employs a hybrid structure of parallel atrous convolutions and depthwise separable convolutions to generate discriminative multi-scale features through dynamic receptive field fusion. Finally, a Dynamic Grid Upsampling Module (DyGridUpsample) is incorporated to perform pixel-level spatially adaptive reconstruction via a learnable deformable grid, thereby enhancing the recovery of high-frequency details. Extensive experiments conducted on the NWPU-RESISC45 [7], UCMercedLandUse [8] and OPTIMAL-31 [9] datasets demonstrate that the proposed method consistently surpasses existing mainstream approaches in terms of PSNR and SSIM under high-noise conditions.

title: High-Precision Acoustic Localization System for Smart Cars Using IM68A130 MEMS Microphone Array
authors: Qiyan Zhang, Wensheng Sun, Jiayi Wang, Fengrui Yang, Rui Long, Hao Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: This paper presents a hardware-centric design of an interactive smart car platform, featuring a multi-sensor architecture with MEMS microphone (IM68A130 SN≥65dB), MPU6050 gyroscope, and 512-line mini-encoder for millimeter-level motion control. The system achieves 92% voice recognition accuracy in noisy environments through optimized acoustic localization algorithms. Future extensions include edge-AI deployment with TinyML models on the CYT4 core board and STEAM education integration through project-based curricula. Hardware schematics and pedagogical validation results demonstrate its dual value in engineering innovation and programming education advancement.

title: Enhanced MRCT Strategy for Synchronous Reluctance Motor Without Offline Inductance Preparation
authors: Shih-Gang Chen, Sin-Ruei Lee
abstract: In this study, an enhanced maximum rate of change of torque (EMRCT) strategy is proposed to improve the performance of response for a synchronous reluctance motor (SynRM) drive system in the constant torque region. The conventional maximum rate of change of torque (CMRCT) implementations often depend on offline inductance lookup tables and complex preprocessing to define the optimal current angle trajectory for the maximum rate of change of torque (MRCT) solution. In contrast, the proposed strategy achieves the MRCT condition by using a proportional-integral (PI) MRCT controller, which directly regulates the EMRCT error from EMRCT index. This EMRCT strategy using a PI MRCT controller eliminates the need for multidimensional inductance tables, significantly reducing control complexity and memory usage. The proposed strategy is validated on a floating-point digital signal processor, and experimental results confirm that it delivers robust, efficient performance under constant torque region without any offline inductance preparation.

title: A Hybrid Modulation Strategy for Asymmetric Half-Bridge Flyback Converters with Wide-Output Voltage Range
authors: Sheng-Yuan Ou, Jhe-Jyun Ho, Ming-Wei Tsai, Cheng-Yu Tang
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid modulation strategy for asymmetric half-bridge (AHB) flyback converters with wide output voltage range. Traditionally, the pulse-widthmodulation (PWM) technique with duty cycle modulation is adopted for the AHB converter. However, under the PD3.1 specification with the wide output voltage range feature, conventional PWM control methods might fail. Therefore, a hybrid modulation strategy for AHB flyback converters is proposed in this paper. The pulse-wide-modulation (PWM), the pulse-frequency-modulation (PFM) and the burst mode control are integrated and developed for the hybrid control. With the proposed approach, the AHB converter with wide output voltage range can easily be realized without complex control mechanisms. Besides, the soft-switching feature can be achieved under different control modes to ensure the high circuit efficiency. The developed control strategy can be realized by microcontrollers without adding extra circuit or components. Finally, a 240 W prototype circuit with hardware experiments that demonstrate the performance and feasibility of the proposed strategy.

title: Design and Implementation of Four-Phase TransInductor Voltage Regulator with Constant On-Time Control
authors: Xuan-Thang Le, Tsorng-Juu Liang, Pei-Wen Li, Kai-Hui Chen, Ching-Ya Chien
abstract: Traditional multiphase buck converters used in high-speed computational processors suffer from poor transient response. The Trans-Inductor Voltage Regulator (TLVR) improves the current slew rate by coupling inductors and adding a compensating inductor $L_{c}$, enabling simultaneous phase response during load changes. This research introduces conventional non-isolated multi-phase buck converter topologies and control methods, presents the operating principle and steady state characteristics of TLVR, and steadystate and transient characteristics of TLVR under constant ontime (COT) control methods are discussed. Then, the impact on magnetizing and compensating inductors on TLVR’s transient response are analyzed and key parameters design procedures are proposed. Finally, an experimental TLVR prototype is implemented with 12 V input voltage, 2.5 V output voltage, 150 kHz switching frequency, and 200 W rated power achieves highest efficiency $\mathbf{9 1. 2 \%}$ under $\mathbf{1 2 0 W}$ load and $\mathbf{8 9. 7 \%}$ at full load.

title: Integrating Generative AI and Immersive Technologies in the Metaverse: Enhancing Learning Experiences through Intelligent Educational Environments
authors: Antonio Juarez, Jordi Rabago, Lesly Pliego, Gabriela Salazar, Tomas Pachajoa, Carlos Hinrichsen, Marietta Castro
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: This study examines the integration of generative artificial intelligence (AI) tools and immersive technologies within metaverse-based higher education environments, framed by established learning science theories on student engagement [8]–[10]. Specifically, it investigates how the application of large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT, MidJourney, and Leonardo AI, combined with Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR), influences vigor, dedication, and absorption in design learning. The research was conducted within the Tec Virtual Campus, a structured metaverse environment, involving 87 undergraduate architecture and design students in interdisciplinary projects. A mixed-methods approach was employed, combining pre- and post-intervention surveys using the Utrecht Work Engagement Scale (UWES-S-9) and qualitative thematic analysis of student reflections. Statistical results revealed significant improvements (p < 0.01) in all UWES-S-9 subscales, with large effect sizes for dedication (d = 0.88) and medium-to-large effects for vigor (d = 0.76) and absorption (d = 0.73). Qualitative findings showed that GenAI tools supported creative ideation, narrative development, and the overcoming of creative blocks, while immersive validation in VR/AR enhanced spatial iteration and experiential design quality. This paper contributes by (1) offering a detailed methodological account of AI/XR integration in metaverse-based courses, (2) grounding the approach in engagement and experiential learning theories [8]–[10], and (3) providing empirical evidence of its positive impact on creativity and spatial competencies. Limitations include the absence of a control group, the lack of direct performance-based spatial assessments, and the manual, non-structured use of AI prompts. Future work should explore comparative studies with control conditions, advanced prompt engineering, and longitudinal tracking of learning outcomes.

title: Research on Communication Signal Recognition based on CNN-LSTM Neural Networks
authors: Zhaolin Wen, Yupeng Wang, Guoyu Li, Yu Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: This paper addresses the issue of degraded accuracy in traditional communication signal recognition under low Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) environments by proposing a Convolutional Neural Network and Long Short-Term Memory hybrid network (CNN-LSTM) architecture that jointly leverages spatiotemporal features for signal identification. Conventional CNN models in low-SNR scenarios tend to overemphasize localized spectral features while neglecting temporal dynamic characteristics of signals, whereas standalone LSTM struggles to effectively extract spatial structural patterns in frequency spectra. To resolve this, spatial feature abstraction is performed on the amplitude/phase two-dimensional distribution of FFT spectra through CNN convolutional and pooling layers, capturing distinctive frequency-domain characteristics of modulated signals. Simultaneously, LSTM gated mechanisms model temporal dependencies between signal segments to extract phase continuity characteristics during symbol transitions. This approach effectively mitigates feature ambiguity caused by noise interference in low-SNR conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed joint modeling strategy achieves a 19.2% improvement in recognition accuracy for QPSK and 16QAM signals at 0dB SNR compared to standalone CNN models, validating the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: The Influence of Social Media on Collaboration in a Work From Home Environment with Technology Acceptance Model
authors: Christian Jones Pamuhardjo, Edbert Kifli, Stephanie Surja
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: The increase in people working from home has created new challenges for companies to keep teams working together effectively. Even though some studies have looked at digital tools used in remote work, there hasn’t been much research on how social media helps with team collaboration. This study addresses that by using the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and the SEM-PLS Purposive Sampling Method to examine how social media supports teamwork in remote settings. The research included a survey with 406 valid responses from students at Binus University in the Jabodetabek area. The study looks at five key factors that is Social Identification (SI), Perceived Usefulness (PU), Online Knowledge Sharing Behavior (KS), Continuance Intention (CI), and Work From Home (WFH). The findings show that social media improves communication, knowledge sharing, and how well teams work together when they’re not in the same place. This research is special because it uses TAM in the context of social media and teamwork, adding to theory about technology use and giving practical advice to companies that want to improve how they manage remote work.

title: A Comparative Study of SVM and CNN for Pneumonia Detection from Radiographic Images: Computational Efficiency and Diagnostic Precision
authors: Nina Sevani, Seruni, Jennifer Budi Muljono, Sanders D. Kean, Rita Wiryasaputra
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) have emerged as powerful artificial intelligence (AI) tools for disease detection, including pneumonia, offering advantages in accuracy and speed. This study compares two approaches: Support Vector Machine (SVM) as a machine learning model and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) as a deep learning model, for binary classification of chest X-ray images into pneumonia or normal condition. Preprocessing techniques were applied to enhance image quality before model training. Model performances were evaluated with several metrics such as precision, recall, F1-score, confusion matrices and training time. Experimental results demonstrated that CNN achieved superior average accuracy with a value of 88% compared to SVM model that only receives 83% in accuracy. The SVM model performed optimally with a poly kernel, yielding the best confusion matrix results and faster training time. In contrast, CNN required larger epoch values and longer training duration to achieve high accuracy. This work highlights the trade-offs between computational efficiency and accuracy for pneumonia detection. Future research involves increasing the size of the training/testing dataset and increasing the power of this model to classify grades of pneumonia severity.

title: Understanding Code Smell Detection Through Hyperparameter Optimization and Metric Correlation Analysis
authors: Marcela Mosquera, Rodolfo Bojorque, Pamela Flores
abstract: Hyperparameter optimization plays a pivotal role in the reliability and generalization of machine-learning models for software quality prediction. This paper presents a comparative evaluation of three search strategies: Grid Search, Random Search, and a Hybrid approach applied to the detection of four types of code smells (BLOB, Functional Decomposition, Spaghetti Code, and Swiss Army Knife). Experiments were performed on three open-source Java systems (Azureus, ArgoUML, and Xerces) using Support Vector Machines (SVMs). The results show that all three strategies produce consistent patterns in accuracy and F1-score across the datasets, confirming the robustness of the evaluation framework. Simultaneously, Random Search tends to achieve higher recall for the Functional Decomposition smell, reflecting its ability to explore sparse and irregular hyperparameter spaces. The Hybrid approach combines the exploratory strength of Random Search with the local refinement of Grid Search, offering greater stability with a moderate computational cost. A correlation analysis of software metrics further reveals that while the Blob smell is consistently associated with size and coupling indicators, the other smells—Functional Decomposition, Spaghetti Code, and Swiss Army Knife are captured more indirectly through general structural proxies such as size, cohesion, and coupling. Overall, these findings suggest that hyperparameter tuning not only enhances predictive performance but also provides valuable insights into the structural factors underlying code smells.

title: HGNNMDA: Hybrid Graph Neural Networks for MiRNA-Disease Association Prediction
authors: Nguyen-Phuc-Xuan Quynh, Hoai-Nhan Tran, Cheng Yan, Jianxin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Molecular, Biological, and Multi-Scale Communications
abstract: MicroRNAs are key biomarkers and therapeutic targets due to their role in regulating biological processes and disease progression. Traditional identification of miRNA-disease associations (MDAs) is costly and slow, motivating computational approaches. In this study, we propose HGNNMDA, a hybrid prediction model applying graph neural networks (GNNs) for predicting MDAs. The key novelty of HGNNMDA lies in its interactive dual-branch architecture, where each branch integrates both graph convolutional networks (GCNs) and graph attention networks (GATs) to extract robust features from diverse biological data sources. This design generates complementary feature representations by leveraging GCNs to capture structural associations through neighborhood aggregation, while employing GATs to prioritize the most relevant interactions via attention mechanisms, effectively overcoming limitations of single-architecture GNNs. The obtained feature vectors are then processed by XGBoosts to generate predictive scores, which are subsequently combined for final predictions. HGNNMDA outperforms seven recent methods in experimental validation on three datasets (HMDD v2.0, HMDD v3.2, and an independent dataset) and shows strong results in de novo validation and case studies. The source code in this work is available at https://github.com/npxquynhdhsp/HGNNMDA/.

title: An On-Chip Pixel Processing Approach With 2.4-μs Latency for Asynchronous Read-Out of SPAD-Based dToF Flash LiDARs
authors: Yiyang Liu, Rongxuan Zhang, Istvan Gyongy, Alistair Gorman, Sarrah M. Patanwala, Filip Taneski, Robert K. Henderson
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: We propose a fully asynchronous peak detection approach for SPAD-based direct Time-of-Flight (dToF) flash LiDAR, enabling pixel-wise event-driven depth acquisition without global synchronization. By allowing pixels to independently report depth once a sufficient signal-to-noise ratio is achieved, the method reduces latency, mitigates motion blur, and increases effective data rate compared to frame-based systems. The framework is validated under two hardware implementations: an offline <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$256\times 128$</tex-math> </inline-formula> SPAD array with PC based processing and a real-time FPGA proof-of-concept prototype with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.4\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>s latency for on-chip integration. Experiments demonstrate robust depth estimation, reflectivity reconstruction, and dynamic event-based representation under both static and dynamic conditions. The results confirm that asynchronous operation reduces redundant background data and computational load, while remaining tunable via simple hyperparameters. These findings establish a foundation for compact, low-latency, event-driven LiDAR architectures suited to robotics, autonomous driving, and consumer applications. In addition, we have derived a semi-closed-form solution for the detection probability of the raw-peak finding based LiDAR systems that could benefit both conventional frame-based and proposed asynchronous LiDAR systems.

title: Perceiving Slope and Acceleration: Evidence for Variable Tempo Sampling in Pitch-Based Sonification of Functions_supp1-3633835.mp4
authors: Danyang Fan
abstract: Sonification offers a non-visual way to understand data, with pitch-based encodings being the most common. Yet, how well people perceive slope and acceleration—key features of data trends—remains poorly understood. Drawing on people's natural abilities to perceive tempo, we introduce a novel sampling method for pitch-based sonification to enhance the perception of slope and acceleration in univariate functions. While traditional sonification methods often sample data at uniform x-spacing, yielding notes played at a fixed tempo with variable pitch intervals (Variable Pitch Interval), our approach samples at uniform y-spacing, producing notes with consistent pitch intervals but variable tempo (Variable Tempo). We conducted psychoacoustic experiments to understand slope and acceleration perception across three sampling methods: Variable Pitch Interval, Variable Tempo, and a Continuous (no sampling) baseline. In slope comparison tasks, Variable Tempo was more accurate than the other methods when modulated by the magnitude ratio between slopes. For acceleration perception, just-noticeable differences under Variable Tempo were over 13 times finer than with other methods. Participants also commonly reported higher confidence, lower mental effort, and a stronger preference for Variable Tempo compared to other methods. This work contributes models of slope and acceleration perception across pitch-based sonification techniques, introduces Variable Tempo as a novel and preferred sampling method, and provides promising initial evidence that leveraging timing can lead to more sensitive, accurate, and precise interpretation of derivative-based data features.

title: EC-Net: A Data-driven Positioning Error Compensation Network for GNSS-Visual-Inertial Navigation System during GNSS Outages
authors: Xiaotong Wang, Haonan Jiang, Yuanli Cai, Yifan Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Global navigation satellite system (GNSS) outages present a significant challenge for the global positioning of autonomous vehicles. In this paper, we propose a data-driven position error compensation method to enhance the positioning accuracy of GNSS-visual-inertial navigation system (GVINS) during GNSS outages. First, we introduce the equivalent inertial navigation system (E-INS), which is an abstraction of sensors such as cameras and inertial measurement units (IMUs) that only have localization capabilities, along with their measurement processing workflows. E-INS is employed to address the challenges posed by the differences in data modalities and measurement frequencies between cameras and IMUs. These differences complicate the design of the neural network. Subsequently, we design an error compensation network (EC-Net). It constructs a mapping between vehicle states and navigation data, enabling compensation of positioning solutions based on historical data when the GNSS signal is unavailable. EC-Net is built using stacked convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and gated recurrent units (GRUs) to effectively capture the spatiotemporal information in vehicle navigation sequences and suppress noise interference from low-cost sensors. Additionally, we utilize a trigonometric function-based Euler angle representation method to process the input features of EC-Net. It avoids the discontinuities at boundaries inherent in radian representations. The experimental results based on public datasets and real-world scenarios demonstrate that, compared to five other widely used methods, our proposed method achieves the highest accuracy during GNSS outages of up to five minutes. This effectively validates the performance of our approach.

title: Robust Event-Triggered $H_{\infty}$ Output Feedback Cooperative Control Strategy for Microgrid Frequency Control under Channel Fading
authors: Chen-Guang Wei, Xing-Chen Shangguan, Yong He, Chuan-Ke Zhang, Xin Yin
abstract: Microgrids (MGs) rely on open communication networks for frequency control to maintain power balance, while channel fading caused by issues such as time delays and packet losses deteriorates system control performance and stability. This degradation severely compromises the safe operation of MGs. The low inertia of the MG and the high volatility of renewable energy sources (RESs) increase the difficulty of MG frequency control. In this article, for the frequency control system (FCS) of MGs under the influence of channel fading, a cooperative control strategy combining secondary frequency control (SFC) and virtual inertia control (VIC) based on an event-triggering mechanism is proposed. First, an MG FCS incorporating a virtual synchronous generator under the influence of channel fading is established. Afterward, using Lyapunov theory and stochastic analysis methods, sufficient conditions are derived to assess the stability and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_{\infty}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> performance of the system under an event-triggered mechanism. Next, the controller gains of cooperative control between the SFC and VIC are obtained by constructing and solving linear matrix inequalities through matrix transformation. Finally, the efficacy of the proposed cooperative control strategy, which integrates SFC and VIC, is rigorously validated through both simulation and experimental testing. This strategy effectively enhances the ability of low-rotational-inertia MGs to handle sudden load changes and RES fluctuations during frequency control, while strengthening their robustness against communication interference.

title: A Threshold-Triggered Deep Q-Network-Based Framework for Self-Healing in Autonomic Software-Defined IIoT-Edge Networks
authors: Agrippina Mwangi, León Navarro-Hilfiker, Lukasz Brewka, Mikkel Gryning, Elena Fumagalli, Madeleine Gibescu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Stochastic disruptions such as flash events arising from benign traffic bursts and switch thermal fluctuations are major contributors to intermittent service degradation in software-defined industrial networks. These events violate IEC 61850-derived quality of service requirements and user-defined service-level agreements, hindering the reliable and timely delivery of control, monitoring, and best-effort traffic in IEC 61400-25-compliant wind power plants. Failure to maintain these requirements often results in delayed or lost control signals, reduced operational efficiency, and increased risk of wind turbine generator downtime. To address these challenges, this study proposes a threshold-triggered Deep Q-Network self-healing agent that autonomically detects, analyzes, and mitigates network disruptions while adapting routing behavior and resource allocation in real time. The proposed agent was trained, validated, and tested on an emulated tri-clustered switch network deployed in a cloud-based proof-of-concept testbed. Simulation results show that the proposed agent improves disruption recovery performance by 53.84% compared to a baseline shortest-path and load-balanced routing approach, and outperforms state-of-the-art methods, including the Adaptive Network-based Fuzzy Inference System by 13.1% and the Deep Q-Network and Traffic Prediction-based Routing Optimization method by 21.5%, in a super-spine leaf data-plane architecture. Additionally, the agent maintains switch thermal stability by proactively initiating external rack cooling when required. These findings highlight the potential of deep reinforcement learning in building resilience in software-defined industrial networks deployed in mission-critical, time-sensitive application scenarios.

title: Delay-Doppler Diversity Analysis of ODDM Modulation in Satellite Communication Systems
authors: Yu Liu, Cunhua Pan, Tantao Gong, Yinlu Wang, Ming Chen
abstract: Orthogonal delay-Doppler division multiplexing (ODDM) modulation offers a promising solution to the problem of severe Doppler effects in low earth orbit (LEO) satellites communications. It has been suggested in the recent literature that ODDM modulation can extract full delay-Doppler (DD) diversity, yet a rigorous analysis has not been presented. In this paper, we present a formal analysis of the DD diversity achieved by ODDM modulation along with supporting simulations. Specifically, the analysis and simulations reveal that the asymptotic DD diversity order of ODDM modulation is one, and this order is achieved at lower bit error rate (BER) values for increased frame sizes. We also present low-complexity detector for ODDM modulation based on the Orthogonal approximate message passing (OAMP) algorithm, and show that this detector extracts full DD diversity with the reduced complexity.

title: Investigation on Non-Uniform Teeth Application in Counter-Rotating Axial-Flux Hybrid-Excitation Permanent Magnet Machine With Low Cogging Torque
authors: Chenxi Xia, Yaojing Feng, Bo Long, Jiangtao Yang, Shoudao Huang
abstract: The counter-rotating axial-flux hybrid-excitation permanent magnet (PM) machine is a novel power device specifically designed for counter-rotating propeller (CRP) systems. Cogging torque (CT) can induce vibrations and noise, adversely affecting its dynamic performance and stealth characteristics, necessitating strict suppression. However, the variable-flux and consequent-pole (CP) structure obscure the characteristics of the CT, leading to a lack of a clear theoretical basis for its suppression. To address this challenge, this paper investigates CT suppression in the counter-rotating axial-flux hybrid-excitation PM machines using non-uniform teeth (NUT) and comprehensively analyzes the implementation consequences. Firstly, a general CT model of the counter-rotating axial-flux hybrid-excitation PM machine is established, and the fundamental principles of NUT are derived. Subsequently, the constraints required to achieve a beneficial effect while preventing phase-phase asymmetry are proposed. Furthermore, the impact of the proposed method on the electromagnetic performance of counter-rotating axial-flux hybrid-excitation PM machine is examined, leading to the formulation of optimal angle allocation principles and recalculation of the winding factor. Finally, theoretical analysis is validated through experimental results, demonstrating that the research work effectively guides the application of NUT and enhances the robustness of counter-rotating axial-flux hybrid-excitation PM machine in CRP drive systems.

title: Asymptotic State Regulation of Fully Actuated Systems With Time-Varying Parameters and Perturbed Input Matrices
authors: Shiyu Zhang, Guangren Duan
abstract: Asymptotic state regulation of fully actuated systems (FASs) with time-varying unknown parameters, perturbed input matrices, and nonlinear uncertainties is considered. Compared to the closely related results on FASs with time-varying parameters, the requirement that the time-varying parameters are differentiable and the assumptions imposed on their derivatives in those works are no longer needed in this article, which means that many types of time-varying parameters that were difficult to handle by previous methods, such as those that are continuous and bounded but not differentiable, can now be handled. Furthermore, inspired by the congelation of variables method, a novel robust adaptive method is proposed, which achieves the global asymptotic convergence of the state variables instead of the global boundedness obtained in previous methods, and guarantees the global boundedness of the estimation. In the developed controller, the adaptive part compensates for time-varying parameters, and the robust part overcomes the effects of incomplete compensation and other remaining uncertainties. Moreover, a parallel extension of the developed method to the disturbed case and a discussion on parameter selection are given. Finally, the proposed method is successfully applied to the control of resonant circuit systems and Norrbin ship steering systems.

title: GuidedMorph: Two-Stage Deformable Registration for Breast MRI
authors: Yaqian Chen, Hanxue Gu, Haoyu Dong, Qihang Li, Yuwen Chen, Nicholas Konz, Lin Li, Maciej A. Mazurowski
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurately registering breast MR imagesfrom different time points enables the alignment of anatomical structures and tracking of tumor progression, sup porting more effective breast cancer detection, diagnosis, and treatment planning. However, the complexity of dense tissue and its highly non-rigid nature pose challenges for conventional registration methods, which primarily focus on aligning general structures while overlooking intricate internal details. To address this, we propose GuidedMorph, a novel two-stage registration framework designed to better align dense tissue. In addition to a single-scale network for global structure alignment, we introduce a framework that utilizes dense tissue information to track breast movement. The learned transformation fields are fused by introducing the Dual Spatial Transformer Network (DSTN), improving overall alignment accuracy. A novel warping method based on the Euclidean distance transform (EDT) is also proposed to accurately warp the registered dense tissue and breast masks, preserving fine structural details during deformation. It also operates effectively with the VoxelMorph and TransMorph backbones, offering a versatile solution for breast registration. We validate our method on ISPY2 and internal dataset, demonstrating superior performance in dense tissue, overall breast alignment, and breast structural similarity index measure (SSIM), with notable improvements by over 20.9% in dense tissue Dice, 2.1% in breast Dice, and 3.5% in breast SSIM compared to the best baseline. The code is available at https://github.com/mazurowski-lab/GuidedMorph.git

title: Cooperative Double IRS Aided Secure Communication for MIMO-OFDM Systems
authors: Weijie Xiong, Jingran Lin, Di Jiang, Yuhan Zhang, Kai Zhong, Qiang Li, Cunhua Pan
abstract: Cooperative double intelligent reflecting surface (double-IRS) has emerged as a promising approach for enhancing physical layer security (PLS) in MIMO systems. However, existing studies are limited to narrowband scenarios and fail to address wideband MIMO-OFDM. In this regime, frequency-flat IRS phases and cascaded IRS links cause severe coupling, rendering narrowband designs inapplicable. To overcome this challenge, we introduce cooperative double-IRS-assisted wideband MIMO-OFDM and propose an efficient manifold-based solution. By regarding the power and constant modulus constraints as Riemannian manifolds, we reformulate the non-convex secrecy sum rate maximization as an unconstrained optimization on a product manifold. Building on this formulation, we further develop a product Riemannian gradient descent (PRGD) algorithm with guaranteed stationary convergence. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme effectively resolves the OFDM coupling issue and achieves significant secrecy rate gains, outperforming single-IRS and distributed multi-IRS benchmarks by 32.0% and 22.3%, respectively.
