title: Problem Statement Parameters Optimization of the Magnetic System of a Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine
authors: N.V. Zakharova, D.V. Zirnit, A.A. Tatevosyan, A.S. Tatevosyan
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: Advances in the development of hard magnetic materials based on rare earth metals (REM) and alloys, along with the expansion of product range and reduction in cost, are driving the development of low-speed synchronous permanent magnet machines (PMSM) as part of high-tech electrical engineering complexes. The absence of energy consumption on magnetic flow excitation and the focus on achieving maximum specific performance indicators across a wide range of practical applications make the use of PMSM as electromechanical energy converters in electrical engineering complexes economically attractive. However, a motion transmission and conversion mechanism in electrical engineering complexes creates an insurmountable barrier to improving their energy efficiency and reliability. This article presents an example of optimizing a magnetic system design of a linear magnetoelectric motor as part of a single-stage piston compressor drive. Expressions for independent variables determining the mass and dimensional parameters of the linear magnetoelectric motor are derived. The magnetic field is studied, and the electromagnetic traction force is calculated with application software.

title: Simulation Model for Estimating Battery State of Charge
authors: Martin Schrötter, Levente Kovács, Ladislav Főző, Rudolf Andoga
abstract: The article discusses methods suitable for estimating the State of Charge (SOC) of batteries used in small Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs). The aim of the article is to construct a simple simulation model, based on a real battery, that can describe the battery with sufficient accuracy and enable estimation of its SOC. The inner resistance of the real battery was obtained through laboratory measurements. To improve the accuracy of the battery model, the Parameter Estimation Toolbox in MATLAB/Simulink was used.

title: Analysis of Security Check Load at Košice Airport
authors: Peter Košcák, Karolína Hrešková, Martina Košcáková
abstract: The article deals with security checks carried out at the airport. The work includes an overview of security checks, types of security checks, items excluded from transport, and security staff. After defining individual terms, the article deals with the development of an analysis to determine the estimated number of passengers who must be checked by security staff at Košice Airport. Finally, we define recommendations for possible assistance in the security checks of passengers departing from Košice Airport.

title: Validating Sustainable Atmospheric Profiling for Future Unmanned Aerial Systems Integration
authors: Aurél Sabó, Maximilián Kupec, Matúš Grega
abstract: This paper presents an independent validation experiment focused on a low-cost, sustainable method for collecting atmospheric data, with potential applications in education and training of unmanned aerial system operators within a training organization. The experiment utilizes a recycled Vaisala RS41-SGP radiosonde, which is planned to be integrated in the future with a certified commercial unmanned aerial system platform, enabling efficient acquisition of detailed atmospheric profiles for simulation and real-world training scenarios. The primary objective is to compare measured temperature, humidity, and pressure values with reference data from a professional Vaisala DigiCORA radiosonde operated by the Slovak Hydrometeorological Authority. The methodology involves a tandem flight of both the recycled and reference radiosonde to ensure robust validation under real-world conditions. Data analysis focuses on quantifying deviations, calculating Root Mean Square Error, and assessing correlations to demonstrate the reliability of the proposed solution, which is critical for evaluating environmental impacts on aviation operations and training. The paper’s findings suggest that this methodology offers a cost-effective alternative for ad-hoc measurements of vertical atmospheric profiles, essential for optimizing UAV training flights, supporting simulation environments, and enhancing the accuracy of meteorological data for training purposes. Meteorological expertise is crucial for interpreting and applying these data in training contexts.

title: Towards the Technical Integration of Vestibular Training for Pilots: Conceptual Design of a Multiaxial Flight Simulation System for Vestibular Illusion Training
authors: Vladimir Socha, Daniel Urban, Stanislav Kusmirek, Lenka Hanáková, Tomas Havel, Lubos Socha
abstract: Spatial disorientation continues to pose a major threat to aviation safety, yet civil pilot training syllabi address vestibular illusions only at the theoretical level. This study presents the conceptual design of a multiaxial aerotrim-based flight simulator developed to provide controlled induction of critical illusions, including the somatogravic, somatogyral, and Coriolis illusions. The system employs unrestricted angular motion in yaw, pitch, and roll, combined with immersive virtual reality, to reproduce illusion-specific motion profiles validated in prior experimental research. Unlike conventional Full Flight Simulators or FNPT devices, which are constrained by motion cueing algorithms and high operational costs, the proposed design offers a technically feasible and economically accessible solution capable of delivering reproducible and safe training scenarios. From a regulatory perspective, the simulator’s modular architecture allows for scalable certification pathways ranging from Other Training Device and Basic Instrument Training Device to FNPT I/II, and potentially Full Flight Simulator, depending on the integrated flight model fidelity. The approach not only addresses a critical training gap but also ensures compatibility with existing instructional frameworks, supporting seamless integration into approved syllabi. By enabling systematic and practical exposure to vestibular illusions, the proposed system bridges the gap between methodological readiness and technical feasibility, thereby strengthening pilot training.

title: A Prototype for Privacy-preserving and Compliant Offline CBDC Transactions
authors: Panagiotis Michalopoulos, Anthony Mack, Cameron Clark, Linus Chen, Johannes Sedlmeir, Andreas Veneris
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: The emergence of blockchain technology has spawned a broader discussion of designs for digital currencies, with Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) - digital forms of fiat currency - being one of them. An important feature of digital currencies is facilitating transactions without network connectivity, which can enhance the scalability of cryptocurrencies and the privacy of CBDC users. However, in the case of CBDCs, this characteristic also introduces new regulatory challenges, particularly when it comes to applying established Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT) frameworks. This paper introduces a prototype for offline digital currency payments, equally applicable to cryptocurrencies and CBDCs, that leverages Secure Elements and digital credentials to address the tension of offline payment support with regulatory compliance. Performance evaluation results suggest that the prototype can be flexibly adapted to different regulatory environments, with a transaction latency comparable to reallife commercial payment systems. Furthermore, we conceptualize how the integration of Zero-Knowledge Proofs into our design could accommodate various tiers of enhanced privacy protection.

title: NEMO: Faster Parallel Execution for Highly Contended Blockchain Workloads
authors: François Ezard, Can Umut Ileri, Jérémie Decouchant
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Following the design of more efficient blockchain consensus algorithms, the execution layer has emerged as the new performance bottleneck of blockchains, especially under high contention. Current parallel execution frameworks either rely on optimistic concurrency control (OCC) or on pessimistic concurrency control (PCC), both of which see their performance decrease when workloads are highly contended, albeit for different reasons. In this work, we present NEMO, a new blockchain execution engine that combines OCC with the object data model to address this challenge. NEMO introduces three core innovations: (i) a greedy commit rule for transactions that do not use shared objects; (ii) refined handling of dependencies to reduce re-executions; and (iii) the use of incomplete but statically derivable read/write hints to guide execution. Through simulated execution experiments, we demonstrate that NEMO significantly reduces redundant computation and achieves higher throughput than representative approaches. For example, with $\mathbf{1 6}$ workers nemo’s throughput is up to $42 \%$ higher than the one of BlockSTM, the state-of-the-art OCC approach, and 61% higher than the pessimistic concurrency control baseline used.

title: Design and Implementation of a High-Torque Testbench for Pneumatic CVT in EVs
authors: Quang Le Thanh, Dat Ly Vinh, Phuc Le Thanh, Phu Tran Long, Quy Nguyen Dinh, Quy Tran Huu
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a dynamic measurement testbench for a pneumatic Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT) system. The proposed setup is developed to comparatively assess the performance advantages of Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSMs) when integrated with a pneumatic CVT, as opposed to conventional motor types such as induction machines. The system incorporates a high-torque dual-chain coupling to ensure reliable torque transmission, high-resolution encoders for accurate rotational speed measurements, INA240-based current sensing circuits for enhanced rejection of PWM switching noise, and an eddy current brake for load emulation and torque evaluation. The PMSM is controlled using Field-Oriented Control (FOC), implemented through an IGBT inverter driven by an STM32 microcontroller. In contrast, the induction motor is operated via a standard inverter with RS485 communication interface. Preliminary experimental results demonstrate that the PMSM configuration yields faster dynamic response, more stable torque output, and improved overall efficiency under identical load conditions compared to the induction motor configuration.

title: Orbital Angular Momentum Multiplexing Metasurface with Tunable Orders
authors: Bo Hu, Feng Qi, Yelong Wang, Nairui Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: This paper proposes a reconfigurable intelligent transmissive metasurface for orbital angular momentum (OAM) multiplexing with tunable orders. A 1-bit transmissive intelligent reconfigurable metasurface with a size of 10×10 operating in the Ka-band is designed. This work analyzes the transmission mechanism of vortex multiplexed beams carrying arbitrary opposite topological charges, and develops an OAM multiplexing tuning scheme based on the reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) with a shared aperture. Simulation results show that the combined purity of the tunable OAM multiplexing modes generated by the metasurface exceeds 71%, and the isolation between modes is close to -17 dB. This verifies that the OAM metasurface can not only provide reliable transmission performance for vortex multiplexed beams but also adjust the OAM multiplexing order. This work provides an effective solution for improving the spatial utilization efficiency of overlapping propagation directions, and provides a new degree of freedom for OAM multiplexing technology.

title: A Method for Assessing Environmental Impacts of Business Processes
authors: Mario Cortes-Cornax, Agnès Front, Raquel Oliveira, Claudia Roncancio
abstract: Six of the nine planetary boundaries have already been crossed, and pressure on most of them continues to rise. This urgent situation calls for a critical examination of our lifestyles to minimize the environmental impact as much as possible. In this paper, we focus on information systems' governance. We propose a method aimed at supporting a systemic approach that enables organizations to control and continuously improve their environmental performance through their business processes. We propose a generic solution that analyzes all utilized resources by considering their environmental impacts using a life cycle-based approach. To facilitate this, we extend the BPMN meta-model by incorporating several environment-related concepts, allowing for the development of environmentally-aware business processes. A prototype demonstrating key features of our approach is also introduced.

title: Continuous Sequencing for Suppressing Rapid Current Increase over Ground Coil Seams in Dynamic Wireless Power Transfer Systems
authors: Hiroshi Kasai, Ryosuke Ota, Keiichiro Kondo
abstract: In dynamic wireless transfer (DWPT) systems with series-series (SS) compensation, the active ground coil sections must be switched according to the position of the onboard coil. Closely laying the ground coil sections together and appropriately switching them ensures that the onboard coil is always coupled with one or two of the ground coils. However, switching the sections may lead to a sharp drop in transmission power due to the sudden transition of the operating point of the circuits. This paper proposes a sequencing method for transmitting power continuously while going over a ground coil seam. Shifting the timing of switching the ground coil sections and operating the two ground coils before and after the seam while the onboard coil is over the seam makes the transition of the operating point gradual. This prevents a drop in transmission power. Besides, transmitting power with two ground coils improves the transmission efficiency compared to transmitting power with only one ground coil. By conducting the scale-down experiment, it is confirmed that switching the operating mode has little effect on power transmission and that the maximum current through crossing the seam is reduced from 19A to 12A.

title: Measurement of the Iron Loss in a DAB Converter for the Transformer with Non-Unity Turns Ratio
authors: Yu-Chen Su, Keiji Wada
abstract: This paper attempts to investigate approaches for measuring the iron loss within a dual-active-bridge (DAB) converter, especially when the transformer with non-unity turns ratio is applied. The regenerative DAB converter is utilized to estimate the transformer under test, which is back-to-back connected to another identical transformer, for the purpose of using the same two power converters on both sides. With the help of power regeneration, the power supply needs only to cover the power loss rather than the power rating, thus reducing the burden of experimental equipment. However, due to the practical presence of leakage inductance in the other transformer, a certain amount of voltage drop is induced in the measured waveform. In this paper, the influence of this voltage drop is theoretically evaluated, emphasizing the discrepancy between the actual system and the developed system. To mitigate this discrepancy, the possibility of different transformer combinations is taken into account as well.

title: Thermal and Electromagnetic Analysis of a Dual-Mode ACG Motor for Start-Stop and Torque Assist Functions
authors: I Wayan Adiyasa, Fransisco Danang Wijaya, Eka Firmansyah
abstract: In this paper, the possibility of utilizing conventional alternating current generator (ACG) motor to be adapted into dual-mode for idle start-stop (ISS) and torque assist (TA) is investigated. The approach used is a model simulation based on the geometric design of the ACG motor on a conventional motorcycle. The results show that in ISS mode, the maximum motor torque output is $\mathbf{6 N} \mathbf{~ n}$ at $\mathbf{1 2 0 ~ r p m}$ with a flux density of 1.84 T, but copper losses are dominant with a total of 145.72 W. In TA mode, the maximum torque of the motor is $1.2 \mathrm{~N}. \mathrm{m}$ at 1400 rpm with a flux density of 1.29 T, and core losses are the dominant factor at 33.01 W. When TA mode is operated for 10 seconds, the winding temperature increase is primarily influenced by copper losses, up to $43{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in the ECE-R40 drive cycle and $40.7^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ in the WMTC drive cycle.

title: Multi-Source Multilevel Inverter with Minimum Number of Power Semiconductor Switches
authors: Sul Janwar, Faizal Arya Samman, Saad Mekhilef, Tsuyoshi Funaki, Luigi Piegari
abstract: This paper presents a 15-level multilevel inverter (MLI) and a 31-level MLI with minimum number of power semiconductor switches. The proposed MLIs uses asymmetric DC sources and minimum numbers of power MOSFET switches. The inverters are designed using a modified Cascaded H-Bridge (CHB) topology, and using a specific modulation strategy namely a Nearest Level Control of Pulse Width Modulation (NLCPWM) with half height method. The performance of the MLI inverters is compare with MLI with conventional techniques and analyzed them in terms of the THD values, input-output power, and power efficiency. The MLI is modelled, designed and simulated using PSIM software. The results showed that without using a filter, the proposed 15level MLI results in a THD of $\mathbf{5 \%}$ and an efficiency of $\mathbf{9 3. 5 3 \%}$. While the proposed 31-level MLI results in a THD value of $2.94 \%$ and an efficiency of $96.55 \%$, showing better performance to conventional MLI.

title: Model Predictive Control for Cruise Control of An Electric Motorcycle under External Disturbances
authors: Muhammad Akhimullah Subari, Ihsan Muhaddisoglu, Andrew McGordon, Truong Dinh
abstract: This paper presents the development and real-time validation of a Model Predictive Control (MPC) strategy for cruise control in an electric motorcycle. The MPC controller is designed to track the reference speed while minimizing both speed error and control effort. The model inside the MPC is constructed based on the speed and acceleration dynamics of the motorcycle through state-space modeling. The designed MPC is then evaluated in a real-time environment using dSPACE Scalexio. To assess its disturbance handling capability, a high-frequency sine wave with an amplitude of 5 km/h is introduced into the vehicle’s longitudinal speed. Two test cases are conducted at cruise reference speeds of 30 km/h and 60 km/h, with the performance of the MPC controller compared against the Proportional-Integral (PI) controller, both with and without disturbance. The results demonstrate that the MPC has a better performance in terms of overshoot reduction and speed regulation, highlighting its potential as a reliable and efficient control solution for electric motorcycles.

title: A Novel Noise Reduction Method based on Wavelet Transform and Least Mean Square
authors: Jie Li, Miaomiao Zhuang, Yupeng Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Aiming at the difficulty of extracting valid information from electromagnetic signals under noisy conditions, a joint denoising method based on Double Tree-Complex Wavelet Transform (DT-CWT) and Least Mean Square (LMS) adaptive threshold algorithm is proposed. This method overcomes the strong dependency of traditional wavelet denoising on wavelet basis functions and achieves lower computational complexity compared to empirical mode decomposition (EMD). Experimental results show that the DT-CWT-LMS algorithm significantly improves the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) under various noise intensities and consistently achieves lower root mean square error (RMSE) than other comparison algorithms, demonstrating excellent denoising performance for single electromagnetic signals. In particular, it exhibits stronger suppression of residual noise. However, experiments also reveal a performance degradation of this method when dealing with coupled electromagnetic signals. Further analysis indicates that the Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) algorithm has a strong decomposition capability for coupled signals, but its denoising performance is highly sensitive to parameter settings. This motivates the optimization of VMD parameters to improve its denoising effectiveness for coupled electromagnetic signals.

title: Multi-Object Tracking Algorithm under Aerial Vehicle Perspective Based on YOLOv8s and DeepSORT
authors: Weiping Zhao, Sikai Zhao, Hongyu Xu, Guoqing Zhou, Feng Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: With the continuous development of aerial vehicle technology, Aerial Vehicle Multi-Object Tracking has become one of the key technologies in aerial vehicle applications. Due to problems such as incorrect identity recognition and target loss during the target tracking process of aerial vehicles, a multi-object tracking algorithm based on improved YOLOv8 + DeepSORT is proposed. First, in the target detection part, the improved YOLOv8s algorithm is adopted. Its backbone network is changed to ResNet-34 to enhance the detection ability of small targets and adapt to the computing power of aerial vehicles. Then, the positioning loss function of YOLOv8s is improved from CIOU to SIOU to improve the detection accuracy and the regression efficiency of anchor boxes. The tracking module uses the CBAM Attention Mechanism for feature fusion in Deep SORT. Compared with mainstream target tracking algorithms, this algorithm performs well in multiple performance indicators. Among them, on the VisDrone-MOT2019 Dataset, the Tracking Accuracy reaches 64.4%, and the Identity Consistency reaches 72.5%, which is significantly better than traditional target tracking algorithms.

authors: Haz Sameen Shahgir, Shamit Fatin, Mehbubul Hasan Al-Quvi, Sukarna Barua, Anindya Iqbal, Sadia Sharmin, Md. Mostofa Akbar, Kallol Kumar Pal, A. Asif Al Rashid

title: Distributed Modularization of Thought: Lets Small Rival Large LMs
authors: Matej Zubic, Dario Bojanjac
abstract: We present the Distributed Modularization of Thought (DMoT) approach for code generation using several small language models, fine-tuned for distinct phases of the code generation process. Instead of the conventional single-model approach in direct code generation, our DMoT method decomposes the task into a hierarchy of subtasks using hierarchical Multi-Level Reasoning (MLR) graphs. Each phase, from solving simple subproblems to verifying syntax and compliance with initial requirements, is handled by a dedicated fine-tuned model. Models were trained through knowledge distillation from a larger model (ChatGPT-4.1) using a quantized LoRA technique, enabling execution on accessible hardware. Experimental evaluation is conducted on the BigCodeBench benchmark, which includes realistic and complex programming tasks. These results show that a system composed of several specialized small models outperforms single-model approaches in terms of accuracy (pass@1) and structural quality (CodeBLEU). So, small fine-tuned language models can rival and even outperform larger models, offering a resource-efficient path in the code generation processes.

title: A Novel Dimensionally Normalized Framework of Maxwell’s Equations for PML-FDTD Applications
authors: Fatih Erden, A. Arda Cosan
abstract: In this study, a novel framework for dimensionally normalized Maxwell’s equations which is suitable for finite difference time domain (FDTD) simulations is presented, where the physical dimensions of electric (E) and magnetic (H) are aligned as inverse meter. This novelty improves both the theoretical formulations and computational efficiency, particularly in applications involving perfectly matched layers (PMLs). By modifying the physical dimensions of the electric and magnetic field vectors into a common unit, this approach introduces mathematical symmetry into the governing equations and simplifies the numerical implementation. The new framework was verified by solving two-dimensional FDTD simulations which showed comparable accuracy to conventional formulations. Three examples were investigated, and modest gains in computational efficiency were observed.

title: Joint User Scheduling and Multi-Domain Resource Allocation for Terrestrial and Non-Terrestrial Networks Integration
authors: Yingdong Hu, Ye Li, Jue Wang, Yicheng Xu, Ruifeng Gao, Sheng Wu, Tony Q. S. Quek
abstract: Efficient resource utilization is vital for terrestrial and non-terrestrial networks (TN-NTN) integration. However, different spatio-temporal resource scales in TN and NTN networks pose challenges for joint resource allocation. To tackle this problem, we propose a joint user scheduling and multi-domain resource allocation scheme in the downlink network, to improve coverage for ground users (GUs). Specifically, the scheme is designed in two time-scales, including large-scale satellite beam-hopping (i.e., spatial resource allocation) and small-scale time-frequency resource allocation. For beam-hopping, we first analyze the coverage of terrestrial base stations (TBS) for GUs, and accordingly propose a joint design of user scheduling and beam-hopping. For time-frequency resource allocation, to cope with the complexity induced by multi-domain and multi-scale resources, we propose a two-step approach which first obtains a preliminary allocation with worst-case co-frequency interference assumption, then employs the genetic algorithm to re-allocate redundant resources, thereby increasing the proportion of successfully served GUs. We evaluate the performance of the proposed scheme through simulations with different user demands and network service settings. Results show that the proposed scheme provides considerable improvement over existing schemes, which can efficiently reduce co-frequency interference and provide service for more GUs.

title: Non-Uniform-Sampling-Enhanced LSTM-FCN Hybrid Network for Inverse Design of Optically Transparent Ultra-Wideband AFSR
authors: Chonghuan Zhang, Li Tang, Juting Hong, Changjun Liu, Richard Xian-Ke Gao, Liping Yan
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A new modeling framework integrating Ramer-Douglas-Peucker (RDP) non-uniform sampling (NUS) with a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)-Fully Connected Network (FCN) hybrid neural network (LFN) is proposed for the inverse design of a single-layer optically transparent ultra-wideband (UWB) absorptive frequency-selective reflector (AFSR). Unlike conventional uniform sampling (US), the RDP-NUS accurately extracts key features while efficiently reducing overall data volume without additional data cropping or dimensionality reduction algorithms. Comparative studies demonstrate that the proposed RDP-LFN framework consistently outperforms US-FCN approaches, achieving lower loss with sparse sampled points and various FCN depths. Utilizing the RDP-LFN framework, a single-layer optically transparent UWB AFSR is designed. The measurement of the fabricated prototype exhibits good agreement with numerical simulation, validating the efficacy and feasibility of the proposed method in addressing the challenging requirements for multifunctional electromagnetic devices in modern electronic systems. This is the first attempt to introduce a NUS strategy into neural networks (NNs) enabled FSS design, offering new insights for intelligent design of microwave devices.

title: IEEE 802.11be Wi-Fi 7: Feature Summary and Performance Evaluation
authors: Xiaoqian Liu, Yuhan Dong, Yiqing Li, Yousi Lin, Ming Gan
abstract: As emerging applications demand increasingly higher throughput, IEEE standard 802.11be – Extremely High Throughput (EHT), also known as Wi-Fi 7, was published on July 22, 2025. It can be used to meet the demand for the throughput of 4k/8k videos up to tens of Gb/s and low-latency video applications such as virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR). Wi-Fi 7 not only scales Wi-Fi 6 with doubled bandwidth, but also supports real-time applications, which brings revolutionary changes to Wi-Fi. In this article, we start by introducing the main objectives and timeline of Wi-Fi 7 and then list the latest key techniques which promote the performance improvement of Wi-Fi 7. Finally, we validate the most critical objectives of Wi-Fi 7 - the potential up to 30 Gb/s throughput and lower latency. System-level simulation results suggest that by combining the new techniques, Wi-Fi 7 achieves 30 Gb/s throughput and lower latency than Wi-Fi 6.

title: High-Precision Modeling of Industrial Process Using Lightweight Deep Forest Regression with Its Application_supp1-3644451.pdf
authors: Heng Xia
abstract: As an amendment to the deep forest, deep forest regression (DFR) has been recently proposed for industrial process modeling. However, training DFR models is an arduous task in terms of computational cost, which incurs limitations for practical industrial applications, such as soft measurement models of difficult-to-measure key process indices. Therefore, we propose a lightweight and high-precision DFR (LHDFR) algorithm to (1) shrink model size, (2) reduce computation cost, and (3) improve modeling accuracy simultaneously without increasing calculation operations. This algorithm is implemented simply and effectively in a deep ensemble structure. In particular, we utilize an unbiased estimation to weaken the swamping effect of representation features among cascade layers. Furthermore, two different types of decision tree algorithms are applied to the forest algorithms in each layer. Then, we present a gradient enhancement strategy with a step factor among layers to enhance the accuracy of the model. The shrinking layer-by-layer method is employed to take advantage of the depth of the decision tree. The comparative results based on six benmark datasets and an actual dioxin soft sensing application case on municipal solid waste incineration process demonstrate the superior performance of our LHDFR model.

title: Hydra: Support Dynamic BFT with Weaker Assumptions and Explicit Request Handling_supp1-3647269.pdf
authors: Zijian Zhang
abstract: This paper presents Hydra, a dynamic BFT protocol that allows replicas to join and leave the system dynamically. It addresses the limitations of traditional static BFTs in managing membership changes and can be used to simplify the implementation of many features in modern blockchain applications. Hydra relies on weaker assumptions to achieve standard properties compared to the existing solution Dyno and introduces a configuration auto-transition protocol to ensure liveness. Through temporary configurations and explicitly defined replica responsibilities for request handling, Hydra pipelines membership requests alongside regular requests and realizes clarity, achieving a more efficient and smoother configuration transitions. It also employs a non-blocking configuration discovery mechanism, enabling new replicas to participate in consensus quickly. We formally prove Hydra's correctness under the dynamic BFT model. Experimental results demonstrate Hydra's ability to maintain throughput fluctuations within 5% during various replica join and leave scenarios, outperforming Dyno and existing BFT system supporting reconfiguration in both stability and efficiency. Hydra effectively manages scenarios that Dyno circumvents with stronger assumptions and quickly restores throughput to normal levels.

title: Minimizing Cuckoo Hashing Insertion Time for Networking Applications in FPGAs
authors: Carlos Megías, Alex Forencich, Eduardo Ros, Javier Díaz
abstract: Cuckoo Hashing is a well-known scheme for maintaining a hash-based data structure with worst-case constant search time. The search can be easily pipelined in FPGAs to obtain a response every clock cycle. However, inserting new elements may require multiple iterations to reallocate elements due to collisions, a challenge that intensifies with increasing table occupancy (load). Here, we pursue an efficient implementation of Cuckoo Hashing in FPGAs that exploits the inherent parallel processing capabilities of the technology to minimize the insertion time and enhance the performance of real-time applications like communications networks. Our analysis shows that the candidate implementation alternatives can be grouped into four different categories, considering the number of iterations required to perform new element insertions relative to the hash table’s load. Within each category, the performance is similar, providing flexibility for implementation. Among these methods, one exhibits the best results under all load conditions, without incurring a large complexity penalty, reducing the number of iterations for the insertion by more than 60% for loads beyond 95% compared to the most recent works. A Cuckoo Hashing architecture for networking applications is presented and used to evaluate and verify all insertion methods through hardware evaluation. Our implementation improves on existing architectures by at least 0.2 operations per clock cycle.

title: Conditional Diffusion Model-Driven Generative Channels for Double RIS-Aided Wireless Systems
authors: Yiyang Ni, Qi Zhang, Guangji Chen, Yan Cai, Jun Li, Shi Jin
abstract: With the development of the upcoming sixth-generation networks (6 G), reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) have gained significant attention due to its ability of reconfiguring wireless channels via smart reflections. However, it remains critical challenges for channel state information (CSI) acquisitions of double-RIS systems with ultra-heavy pilot overhead and multi-path interference. This paper proposes a novel channel generation method in double-RIS communication systems based on the utilization of conditional diffusion model (CDM). The CDM model is carefully designed and trained on synthetic channel data to capture the high-dimensional channel characteristics. It addresses the limitations of conventional deep learning-based CSI estimation approaches, such as insufficient model understanding capability and poor environmental adaptability. Then we provide a detailed analysis of the diffusion process for channel generation, elaborating on how CDM is able to acquire CSI efficiently. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed CDM based channel acquisition method outperforms benchmarks in terms of normalized mean squared error, achieving an improvement of approximately 18%.

title: A Low-Complexity Sparse Bayesian Acoustic Source Localization Method Based on ℓ p -Norm Constraint
authors: Xiaobo Zhang, Jinchan Zhu, Xiaosong Li, Lin Tong, Chun Li, Maoheng Jing, Ning Li, Haijun Wang, Ping Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Sparse Bayesian inference (SBI) has emerged as a promising approach for direction of arrival (DOA) estimation in acoustic signal processing due to its robust statistical framework. However, conventional SBI methods often lack flexibility due to their dependence on prior models for sparsity constraints, also struggle with high computational complexity caused by covariance matrix inversion, and additionally suffer from precision degradation due to grid mismatch. To address the aforementioned issues, this study proposes an enhanced hierarchical sparse Bayesian inference algorithm (ℓp-IFSBI) that integrates ℓp-norm penalty. A non-convex ℓp-norm regularization model (with 0 < p < 1) is constructed to control the sparsity of the model within a hierarchical Bayesian framework. Additionally, the likelihood function is reformulated through theoretical derivation to eliminate covariance matrix inversion, thereby reducing computational complexity. Furthermore, the coati optimization algorithm (COA) is introduced to perform adaptive searching for the actual source position within the signal subspace, effectively compensating for model errors caused by grid mismatch. Simulation and real-time acoustic source localization experiments show that, at a signal-to-noise ratio of 0 dB, the proposed ℓp-IFSBI-COA algorithm achieves a root mean square error of less than 0.3° in DOA estimation. To facilitate further research and reproduction, the source code is available at https://github.com/Xiaob0-Zhang/lp-IFSBI.

title: Polarization-Selective Tapered Fiber Interferometer for Mode-Locked Ultrafast Laser
authors: Chen Jiang, Xiaolong Fan, Ying Wan, Yuehui Ma, Zhiqiang Wang, Chengbo Mou, Yunqi Liu, Zuxing Zhang
abstract: An all-fiber ultrafast laser based on an interferometric polarization-selective element is proposed and demonstrated. The element is constructed from a tapered polarization-maintaining fiber (PMF), which forms a polarization-dependent Mach–Zehnder interferometer (PD-MZI) along the orthogonal polarization axes of the fiber. Different interference intensities and wavelength responses of the two polarization modes induce a strong polarization-selective effect. For the PD-MZI with a waist diameter of 40 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula> m and a taper length of 1.8 cm, within the wavelength range of 1537–1607 nm, the maximum polarization-dependent loss (PDL) reached 19.4 dB. The MZI exhibited nonuniform loss and PDL characteristics, enabling its use as both a wavelength-selective and mode-locking component in nonlinear polarization rotation (NPR) based fiber laser systems. The designed laser achieved a 3 dB spectral bandwidth of 7 nm, a pulse separation of 448.3 fs, and a repetition rate of 21.5 MHz, corresponding to a conventional soliton. Moreover, by adjusting the pump power and cavity polarization state, a soliton molecule state was also observed. Owing to its simple fabrication, compact structure, and high damage threshold, this all-fiber polarization-selective device provides an effective alternative to conventional mode-locking elements in NPR-based ultrafast fiber laser systems.

abstract: It's easy to ignore something when it exists below the surface. Nearly everyone knows how to operate a car, but not many can accurately explain how a car converts explosive gasoline into easily controlled motion. Drivers don't care much, as long as the vehicle works reliably.

title: Controllability and Small-Signal Oscillations of Magnetic Flux Linkages in Doubly Fed Induction Machines
authors: Boštjan Polajžer, Annette Muetze, Seyed Ali Seyed-Bouzari, Jožef Ritonja
abstract: This paper examines the controllability of the stator and rotor magnetic flux linkages of doubly fed induction machines (DFIMs), considering small-signal oscillations and their relationship with electromagnetic machine design. To this aim, we first analyze 66 sets of lumped parameters from the dynamic model of a DFIM. Based on this, we classify DFIMs into three categories based on their modal parameters, namely, two for wind applications and one for pumped-hydro applications. Additionally, we identify reciprocal relationships between the damping of both identified oscillatory modes and the largest eigenvalues of the stator and rotor controllability Gramian matrices. Among the different lumped parameters, the winding resistances are found to influence these relationships the most. All analyzed DFIMs for wind applications were found to be less controllable and to exhibit better damping of oscillatory modes than DFIMs for pumped-hydro applications. Furthermore, based on the results of the controllability analysis, we selected three objective function candidates suitable for an optimization procedure aimed at minimizing the energy required to control the rotor flux linkages. An example objective function was evaluated in a multi-objective DFIM design process for wind applications that enables the design of more controllable machines that provide the desired damping of oscillations, which can consequently contribute to improving grid resilience.

title: RSS-Net: A Mamba-Based Network for SAR Image Denoising
authors: Min Huang, Yunzhao Yang, Qiuhong Sun
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR), with its outstanding features, has developed into a vital technical method for the global detection of maritime and terrestrial targets. However, the unique imaging mechanism intrinsic to SAR inherently produces coherent speckle noise. This noise significantly deteriorates the quality of the image, thereby adversely affecting downstream applications like target recognition and classification. Therefore, research on SAR image denoising holds significant practical and theoretical value. However, due to the limitations of the local receptive field of CNN, it is difficult for it to capture global spatial features. Although Transformer can achieve global spatial modeling, its quadratic complexity results in a large amount of computational overhead. To tackle these issues, this paper introduces RSS-Net, a new denoising network for SAR images, built on an encoder-decoder architecture. RSS-Net demonstrates significant improvements in SAR image denoising performance, due to its ability to extract multi-scale feature information. The network incorporates the Residue State-Space Block (RSSB), which fuses Mamba's Vision State Space Module (VSSM) and a CNN-based Channel Attention Block (CAB). VSSM leverages 2D-Selective Scan (SS2D) better acquires spatial information features in SAR images by scanning in four directions. RSSB efficiently merges Mamba's ability to model long-range dependencies and conventional convolution's strengths in extracting local features. This integration effectively alleviates the common detail blurring problem in existing SAR denoising methods and strengthens the restoration of high-frequency image details. The novel application of the Mamba to SAR image denoising enables the proposed method to attain both long-range contextual dependency modeling and linear computational cost, thus resolving the balance between global modeling capacity and efficiency in computation, while also pointing to new avenues for future research. Experimental evaluations confirm the superior denoising efficacy of the proposed algorithm.

title: Expansion of Light-Load Operating range for DAB-type Converter Based on Mode Switching
authors: PuChun Yang, JianJun Ma, Miao Zhu
abstract: The traditional Dual Active Bridge (DAB) converter suffers from a reduced zero-voltage switching (ZVS) range under light loads. To address this, this paper proposes a mode-switching strategy combining Single Active Bridge (SAB) and Semi-Active Bridge (Semi-AB) operation modes. By partially gating secondary-side switches during light-load conditions, the method suppresses circulating current, extends ZVS range, and improves efficiency while maintaining simple single-phase-shift (SPS) modulation. Steady-state analysis defines optimal mode transitions, and a hysteretic control ensures smooth switching with minimal transient impact. Experimental results on a 500 W prototype validate the approach.

title: Designing Frequency Ancillary Service in Lombok Island: Study Case and Quantification
authors: Indri Haryani, Rian Fatah Mochamad, Sarjiya, Andrew Cahyo Adhi, Agussalim Syamsuddin, M. Rifqi Alkayyis, Valensi Erza, Indra Ardhanayudha Aditya
abstract: This paper presents a technical design and quantification of frequency ancillary services for the low-inertia Lombok power system. Using electromagnetic transient simulations in DIgSILENT PowerFactory 2022, five operating scenarios are compared following the loss of the largest infeed ($\approx 63 \mathrm{MW}$): (1) the current base case with $50 \%$ generator participation in primary frequency response (PFR); (2) full PFR participation; (3) base case with automatic generation control (AGC); (4) base case with AGC plus a $\mathbf{3 0 ~ M W}$ battery energy storage system (BESS) providing fast frequency response (FFR); and (5) full PFR with AGC. Key findings show that mandating $100 \%$ PFR substantially reduces the frequency nadir but does not change the initial rate of change of frequency (RoCoF). A $\mathbf{3 0 ~ M W}$ BESS delivers rapid inertial support and markedly improves the nadir, yet a short BESS discharge duration can produce a secondary frequency dip when AGC has not fully taken over. The results demonstrate that resilience requires both near-instantaneous FFR and sufficient energy capacity plus coordinated AGC and PFR. The paper recommends a hybrid BESS-conventional procurement and control approach as a practical blueprint for islanded and lowinertia systems.

title: Multi-Rate Sampling-Based Direct Digital Control with Minimal Closed-Loop Pole Drift for PMSMs
authors: Woei-Luen Chen, Chia-Hsi Lin, Tian-Hua Liu
abstract: Fixed-rate sampling techniques are commonly employed in microcontroller unit (MCU)-based real-time digital control applications, offering simplified analog-to-digital conversion (ADC) process and confined closed-loop pole locations. However, in electric motor control, rotor position is typically obtained from an encoder that generates pulses as the shaft rotates. Due to variable speed, the pulse intervals become non-uniform, leading to a variable sampling rate that prevents the use of fixed-rate sampling. To address this issue, a direct digital control strategy based on a proportional-integral (PI) controller is proposed. By optimizing the controller’s zero location and gain, the drift of closed-loop poles is minimized, ensuring consistent control performance despite variations in current command and load conditions. Experimental validation on a permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Implementation of Adaptive DC-Link Voltage to Enhance Efficiency in Electric Motor Emulator
authors: Chih-Chun Chiang, Shih-Pin Tu, Yaow-Ming Chen
abstract: This paper implements a symmetric, non-isolated bidirectional DC-DC converter for integration into a Power-Hardware-in-the-Loop (PHIL) motor-driver test bench. The converter equips the electric motor emulator (EME) with an independently regulated, adaptive DC-link, thereby decoupling it from the drive’s fixed common bus and balancing high-speed voltage margin against low/medium-speed efficiency. Required EME voltages are derived by matching current slopes to a target PMSM, and worst-case DC-link sizing follows from spacevector zero-vector conditions. Hardware results show that the adaptive scheme preserves high-speed emulation fidelity comparable to the constant-voltage case while substantially reducing semiconductor and passive losses at lower speeds and improving zero-sequence control margin. The transformer-free topology is retrofit-friendly and requires no changes to the drive under test or to standard EME modulation, offering a practical path to extend speed range and raise efficiency in PHIL applications.

title: Integrated Inductors with Increased Current Load in Power Supply Circuits of Active Microwave Devices Using a GaAs 150 nm Technology
authors: A.V. Kontorin, A. N. Lyashuk, S. M. Kulyasov, I. A. Melnichenko, S. A. Zavyalov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This paper present various variants of integrated inductors implemented using GaAs 150 nm technology are considered. By making changes to the design of the coils, it was possible to increase their current load without compromising the quality factor and maintaining small dimensions. The maximum current was doubled, but the dimensions were reduced and the quality of the coil was maintained. The developed inductors, which maintain high quality-factor and compact dimensions, are suitable for application as RF chokes in the power supply circuits of high-current devices.

title: Research and Prospects on Low-Cost Technologies for Starlink Terminals
authors: Ziping Wei, Kaiqi Guo, Zizhen Li, Yongchun Chen, Bingsen Liu, Qinghua Zeng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: As a key hub for the integration of space and terrestrial networks, the technological advancement and industrialization capability of satellite internet terminal devices directly influence the operational efficiency and commercial value of satellite internet systems. This paper introduces the characteristics and development history of each generation of Starlink terminals, with a focus on analyzing and exploring the technological evolution of its terminal devices and the core cost control strategies. On this basis, the current situation and challenges faced by satellite terminals in terms of technological capacity and cost control are studied, and corresponding improvement suggestions are proposed. This study provides theoretical support and practical guidance for the industrial development of satellite terminal devices, playing a strategically significant role in establishing an independent and controllable satellite internet industry system.

title: Speech Source Tracking Based on Interacting Multiple Model and Particle Filter in Noisy and Reverberant Environments
authors: Ruifang Wang, Rong Wang, Guodong Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Robust tracking of a moving speech source in adverse acoustic indoor environments is a significant challenge. This paper introduces a novel tracking framework which integrates the Interacting Multiple Model (IMM) algorithm with the Particle Filter (PF) in microphone networks. To accurately capture the speech source's complex dynamics, we employ multiple motion models. For each model, several Time Difference of Arrival (TDOA) candidates, derived from the generalized cross-correlation (GCC) function, serve as measurements. A multiple-hypothesis likelihood model is then utilized to calculate particle weights, enabling accurate position estimation for each motion mode through a weighted particle set. The final state estimate is obtained by fusing the approximated positions of all motion models based on the IMM algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate the superior robustness of the proposed method against noise and reverberation, achieving consistently lower tracking errors compared to existing approaches.

title: Performance of User Pairing Schemes for Maximizing the Capacity of Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access Communication Systems with Imperfect Successive Interference Cancellation
authors: Tan-Hsu Tan, Yi-Huei Lin, Yung-Fa Huang, Shing-Hong Liu
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: In this paper, three inter-user interference estimation models are proposed in Imperfect Successive Interference Cancellation (IPSIC) to investigate the performance of SIC in nonorthogonal multiple access (NOMA) communication systems. Simulation results show that that the proposed model III can reach the average rate by 8.3867 bps/Hz in 2 users environments which is close to the average rate 8.5307 bps/Hz of perfect SIC NOMA. Moreover, two user pairing methods are proposed for multiple users in a cell to investigate the optimal system capacity. Simulation results show that in comparison of pairing methods A and B, the model III with pairing method A can reach the average rate by 4.7932 bps/Hz in 10 users environments which is higher than the average rate 3.7611 bps/Hz of pairing method B.

title: Critical Parameters and Components for Implementing Blockchain in Digital Certificates
authors: Taqwan Thamrin, Yulyani Arifin, Evaristus Didik Madyatmadja, Widodo Budiharto
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Blockchain technology presents transformative possibilities for digital certificate systems by improving security, immutability, and trustworthiness. Nevertheless, real execution encounters obstacles including transaction expenses and scalability constraints. This paper delineates essential parameters (gas fees, block size) and architectural elements (off-chain/IPFS storage, on-chain verification) via empirical experimentation and system design. We implement a prototype that executes 21 digital certificate transactions on an Ethereum-based blockchain, documenting gas fees and block sizes. Results indicate that gas costs exhibit considerable variation ($0.0098-$0.06), while block sizes oscillate (505-600 KB), underscoring the interdependencies of cost and scalability. An integrated off-chain/IPFS design decreases on-chain storage requirements by 85% while preserving cryptographic integrity. Our research offers practical recommendations for enhancing blockchain implementations in certificate systems, ensuring a balance among cost, scalability, and security. Subsequent research will investigate Layer-2 methods for gas optimization.

title: A New Novel of Nonlinear Time-Delayed Control and its Implementation to ABS System
authors: Xuan Phu Do, Thi Truc Thao Phan
abstract: This paper proposes a novel control design for nonlinear time-varying systems, addressing the challenges posed by external disturbances, including cyber-attacks. The control framework incorporates a signum-based mathematical function to enhance system robustness and responsiveness to abrupt changes. This approach introduces a new perspective in handling system nonlinearity while improving resilience against time-dependent variations and adversarial influences. Additionally, boundaries for state variables are defined to extend the applicable range of control, allowing greater flexibility in practical implementation. The proposed control is validated through simulations under modeled cyber-attacks for ABS system. Results demonstrate that the controller maintains stability and achieves strong performance, even in the presence of significant disruptions.

title: Reasoning With Multi-Valued Logic in the Field of Security Education
authors: Mikhail Kucherov, Vitaly Vainshtein, Roman Shimanovich
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The paper introduces an analysis of random variables using Shramko-Wansing multi-valued logic. This provides for the first time a link between the multi-valued logic and decision theory under uncertainty, treating falsity order in a lattice as natural order with respect to errors, such as false positive or false negative outcomes of statistical hypothesis tests. False negative represents the top element with respect to the falsity order and false positive is the bottom element. This gives us the rich language to reason about the expected values of random variables. As an illustration of the applicability of our model, we present a logical version of educational scenario.

title: Decision-Making Algorithm in Physical Security Systems of Centrally Guarded Facilities
authors: A. V. Telny, M. Yu. Monakhov, S. N. Matveev, A. P. Matveeva, Yu. M. Monakhov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: this article proposes an algorithm for automating decision-making for automated workstations (AWs) of physical protection systems at centrally guarded facilities based on prioritization of the protected facilities. Decisions are made by the duty operator of the central security post (CSP). Decisions are made on the issue of dispatching a physical security detail to the facility from which an alarm message has been received under conditions of CSP overload, when all detailes are busy at other facilities. The information stored in the following data is used for decision-making: in AW operation protocols of physical protection systems at centrally guarded facilities; in AW protected facility databases; and based on the results of facility inspections. The paper proposes a list of factors influencing prioritization, generates their importance coefficients based on expert assessments using the Delphi method, and develops a generalized decision-making algorithm. It is shown that, based on the application of the algorithm for automating decision-making in AWs of physical protection systems at centrally guarded facilities, a decision-support system for CSP duty operators can be created.

title: Virtual Reality and Artificial Intelligence in Aviation Safety Training: A Comparative Review
authors: Slavomíra Vargová, Petr Adolf Skrehot, Denisa Charvátová, David Tucek
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) are increasingly transforming aviation safety training by offering immersive, adaptable, and cost-efficient alternatives to conventional full-flight simulators. This paper systematically reviews and compares recent studies to evaluate VR and AI applications in pilot and air traffic control training, collaborative environments, and human factors. Using a structured review methodology-including PRISMA for study selection, JBI for methodological appraisal, and ROBINS-I for bias assessmentnineteen studies were identified and analyzed. Results indicate that VR training achieves outcomes comparable to traditional methods while significantly improving engagement and accessibility. AI systems enhance scalability through automation and personalized feedback. Persistent challenges include cybersickness, cognitive load, limited longitudinal validation, and regulatory integration. The convergence of VR and AI has the potential to revolutionize aviation training, provided future research addresses these technical and human-factors constraints.

title: Optimizing VHF Antenna Placement on Aircraft: A Comparative Simulation Study
authors: Marek Češkovič, Natália Gecejová, Maroš Komjáty
abstract: Reliable VHF communication is a cornerstone of civil and military aviation, but optimal antenna placement on aircraft remains a complex engineering challenge due to shadowing, coupling, and aerodynamic constraints. This paper analyses five potential antenna locations on a representative tactical aircraft-nose, lower fuselage, upper fuselage, vertical tail, wing pylon and dual configuration (upper and lower)—using full-wave electromagnetic simulations in Altair FEKO. The results demonstrate significant trade-offs in coverage performance across positions: nose and tail placements offer directional advantages but suffer from shadowing, while pylonmounted solutions exhibit severe anisotropy. The lower fuselage provides the most balanced air-to-ground coverage, and the upper fuselage ensures robust air-to-air connectivity. The study confirms that no single location achieves omnidirectional coverage; instead, dual placement on upper and lower fuselage surfaces emerges as the most effective and reliable strategy, aligning with both civil and military best practices.

title: Ethereum Price Prediction Employing Large Language Models for Short-term and Few-shot Forecasting
authors: Eftychia Makri, Georgios Palaiokrassas, Sarah Bouraga, Antigoni Polychroniadou, Leandros Tassiulas
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Cryptocurrencies have transformed financial markets with their innovative blockchain technology and volatile price movements, presenting both challenges and opportunities for predictive analytics. Ethereum, being one of the leading cryptocurrencies, has experienced significant market fluctuations, making its price prediction an attractive yet complex problem. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the effectiveness of Large Language Models (LLMs) in predicting Ethereum prices for short-term and few-shot forecasting scenarios. The main challenge in training models for time series analysis is the lack of data. We address this by leveraging a novel approach that adapts existing pre-trained LLMs on natural language or images from billions of tokens to the unique characteristics of Ethereum price time series data. Through thorough experimentation and comparison with traditional and contemporary models, our results demonstrate that selectively freezing certain layers of pre-trained LLMs achieves state-of-the-art performance in this domain. This approach consistently surpasses benchmarks across multiple metrics, including Mean Squared Error (MSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), demonstrating its effectiveness and robustness. Our research not only contributes to the existing body of knowledge on LLMs but also provides practical insights in the cryptocurrency prediction domain. The adaptability of pre-trained LLMs to handle the nature of Ethereum prices suggests a promising direction for future research, potentially including the integration of sentiment analysis to further refine forecasting accuracy.

title: ReAcct: Redaction Control for Interoperable Blockchains
authors: Tirthankar Sengupta, Sandip Chakraborty, Shamik Sural
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Interoperable blockchain networks require robust redaction control mechanisms to uphold privacy, regulatory compliance, and trust, especially when managing modifications and deletions across multiple autonomous systems. While existing redaction frameworks primarily apply to isolated blockchains, cross-network redaction needs a separate handling process due to varying governance models across chains and inter-consortium trust. In this paper, we propose $\operatorname{ReAcct}$, a comprehensive redaction control framework for blockchain interoperations that regulates and validates redaction requests across chains. ReAcct refines internal metadata for redaction request and response exchange to protect sensitive information. It also enables proof of redaction across interconnected networks. We present a rigorous system architecture, incorporating a detailed threat and trust model for cross-network redaction control. We implement ReAcct using Hyperledger Cacti as the interoperability layer for redaction request-response communication exchange between Hyperledger Fabric networks and leverage IPFS for distributed storage. Our evaluation shows that $\boldsymbol{R} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{A} \boldsymbol{c} \boldsymbol{t}$ effectively enforces redaction policies across interoperable blockchains, maintaining low performance overhead and demonstrating scalability under increasing workload.

title: Poster: Single-TEE Solution for Offline Blockchain Transactions
authors: Srivatsav Chenna, Christian Prehofer
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: In recent research, several approaches based on Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) for offline blockchain solutions have been proposed. These solutions leverage a two-TEE model which requires all involved devices to be equipped with a TEE, leading to increased overhead, and reduced flexibility in deployment. This paper introduces a novel “Single-TEE” solution to facilitate secure offline blockchain transactions. We propose a transaction mechanism that ensures integrity at the receiver-side by leveraging identity credentials and TEE verification, thereby eliminating the need for a receiver-side TEE. We detail the system architecture and the protocols for secure offline transactions.

title: Enabling a Secure and Resilient Internet of Everything: A Multi-Layer Non-Cryptocurrency Blockchain Approach
authors: Porya Elahi Kheibary, Navidreza Asadi, Wolfgang Kellerer
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: The Internet of Everything (IoE) remains fragmented by vendor-specific stacks, centralized bottlenecks, and the economic friction of transaction-fee-based blockchains. We present Versatile Network, a multi-layer, non-cryptocurrency blockchain architecture that separates high-volume peer-to-peer (P2P) data streams from global state validation. An intent-based communication model enables seamless interoperability among heterogeneous devices, while a resource-sharing framework lets constrained endpoints leverage network-wide compute and storage. Resource-based Sybil resistance and adaptive validation provide robust security without fees. Compared with Ethereum, Solana, and IPFS, Versatile Network achieves better suitability for IoE through cost-free operation, scalability, and seamless off-chain integration—positioning it as a pragmatic foundation for Web 4.0.

title: Impact Analysis of Adversarial Attacks on Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based Wide-Area Microgrid Control
authors: Zain Ul Abdeen, Suman Rath, Vivek Kumar Singh
abstract: The growing integration of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) into power system control offers unprecedented adaptability and performance benefits. However, it also introduces new vulnerabilities that can be exploited by adversarial cyber threats. Unlike traditional model-based controllers, DRL agents depend heavily on real-time observations, feedback loops, and learned policies—making them inherently susceptible to malicious manipulation. This paper investigates the cybersecurity and resilience of a DRL-based wide-area secondary controller operating within an autonomous microgrid. Specifically, we evaluate a Deep Q-Learning Network (DQN) agent responsible for maintaining voltage and frequency stability through coordinated decision-making. To assess its robustness, we simulate a comprehensive suite of cyberattack scenarios—including false data injection, strategically triggered backdoors, spoofing, reward poisoning, and coordinated multi-vector attacks targeting both observation and actuation channels of the trained DQN. We also introduce a set of evaluation metrics—including reward degradation, frequency and voltage deviation, and a composite system stability index—to quantitatively assess the impact of these attacks. Our simulation results reveal that even subtle, state-dependent, or reward-level manipulations can significantly degrade control performance while evading detection by conventional monitoring systems. In contrast, high-magnitude sensor attacks result in a complete loss of observability but are easier to detect by system operators. Our experimental results also showed that coordinated attacks that simultaneously disrupt multiple channels induce severe impacts, triggering transient instability in frequency and voltage regulation.
