title: A Study of Solving Life-and-Death Problems in Go Using Relevance-Zone Based Solvers
authors: Chung-Chin Shih, Ti-Rong Wu, Ting Han Wei, Yu-Shan Hsu, Hung Guei, I-Chen Wu
abstract: This paper analyzes the behavior of solving Life-and-Death (L&D) problems in the game of Go using current state-of-the-art computer Go solvers with two techniques: the Relevance-Zone Based Search (RZS) and the relevance-zone pattern table. We examined the solutions derived by relevance-zone based solvers on seven L&D problems from the renowned book “Life and Death Dictionary” written by Cho Chikun, a Go grandmaster, and found several interesting results. First, for each problem, the solvers identify a relevance-zone that highlights the critical areas for solving. Second, the solvers discover a series of patterns, including some that are rare. Finally, the solvers even find different answers compared to the given solutions for two problems. We also identified two issues with the solver: (a) it misjudges values of rare patterns, and (b) it tends to prioritize living directly rather than maximizing territory, which differs from the behavior of human Go players. We suggest possible approaches to address these issues in future work.

title: Dual Satellite STBC Combining Under Imperfect Symbol Time Alignment
authors: Carlos L. Marcos Rojas, Jorge L. Gonzalez Rios, Luis M. Garces Socarras, Vibhum Singh, Raudel Cuiman Marquez, Juan C. Merlano Duncan, Vu Nguyen HA, Symeon Chatzinotas, BjÖrn Ottersten
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: In distributed satellite communication systems, spatial diversity techniques such as Space-Time Block Coding (STBC) offer an attractive opportunity to enhance the link’s capabilities without additional spectrum consumption. One of the major challenges that still remains is the degradation of the Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR) at the receiver, primarily due to time misalignment between satellites. This paper presents a robust receiver architecture that demonstrates strong resilience against SINR degradation caused by time misalignment between satellites and maintains robust performance even under additional impairments such as power imbalance and Doppler shifts. Moreover, we present an efficient implementation of the receiver, which combines both software and hardware platforms.

title: UDE-MPC: Robust Model Predictive Control with Flexible Constraints for Pointing Servo Systems
authors: Shiyao Li, Chen Wei, Baoqing Yang, Yining Zhou, Bo Zhu, Jie Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Pointing control technology is critical for numerous applications such as space communication and target surveillance. The challenge for pointing systems is to achieve the highest possible control accuracy under actuator constraints and various uncertainties, where the typical single-controller structure struggles to deliver the desired performance due to its inherent conflict between different objectives. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a robust model predictive control (MPC) framework enhanced by an uncertainty and disturbance estimator (UDE). The framework incorporates two innovative strategies: 1) a time-varying UDE (TV-UDE) to avoid transient peaking phenomena and ensure reliable disturbance estimation, and 2) a flexible mechanism that dynamically adjusts the range of nominal control based on UDE’s output such that the actuator constraint is fulfilled. This flexible mechanism avoids the usage of offline over-tightened constraints, providing a safe and less-conservative input range for MPC. As far as we know, this paper provides the first comprehensive framework for pointing systems, which is capable of maximizing control performance while handling constraints and disturbances. The proposed framework is validated and compared to existing methods through simulations and experiments on a pointing platform, demonstrating the highest servo accuracy under different disturbance conditions.

title: Balaton Borders: Data Ceramics for Ecological Reflection
authors: Hajnal Gyeviki, Mihály Minkó, Mary Karyda, Damla Çay
abstract: Balaton Borders translates ecological data from Lake Balaton into ceramic tableware that represents human impact on the landscape, from reedbed reduction to shoreline modification and land erosion. Designed for performative dining, the pieces turn shared meals into multisensory encounters where food and data ceramics spark collective reflection on ecological disruption.

title: Thermal Prediction for a 20 kW Permanent Magnet Axial Flux Electric Tractor Motor
authors: Rahul Roy, Lenin Natesan Chokkalingam, Sivakumar Ramasami, Arjun Seshadri, Yacine Amara
abstract: Axial flux permanent magnet (AFPM) motors are increasingly preferred in traction applications due to their high-power density and torque density. To maintain this power density during continuous operation, proper thermal management is of utmost importance. This paper presents the design of various liquid cooling arrangements for a 20 kW axial flux motor used to drive an electric tractor. Loss estimation was performed using finite element analysis and verified through analytical calculations. Three different cooling structures were designed, and their pressure drop, velocity distribution, and temperature distribution were compared. The key advantages of the proposed models are highlighted in the conclusion.

title: On the Inverse Problems of Trajectory Control
authors: B. K. Nartov, A. N. Poluyanov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The paper presents a general approach to optimization of initial conditions in trajectory control problems. This approach is based on alternating solutions of direct and special inverse problems. The possibilities of the approach are demonstrated for control problems of smooth non-autonomous dynamical systems, classical optimal search problems and standard pursuit problems for targets with specified trajectories. For these problems, directional algorithms of optimization of initial conditions, i.e. the initial coordinates of controlled objects, with monotonous improvement of the control performance functional at each dual optimization step are proposed. Some of the analytical results have been verified by simulation tests and all omitted proofs have been completed.

title: Hazardous Energy control in Maintenance Operations
authors: Hana Pačaiová, Andrea Sütőová, Renáta Turisová, Michal Hovanec, Slavomíra Vargová
abstract: In the current industrial environment, where increasingly complex machines, automated production lines, pressure and electrical systems are used, the management of hazardous energy risks plays a key role in the field of occupational health and safety. Risks associated with electrical, mechanical, hydraulic, pneumatic, chemical or thermal energy are among the most common causes of serious injuries during maintenance, repair and cleaning of machines and equipment. The LOTO or LOTOTO concept (Lockout - Tagout - Tryout) represents a systematic approach to preventing accidental release or unintentional restart of equipment during maintenance. The purpose of this paper is to provide an overview of the development, implementation and practical aspects of LOTOTO management as one of the basic elements of accident prevention during interventions on equipment. The paper provides a new methodological approach to monitoring and improving the LOTOTO implementation in organizations through the effectiveness measurement of its application. The development of a proposed effectiveness index provides a new methodological approach for evaluating and improving the performance of LOTOTO implementation in organizations.

title: Achieving Unanimous Consensus Through Multi-Agent Deliberation
authors: Apurba Pokharel, Ram Dantu, Shakila Zaman, Vinh Quach, Sirisha Talapuru
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Blockchain consensus mechanisms have relied on algorithms such as Proof-of-Work (PoW) and Proof-of-Stake (PoS) to ensure network functionality and integrity. However, these approaches struggle with adaptability for decision-making where the opinions of each matter rather than reaching an agreement based on honest majority or weighted consensus. This paper introduces a novel deliberation-based consensus mechanism where Large Language Models (LLMs) act as rational agents engaging in structured discussions to reach a unanimous consensus. By leveraging graded consensus and a multi-round deliberation process, our approach ensures unanimous consensus for definitive problems and graded consensus for prioritized decision problems and policies. We provide a formalization of our system and use it to show that the properties of blockchains are maintained, while also addressing the behavior in terms of adversaries, stalled deliberations, and confidence in consensus. Moreover, experimental results demonstrate system feasibility, showcasing convergence, block properties, and accuracy, which enable deliberative decision-making on blockchain networks.

title: Identity-Private Healthcare Data Sharing on Blockchain via Zero-Knowledge Proofs and Account Abstraction
authors: Kun Li, Ankur Lohachab, Visara Urovi
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Blockchains are considered for healthcare data sharing due to their immutability, decentralization, and auditability. However, ledger transparency exposes on-chain identifiers and activity metadata, enabling linkage across pseudonyms and inference over user behavior. Prior work has primarily focused on content confidentiality and access control, while leaving identity unlinkability insufficiently addressed. To this end, we present an approach that integrates Account ion (AA), zeroknowledge proofs (Groth16), and Pedersen commitments. The approach embeds proof- and commitment-based verification into programmable smart contract accounts (SCAs), enabling authentication without disclosing identifiers and decoupling transactions from static keys. We develop a proof-of-concept on the Polygon Amoy testnet using Circom and Solidity, and evaluate privacy under a global, passive, external, static, and computationally bounded attacker. For the ERC-4337 comparison, the attacker is assumed to know user-SCA mappings; for the account-shuffling comparison, the attacker knows one SCA per user. Using entropy metrics and clustering-based inference over on-chain metadata, our approach achieves the maximum entropy of $\log _{2}(10) \approx 3.32$ in a ten-user setting (versus 0 for ERC-4337 as specified, i.e., without privacy extensions) and substantially reduces clustering accuracy relative to address shuffling (ARI $0.468 \rightarrow 0.038$, NMI $0.653 \rightarrow 0.177$), while maintaining the auditability required for healthcare governance.

title: Forensic Analysis of the Libra Memecoin Incident
authors: Tao Yan, Sheng-Nan Li, Claudio J. Tessone
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: This paper investigates the Libra memecoin incident on February 14, 2025, triggered by a social post from Argentina’s president. Using blockchain forensic methods, we reconstruct the event timeline, token supply concentration, liquidity operation and trading microstructure. Our analysis reveals strong token concentration, with 92.8% of supply controlled by the creator, who provided one-sided liquidity in the Libra-USDC pool and profited approximately 13M USDC through fee collection. Among traders, 67.9% incurred losses, while early participants, especially those who transacted before the post or traded Libra within the first minute after the post achieved abnormal profits, suggesting insider trading. The findings highlight the obvious risks of high-profile public figures endorsing speculative, highly tradable cryptoassets in a move that - in the best case - constitutes extreme negligence.

title: Research on Optimization of LLC-SRC Resonant Converter with Valley Switching Control Method
authors: Yi-Feng Lin, Hsiang-Jen Yu, Yen-Te Li
abstract: In modern power electronics applications, the LLC-SRC has been widely adopted in various power supply systems due to its advantages such as high efficiency, low electromagnetic interference (EMI), and electrical isolation. However, under traditional pulse frequency modulation control, the LLC-SRC suffers from limited output gain and poor output voltage regulation under light-load conditions. Common improvement techniques include burst-mode control, PWM control, primary-side phase-shift-controlled and secondary-side phase-shift-controlled, and valley switching control (VSC). Compared to these methods, the VSC offers higher light-load efficiency, lower output ripple, and wider output voltage gain range. This study investigates the impact of switching position in VSC control on the efficiency of an LLC-SRC converter. By adjusting the switching to different valley points, higher efficiency can be achieved. The analysis includes circuit operation, valley point characteristics, and loss analysis. Finally, a 1 kW LLC-SRC converter employing full-range valley switching control is implemented, featuring an input and output voltage of $400 V_{D C}$.

title: Development of a Microcontroller-Based Hardware-Software Complex for Simulating Cardiac Activity
authors: Ivan Vasiliev, Bogdan Solovev, Regina Khazieva
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: Effective biomedical simulators are becoming increasingly necessary. There is an urgent need for realistic, accessible, and multifunctional physical models of the heart to train future cardiac surgeons and echocardiography specialists. The simulators presented on the market are often either excessively expensive or do not provide sufficient functional accuracy. The proposed complex simulates basic hemodynamic parameters, such as stroke volume, heart rate, and chamber pressure

title: Design and Implementation of a Low-Altitude Situational Awareness System for Helicopters Based on Radar Detection Technology
authors: Zhichao Xiao, Yuanjin Peng, Liang Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Low-altitude helicopter operations face complex obstacle environments and collision risks. The millimeter-wave radar-based low-altitude situational awareness system designed herein employs a distributed architecture and multi-level signal processing workflow to achieve comprehensive environmental perception and real-time situational awareness generation. The system integrates deep learning algorithms to enhance obstacle recognition capabilities and utilizes augmented reality technology for intuitive display and early warning. Flight validation demonstrates that this system significantly enhances helicopter low-altitude flight safety, providing effective technical support for military and civilian low-altitude helicopter operations.

title: An Evaluation Method for Aerospace Engine Failure Modes Based on Fuzzy AHP-GA-BP Neural Network
authors: Borui Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Addressing the bottleneck problems in aerospace engine failure mode evaluation, where traditional methods struggle to handle the fuzziness of expert knowledge and nonlinear risk mapping, this paper proposes an intelligent assessment model that integrates fuzzy analytic hierarchy process (FAHP) and a back propagation (BP) neural network optimized by a genetic algorithm (GA). A three-layer GA-BP network is designed, utilizing the GA to globally optimize the initial weights and thresholds. Experiments demonstrate that compared to a traditional BP neural network, the GA-BP model reduces the mean absolute error (MAE) by 83.0% and the mean squared error (MSE) by 98.2%, significantly enhancing the identification capability for high-risk failure modes.

title: Topic Modeling of Indonesian-Language Travel Reviews on Things to Do in Bali Using BERTopic and IndoBERT
authors: I Komang Tryana Mertayasa, Lili Ayu Wulandhari
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: User-generated reviews on travel platforms offer valuable insights into tourist experiences, but analyzing such data in local languages like Indonesian remains underexplored. This research addresses the problem of uncovering latent topics from Indonesian-language reviews in the "Things to Do" section on TripAdvisor, focusing on tourist attractions in Bali. To tackle this, we propose a topic modeling approach using BERTopic enhanced with IndoBERT embeddings. The dataset is divided into three categories beach, nature, and temple tourism with each category modeled independently to preserve contextual relevance. Through extensive hyperparameter tuning, the model achieved coherence scores of 0.6147 for nature, 0.5298 for temple, and 0.4539 for beach reviews. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of combining transformer-based embeddings and multimodal data preprocessing to generate coherent, interpretable topics from Indonesian travel reviews. These findings suggest that BERTopic with IndoBERT is well suited for Indonesian tourism review analysis, offering insights into visitor perceptions across various attraction types.

title: A Hybrid CNN and LSTM Approach for Stock Price Forecasting on the Five Leading FMCG Company in Indonesia
authors: Clarence Mylordick, Lili Ayu Wulandhari
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: The global economy is influenced by various factors, among which stock prices play an important role. Grounded analysis and informed decisions are essential skills for investors to succeed in the stock market business. With the advancement of modern technology development, artificial intelligence can be utilized to make predictions of stock prices. Deep learning models have shown potential in making predictions. However, a deep learning model that yields good results for one company’s stock may not perform as well on others. For this reason, this research aims to compare the performance of a well-known deep learning model, CNN-LSTM, with other models on the leading five FMCG companies in Indonesia. Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) was first applied to each dataset. Then, the datasets were preprocessed and trained using different models with hyperparameter tuning. To measure model performance, metrics such as Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score were used. After experiment and analysis, the best result from all companies averages an MAE and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 64,96 and 0,894 respectively. These results came from more than one model, as CNN-LSTM and LSTM-CNN performed better across the companies. These results may be influenced by the unique fluctuations in each company’s stock price, which could be better captured by different deep learning models.

title: Handling Imbalanced Data in Random Forest Algorithms Using SMOTE and ADASYN Methods for Rainfall Classification in Bandung City
authors: Alyka Utami Zialuna, Rukun Santoso, Puspita Kartikasari, Rizwan Arisandi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Rainfall is a significant natural phenomenon that impacts various sectors of life especially in tropical countries like Indonesia. Rainfall prediction is essential to support planning in agriculture, environmental management, and disaster mitigation. The random forest algorithm is widely used in weather data classification due to its ability to handle complex data. Challenges occur when the data is imbalanced, meaning that the number of instances in each class differs significantly. This condition causes the model to be biased toward the majority class. Data balancing methods such as Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) and Adaptive Synthetic Sampling Approach (ADASYN) are used to overcome this issue. This study aims to determine the effect of applying SMOTE and ADASYN on the performance of the random forest algorithm in classifying rainfall data in Bandung City. Evaluation was carried out using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score metrics. The results show that the random forest model without balancing achieved an accuracy of only 70.3%, whereas after applying SMOTE and ADASYN the accuracy increased to 84% and 79%, respectively. Precision, recall, and F1-score values also improved significantly. Based on these findings, it can be concluded that SMOTE is more effective than ADASYN in improving the classification performance of imbalanced rainfall data.

title: Toward Understanding the Adoption and Role of Communities of Practice in Large-Scale Agile Software Development
authors: Franziska Tobisch, Florian Matthes
abstract: Organizational responsiveness has become critical for organizations, particularly in the software development industry, leading to the widespread adoption of agile methodologies. While agile practices have demonstrated effectiveness in smallscale settings, their implementation at scale introduces considerable challenges related to coordination, communication, alignment, and collaboration between teams and units. Communities of Practice (CoPs) can be a mechanism to address these challenges by connecting roles or individuals interested in a specific topic within the scaled agile setting. However, insights on the role and functioning of CoPs across different large-scale agile contexts remain limited. Therefore, we conducted a literature review that systematically synthesizes 53 empirical studies to examine how CoPs support organizations in successfully scaling agility. Our review provides a consolidated understanding of CoPs as enablers of adopting agile methods at scale, gives recommendations for practitioners, and identifies areas for future research.

title: Efficiency Improvement of a Half-Bridge Dual-Active-Bridge Converter Under Light-Load Conditions
authors: Tzu-Chiang Kao, Le-Ren Chang-Chien, Chung-Chia Wu
abstract: The dual-active-bridge (DAB) converter is widely used in electric charging systems due to its bidirectional power flow capability, grid-friendly interface, and structural simplicity. However, under light-load conditions and a conversion ratio $M\lt 1$, the conventional single-phase-shift DAB may lose its zero-voltage-switching (ZVS) capability, resulting in decreased efficiency. This paper proposes a Switched-Capacitor-Assisted Half-Bridge Dual-Active-Bridge (SC-HBDAB) DC-DC converter to enhance efficiency under light-load and $M\lt 1$ conditions. First, the ZVS operating mechanism of the SC-HB-DAB is illustrated using vector diagrams across various load conditions. Then, the proposed architecture is analyzed to verify the effectiveness of ZVS operation at light loads and low output voltages. Experimental results demonstrate that the SC-HB-DAB achieves up to a $10 \%$ efficiency improvement compared to a conventional half-bridge DAB under light-load conditions (below $10 \%$ of rated power), confirming the performance benefits of the proposed design.

title: Power Loss Forecasting in Distribution Systems Using A3T-GCN
authors: Muhammad Hadi Putra, Syukron Abu Ishaq Alfarozi, Avrin Nur Widiastuti
abstract: Precise forecasting of power losses in electrical distribution systems is critical to maintaining voltage stability, reducing energy waste, and lowering operational costs. Traditional methods include load-flow analysis and statistical regression, which often fail to capture the inner complexity of relationships among network nodes and time-varying load patterns. To overcome this, we propose a deep learning model called A3T-GCN, which combines graph-based learning for spatial features, recurrent networks for time sequences, and an attention mechanism to focus on the most relevant historical data. We trained and tested this model using hourly data from Bengkulu Province, Indonesia, between January and August 2025. We evaluated the model in six forecasting horizons from 1 hour up to 1 month. The model outperformed others: from the shortest to the longest horizon, with a percentage increase in RMSE at 36.54% and in MAE at 44.54%, the benchmark models exceeded 70% and 100%, respectively. The results show that A3TGCN plays a significant role in improving energy efficiency and maintaining voltage stability, while also serving as a valuable tool for optimizing infrastructure planning and investment strategies in distribution systems.

title: Government Guidance Funds and Total Factor Productivity in Renewable Energy Enterprises: Insights From Financing Capability and Innovation Input Structure
authors: Jiawen Xie, Boqiang Lin
abstract: High-quality renewable energy development requires a shift to a productivity-driven growth model and government guidance funds emerge as a crucial industrial policy tool for new industries. However, the role of government guidance funds in improving firm-level productivity in the renewable energy sector remains underexplored. Based on data from government guidance fund investment events and a sample of listed renewable energy firms in China from 2008 to 2022, this study employs a two-way fixed effects model to examine the correlation between government guidance funds and renewable energy companies' total factor productivity. Our results indicate that: (1) Government guidance funds are associated with productivity improvements in the renewable energy sectors. The robustness of the main findings is verified through multiple approaches addressing potential endogeneity, including propensity score matching, Heckman selection, dynamic panel, instrumental variable, and staggered difference-in-differences methods. (2) Financing capability and innovation input are two important influence paths. (3) The effects of government guidance funds on productivity promotion exhibit heterogeneity in renewable energy firms, under the influence factors including corporate risk-taking, industry competition, and regional factor markets. This study contributes to the literature on renewable energy policy incentives and government venture capital, providing theoretical and practical insights for leveraging government guidance funds to advance the low-carbon energy transition.

title: Blind Recognition of Reed-Solomon Codes Using Efficient Single-Error Correction
authors: Hao Wang, Zhuolun Wu, Wei Zhang, Yihan Wang, Yanyan Liu
abstract: This paper proposes a blind recognition method for Reed-Solomon (RS) codes that is both low in complexity and capable of single-error recognition and correction. Existing methods based on the Galois field Fourier transform (GFFT) still rely on error-free polynomials for recognition. The proposed solution to this problem is a blind recognition algorithm with single-error recognition and correction under harsh channel conditions. The approach involves calculating a part of the spectrum, which allows for accurately identifying a received polynomial with a single error and its error position, making it possible due to the property of the finite field of the Galois field, enabling recognition without the need for error-free polynomials. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves higher recognition performance with lower computational complexity compared to existing methods.

title: High-Resolution Mapping of Dry and Wet Snow Using Multi-Source Remote Sensing Data in Mountainous Regions
authors: Yonghui Zhang, Xiaodong Huang, Ying Ma, Yuxin Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate identification of dry and wet snow extents is crucial for runoff modeling and water resource management. This study, carried out in Qilian County from January 26 to May 2, 2020, introduces a novel approach that integrates optical and synthetic aperture radar (SAR) data to map snow cover conditions. Specifically, snow extent was derived from fused MODIS and Landsat-8 OLI data using the Enhanced Spatial and Temporal Adaptive Reflectance Fusion Model (ESTARFM), which generated 7-day mean Landsat-8 simulated images with a spatial resolution of 30 m. The snow extent was classified using the SNOMAP algorithm. The wet snow extent was identified using a multi-temporal, multi-polarization change detection algorithm applied to Sentinel-1 SAR data, with local incidence angle (LIA) correction. Corrections for dry and wet snow extents were made by estimating the mean elevation of wet snow across different slope orientations. Ultimately, we produced maps of dry and wet snow extents at a spatial resolution of 30 m for every 7-day period. The results demonstrate that the fusion of MODIS and Landsat-8 images performs effectively, with R² values between the corresponding bands of simulated and real images exceeding 0.73. The extent of dry and wet snow in the study area exhibits significant variability with temperature and undergoes multiple melting processes. The method proposed in this study enables continuous and detailed monitoring of large-scale snowmelt processes, providing essential scientific support for extensive studies on energy, climate, and the water cycle.

title: WPTCE 2025 – IEEE Wireless Power Technology Conference and Expo, June 3–6, 2025, Rome, Italy
authors: Francesca Maradei, Mauro Feliziani
abstract: The IEEE Wireless Power Technology Conference and Expo (WPTCE) is the world's largest and most prestigious event dedicated to wireless power transfer (WPT). As an annual event rotating among North America, Europe, and Asia-Pacific, WPTCE serves as the central hub for the latest breakthroughs and collaborations in the WPT ecosystem. The conference brings together the global community of engineers, researchers, and industry leaders advancing the future of wireless power. WPT is enabling a true technological revolution powering electric vehicles in motion, energizing biomedical implants and flying devices, and even harvesting solar energy from space.

title: Optimizing Online Gaming Performance: The Impact of DSL Interleave Modes on Latency
authors: Mustafa Serdar Osmanca
abstract: Online gaming performance is highly dependent on low latency, as even small delays can disrupt gameplay and reduce competitiveness. Türk Telekom provides both fiber and DSL-based internet connections. In DSL connections, interleave modes have a significant impact on latency. This study investigates the effect of two interleave modes, interleave-0 (fastpath) and interleave-16, on gaming performance, focusing on their influence on ping values and connection stability. Experimental measurements were conducted on multiple DSLAM and modem types, both with and without IPTV service. This paper indicates that interleave-0 mode can substantially reduce ping times and download latency, in some cases nearly halving them (e.g., from 22 ms to 13 ms for ping and from 55 ms to 17ms for download latency on H-chassis DSLAMs with 100 Mbps connections). This improvement leads to smoother online gameplay and an enhanced user experience. The study used Huawei and ZTE modems across H- and V-chassis DSLAMs, providing actionable insights for ISPs.

title: Bistable Stochastic Resonance for Weak Signal Detection: Constructing A New Asymmetric Unsaturated Potential Function
authors: Yifan Wang, Hang Geng, Kai Chen, Zhen Liu, Bo Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The stochastic resonance (SR) method enhances the weak periodic signal by transferring the noise energy to that of the weak signal, and is regarded as an excellent tool to extract weak signal from strong noise environment. Among the various SR methods, the classical bistable SR (CBSR) method is the most widely use one due to its simplicity and conciseness, but the output saturation phenomenon exhibited by the CBSR limits its weak signal enhancement ability, resulting in unsatisfactory signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) thresholds for detecting weak signals. Aiming at overcoming the output saturation issue of CBSR and further reducing the SNR detection threshold, this paper proposes a new under-damped unsaturated piecewise asymmetric bistable stochastic resonance (UDUPABSR) method by taking advantage of a newly established unsaturated bistable potential function as well as a newly constructed second-order SR system. Furthermore, the output SNR of the proposed UDUPABSR method is determined to represent the capability of weak signal enhancement, and the particle swarm optimization (PSO) method is used to optimize the corresponding system parameters. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated by using both simulated weak periodic signals and real rolling bearing fault datasets of different fault types. Validation results show that the proposed method has better weak signal enhancement ability in terms of noise suppression and signal augmentation in comparison with existing SR methods.

title: Adaptive UAV-Aided Fair Task Offloading with Fuzzy Caching for Vehicular Edge Computing via Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Qin Yang, Sang-Jo Yoo
abstract: Vehicular edge computing (VEC) faces critical challenges due to overloaded ground networks, high traffic demand, and limited resources, resulting in delayed responses and task failures. To address these issues, we propose an adaptive ground-air collaboration that integrates roadside unit (RSU) and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) networks. Unlike existing methods with a fixed UAV configuration, our system dynamically learns when to deploy or retract UAVs based on real-time conditions, thereby improving aerial resource utilization. We introduce UDMP-CTOP, a two-timescale hierarchical framework based on proximal policy optimization (PPO), which consists of UAV deployment management (UDMP) and collaborative task offloading (CTOP). A multi-objective utility function is designed to minimize system costs while ensuring regional fairness, preventing localized performance degradation during global optimization. In addition to learning optimal policies for task offloading and cache placement, we address the underexplored cache replacement problem under edge memory constraints. To this end, we propose a fuzzy logic-based cache replacement (FCR) mechanism that considers data recency, frequency, and volume. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the proposed algorithms achieve superior task success rates and low system costs under diverse conditions, yielding higher total utility across various topologies while reducing UAV energy consumption.

title: A Parallel PPO-Based Federated Transfer Reinforcement Learning Method for Multiple Home Energy Management via Cross-Domain Adaption
authors: Yiwen Zhang, Zhen Mei, Huaiguang Jiang, Ying Xue, Wei-Neng Chen, Jun Zhang, Wenzhong Gao
abstract: The research on home energy management systems (HEMSs) has attracted wide attention because of the development trend of urban smart buildings. However, coordinating various homes is a nontrivial task due to uncertainties regarding renewable energy, user behavior, and the concern of privacy disclosure. The complex properties of household appliances further put forward requirements for the decision-making procedure. To solve these, this article proposes a novel federated transfer framework based on a teacher–student learning paradigm for the energy optimization process. The pretrained model based on an open-source building environment is introduced to assist the learning procedure under a cross-domain adaption mechanism, which avoids the time-consuming learning process from scratch. Considering household appliance discrepancies, a hybrid proximal policy optimization method with discrete-continuous action space is proposed to schedule these devices optimally. Extensive experiments have demonstrated the effectiveness of our proposed method in terms of training performance, cost efficiency, and comfort level.

title: SDAD: Structured Semantic Disentanglement and Attention Diffusion for Open-Vocabulary Grasping_supp1-3647137.mp4
authors: Kai Sun
abstract: Open-vocabulary grasping is essential for enabling robots to operate robustly in open and dynamic real-world environments. Current methods typically focus on predicting grasp poses from fused cross-modal features. The coupling of visual features and textual semantics in the feature space results in scene-level representations. However, such representations lack object-level discrimination, thereby limiting the model’s ability to recognize and generalize to novel targets. Moreover, existing positional encoding methods employed in cross-modal modeling lack the capacity to effectively capture spatial relationships between regions, which limits the model’s spatial reasoning performance. To tackle these challenges, we propose a method that combines Structured Semantic Disentanglement with Attention Diffusion (SDAD) for open-vocabulary robotic grasping. Specifically, to improve the semantic disentanglement in cross-modal features, a language-guided Disentanglement strategy that regularizes the feature space is proposed to disentangle target semantics features and conditional semantics features. To further improve spatial context modeling, we introduce an attention diffusion mechanism inspired by Fick’s law, which describes natural diffusion driven by concentration gradients, enabling attention to propagate smoothly from condition-feature-anchored regions across the scene. The target features are subsequently used to complete the matching and localization of the corresponding object regions. Extensive quantitative and qualitative experiments demonstrate that our method outperforms existing approaches in open-vocabulary grasping tasks. Moreover, in real-world scenarios, the proposed model achieves a grasp success rate of 84% on base categories and 66% on novel categories, outperforming the state-of-the-art method GLIPv2 by 7% and 5%, respectively.

title: PriDFL: Computation-optimized Secure Aggregation with Byzantine-resilient in Decentralized Federated Learning_supp1-3646726.pdf
authors: Youliang Tian
abstract: Privacy-preserving federated learning (PPFL) is a strong-privacy distributed learning paradigm, which typically employs secure aggregation (SA) protocols to protect the aggregation results of federated learning. However, the high computational cost of existing SA protocols is difficult to generalize to decentralized federated learning (DFL) with the large number of clients and fails to defend against model poisoning attacks launched by Byzantine adversaries. In this paper, we propose an efficient computational SA protocol compatible with DFL, referred to as PriDFL, and address the issue of Byzantine-robust aggregation. Specifically, we design an advanced secret-sharing protocol based on number-theoretic transformations to reduce the computational complexity from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O(n^{2})$</tex-math></inline-formula> to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {O}(n\log n)$</tex-math></inline-formula> during data sharing. We employ a single-mask approach to provide lightweight gradient privacy protection for DFL. To mitigate the impact of poisoned gradients on model convergence, we develop a Byzantine resilience criterion grounded in model cross-updating. The proposed criterion efficiently detects poisoned gradients and non-independent identically distributed (non-IID) data with local computation. Security analysis shows that PriDFL satisfies the security requirements in an honest but curious setting. We evaluate PriDFL on typical datasets (e.g., MNIST and CIFAR-10) and the results show that PriDFL is computation-communication efficient and Byzantine resilient. In particular, PriDFL optimizes the computational efficiency by 6-10× compared to the well-utilized SA protocols while supporting Byzantine robustness.

title: Selective Mapping-Aided CE-OFDM: A Robust Waveform Against Phase Wrapping for IoT Networks
authors: Hao Chen, Yue Xiao, Yanrui Wang, Lilin Dan, Saviour Zammit, Ming Xiao
abstract: Constant envelope orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (CE-OFDM) has attracted increasing attention as a power-efficient modulation scheme for Internet of Things (IoT) networks, particularly in energy-constrained scenarios such as space–air–ground integrated networks (SAGINs). Despite its inherently low peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR), CE-OFDM suffers from significant bit error rate (BER) degradation due to nonlinear phase wrapping caused by phase modulation. To address this limitation, we propose a selective mapping (SLM)-aided CE-OFDM scheme, in which the transmit sequence with the minimum number of phase jumps is selected from a pre-defined set of candidates. This strategy effectively mitigates the impact of phase wrapping and significantly improves BER performance. Furthermore, to eliminate the spectral overhead caused by conventional side information transmission, we propose an embedded side information (ESI) mechanism that seamlessly incorporates index data into the transmitted signal without requiring additional bandwidth. Simulation results verify that the proposed SLM-aided CE-OFDM scheme, equipped with ESI, achieves substantial BER improvements over conventional CE-OFDM systems, while maintaining the low-PAPR property essential for energy-constrained IoT devices.

title: Minimum-Cost Charger Deployment for Long-Running Multitask Applications in Large-Scale Sensor Networks
authors: Lijie Xu, Longsheng Chai, Tianyu Pang, Xin Zhai, Jialei Zhang, Jia Xu
abstract: Wireless sensor networks face significant challenges in large-scale multitask scenarios (LSM-WSNs), where traditional data collection methods lead to high energy consumption and packet collisions. Mobile data collection, employing mobile collectors, mitigates these issues but introduces electricity shortages due to limited battery capacity. This paper addresses the core research problem of minimizing charger deployment costs while ensuring uninterrupted power for mobile collectors in long-running LSM-WSNs. We formulate the Minimum-Cost Charger Deployment (MCCD) problem, prove its NP-hardness, and establish its equivalence to the Overflow-Free MCCD (OF-MCCD) problem. By refining constraints and transforming OF-MCCD into a Minimum-Cost Submodular Cover (MCSC) problem, we propose a greedy algorithm with an approximation ratio of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$ln\gamma +1$</tex-math></inline-formula>, where <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gamma$</tex-math></inline-formula> is a system parameter. Further, we extend MCCD problem to adjustable power allocation case, showing that continuous power allocation reduces to linear programming, while discrete power allocation remains NP-hard, for which we devise an efficient <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$ln\gamma +1$</tex-math></inline-formula>-approximation solution. Additionally, we tackle the Charger Deployment Extension (CDE) problem for evolving network requirements. The unique contributions include the first systematic study of cost-optimal charger deployment for LSM-WSNs, novel problem formulations, and theoretically grounded algorithms with provable guarantees. Simulations validate that our solutions outperform baselines across diverse scenarios.

title: Development of a Preclinical PET Scanner With DOI Capabilities Using Semi-Monolithic Detectors
authors: Neus Cucarella, Marta Freire, Antonio J. González, David Sánchez, Andrea Gonzalez-Montoro, Santiago Jiménez-Serrano, Francis Loignon-Houle, Laura Moliner, Celia Valladares, Peter Bruyndonckx, Carlos Correcher, José M. Benlloch
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Most preclinical PET scanners are based on pixelated detectors without Depth of Interaction (DOI) capabilities, which is crucial to correct for parallax errors. Semi-monolithic crystals have the potential to combine the timing capabilities of pixelated crystals and the 3D positioning accuracy of monolithic scintillators. In this work, we present a preclinical PET prototype consisting of 2 rings defining an inner diameter of 106 mm and an axial length of 52 mm. Each ring contains 14 arrays of 1 × 22 LYSO slabs of 0.97 mm × 25.6 mm × 12 mm, coupled to 8 × 8 SiPMs arrays. The sensitivity, spatial resolution, count rate performance and image quality were studied using the NEMA NU 4-2008 protocol. All images were reconstructed using the MLEM algorithm with 0.5 mm voxel size, including DOI information and normalization correction. A mean spatial resolution for all measured positions and across the three directions (axial, transaxial and radial) of 1.61 ± 0.19 mm was obtained at the center of the FOV. A peak sensitivity of 3.5% was obtained at the center of the scanner, for an energy window (EW) between 358 keV -664 keV. The noise equivalent count rate peak reached 106.9 kcps for an activity of 11.7 MBq using the mouse-sized phantom, the same EW window and a time coincidence window of 10 ns. For the image quality phantom, contrast recovery coefficients of 0.20, 0.62, 0.75, 0.81 and 0.85 were found for the 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 mm rods, respectively. Spill-over-ratio values of 0.10 for air-filled and 0.23 for water-filled cylinders were measured. Also, according to the Rayleigh criterion, 1.5, 1.2 and 1 mm hot spots of a micro-Derenzo phantom were well distinguished.

title: Offline Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for 6G Communications: Fundamentals, Applications and Future Directions
authors: Eslam Eldeeb, Hirley Alves
abstract: The next-generation wireless technologies, including beyond 5G and 6G networks, are paving the way for transformative applications such as vehicle platooning, smart cities, and remote surgery. These innovations are driven by a vast array of interconnected wireless entities, including IoT devices, access points, UAVs, and CAVs, which increase network complexity and demand more advanced decision-making algorithms. Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML), especially reinforcement learning (RL), are key enablers for such networks, providing solutions to high-dimensional and complex challenges. However, as networks expand to multi-agent environments, traditional online RL approaches face cost, safety, and scalability limitations. Offline multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) offers a promising solution by utilizing pre-collected data, reducing the need for real-time interaction. This article introduces a novel offline MARL algorithm based on conservative Q-learning (CQL), ensuring safe and efficient training. We extend this with meta-learning to address dynamic environments and validate the approach through use cases in radio resource management and UAV networks. Our work highlights offline MARL’s advantages, limitations, and future directions in wireless applications.

title: KAFL-HD: Knowledge Alignment in Asynchronous Federated Learning With Heterogeneous Data
authors: Mingjian Zhi, Yuanguo Bi, Lin Cai, Tianao Xiang
abstract: Asynchronous Federated Learning (AFL) can mitigate the straggler problem due to unbalanced training time of clients in Synchronous Federated Learning (SFL), thereby reducing the aggregation time and improving the training efficiency. However, AFL introduces training bias since different updating frequencies of heterogeneous clients can cause unequal knowledge contributions to the global model. Meanwhile, if the client data are heterogeneous, the local optimum may be drifted from the global one, which exacerbates the training bias problem. In order to solve the above issues, we propose a Knowledge Alignment framework for AFL with Heterogeneous Data, termed as KAFL-HD. Firstly, considering data heterogeneity, a data quality-aware aggregation method is proposed to estimate client contributions precisely, where both model staleness and data quality are utilized in aggregation weights. Secondly, a knowledge distillation method with staleness is designed to supplement more knowledge from slow clients to the global model. Thirdly, an adaptive learning rate adjustment method is proposed to customize the local learning rate based on the aggregation frequency and weight, which aligns the knowledge contributions of clients in the local training process. Furthermore, we provide theoretical analysis under a non-convex setting to show the convergence speed of KAFL-HD. Finally, comprehensive experiments are conducted, and the results show that KAFL-HD achieves the highest accuracy and fairness performance compared to the state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Wavelength-Tunable Cascade Raman Lasing beyond 2 Microns in a Tellurite Microresonator
authors: Elena A. Anashkina, Arseny A. Sorokin, Alexey V. Andrianov
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate tunable cascade Raman lasing in a 34-μm microsphere fabricated from tungsten-tellurite glass, which possesses high and ultrabroadband Raman gain. Lasing was observed in the first cascade from 1665 nm to 1895 nm and in the second cascade from 1952 nm to 2189 nm when the pump wavelength was tuned from 1488 nm to 1612 nm. To the best of our knowledge, the 2189 nm wavelength is the longest wavelength ever achieved via Raman generation or other nonlinear optical processes in tellurite glass microresonators. We also constructed and analyzed a theoretical model incorporating four nonlinearly interacting Raman modes. The model accounts for two modes in the first cascade and two in the second. Each of these modes is associated with a different peak of the Raman gain function. The results of numerical simulations support and explain the experimental findings.

title: Seamless Inverter Control for Clean Voltage in Standalone and Clean Current in Grid-Connected
authors: Mehdi Pourmohammad, Mohammad Ebrahimi, S. Ali Khajehoddin
abstract: In many applications, inverter-based distributed energy resources (DERs) must operate in both grid-connected (GC) and standalone (SA) modes. To meet standards, inverters are required to deliver purely sinusoidal current in GC mode and purely sinusoidal voltage in SA mode. This article proposes a novel control structure that delivers high-quality output voltage and current in SA and GC modes, respectively. Unlike many existing approaches, the proposed structure also provides active damping of LCL output filter resonance, current limiting, and ensures seamless mode transitions. In addition, a systematic and optimal design procedure is presented to achieve fast dynamics, enabling higher order harmonic rejection without sacrificing stability or robustness against uncertainties such as load type or grid impedance. The effectiveness of the proposed control structure is validated through simulations and experiments across various scenarios, demonstrating its superior performance.

title: Consistent Identification for FIR Systems With Multilevel Quantized Observations Subjected to Data Tampering Attacks: A Joint Estimation Approach
authors: Wenke Liu, Yinghui Wang, Jin Guo
abstract: With the rapid development of artificial intelligence technology and Internet of Things technology, cyber–physical systems (CPSs) have also been fully developed, which promotes the widespread use of CPS in a variety of areas and brings many new opportunities and challenges. This article considers the consistent identification of finite impulse response (FIR) systems with multilevel quantized observations subjected to data tampering attacks. First, a defense algorithm based on known parameters is designed for the case where the attack is known. Second, on the basis of the algorithm with known attack, a joint consistent estimation approach is proposed for estimating system parameters, and the convergence and asymptotic normality of the algorithm are proved. Then, according to the asymptotic normality of the algorithm, the trace of the defense algorithm’s asymptotic error covariance matrix is used as the defense index to establish the optimal defense model. Finally, the effectiveness of the defense strategy is verified through experiments.

title: Class-Domain Incremental Segmentation for Remote Sensing Images
authors: Xingxing Weng, Chao Pang, Jiayu Li, Xiaoqian Sun, Gui-Song Xia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Significant progress has been made in class-incremental (learning new classes without forgetting old ones) and domain-incremental (adapting to data from different distributions) semantic segmentation for remote sensing images. However, in real-world deployment, class-space changes and distribution shifts may co-occur between old and new data. Existing incremental learning methods typically address only one type of shift, struggling to handle joint class and domain incremental learning. To achieve class-domain incremental segmentation, we propose CDISeg, a novel framework that enables cross-domain knowledge accumulation through feature synthesis. CDISeg employs a temporary style encoder while repurposing the segmentation model’s backbone as the content encoder. By enforcing orthogonality between their outputs, the model disentangles image content from style, thereby preserving domainspecific style features throughout incremental learning steps. The framework synthesizes old-domain features by projecting old-domain styles onto new-domain content, which supports the preservation of old knowledge, extends new classes to past domains, and facilitates the learning of old classes over new-domain images. Additionally, we introduce class-aware style randomization to enhance feature disentanglement and improve synthesis quality. Extensive experiments on ISPRS and Open-EarthMap datasets demonstrate the remarkable superiority of CDISeg in enabling models to progressively acquire new classes from new domains while recognizing all learned classes across all encountered domains.

title: Conan: Secure and Reliable Machine Learning Inference against Malicious Service Providers
authors: Hanxiao Chen, Hongwei Li, Meng Hao, Pengzhi Xing, Jia Hu, Wenbo Jiang, Tianwei Zhang, Guowen Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: In the Machine Learning as a Service paradigm, a service provider (e.g., a server) hosting a model offers inference APIs to clients, who can send their queries and receive the inference results. While most recent secure inference works focus on addressing privacy issues, they overlook the importance of checking the service quality and reliability. A malicious server may deviate from the protocol specification to deliberately provide incorrect services such as using low-quality models. Thus, it is necessary to design new solutions to empower clients to verify the server’s model accuracy and inference integrity while protecting both parties’ privacy. We present Conan, a new secure and reliable inference framework against malicious servers to achieve accuracy verification, inference integrity, and privacy simultaneously. In Conan, the server first commits to the model and proves in zero-knowledge that the committed model achieves the claimed accuracy. Then both parties perform secure inference on the committed model against the malicious server. To instantiate the above framework, we design generic maliciously secure two-party computation (2PC) protocols with a fixed corrupted party, which may be of independent interest. Our protocols achieve high efficiency by utilizing the advantage that the semi-honest party can check the behavior of the corrupted party. Furthermore, they support both arithmetic and Boolean circuit evaluation, a crucial attribute for secure inference on complicated machine learning models. We implement the fixed-corruption 2PC protocols for our secure and reliable inference. The experimental results show 1 ~ 2 orders of magnitude improvements over conventional maliciously secure protocols in terms of communication and computation costs.

title: A Customer-Focused Resilience Enhancement Planning Framework in Distribution Systems Through a Leader-Follower Approach
authors: Amin Alavi-Eshkaftaki, Mohammad Amin Latify, Mahmoud Fotuhi-Firuzabad, Payman Dehghanian, Mohammad Sadegh Ghazizadeh
abstract: This paper proposes a customer-focused resilience enhancement planning framework in power distribution systems considering a leader-follower approach under appropriate regulatory mechanisms. The regulator, distribution system operator (DSO), and customers are the key players in this framework, implemented through a three-step process. Firstly, the regulator establishes a penalty-reward model (PRM). Subsequently, the revenue-cap regulation is applied, and finally, customers' participation is incorporated through a leader-follower approach, modeled using a bi-level optimization problem. This approach considers the individual objectives of the DSO (as the leader) and interested customers to invest in self-generation (as followers), reflecting the accuracy, realism, and practicality of this framework since each entity looks for optimizing its own objective. Furthermore, the incentives provided by the DSO for customers' participation are directly modeled into the objectives of both the leader and followers. The proposed stochastic bi-level optimization problem, which takes the form of a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model, is solved using a reformulation and decomposition technique based on the column-and-constraint generation. Deploying the IEEE 33-bus test system exposed to a hurricane, the capability of the proposed framework is validated in enhancing the energy supply resilience under the regulatory objectives while achieving economic benefits for all involved entities.

title: Improving the Accuracy of DC Optimal Power Flow Formulations Via Parameter Optimization
authors: Babak Taheri, Daniel K. Molzahn
abstract: DC Optimal Power Flow (DC-OPF) problems optimize the generators' active power setpoints while satisfying constraints based on the DC power flow linearization. The computational tractability advantages of DC-OPF problems come at the expense of inaccuracies relative to AC Optimal Power Flow (AC-OPF) problems that accurately model the nonlinear steady-state behavior of power grids. This paper proposes an algorithm that significantly improves the accuracy of the generators' active power setpoints from DC-OPF problems with respect to the corresponding AC-OPF problems over a specified range of operating conditions. Using sensitivity information in a machine learning-inspired methodology, this algorithm tunes coefficient and bias parameters in the DC power flow approximation to improve the accuracy of the resulting DC-OPF solutions. Employing the Truncated Newton Conjugate-Gradient (TNC) method, a Quasi-Newton optimization technique, this parameter tuning occurs during an offline training phase, with the resulting parameters then used in online computations. Numerical results underscore the algorithm's efficacy with accuracy improvements in squared two-norm and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\infty$</tex-math></inline-formula>-norm losses of up to 90% and 79%, respectively, relative to traditional DC-OPF formulations.

title: Out of Core and Adaptive Image Blending Approach for Large Scale Image Mosaics
authors: Marcus Quincy, Steve Petruzza
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th Symposium on Large Data Analysis and Visualization (LDAV)
abstract: Color blending is a widely used technique in mosaic or panorama image processing, particularly for seamlessly combining images with varying lighting or weather conditions. One key application is in aerial image mosaics, where seams often arise between images captured by aircraft. Blending large-scale mosaics, however, typically requires access to global image information, resulting in high memory demands. Prior work has addressed this challenge either through interactive local blending or by leveraging high-performance computing (HPC) systems with distributed memory.In this work, we present an out-of-core blending approach that processes large mosaics tile by tile using an iterative Poisson solver. Our method leverages a downsampled global mosaic to guide local blending, eliminating the need to load the full-resolution dataset into memory. We further introduce two adaptive execution strategies that vary the number of solver iterations per tile, improving both efficiency and quality. We demonstrate our approach using large orthomosaic datasets from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), and implement the pipeline using the SYCL programming model for cross-platform portability.

title: FPGA-Based Feedback Deadbeat Speed Control for PMSM Drives Considering Mechanical Resonance
authors: Ryosuke Morita, Sari Maekawa, Takeshi Shibayama, Toshimitsu Aizawa
abstract: This study proposes feedback deadbeat speed control using FPGA for PMSMs considering mechanical resonance. While existing two-degree-of-freedom deadbeat methods offer high tracking performance, they depend on conventional PI controllers and notch filters for feedback control. This paper applies deadbeat control to the feedback loop. It improves responsiveness and reduces the complexity of tuning. The control system is implemented on an FPGA, and its high-speed current control and precise speed detection enables reliable deadbeat speed control.

title: A Fast-Transient Current-Mode Buck Converter with Transient Assistance Circuit
authors: Shao-Jin Ding, Pang-Jung Liu, Lin-Hao Chien, Jian-Min Wang, Ching-Chun Chuang
abstract: This paper presents a transient assistance circuit (TAC) designed to enhance the transient response of buck converters employing peak current-mode control under sudden load variations. The TAC is activated upon detection of output voltage deviations and provides auxiliary current paths to accelerate the charging or discharging of both the output and compensation capacitors. This results in a significant reduction in output voltage recovery time. To maintain low power consumption, the TAC remains inactive during steady-state operation. The proposed design is implemented using a 0.35 μ m CMOS process. Experimental results demonstrate that the TAC reduces transient recovery time by a factor of nine and effectively suppresses output voltage ripple compared to conventional architectures, thereby confirming its superior transient performance and practical viability.

title: Machine Learning Classification to Detect Bots Using Mouse Movement
authors: N. S. Afanaseva, P. S. Lozhnikov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This paper discusses the effectiveness of various machine learning algorithms for solving the problem of bot detection based on the analysis of dynamic biometric images. Logistic regression, support vector machines, k-nearest neighbors, and random forests methods are studied. The experiments are carried out on real and synthetic datasets, with the random forest algorithm showing the best result accuracy.

title: Mulit-scale enhancing local and global features for point cloud completion network
authors: Yuchen Yang, Xuan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Due to the limitations of laser scanners, scanned point clouds often suffer from uneven density and incomplete regions, which hinder downstream 3D vision tasks such as classification and segmentation. Traditional CNN-based methods are constrained by limited receptive fields, resulting in the loss of fine-grained local structures and contextual information. To tackle these challenges, we propose a novel point cloud completion network that integrates self-attention and cross-attention mechanisms to jointly enhance global context understanding and local detail restoration. Our model adopts an encoder-decoder architecture combined with a GAN framework to improve completion fidelity and geometric consistency. Experimental results on multiple public datasets show that the proposed method achieves significant improvements in average Chamfer Distance (CD) compared to the baseline model PF-Net. Moreover, qualitative visualization results and robustness experiments further validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Self-Similar Traffic Prediction Algorithm Based on Neural Networks
authors: Xin Li, Yuxia Bie, Xiaoyu Wang, Bochen Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: To address the high-precision prediction demand for data transmission due to the self-similarity and long correlation characteristics of business traffic, this paper proposes a Self-similar traffic prediction algorithm based on Convolutional Neural Network-Bi-directional Long Short-term Memory (CNN-BiLSTM) neural networks. The algorithm firstly uses convolutional neural network to extract local features from the original traffic to effectively capture the spatial characteristics of the traffic sequence. Subsequently, the extracted features are forward, and reverse modeled by bidirectional long- and short-term memory neural network to comprehensively capture the temporal dynamics of the traffic data. Finally, the predicted traffic is generated for performance evaluation based on error and time metrics. The simulation results show that the Self-similar traffic prediction algorithm based on Convolutional Bi-directional Long Short-Term Memory neural network has higher prediction accuracy and efficiency, which effectively improves the stability and reliability of data transmission.

title: A Low-Power Consumption Image Classification Model for Abnormal States in Water Supply Stations Based on Progressive Hierarchical Inference
authors: Yongtao Yu, Kun Zhang, Linlin Zhu, Yansong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: With the heightened security requirements for critical areas within water supply stations, the need for enhanced security in key zones such as distribution rooms and pump houses has grown significantly. Real-time monitoring serves as a pivotal component in ensuring the operational maintenance of these facilities. Existing embedded intelligent perception systems, which integrate traditional security measures with deep learning, can improve automated detection capabilities. However, they commonly struggle to balance energy consumption with real-time performance. To address this, this paper proposes Resnet50-MHC, a progressive hierarchical inference image classification model based on Resnet50. This model detects abnormal human behaviour and environmental anomalies in critical station areas. It employs multi-task training through hierarchical labelling and, during inference, aligns multi-level classification tasks with model layers from coarse to fine. This progressive inference optimises power consumption and real-time performance for classification tasks. Practical testing on NVIDIA Jetson Nano and Huawei Atlas 200I DK A2 edge computing platforms demonstrates that compared to the original ResNet50, ResNet50-MHC achieves classification accuracy improvements of 3.06% and 3.07% respectively across both platforms. Inference speed increases by 42% and 50%, while average power consumption decreases by 22.6% and 7.1%. These experiments conclusively validate the model's effectiveness in enhancing detection accuracy, real-time performance, and energy efficiency, thereby providing an energy-saving and high-performance technical solution for intelligent security at water supply stations.

title: Automation of Selection of Countermeasures to Threats to Information Security of an Information Technology Object
authors: Anton Kiselev, Victor Belov, Vladislav Sosnovsky
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The paper presents an algorithm and software for implementing the procedure for generating a list of countermeasures in accordance with existing regulatory requirements for information security aimed at neutralizing current threats to information technology objects. The algorithm includes a number of steps: entering initial data; searching the database of information security measures; determining data processing technologies that are not used in the organization; generating an adapted set of information security measures; entering current threats to information security and searching for protection measures for them; outputting all work results. The software solution is implemented as a multi-page application consisting of: a welcome window, pages for selecting the system type, selecting the security level, outputting a basic set of countermeasures, selecting IT data processing, a page with an adapted set of measures, selecting current threats, and the final results of the work. The article presents testing of the program for generating a list of countermeasures taking into account the FSTEC of Russia threats database. A division of an educational institution of higher education was selected as the object under evaluation.

title: Portable 3D Scanning Technologies for Flight Ground Support: A Literature Review
authors: David Demydenko, Jan Bořil, Ludek Čičmanec
abstract: This literature review synthesizes current research and technological trends in three-dimensional (3D) scanning for Ground Support (GS) and flight traffic support. It surveys 3D scanning methods and their integration into mobile, field-deployable systems, and provides a comparative analysis across accuracy and measurement range. The review delineates requirements for mobile 3D scanning systems applicable to GS and establishes a research basis for experimental validation of selected methods and solutions. The findings underpin the integration of 3D scanning with additive manufacturing for field maintenance and repair of ground-based aviation equipment under deployment conditions.

title: Review of a Historical Timeline and Evolution of Sustainable Aviation Fuel Development
authors: Anna Yakovlieva, Rudolf Andoga, Pavol Kurdel, Sergii Boichenko, Marek Ceškovic, Natália Gecejová
abstract: The aviation sector faces urgent challenges in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, with sustainable aviation fuels recognized as the most viable near- and mid-term decarbonization solution. This review analyzes the historical timeline and evolution of sustainable aviation fuel development, from early exploratory studies through the first biofuel demonstration flights, regulatory breakthroughs, and subsequent institutional support. The analysis has revealed exponential growth in research activity and policy frameworks, with eight production pathways now certified and constantly rising global SAF production. The paper identifies key technological advances, feedstock challenges, and policy drivers, and highlights the gap between ambitious net-zero targets and the current state of sustainable aviation fuel production capacities. Novel approaches and technological solutions, which may contribute to faster decarbonization of air transport sector are considered.

title: From Image to Immersion: AI-Assisted Texture Transfer for 3D Environment Creation in the Metaverse
authors: Mutawally Syarawy, Rio Mukhtarom Paweroi, Mario Köppen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: Texture transfer plays a crucial role in 3D graphics development for the metaverse. However, traditional texturing methods are often time-consuming, require specialized artistic skills, and face scalability challenges across diverse assets. To overcome these limitations, this research introduces an AI-assisted, region-aware texture transfer framework that leverages generative AI models to efficiently extract textures from real-world images and seamlessly apply them to 3D models within virtual environments. Our approach aims to accelerate the asset creation pipeline, minimize manual effort, and enhance the visual quality of metaverse graphics.We explore two complementary methods: a guided prompt-based texture generation technique that synthesizes context-aware textures using textual prompts, and a segmentation-based method that employs region-aware segmentation for precise texture application on targeted areas of 3D objects.Experimental tests conducted across two datasets reveal that segmentation guidance significantly improves texture fidelity. On the SNED dataset, the segmentation-based method outperforms guided prompting with a 10.1% increase in CLIP similarity, a 12.7% reduction in LPIPS, and a 75.7% improvement in ResNet50 cosine similarity. On the IKEA dataset, while the improvements are more modest—such as a 2.5% increase in CLIP score and an 8.3% reduction in LPIPS—the segmentation-based method still performs competitively overall, despite a slight 1.4% drop in ResNet50 cosine similarity.These findings affirm the strong potential of generative AI to facilitate faster, more diverse, and higher-quality texture generation than conventional manual methods, enabling more efficient and scalable content creation in metaverse environments.

title: Privacy Attitudes and Data-Sharing Behaviors in AI Interactions: A Correlation and Factor Analysis Approach
authors: Shaila Rana
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: With the increasing integration of generative artificial intelligence (AI) in everyday digital interactions, understanding users’ personal information-sharing behaviors and privacy attitudes has become crucial. This study explores the extent to which individuals share personal data, their motivations for doing so, and their responses to AI retaining such information. A survey conducted via SurveyMonkey targeted a general population of individuals over 18 years old. The findings reveal three distinct user clusters: privacy-conscious, privacy-indifferent, and privacy-adaptive. Correlation analysis highlights strong links between privacy attitudes and sharing behaviors, while factor analysis identifies underlying dimensions that shape privacy decision-making. These insights highlight the need for AI service providers and policymakers to implement differentiated privacy strategies, increase transparency, and enhance user control over data-sharing preferences. The study also offers recommendations for businesses, regulatory bodies, and cybersecurity professionals to better align AI privacy policies with user expectations.

title: Development and Validation of the High Accuracy 60 m by 30 m EMC Antenna Calibration Site
authors: Mehmet Çinar, Savaş Acak, Osman Şen, Aykut Ayaydin, Serdar Büyük, Ramiz Hamid
abstract: A high accuracy 60 m × 30 m EMC antenna calibration site has been established at National Metrology Institute (TÜBÍTAK UME). The site has been built of welded steel plates as floating system and the flatness of the site floor is within ± 5 mm for 95%. Its validation was carried out in accordance with the CISPR 16-1-5 [1]. In this scope, site attenuation measurements (site insertion loss-SIL) were performed with CHINA National Institute of Metrology (NIM) calculable dipole antennas. Site attenuation measurements are than lower 0,6 dB for horizontal polarization (HP) and 1 dB for vertical polarization (VP). After the validation of the site, it can be used as a reference test site (REFTS) and a calibration test site (CALTS).
