title: Improving Energy Consumption Efficiency of Boom Cylinder System Using Hydraulic Accumulator
authors: Huu Tuan Do, Van Tram Bui, Tri Cuong Do, Tri Dung Dang, Van Hien Nguyen, Kyoung Kwan Ahn
abstract: This paper suggests an energy regeneration system that utilizes a gas accumulator connected to a piston cavity of an excavator’s boom cylinder (ERSUA). When the boom descends, the gravitational energy equivalent mass is converted into energy of oil and accumulated in the gas accumulator. This stored energy is then supplied to the suction line of the hydrostatic pump to assist during the boom lifting process. As the pressure differential across the pump is reduced, the energy required to drive the pump decreases accordingly. Simulation results using the Amesim software demonstrate that the energy requirement of the hydraulic pump is reduced by nearly 20% in the regeneration circuit. Meanwhile, kinematic factors such as boom cylinder displacement and velocity remain largely unchanged compared to the conventional system.

title: A New Novel of Backstepping Observer Model Design and its Application for Controlling of Marine Surface Vessel
authors: Nguyen Thi My Linh, Ngo Phong Nguyen, Xuan Phu Do
abstract: This paper presents a disturbance-observer-aided backstepping controller for a 3-DOF marine surface vessel subject to unknown environmental loads. A fixed-order disturbance observer estimates lumped wind/wave/current forces online and feeds them forward so that nominal backstepping gains can be kept modest while preserving stability guarantees from a composite Lyapunov analysis. On the Cybership II benchmark in MATLAB/Simulink, the method achieves ≈0.3 s settling, millimetre-level position error, and milli-radian heading error under sinusoidal disturbances, while reducing peak thrust by ~25× versus an LQR baseline; tuned PID exhibits larger steady oscillations and phase lag. These results are simulation-based (no sensor noise/actuator dynamics) but indicate an implementation-ready alternative to classical marine regulators.

title: You Only Have Seven Seconds: From Intimate Whispers to Shared Worlds in Participatory Data-Driven Cinematic Art
authors: Weidi Zhang, Lijiaozi Cheng, Paul Taro Schmidt, Jieliang Luo
abstract: You Only Have Seven Seconds is a cinematic artistic visualization derived from an interactive AI art installation (ReCollection) that explores how machine intelligence can reassemble collective human memory through language input. Motivated by the artist’s personal response to her grandmother’s cognitive decline and informed by current research in Critical Dementia Studies that advocates for reimagining—rather than repairing—memory, the project collects and curates whispered, seven-second recollections and machinegenerated image data from installation participants. These selected datasets are transformed into a generative visualization presented as a cinematic art using custom-designed AI systems and experimental visualization strategies. This paper introduces the conceptual foundations and technical development of this project, with emphasis on data collection, experimental visualization, narrative construction, sound design, and intelligent system integration. Through the design of artificial memory, You Only Have Seven Seconds constructs a dynamic archive of shared, ephemeral recollections for storytelling.

title:
Research on CO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Gas Detection Based on Mid-Infrared Light Sources
authors: Qian Wang, Feng Qi, Rui Wang, Nairui Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: This paper designs and builds a CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> gas detection system based on mid-infrared light sources. The BaGaSe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7</inf>-OPO is efficiently pumped by a 1064nm laser to achieve a continuous tunable mid-infrared light source output in a wide band of 3-8μm. With the simulation results of the Hitran database, the variation of infrared light intensity passing through carbon dioxide was detected at 4.26μm using a photodetector. The absorbance corresponding to different concentrations of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> was quantitatively calculated by combining Lambert-Beer’s law. The results show that the absorbance is significantly linearly positively correlated with the CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> concentration, and the correlation coefficient of the fitting curve between the experimental measured values and the theoretical calculated values is relatively high. This system breaks through the light source limitations of traditional single-gas detection systems. The output mid-infrared light has the characteristic of continuous tunability in a wide band of 3-8μm. Theoretically, it can achieve synchronous detection of multi-component gases with a single light source. The CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> quantitative detection method established through research offers direct reference for the development of detection technologies for other gases, and has a clear engineering application prospect.

title: PCA-Enhanced Weighted KNN for Predicting Patient Discharge Outcomes from Nursing Assessments
authors: Jong-Shin Chen, Yu-Cheng Chang, Yoshua Richard Agustinus Lesnussa
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: With the advent of an aging society, the demand for medical care continues to grow, and traditional manual documentation methods are no longer sufficient to manage and analyze large volumes of patient data efficiently. This study proposes a predictive classification model for patient discharge outcomes based on the admission nursing assessment questionnaire from a medical institution. By integrating data mining and machine learning techniques, the study employs the K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN) algorithm as the core classifier, further enhanced by Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for dimensionality reduction and Weighted KNN (WKNN) to improve classification accuracy. Additionally, random oversampling is applied to address data imbalance issues. Experiments were conducted using six training set sizes under two preprocessing strategies—basic numerical transformation and advanced numerical encoding—and evaluated in both multiclass (six-class) and binary classification tasks. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed PCA-WKNN model consistently outperforms other approaches in terms of accuracy, precision, and recall. These findings suggest that the proposed method is effective in enhancing predictive performance and holds significant potential for clinical applications in nursing care.

title: Analysis of Grid-connected Dual T-type Five-Level Inverter with Talkative Power Conversions
authors: Ch. Rajender, A. Kirubakaran
abstract: By including information into the switching ripple, Talkative Power Conversion (TPC) might lessen the need for extra communication infrastructure in cyber-physical systems such as smart grids and renewable energy plants. This allows power and data to be transmitted simultaneously, removing the need for additional hardware. Without requiring additional hardware, data injection into power converter control signals enables simultaneous power and data transfer. The five-level Dual T-type inverter used in this research has TPC technology installed, which uses the phase and switching frequency as degrees of control freedom to simultaneously modulate power and data. Dual T-type inverters with Talkative Power are connected to the grid via a PR controller to be analyzed. The accuracy and effectiveness of the theoretical analysis are well demonstrated by the simulation findings. Demodulation is done using the FFT approach. Using FSK and PSK techniques, the data was successfully transported at a rate of 200 bits per second.

title: Optimized Neural Network Model for State Estimation of Lithium-Ion Batteries
authors: Yi-Feng Luo, Sheng-Chien Ko, Chih-Hsun Chang, Kun-Che Ho, Zong-Zhen Yang
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries are widely used in electronics, electric vehicles (EVs), and energy storage systems (ESS), but their performance declines over time, reflected in changes in state of health (SOH) and state of charge (SOC). Accurate estimation of these states is essential for reliable operation. This study evaluates several optimization algorithms for artificial neural networks (ANNs) and finds that particle swarm optimization (PSO) achieves the best performance, with mean relative errors of $\mathbf{0. 8 9 3 \%}$ for SOH and $\mathbf{1. 8 6 \%}$ for SOC, confirming its effectiveness for battery state estimation.

title: A Study on Silicon Carbide (SiC) MOSFET Model Behavior Analysis and Influence of Parasitic Capacitance on Switching Characteristics
authors: Ravi Nath Tripathi, Ichiro Omura
abstract: This paper presents a study of the recent generation trench silicon carbide (SiC) MOSFET simulation model behavior analysis for switching characteristics, considering the effect of device parasitics. A MATLAB-Simulink-based device model was created using the manufacturer’s Spice file to evaluate the switching characteristics of the SiC-MOSFET. A simple capacitance evaluation method using the device simulation model is proposed in the paper. The switching characteristic of SiC-MOSFET is experimentally extracted using a single-pulse test (SPT). The behavior of the simulation model was then compared to the characteristics obtained from the SPT to assess model performance. This analysis reveals an interesting phenomenon related to the variation in device capacitance parasitic concerning the drain-source voltage during switching, during the turn-on and turn-off phase.

title: Development of a Geometrically Summing Voltage Inverter Circuit for Water Pumps Operating in Photoelectric Systems
authors: Shukurillo Usmonov, Dilnoza Kuchkarova, Sanjarbek Odilov, Botirjon Khaliljonov, Bakhodir Jobborov, Bobonazar Soliyev
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: Conventional single-stage PV inverters typically require ≥ 10.8 V and drop out under poor irradiance, interrupting the 220 V supply. We propose a low-voltage architecture based on two series-connected inverter modules and a specialized controller that performs geometric (vector) voltage addition with dynamic phase coordination. Each module can operate from ≥ 6 V, and the controller synchronizes amplitude and phase to synthesize a stable 220 V output across wide irradiance variations. The control stack integrates low-voltage MPPT, PLL synchronization, adaptive amplitude regulation, and seamless mode transitions with built-in protections. Across representative overcast conditions, the architecture increases delivered AC energy by ≈6–15% (median ≈10–12%) versus a single inverter with a 10.8 V cutoff, by harvesting low-irradiance windows; low-voltage conversion efficiency improves by ≈5–7 percentage points at 0.2–0.4 p.u. input while remaining within ±1 pp of the baseline at nominal irradiance. The concept is applicable to distributed PV/ESS and retrofit scenarios where maintaining 220 V under sub-nominal DC conditions is critical, extending the operating envelope of PV inverters toward lower input voltages.

title: zkSABER: Zero-knowledge Succinct Authentication using Biometric Embedding Representation
authors: Tomoki Chinen, Christopher Wiraatmaja, Yu Nakahata, Takanori Hara, Shoji Kasahara
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Executing biometric matching between two embedding vectors on the blockchain remains a challenging problem due to inherent privacy concerns and the computational constraints imposed by block gas limits. To address these challenges, we propose zk-SABER, a succinct blockchain-based biometric authentication scheme that allows constant proof size and verification cost with respect to the embedding vector length. Our design combines a Merkle Tree and a biometric matching algorithm within a zkSNARK circuit to prove that a user’s biometric trait matches one of the registered templates in an anonymous manner. To ensure compatibility with state-of-the-art Deep Neural Network (DNN) models, we introduce a complete quantization pipeline that converts floating-point embeddings into zkSNARK-friendly representations. Our experiment results show constant transaction gas cost and proof size, regardless of the embedding vector length, thereby demonstrating the practicality of zk-SABER for real-world blockchain environments.

title: When Can You Trust Bitcoin? Value-Dependent Block Confirmation to Determine Transaction Finality
authors: Ethan Hicks, Joseph Oglio, Mikhail Nesterenko, Gokarna Sharma
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: We study financial transaction confirmation finality in Bitcoin as a function of transaction amount and user risk tolerance. A transaction is recorded in a block on a blockchain. However, a transaction may be revoked due to a fork in the blockchain, the odds of which decrease over time but never reach zero. Therefore, a transaction is considered confirmed if its block is sufficiently deep in the blockchain. This depth is usually set empirically at some fixed number such as six blocks. We analyze forks under varying network delays in simulation and actual Bitcoin data. Based on this analysis, we establish a relationship between block depth and the probability of confirmation revocation due to a fork. We use prospect theory to relate transaction confirmation probability to transaction amount and user risk tolerance.

title: Fast Chaincode Prototyping: a productivity IDE Plugin for Chaincode Development in Hyperledger Fabric
authors: Stefano Avola, Pierpaolo Baglietto, Andrea Parodi
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Permissioned Blockchains like Hyperledger Fabric (HLF) are precious tools for enhancing trust and speed up digitalization and data sharing within industry consortia. Though, given the complexity and the many components of the framework, the development process is rather articulated, with lots of pre-requirements and preparation steps. In this demo paper we introduce FCP: an innovative tool for Fast Chaincode Prototyping. FCP is a tool that helps speeding up the development of HLF Chaincodes (CCs), provided as a JetBrains IDE plugin. FCP is still under development.

title: Development and Validation of a Frequency-based Quality Index for Contactless Respiratory Volume Analysis
authors: Antonio Nocera, Linda Senigagliesi, Gianluca Ciattaglia, Michela Raimondi, Ennio Gambi
abstract: In contactless continuous monitoring of vital signs, assessing the quality of extracted signals is essential to increase the fidelity of the estimation. For this reason, a set of frequency-based quality indices is studied and analysed on a public dataset of torso displacements related to respiratory volume and recorded remotely under free breathing conditions. All the indices are based on the ratio between the power extracted in a frequency band associated with respiratory activity, against the complementary frequency band associated with noise. Parameters affecting the proposed indices, such as the number of harmonics and the frequency bandwidth around each harmonic, are evaluated to choose the most appropriate frequency band. Moreover, the indices are evaluated theoretically to understand in what range of noise they could properly work. Three experiments are performed: in the first one, white Gaussian noise is added to the considered signals to generate respiratory signals with a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) ranging from -30 to 27 dB; in the second one, the temporal noise extracted from a depth camera at distances less than 4 meters from a wall is added to the considered signals to simulate a scenario closer to the real application. Mean absolute error (MAE) of less than 2 dB, root mean square error (RMSE) of less than 3 dB, and Pearson’s correlation between 0.97 to 0.99 in the defined range of applicability are the obtained results for the evaluated quality indices. In the third one, an experimental scenario with recordings from Intel RealSense D455 and Kinect V2, the proposed metrics demonstrated to discriminate adequately between lower and higher quality signals determined by subjects at increasing distances from the camera. The metrics showed to recognise the presence of occlusions and motion artefacts; a Respiration-to-Noise Ratio (RNR) with frequency interval of 0.4 Hz showed a great sensitivity to occlusions with a median worsening of the signal quality of 6 to 10 dB; on the other hand, an RNR with frequency interval of 0.05 Hz showed greater sensitivity to low-frequency body movements when comparing the breathing signals extracted from sitting against standing subjects.

title: Towards Accurate Partial Discharge Measurements under Impulsive Pulse Voltages for Turn-to-Turn Insulation of Inverter-Fed Motors: Time Interval Selection, Frequency Investigation and PD Pattern
authors: Mehmet Güleç, Muhammad Azeem, Kotb B. Tawfiq, Ting Helmholdt-Zhu, Peter Sergeant
abstract: This paper aims to provide keynotes to improve the partial discharge (PD) measurements of turn-to-turn insulation in inverter-fed motor windings. The first point is to investigate the time interval between the voltage steps during PD tests, an aspect which is rarely addressed in the literature. To enhance measurement accuracy, the impact of the time interval is analyzed when applying repetitive pulses with fast rise times, and practical recommendations are proposed. As second topic, the influence of switching frequency is compared for different frequencies with an equal number of pulses. The combined effects of switching frequency and time interval between each voltage step are thoroughly examined. Last point is to investigate PD patterns to assess their potential for use as post-processing indicators of insulation degradation. An experimental test cases are conduced with twisted pair samples with various insulation grades to obtain the keynotes.

title: Finite-Time Distributed Filtering for Multi-Rate Nonlinear Systems Suffering from Denial-of-Service Attacks: A Binary Encoding Scheme
authors: Weijian Ren, Mengdi Chang, Fengcai Huo, Chaohai Kang, Lu Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing over Networks
abstract: This paper is concerned with filtering problem related to multi-rate systems in sensor networks suffering from denial of service attacks under binary encoding scheme. Binary encoding scheme is used for scheduling the transmission of innovation between sensor nodes due to limited bandwidth. Random bit error is considered in order to reflect the existence of binary bit flipping during actual channel transmission. A switching-model approach is adopted to convert the multi-rate systems into the single-rate ones. Stochastic nonlinearity is characterized by statistical properties to enhance generality. Different occurrence probabilities of attacks in distinct channels are characterized by virtue of a group of random variables following the Bernoulli distribution. The objective of the addressed filtering issue is to design a distributed filter such that the filtering error dynamics is stochastically finite-time bounded and satisfies <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_{\infty }$</tex-math></inline-formula> performance requirement. Sufficient conditions guaranteeing the satisfaction of specified filtering performance are established with the assistance of matrix inequalities and stochastic analysis techniques. The gain parameters of the distributed filter are determined by solving certain linear matrix inequalities. Simulation outcomes validate the efficacy of the proposed filtering method.

title: Orthogonal Linear Array-Based Product Beamforming for Real Time Underwater 3-D Acoustical Imaging
authors: Mimisha M. Menakath, Mahesh Raveendranatha Panicker, Hareesh G.
abstract: Ocean exploration using acoustical 3-D imaging is gaining popularity as it provides information about the 3-D geometry of the targets even under mild turbid conditions. A major challenge in underwater 3-D imaging is the high cost of the planar arrays and the computational complexity of the image reconstruction algorithms. In this work, we introduce the use of a uniform rectangle array placed at the edges of a uniform planar array for underwater 3-D imaging. During reconstruction, an orthogonal combination of two linear arrays which forms an L-shape is used to perform two independent and parallel 2-D delay and sum beamforming and the 3-D image is reconstructed using the product of the resulting beams. Each quadrant in the imaging slice is reconstructed in parallel using different L-shaped arrays. This quadrant-based time domain receive beamforming focuses on achieving relatively low computational complexity for real-time 3-D imaging in underwater environments. The proposed method with 47 hydrophones has reduced the main lobe width by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{2}^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula> with 6 dB increase in the peak side lobe level when compared to the conventional delay and sum beamforming using a uniform planar array of 576 elements. Although there is an increase in the side lobe level, the asymmetric beam pattern of the proposed L array and the quadrant-based beamforming restrict the side lobes within a quadrant. The proposed method achieves a reduction in computation time by a factor of 97 for 3-D imaging compared to the conventional method, while maintaining acceptable image quality. For qualitative analysis, the 3-D images of different underwater targets have been reconstructed and compared in simulation and experiment.

title: Modeling Adaptive Tracking of Predictable Stimuli in Electric Fish
authors: Yu Yang, Andreas Oliveira, Louis L. Whitcomb, Felipe Pait, Mario Sznaier, Noah J. Cowan
abstract: The weakly electric fish Eigenmannia virescens naturally swims back and forth to stay within a moving refuge, tracking its motion using visual and electrosensory feedback. Previous experiments show that when the refuge oscillates as a low-frequency sinusoid (below about 0.5 Hz), the tracking is nearly perfect, but phase lag increases and gain decreases at higher frequencies. Here, we model this nonlinear behavior as an adaptive internal model principle (IMP) system. Specifically, an adaptive state estimator identifies the a priori unknown frequency, and feeds this parameter estimate into a closed-loop IMP-based system built around a lightly damped harmonic oscillator. We prove that the closed-loop tracking error of the IMP-based system, where the online adaptive frequency estimate is used as a surrogate for the unknown frequency, converges exponentially to that of an ideal control system with perfect information about the stimulus. Simulations further show that our model reproduces the fish refuge tracking Bode plot across a wide frequency range. These results establish the theoretical validity of combining the IMP with an adaptive identification process and provide a basic framework in adaptive sensorimotor control.

title: Development of Layered Origami Smart Cushioning Device with Wireless Self-Inductive Sensors
authors: Satoshi Motoyama, Hiroaki Minamide, Takuma Harada, Hiroki Shigemune
abstract: In this article, we propose a smart cushioning device (SCD) that integrates a self-folded corrugated structure (SCS) with a passive wireless sensing mechanism. Using inkjet printing–based self-folding, highly reproducible corrugated geometries were formed from planar paper sheets in a simple and scalable manner. By increasing the number of layers and paper thickness, the SCD achieved a maximum load capacity of 39.0 N, exhibiting a 1014% improvement in load-bearing capability compared to a single-layer configuration. A planar spiral coil integrated within the structure enabled LC resonance wireless sensing of deformation, showing up to 51.5% inductance variation and corresponding resonance frequency shifts. The response remained stable after 1000 compression cycles, confirming high mechanical durability. In a load-position identification test, the device exhibited a frequency shift of Δf/f₀ = 0.10, demonstrating high spatial sensitivity to localized deformation. Owing to its modular design, the proposed SCD allows flexible adjustment of sensor number and placement, offering a promising approach for real-time pressure-distribution sensing in evacuation shelters, nursing care, and smart furniture applications.

title: Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning for the Edge-Intelligent 6G Ecosystem
authors: Deepak Puthal, Chan Yeob Yeun, Pradip Kumar Sharma, Zhiguo Ding
abstract: The 6th Generation (6G) wireless standard is forecasted to enable wide-ranging, edge-native AI, facilitating advanced applications like real-time digital twins and fully autonomous systems. Centralized cloud-based AI models, however, conflict with intensifying requirements around data privacy, along with cybersecurity risks, due to reliance on the data for intelligence. This article detailed that Federated Learning (FL) is the optimum architectural solution for resolving the 6G conundrum. We explain how FL’s corner-stone principle of collaborative model training with edge clients, lacking raw data transfer, aligns with 6G infrastructure and privacy-by-design edge computing. The study focuses on the 6G ecosystem’s technical integration of FL and its application in building secure digital twins and collaborative intelligence. Moreover, the article methodically addresses FL persistent challenges, from communication overhead, Byzantine, and data poisoning attacks, while proposing robust countermeasures like Differential Privacy and Secure Aggregation.

title: A Novel Evolutionary Bayesian Optimization Algorithm Based on Decomposition for Expensive Constrained Multiobjective Optimization Problems_supp1-3637210.pdf
authors: Yong Wang
abstract: This article proposes a novel constrained multiobjective evolutionary Bayesian optimization algorithm based on decomposition (named CMOEBO/D) for expensive constrained multiobjective optimization problems (CMOPs). In CMOEBO/D, an expensive CMOP is decomposed into some approximate constrained subproblems by Gaussian process models, reference vectors, and the augmented Tchebycheff function. Then, we devise a new infill criterion (named CPoB) to evaluate the performance of solutions. Specifically, in CPoB, on each approximate constrained subproblem, any two solutions are compared based on the product of two probabilities. For each solution, the first probability (denoted as PoB) is its likelihood of outperforming the other in terms of the predicted augmented Tchebycheff function value, and the second probability (denoted as PoF) is its likelihood of satisfying all constraints. It is obvious that PoB and PoF measure the convergence and feasibility of a solution, respectively. Based on CPoB, the approximate constrained subproblems are solved via collaborative evolutionary optimization to obtain their near-optimal solutions. Furthermore, by combining the information of the database, we design a bilevel candidate selection strategy to select some of these near-optimal solutions for expensive fitness evaluations, which can make good diversity, convergence, and feasibility contributions simultaneously to the database. Extensive experiments verify the competitiveness of CMOEBO/D.

title: Concurrent Self-testing and Uncertainty Estimation of Neural Networks Using Uncertainty Fingerprint
authors: Soyed Tuhin Ahmed, Mehdi B. Tahoori
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computing
abstract: Neural networks (NNs) are increasingly used in always-on safety-critical applications deployed on hardware accelerators employing various memory technologies. Reliable, continuous operation of NN is essential for safety-critical applications. During online operation, NNs are susceptible to (single and multiple) permanent and soft errors due to factors such as radiation, aging, and thermal effects. Explicit testing methods for hardware accelerators cannot detect transient faults during inference, are unsuitable for always-on applications, and require extensive test vector generation and storage. Therefore, in this paper, we propose the uncertainty fingerprint approach that represents the online fault status of NN. Furthermore, we propose a dual-head NN topology specifically designed to produce uncertainty fingerprints and the primary prediction of the NN in a single shot. During the online operation, by matching the uncertainty fingerprint, we can concurrently self-test NNs with up to $100\%$ coverage in the backbone and in the full model (with a modified approach) with a low false positive rate while maintaining the performance of the primary task similar to the baseline. Compared to existing works, memory overhead is reduced by up to 243.7 MB, multiply and accumulate (MAC) operations are reduced by up to $10000\times$, and false-positive rates are reduced by up to $89\%$.

title: Exploring Time Predictability for High-Bandwidth Memory Technology
authors: Alessandro Cilardo, Manuel Maddaluno
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computing
abstract: High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) is an interface standard for 3D-stacked synchronous dynamic random-access memory achieving higher bandwidth, lower power, and a smaller footprint than DDR4 and GDDR5. It is becoming a key component of compute devices used in supercomputers and datacenters as well as in high-end embedded platforms, such as autonomous driving systems, as it matches the performance requirements of Artificial Intelligence and other emerging data-intensive workloads. In many cases, these applications require some form of determinism or guarantees in terms of response time, in addition to mere performance. This is the case of hard real-time tasks in safety-critical environments, e.g. in automotive applications. However, deterministic response is also relevant for the multi-tenant settings of HPC, datacenter, and cloud systems, where tenants may be offered precise guarantees in terms of Quality of Service (QoS). Performance predictability has been investigated for DDR memory controllers, while it is an unexplored topic for HBM. While DDR and HBM share some technical aspects, such as the opportunity of reducing data bus reversals by command reordering, the HBM standard also poses additional difficulties compared to DDR, such as tougher timing constraints, which increase the latency of commands targeting the same bank group. In this work, we introduce an implementable architectural model of a deterministic HBM controller, which addresses the above technical issues, along with a quantitative closed-form analysis to fully characterize its response times. We also demonstrate a complete physical implementation derived from the model, along with practical simulation and synthesis toolflows, which allow an extensive experimental evaluation and the test of the controller under real-world memory-intensive workloads. We measure a peak throughput of 13.5 GB/s per pseudo-channel, which is higher than a recent comparable controller design, and an aggregate peak throughput of 432 GB/s under time predictability guarantees. Our evaluation also sheds some light on how the mapping of address bits to banks/rows/columns impacts the performance of HBM commands.

title: PDFL:A Privacy-Enhancing and Robust Poisoning Defense Federated Learning Scheme
authors: Gang Wang, Huiwen Wu, Qingming Li, Ziyao Liu, Jun Zhao, Kwok-Yan Lam, Qingkuan Dong, Yao Yang, Li Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: This paper addresses the security and privacy issues of the global models in Federated Learning by proposing a new approach, called PDFL, which tackles the challenges of poisoning attacks and privacy leakage in FL rounds. PDFL is based on secure multi-party computation and performs privacy-preserving cluster analysis on encrypted data from participants in order to identify malicious poisoning attackers. This approach involves a two-server mechanism and integrates four privacy-preserving protocols based on two-party computation (2PC): SecJudge for normalizing gradients, SecCosine for computing the cosine similarity values among gradients, SecClu for countering poisoning attacks, and SecAgg for secure aggregation by the server. These protocols are designed to achieve low computational costs, preserve client data privacy, and mitigate poisoning attacks from the potentially malicious clients. We provide a theoretical proof that our four sub-protocols and the PDFL scheme are both safe and reliable, demonstrating that PDFL can ensure the privacy and security of the participating data. Additionally, we conduct extensive simulation experiments to evaluate the accuracy, efficiency, computational overhead, and communication overhead associated with the PDFL scheme. Experimental results show the potential of the PDFL scheme in significantly enhancing the ability to identify malicious poisoning attackers in federated learning systems accurately and efficiently, hence making PDFL a promising solution for addressing privacy and security concerns in this domain.

title: HSA: An Efficient Sparse CNN Accelerator Based on Kernel-Aware Hybrid Pruning
authors: Xiyan Liu, Qiang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: The deployment of large-scale convolutional neural networks (CNNs) on hardware often results in reduced execution efficiency and increased hardware overhead. Prior works have addressed this challenge by employing pruning techniques to reduce parameters and computational loads. Among these techniques, fine-grained N:M pruning methods achieve high sparsity rates but at the cost of generating substantial indexing overhead and potential workload imbalance. In contrast, pattern-based pruning methods reduce indexing complexity and achieve workload balancing but suffer from low sparsity. To overcome these limitations, this article proposes a kernel-aware hybrid pruning (KAHP) method that simultaneously attains high sparsity, workload balancing, and reduced indexing overhead. Moreover, to accelerate the inference of the models pruned by the KAHP method, we design an efficient accelerator based on the systolic array architecture. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to the N:M pruning method, the KAHP method achieves workload balancing and reduces the number of indices by up to 88.7% on ResNet-20. Compared to pattern-based pruning methods, the KAHP method achieves up to $31.8\times $ sparsity. The proposed accelerator achieves up to 93.18 GOPS/W power efficiency and 0.721 GOPS/DSP computation efficiency.

title: Region-Aware Cross-Modal Embedding for Fine-Grained Text-To-Video Retrieval
authors: Vu-Hoang Tran, Trieu-Huy Phan, Van-Thuyen Ngo
abstract: The increasing prevalence of video clips has sparked growing interest in text-video retrieval, where the core challenge lies in effectively matching textual queries with relevant video segments. Previous approaches learn a joint embedding space based primarily on global frame-level alignment, often overlooking the rich semantic cues present at the region level. In this paper, we argue that region-level modeling and stochastic text representation can significantly enhance video understanding by capturing fine-grained semantic information and textual ambiguity. We propose a novel cross-modal embedding framework that jointly captures frame-level and region-level interactions while modeling text as a multivariate distribution. Our design integrates a vision encoder with proxy-guided attention, a cross-embedding association graph, and a stochastic text encoder. Empirical results on MSR-VTT dataset show that incorporating both region-aware modeling and stochastic embedding boosts retrieval accuracy to 17% R@1, compared to only 12% R@1 in frame-only settings. In addition, compared to the existing robust methods, the proposed system also shows superior performance. This highlights the benefit of combining local spatial details and probabilistic semantics in video retrieval.

title: Experimental Validation of Automatic Balancing Control Strategy in AMB System Using a Synchronous Notch Filter in Combination with a PLL-based Speed Estimator
authors: Thien-Vuong Bui, Myounggyu D. Noh
abstract: Synchronous vibration due to mass unbalance can significantly degrade the performance of Active Magnetic Bearings (AMBs) control systems. In this paper, an experimental validation of automatic balancing control strategy using a synchronous notch filter and a PLL-based speed estimator is carried out on a laboratory scale test rig. For the operation of the synchronous notch filter, rotational speed of the rotor must be provided. By leveraging the orthogonality property of the sine and cosine functions, the rotational speed of the rotor can be estimated using a Phase-locked Loop (PLL) structure, thereby streamlining the system since no additional speed sensor is needed. The PLL structure is described and discussed in detail from a practical application perspective, ensuring the implementation with the synchronous notch filter is straightforward. Experimental results show that the fundamental components of the synchronous vibration are removed from the control signal when the synchronous notch filter and PLL-based speed estimator are enabled.

title: Extracting Complex Topology from Multivariate Functional Approximation: Contours, Jacobi Sets, and Ridge-Valley Graphs
authors: Guanqun Ma, David Lenz, Hanqi Guo, Tom Peterka, Bei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th Symposium on Large Data Analysis and Visualization (LDAV)
abstract: Implicit continuous models, such as functional models and implicit neural networks, are an increasingly popular method for replacing discrete data representations with continuous, high-order, and differentiable surrogates. These models offer new perspectives on the storage, transfer, and analysis of scientific data. In this paper, we introduce the first framework to directly extract complex topological features—contours, Jacobi sets, and ridge-valley graphs—from a type of continuous implicit model known as multivariate functional approximation (MFA). MFA replaces discrete data with continuous piecewise smooth functions. Given an MFA model as the input, our approach enables direct extraction of complex topological features from the model, without reverting to a discrete representation of the model. Our work is easily generalizable to any continuous implicit model that supports the queries of function values and high-order derivatives. Our work establishes the building blocks for performing topological data analysis and visualization on implicit continuous models.

title: Reinforcement learning-based improvement of a PD-TDE controller for an upper limb rehabilitation robotic system
authors: Thanh Nha Nguyen, Xuan Tra Nguyen, Quoc Thanh Truong, Diep Cong Thanh Tu, Jee Hwan Ahn, Kyoung Kwan Ahn, Duc Thien Tran
abstract: Controlling upper limb rehabilitation robots is challenging due to their nonlinear dynamics and various uncertainties, including modeling errors, friction, and patient-specific variations. To enhance robustness and tracking performance, a hybrid Proportional-Derivative Time-Delay Estimation (PD-TDE) controller is adopted. However, the optimal tuning of PD-TDE parameters remains a critical issue. This paper proposes a Reinforcement Learning (RL) approach based on the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) agent algorithm in reinforcement learning to automatically optimize the controller parameters. The proposed method does not require prior dynamic knowledge of the system and employs an Actor-Critic architecture. After the agent is successfully trained offline, the Actor network is extracted and used to tune the parameters of the PD-TDE controller by observing the system state and applying a reward function that encourages accurate and smooth motion. Finally, the proposed approach is validated through simulations in MATLAB/Simulink using a 3D Simscape robot model imported from SolidWorks, demonstrating superior performance compared to conventional PD-TDE tuning method.

title: Mathematical Model for Estimating Water Intake and Energy Consumption of Centrifugal Pumps in Irrigation Systems
authors: Sanjarbek Odilov, Zafarjon To’ychiyev, Botirjon Khaliljonov, Bakhodir Jobborov, Bobonazar Soliyev, Abdullajon Khomidov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: Centrifugal water pumps are widely used in industrial enterprises, water intake structures, irrigation systems, and domestic applications. Their efficiency and reliability make them ideal for various water supply needs. This paper presents a mathematical model developed to determine the water intake and electrical energy consumption of a centrifugal pump featuring a separated rotor and impeller. The pump is powered by electricity generated from photovoltaic panels. The model considers hydraulic parameters and solar power characteristics to accurately estimate both flow rate and energy use. This approach is especially useful for designing autonomous, energy-efficient pumping systems in rural or agricultural areas where solar energy is a practical power source. The developed expression supports analysis and optimization of sustainable water pumping operations.

title: Multiview X-ray Systems at Regional Airports: Economic Feasibility
authors: Peter Koščák, Ľubomíra Szokeová, Martina Koščáková, Michaela Tirpáková
abstract: This paper analyzes the economic feasibility of implementing multiview X-ray systems at regional airports with varying operational scales. Using a structured simulation approach, the study evaluates investment return scenarios under different passenger growth rates while considering the specific capacity and cost structures of regional environments. The objective is to determine whether multiview systems can serve as a financially sustainable and operationally beneficial upgrade for smaller airports, supporting informed decision-making in public and EU-funded transport projects. The analysis further explores how these technologies can contribute to the financial stability of regional airports while improving security and throughput, providing evidence for data-driven modernization in the aviation sector.

title: A Graph-Theoretical Analysis of the Lightning Network
authors: Simone Samoggia, Stefano Ferretti, Luca Serena, Moreno Marzolla, Gabriele D’Angelo
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: The Lightning Network is the most adopted layer-2 solution for Bitcoin, shifting many transactions off-chain through bidirectional channels to improve scalability and reduce costs. Despite its growing usage, few studies have been conducted to investigate its structure and how it evolved over time. In this work, we analyze the structural properties of the public Lightning Network using graph theory, collecting both real-time and historical data. We have then considered multiple filtering strategies to isolate different parts of the network, such as excluding single-connection nodes or central hubs. The results show that as the network has grown, its average connectivity has decreased, and its reliance on hubs has increased. This structure enables efficient routing, but also conceals some issues concerning the network resilience in case of hub failures.

title: Implementation of Bidirectional T-type AC/DC Converter for Electric Vehicle Charging
authors: Yi-Hung Chen, Hong-Zhang Lin, Che-Wei Hsu, Jiann-Fuh Chen
abstract: A bidirectional T-type converter, which applies to electric vehicles Level 2 charger is implemented in this paper. The T-type converter is a three-level topology which owns the benefit of low current ripple as lower inductor voltage. Also, the voltage stress of power devices is half of DC side voltage, therefore, the switching loss is reduced. Meanwhile, wide bandgap components, Silicon Carbide (SiC) MOSFETs, which with better high-frequency performance are utilized as power devices to increase the circuit efficiency. In AC-DC mode, the average current control is used as the control method; In DC-AC mode, the dual loop control in d-q coordinate is used as the control method. Finally, a converter prototype with specifications of AC side voltage 220 V rms, DC side voltage $800 \mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{dc}}$, switching frequency 50 kHz and rated power 6 kW is implemented for validation. The experimental results show that the maximum efficiency of AC-DC mode reaches $98.86 \%$, and the maximum efficiency of DC-AC mode reaches $98.96 \%$.

title: Current-Sensorless Interleaved Totem-Pole PFC Converter with Coupled Inductor
authors: Kuo-Yuan Lo, Hsuan-Yi Huang
abstract: This paper presents a current-sensorless interleaved totem-pole power factor correction (PFC) converter using coupled inductors. The conventional boost inductor is replaced with a coupled inductor, and a two-phase interleaved totem-pole architecture is adopted to improve performance. The operating principles of the proposed PFC and the method for achieving zero-voltage switching (ZVS) are described in detail. A current-sensorless control strategy based on average current estimation is implemented to validate the proposed control method. Experimental results from a 1.6 kW prototype demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the design. The prototype operates with a $220 V_{A C}$ input and delivers a $400 V_{D C}$ output at 1.6 kW. The proposed converter achieves ZVS for the high-frequency MOSFETs and reaches a peak efficiency of 97.6%.

title: Variant of the CASCADE Reconciliation Protocol for Non-Uniform Error Distributions in Quantum Channel
authors: Vladimir Faerman, Egor Vasilyev, Valeriy Avramchuk
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: Quantum key distribution (QKD) enables secure communication by using the principles of quantum mechanics. A critical stage in QKD protocols such as BB84 is information reconciliation, where the communicating parties correct errors in their sifted sequences without revealing extra information to a potential eavesdropper. The CASCADE protocol is a widely used interactive error-correction algorithm for this purpose. The classical CASCADE and its known modifications perform well under the assumption of uniformly distributed errors in the quantum channel. However, this assumption can break down in real conditions, where short-term noise bursts create clusters of errors. This paper proposes a modification of the CASCADE designed to improve its efficiency in channels with time-varying, non-uniform error distributions. The main idea is to identify and discard blocks with a relatively high concentration of errors during reconciliation, preventing inefficient correction attempts and reducing the number of communication rounds. Two new modifications based on existing CASCADE variants are presented. The proposed approach reduces the number of interactions, which is a critical performance metric for reconciliation protocols.

title: A deep learning framework for hyperspectral image classification with mixed frequency-domain – spatial domain feature representation
authors: Jiesong Luo, Chulin Wang, Qingyang Guan, WeiHai Pang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Hyperspectral image classification plays a key role in accurately identifying land cover, but still faces challenges such as mixed pixels, spectral heterogeneity, and multi-scale fusion. Existing methods remain limited in frequency-domain feature extraction, cross-modal interaction, and multi-scale information integration. To address these issues, this paper proposes FDSNet, a model that fuses frequency- and spatial-domain features to enhance classification performance. In the spatial stream, a dual-path encoding mechanism extracts frequency and spatial features, while cross-cooperative attention further captures spatial context. In the spectral stream, a cross-scale interaction pyramid strengthens multi-scale spectral representations, combined with dynamic convolution and spectral–spatial attention to refine feature learning. Finally, an improved cross-modal interaction module achieves efficient fusion of spectral and spatial features. Experiments on the PU dataset show that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches in overall accuracy (OA), average accuracy (AA), and the Kappa coefficient, demonstrating superior effectiveness and robustness.

title: Optimizing Elevator Energy Efficiency: Fuzzy Logic-Controlled Bidirectional DC-DC Converter with Supercapacitor Energy Storage
authors: Nur Addini Mohamad Azhar, Masfiqur Rahman, Norjulia Mohamad Nordin, Madihah Md Rasid, Shahrin Md Ayob
abstract: Elevator systems are among the major energy consumers in buildings, with substantial energy losses occurring during motor braking. This study proposes the integration of a supercapacitor as an energy storage device, managed by a fuzzy-based bidirectional DC-DC converter, to optimize regenerative energy recovery and improve elevator efficiency. In the proposed system, the supercapacitor captures braking energy and releases it during motoring operation, while the bidirectional converter regulates power flow between the motor, supply, and storage unit. Two fuzzy logic controllers—dedicated to voltage and current regulation—are employed to ensure efficient charge—discharge management. The objective is to evaluate the effectiveness of fuzzy-based control in enhancing energy storage and utilization. Simulation results confirm that the supercapacitor substantially reduces energy wastage during generating mode by storing and reusing energy in motoring mode, thereby improving about 80% of the overall performance of the elevator system.

title: Research on Heat Transfer of Rotor Oil Jet Impingement Cooling of Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor for Electric Vehicles
authors: Bowei Li, Kan Akatsu
abstract: In this study, the oil jet impingement cooling to the rotor from the axial side is proposed. This research simplified the rotor as a rotating disk to study the convection Heat Transfer Coefficient (HTC) on the cooling surface. The experiment is set to obtain the heat transfer result. When the disk rotates over 2000 rpm, the effect of speed on heat transfer becomes very small. For the nozzles with a diameter of 2.5 and 2.0 mm, the heat transfer ability no longer increases with the pressure over $\mathbf{0. 2 ~ M P a}$. The longer injection distance with $\mathbf{8 0}$ mm helps heat transfer but the improvement is not significant.

title: The Study of Grid-Forming Dispatchable Virtual Oscillator Control in a 50 kW Three-Phase Inverter
authors: Mei-Fang Wang, Senit Araminta Jasmine, Tzung-Lin Lee
abstract: Dispatchable Virtual Oscillator Control (dVOC) is an oscillator-based control strategy for regulating the operation of grid forming inverter. This paper investigates the application of dVOC to a 50 kW three-phase inverter system. A mathematical model of the controller is derived from the oscillator formulation, and LCL filter design of the inverter is provided in this paper. The method is evaluated in both islanded and grid-connected modes. In islanded operation, dVOC exhibits droop-like behavior for frequency and voltage regulation, while in grid-connected operation it enables accurate active power tracking while maintaining stable frequency. Simulation results in PLECS, including power setpoint variations and load step tests, show that the $50-\mathrm{kW}$ inverter with dVOC achieves correct steady-state power regulation and demonstrates faster, smoother transient responses compared to conventional droop control.

title: Field-Calibrated Aerodynamic and Electromechanical Dynamic Simulation of a Bergey Excel 15 Wind Turbine for Distributed Generation
authors: Jorge A. Leon Quiroga, Luis E. Rodriguez-Rodriguez, Rachid Darbali-Zamora, Erick E. Aponte-Bezares
abstract: This paper presents a modeling and control framework for the Bergey Excel 15, a $15-\mathrm{kW}$ small-scale wind turbine designed for distributed energy applications. The system is modeled in MATLAB<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup>/Simulink<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup> and includes detailed representations of the aerodynamic subsystem, permanent magnet synchronous generator (PMSG), power electronics, and control algorithms. This work introduces a robust method to estimate the power coefficient curve $C_{p}(\lambda)$ from field data corrected for turbulence and sensor noise, yielding a physically consistent lookup table for aerodynamic torque calculation. The electrical subsystem consists of a back-to-back converter with dq-frame current control. The generator-side controller implements maximum power point tracking (MPPT) through speed regulation at the optimal tip-speed ratio. The grid-side controller maintains the DC-link voltage and regulates both active and reactive power exchange with the grid. The model enables real-time dynamic simulations and supports integration studies for microgrids and off-grid applications. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach and demonstrate its capability to capture the key dynamics of the Bergey Excel 15 DW turbine under variable wind conditions.

title: Generation and Transmission Expansion Planning for Resilience to Compound Hazards
authors: Rachael M. Alfant, J. Kyle Skolfield, Nicole D. Jackson, Thom R. Edwards
abstract: Electricity demand is forecast to increase at unprecedented rates over the coming decades. Simultaneously, aging infrastructure and compound hazards threaten to significantly damage the power grid. To maintain current grid functionality, meet future demand, and enhance the security of the power system, it is necessary to build significant additional generation and transmission infrastructure. This work proposes a generalized disjunctive programming optimization model to solve a generation and transmission expansion planning model alongside a Markov Random Field approach to model the spatiotemporal relationships among compound hazards. This approach is demonstrated on a 123-bus representation of the Texas grid, adapted herein to be suitable for the proposed model.

title: AI-Generated Images for representing Individuals : Navigating the Thin Line Between Care and Bias
authors: Julia C. Ahrend, Björn Döge, Tom M Duscher, Dario Rodighiero
abstract: This research discusses the figurative tensions that arise when using portraits to represent individuals behind a dataset. In the broader effort to communicate European data related to depression, the Kiel Science Communication Network (KielSCN) team attempted to engage a wider audience by combining interactive data graphics with AI-generated images of people. This article examines the project’s decisions and results, reflecting on the reaction from the audience when information design incorporates figurative representations of individuals within the data.

title: Study on damage evolution process and internal physical mechanism of LNA Induced by HPM
authors: Zidong Chen, Jingtao Zhao, Lei Cao, Xixi Feng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: In this paper, the damage evolution process and internal physical mechanism of Low Noise Amplifier (LNA) module caused by High Power Microwave (HPM) are systematically analyzed. The method of combining numerical simulation, effect test and microscopic detection is adopted. It is found that when the injection power reaches the device damage threshold, the damage positions of High Electron Mobility Transistor (HMET) under HPM are consistent with the numerical simulation results, but the effect threshold of damage test is higher. This is mainly because, in numerical simulation, the damage criterion is usually used as whether the internal temperature of the device reaches the melting point. However, in the experiment, the function of the device will be completely disabled only when all the gate metal strips have fuse damage. At this time, the input channel of the device signal is interrupted, the channel loss increases, and the gain of the device decreases to 0 or even exhibits attenuation characteristics.

title: A low-complexity task offloading algorithm for 5G base station energy conservation based on multi-agent reinforcement learning
authors: Peishuo Si, Yufeng Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: To address the challenges of high energy consumption, high latency, and the inconsistency between algorithmic complexity and the limited computing resources at the edge in task offloading for 5G base station clusters operating under dynamic traffic conditions, this paper presents a low-complexity task offloading framework based on Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL). This framework models each base station as an independent agent and uses an Actor-Critic dual-network architecture to generate task offloading and operation mode adjustment actions. By integrating a multi-dimensional state model that combines real-time traffic load, remaining computing resources, the framework enhances resource matching accuracy. Additionally, it utilizes an optimized experience replay mechanism to improve sample sampling and training stability, achieving a coordinated optimization of energy consumption and latency. Simulation experiments show that compared with the full-power operation mode, this method reduces energy consumption by an average of 18.7%, with a slight increase in latency but still significantly better than the low-power operation mode. Compared with the genetic algorithm, energy consumption is reduced by an average of 3.7%, and latency is basically the same under various task loads. Compared with the all-low-power operation mode, latency is reduced by an average of 12.6%, effectively balancing energy efficiency and service quality, and meeting the task processing requirements of 5G dynamic traffic scenarios.

title: PushingBots: Collaborative Pushing Via Neural Accelerated Combinatorial Hybrid Optimization
authors: Zili Tang, Ying Zhang, Meng Guo
abstract: Many robots are not equipped with a manipulator and many objects are not suitable for prehensile manipulation (such as large boxes and cylinders). In these cases, pushing is a simple yet effective non-prehensile skill for robots to interact with and further change the environment. Existing work often assumes a set of predefined pushing modes and fixed-shape objects. This work tackles the general problem of controlling a robotic fleet to push collaboratively numerous arbitrary objects to respective destinations, within complex environments of cluttered and movable obstacles. It incorporates several characteristic challenges for multi-robot systems such as online task coordination under large uncertainties of cost and duration, and for contact-rich tasks such as hybrid switching among different contact modes, and under-actuation due to constrained contact forces. The proposed method is based on combinatorial hybrid optimization over dynamic task assignments and hybrid execution via sequences of pushing modes and associated forces. It consists of three main components: (I) the decomposition, ordering and rolling assignment of pushing subtasks to robot subgroups; (II) the keyframe guided hybrid search to optimize the sequence of parameterized pushing modes for each subtask; (III) the hybrid control to execute these modes and transit among them. Last but not least, a diffusion-based accelerator is adopted to predict the keyframes and pushing modes that should be prioritized during hybrid search; and further improve planning efficiency. The framework is complete under mild assumptions. Its efficiency and effectiveness under different numbers of robots and general -shaped objects are validated extensively in simulations and hardware experiments, as well as generalizations to heterogeneous robots, planar assembly and 6D pushing.

title: Adaptive High-Order Fusion Learning for Brain Disorder Detection
authors: Hengsheng Tang, Junji Jiang, Junhao Zhang, Yining Zhang, Shufeng Zhou, Yueying Zhou, Lishan Qiao
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: The functional brain network (FBN) serves as an important tool for investigating neurological and mental disorders. Unlike many traditional networks whose structures are often known in advance, FBNs need to be estimated from neuroimaging or electrophysiological data, and their quality generally determines the performance of downstream tasks, particularly in disorder detection. Recent studies have shown that high-order FBNs tend to achieve better discriminative performance, while some other work indicates that increasing the order of FBN does not necessarily bring additional gains in discriminative performance and may even lead to a rapid decline in discriminability. To fully leverage information across different-order FBNs and identify optimal order for downstream tasks, we design an adaptive high-order FBN fusion learning framework (AHFL) with attention mechanism for brain disorder detection. Specifically, we first construct a series of FBNs with continuously increasing orders and propose a data-driven approach to evaluate each order's contribution to the classification performance. The self-attention mechanism is employed to capture contextual dependencies during the sequential generation of multi-order FBNs, thereby offering a natural fusion approach. Experimental evidence shows that the proposed method achieves superior performance compared to the baseline. In particular, we find that third-order FBN is achieved the highest weights, playing a crucial role for the detection of autism spectrum disorder (ASD), whereas second-order FBN is the most effective for identifying patients with major depressive disorder (MDD). Our findings advance the identification of discriminative high-order FBNs and establish a generalizable diagnostic framework for brain disorders.

title: Complementary Field Effect Transistor (CFET) for the 2-nm Technology Node: A Review From Device to Circuit Perspectives
authors: J. Ajayan, Vakkalakula Bharath Sreenivasulu, Amit Krishna Dwivedi, Shubham Tayal
publish: IEEE Journal of the Electron Devices Society
abstract: The relentless advancement of the semiconductor industry continues to be fueled by the pursuit of enhanced transistor performance. As CMOS technology undergoes aggressive scaling to enable higher integration densities in modern integrated circuits (ICs), there arises a pressing demand for novel device architectures that can minimize cell area without compromising functionality. The complementary-field-effect-transistor (CFET) is emerging as a leading contender to succeed gate-all-around (GAA) FETs beyond the 2-nm technology node, offering a compelling pathway to sustain Moores Law into the next era of scaling. Unlike forksheet FET (FSFET) architectures, where nFET and pFET devices are laterally separated, CFETs adopt a vertically stacked configuration. This vertical integration minimizes the required device footprint, constrained primarily by cell height rather than horizontal spacing. As a result, CFETs not only enhance the effective channel width and drive current but also offer the potential for up to a twofold increase in integration density compared to conventional CMOS technologies. This review explores recent advances in CFET architectures, fabrication progress, and associated challenges, exciting prospects in IC design enabled by CFET’s compact structure and vertical integration. Finally, the article highlights critical reliability concerns, emphasizing the need for continued innovation to ensure robust device performance. CFET stands at the forefront of next-generation transistor technologies.

title: FedMeld: A Model-Dispersal Federated Learning Framework for Space-Ground Integrated Networks
authors: Qian Chen, Xianhao Chen, Kaibin Huang
abstract: To bridge the digital divide, space-ground integrated networks (SGINs) are expected to deliver artificial intelligence (AI) services to every corner of the world. One key mission of SGINs is to support federated learning (FL) at a global scale. However, existing space-ground integrated FL frameworks involve ground stations or costly inter-satellite links, entailing excessive training latency and communication costs. To overcome these limitations, we propose an infrastructure-free federated learning framework based on a model dispersal (FedMeld) strategy, which exploits periodic movement patterns and store-carry-forward capabilities of satellites to enable parameter mixing across large-scale geographical regions. We theoretically show that FedMeld leads to global model convergence and quantify the effects of round interval and mixing ratio between adjacent areas on its learning performance. Based on the theoretical results, we formulate a joint optimization problem to design the staleness control and mixing ratio (SC-MR) for minimizing the training loss. By decomposing the problem into sequential SC and MR subproblems without compromising the optimality, we derive the round interval solution in a closed form and the mixing ratio in a semi-closed form to achieve the optimal latency-accuracy tradeoff. Experiments using various datasets demonstrate that FedMeld achieves superior model accuracy while significantly reducing communication costs as compared with traditional FL schemes for SGINs.

title: MCDI-net: A Deep Learning Model for Pilot Spoofing Detection and Identification in Massive MIMO Networks
authors: Shiguo Wang, Yuemei Li, Xiukai Ruan, Qingyong Deng
abstract: Massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) architecture is promising to be adopted in the 5G/6G communication systems to combat the severe attenuation of millimeter-wave and terahertz bands by implementing precoding and combining at the transmitter and receiver jointly. Nevertheless, such massive MIMO-based systems are highly susceptible to pilot spoofing attacks (PSAs) because of the openness of wireless channel and the public pilot sequences. These PSAs will not only render significant decrease in system capacity, but also make the transmitted information leak to the attackers. In this paper, a novel multi-cue detection and identification network (MCDI-net) is proposed to conduct spoofing detection and identify the attacked user simultaneously. The MCDI-net integrates a dual-branch convolutional neural network with squeeze-and-excitation (SE) attention modules to extract the complementary features from two distinct cues, which are in-phase/quadrature (I/Q) and statistical features derived from pilot correlation and projected average power. This multi-cue fusion approach can enhance the network’s ability to detect pilot spoofing and identify the attacked legitimate user accurately. Numerical results are presented to validate the superior performance of the MCDI-net framework in detection and identification accuracy compared to the existing ones.

title: IRS-Assisted FSO System for LEO Satellites Constellations
authors: Celia Sánchez-De-Miguel, Miguel Castillo-Vázquez, Thiago R. Raddo, Beatriz Soret, Antonio Jurado-Navas
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: In this work, we explore the use of intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRSs) as transparent relays in free-space optical (FSO) links for low earth orbit (LEO) satellites constellations. We introduce a novel IRS design featuring a slightly convex surface geometry to broaden the reflected beam, thereby mitigating the beam alignment challenges typically encountered in satellite-based FSO systems. We investigate the impact of IRS size, curvature, and transmitter beam width on end-to-end system performance, taking into account attenuation, atmospheric turbulence, and pointing errors. To accommodate the effects of surface curvature, we enhance and refine the channel pointing model and derive novel closed-form expressions for key performance metrics, including bit error rate, outage probability, and ergodic capacity. Numerical results based on realistic system parameters confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach, albeit at the cost of increased geometric channel losses. Finally, we carry out numerical simulations to validate the new channel model and derived closed-form expressions, providing valuable insights for the design of future non-terrestrial networks architectures based on FSO systems.

title: Dual-Band Phase Shifter With Independent Phase Control and Diplexer Functionality for K/Ka-Band LEO Satellite Systems
authors: Haoyu Zhou, Lei Guo, Christophe Fumeaux, Amin Abbosh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: A dual-band phase shifter with simultaneous and independent phase control across two operating bands, designed for emerging low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite communications systems in the K/Ka-band, is presented. The proposed structure utilizes a dual-stub-loaded 3-dB hybrid to separate signals by their frequency, allowing for independent phase tuning in each band. To achieve a wide phase range, low insertion loss, and minimal phase range deviation, both the 3-dB hybrid and reflective loads are optimized for their respective bands. Additionally, the circuit can seamlessly switch between phase shifter and diplexer modes without redesign, enhancing its versatility. To validate the proposed concept, phase shifter and diplexer prototypes operating at <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathrm {19.3~GHz}~\text {to}~\mathrm {20.3~GHz}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathrm {29.5~GHz}~\text {to}~\mathrm {30.5~GHz}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> have been fabricated and tested. Both prototypes demonstrate a phase tuning range exceeding <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathrm {180~\!^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> with a maximum phase range deviation of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathrm {\pm 1.25~\!^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and an insertion loss below 2.5 dB. For the diplexer mode, port-to-port isolation exceeds 25 dB across all phase states. The proposed phase shifter design offers simplicity, robustness, and flexibility, with flat phase range and amplitude, while allowing independent tunable phase states across transmit and receive bands, making it highly suitable for LEO satellite communications systems.

title: Higher-Order Meta Distribution Reliability Analysis of Wireless Networks
authors: Mehdi Monemi, Mehdi Rasti, S. Ali Mousavi, Matti Latva-aho, Martin Haenggi
abstract: Communication reliability, as defined by 3GPP, is the probability of achieving a desired quality of service (QoS). Traditionally, this metric is evaluated by averaging the QoS success indicator over spatiotemporal random variables. Recently, the meta distribution (MD) has emerged as a two-level analysis tool that characterizes system-level reliability as a function of link-level reliability thresholds. However, existing MD studies have two limitations. First, they focus exclusively on spatial and temporal randomness corresponding to node distribution and fading channels, respectively, leaving stochastic behaviors in other domains largely unexplored. Second, they are restricted to first-order MDs with two randomness levels, restricting applicability to scenarios requiring higher-order MD characterization. To address these gaps, we propose a hierarchical framework for higher-order MD reliability in wireless networks, where each layer’s success probability is formulated and fed into the next layer, yielding overall MD reliability at the highest level. We apply this framework to wireless networks by capturing three levels of temporal dynamics representing fast, slow, and static random elements, and provide a comprehensive second-order MD reliability analysis for two application scenarios. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated via these representative scenarios, supported by detailed analytical and numerical evaluations. Our results highlight the value of hierarchical MD representations across multiple domains and reveal the significant influence of inner-layer target reliabilities on overall performance.

title: Enabling Secure Edge Intelligence: TinyML-Based Threat Detection in 5G and Future Networks
authors: Sandeep Pirbhulal, Muhammad Muzammal, Habtamu Abie
abstract: The evolution of 5G networks toward 6G presents an opportunity to shift from centralized security to decentralized, intelligent, and autonomous security. While 5G introduces decentralization through software-based virtualization and edge computing, it also exposes network infrastructure to a new and dynamic threat landscape that still relies largely on static, centrally deployed threat detection. This work proposes a lightweight anomaly detection framework based on Tiny Machine Learning (TinyML), specifically designed to address the latency, memory, and energy constraints of 5G edge devices. Using promising model compression techniques, including integer quantization and pruning, we demonstrate that highly optimized models can run entirely on-device without relying on cloud infrastructure. Our experiments using a real-world 5G dataset demonstrate that the quantized TinyDenseNet achieves over 99% detection accuracy while keeping the model size below 30 KB and inference latency under 11 ms. By embedding intelligent detection at the network edge, this approach presents self-defending, ultra-reliable, and context-aware infrastructures for future 6G networks. The proposed approach focuses on next-generation networks, in which decentralized, low-power, and privacy-preserving security mechanisms will be essential.
