authors: Amrutha R Menon, Hemprasad Y. Patil, Ashutosh Mahajan, Niroj Kumar Sahu
abstract: This work presents, for the first time, a Physics Informed Neural Network (PINN) model for magnetic hyperthermia, a promising non-invasive cancer therapy known for its high efficacy and minimal side effects. Effective cancer cell destruction requires heating to 42-45 °C. The heat generated by magnetic nanoparticles (MNP) under an alternating magnetic field depends strongly on their physicochemical properties. Hence, the optimization of MNP for effective heat generation remains a key challenge and constitutes the fundamental motivation of this study. In this work, we study and compare various approaches employing regression models, Artificial Neural Network (ANN), and PINN to address the challenges associated with magnetic fluid hyperthermia (MFH) prediction and analysis. The model incorporates input parameters, including particle size, saturation magnetization, magnetic field intensity, frequency, specific heat of fluid, nanoparticle concentration, and time, to predict temperature evolution as the output. The dataset is compiled from our published research work, comprising 3,690 data points, ensuring sufficient variability and robustness for model training and evaluation. Our PINN model shows an excellent R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value of around 0.98 against the test data.

title: Synthesis Method for Millimeter-Wave High-Selectivity On-Chip Filter in IPD Process Supported by Circuit Transformations
authors: Dongzhe Pan, Bin You, Jun Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a synthesis method for on-chip fourth-order bandpass filters (BPFs) for 5G millimeter-wave (mmWave) applications. The method transforms the conventional <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$K$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-filter prototype into microstrip schematics comprising capacitively loaded microstrip (CLM) resonators and semi-lumped vias acting as impedance inverters. The approach enables rapid calculation of design parameters under varying bandwidth, center frequency, and harmonic suppression requirements. Two BPFs are designed and fabricated using the integrated passive device (IPD) process to validate the method. The first operates at 24 GHz with an insertion loss of 3.98 dB, a 3-dB fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 13.5% and 53-dB stopband attenuation. The second employs a cross-coupled structure at 26 GHz, achieving an insertion loss of 3.92 dB, a FBW of 12.5%, and transmission zeros (TZs) at 22.8 and 28.4 GHz, corresponding to a rectangular coefficient (20-dB BW/3-dB BW) of 1.53. The results validate the theoretical counterparts and demonstrate that the designed filters exhibit good passband selectivity and stopband suppression.

title: Real-Time Super-Resolution Imaging System Based on Zero-Shot Learning for Infrared Non-Destructive Testing
authors: Pengfei Zhu, Ziang Wei, Ahmad Osman, Clemente Ibarra-Castanedo, Andreas Mandelis, Xavier Maldague, Hai Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Infrared thermography (IRT) and photothermal coherence tomography (PCT) exhibit potential in non-destructive testing and biomedical fields. However, the inevitable heat diffusion significantly affects the sensitivity and resolution of IRT and PCT. Conventional image processing techniques rely on capturing complete thermal sequences, which limits their ability to achieve real-time processes. Here, we construct a real-time super-resolution imaging system based on zero-shot learning strategy for the non-invasive infrared thermography and photothermal coherence tomography techniques. To validate the feasibility and accuracy of this super-resolution imaging system, IRT systems were employed to test several industrial samples and one biomedical sample. The results demonstrated high contrast in the region of interest (ROI) and uncovered valuable information otherwise obscured by thermal diffusion. Furthermore, three-dimensional photothermal coherence tomography was used to validate the excellent denoising and deconvolution capabilities of the proposed real-time super-resolution imaging system.

title: ViT4LPA 2.0: A Smart Meter Pre-trained Vision Transformer for Aggregated-level Load Disaggregation
authors: Hyeonjin Kim, Ning Lu
abstract: Pre-trained neural networks have significantly advanced machine learning, enhancing performance and reducing reliance on labeled datasets. In this study, we analyze a pre-trained neural network trained with residential smart meter load data and its transferability for aggregated-level load profile analysis. This study introduces ViT4LPA 2.0, a pre-trained hierarchical vision transformer (H-ViT) tailored for load profile analysis. ViT4LPA 2.0 is adapted for heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) load disaggregation at an aggregated-level, leveraging knowledge from individual smart meter load profiles. The H-ViT model employs a window self-attention mechanism to capture both local and global features. Pre-training is performed using masked image modeling on 2,000 smart meter load profiles, followed by domain adaptation and fine-tuning with limited labeled data. Extensive simulations demonstrate the model’s effectiveness, achieving approximately 5% daily accumulated error on aggregated-level load disaggregation with less than 15% HVAC consumption visibility in residential households. The model significantly outperforms state-of-the-art benchmarks, showing a 20–35% performance improvement. Additionally, a comprehensive sensitivity analysis and interpretability study provide insights into hyperparameter selection and the model’s decision-making process.

title: Evaluation of Verbal Intelligibility when Using Quadcopters to Organize an Acoustic Information Leakage Channel
authors: Andrey V. Telny, E.A. Matveeva, Mikhail Yu. Monakhov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This article examines a model of an acoustic information leakage channel created by a quadcopter-type unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). When using a UAV, it is necessary to consider destabilizing factors that lead to random changes in microphone orientation and random fluctuations in the UAV’s spatial position. To assess the potential for information leakage, a formant calculation was performed using five octave frequencies of verbal intelligibility for various signal-to-noise ratios depending on the distance to the UAV. It is shown that using a UAV to create an acoustic information leakage channel can be effective when the UAV is no more than 30–35 meters away. However, the main destabilizing factor affecting the distance from which information can be collected is the noise of the UAV’s propellers.

title: AetherLedger: A Novel Hierarchical Layer-2 Blockchain Architecture for Secure Satellite Communications
authors: Marian Podmajersky, Marek Košuda, Martin Kelemen, Ladislav Főző
abstract: This electronic document is a “live” template and already The global economy and critical national security infrastructure are increasingly reliant on satellite communication (SATCOM) systems. This dependence, coupled with the rapid commercialization of space, has significantly expanded the cyber-attack surface, exposing vulnerabilities in data integrity, command and control, and access management. While Layer-1 (L1) blockchains offer robust security through decentralization and immutability, their inherent limitations in scalability, latency, and transaction costs make them unsuitable for the high-throughput, resource-constrained environment of SATCOM networks. This paper proposes AetherLedger, a novel hierarchical Layer-2 (L2) blockchain architecture designed to provide scalable, efficient, and secure communications for SATCOM systems. The framework integrates a ZK-Rollup as its primary L2 solution to bundle and process the bulk of transactions—such as telemetry data, command logs, and access requests—off-chain, inheriting the security of an underlying L1 blockchain through cryptographic validity proofs. For high-frequency, time-sensitive operations between specific nodes, AetherLedger incorporates off-chain State Channels that settle their final state on the L2 rollup. This architecture is supported by a resource-aware model where powerful ground stations and LEO satellites act as L2 sequencers and provers, while resource-constrained terminals and sensors operate as lightweight nodes. A comparative analysis indicates that AetherLedger can theoretically increase transaction throughput by several orders of magnitude and drastically reduce transaction costs and latency compared to a purely L1-based approach. The ZK-Rollup layer provides fast transaction finality, which is critical for timely command verification, while State Channels offer near-instantaneous interaction for mission-critical maneuvers. The architecture provides robust defenses against prevalent SATCOM cyberattacks, including command spoofing, data manipulation, and denial-of-service, by ensuring cryptographic verification and data integrity. AetherLedger presents a viable and sophisticated framework for securing next-generation SATCOM networks. By strategically combining ZK-Rollups and State Channels in a hierarchical model, it effectively addresses the blockchain trilemma-balancing security, scalability, and decentralization-within the unique operational constraints of the space domain.

title: Kinematic Error Modeling and Calibration for Serial Robots via MDH–POE Hybrid and BCH Expansion
authors: Phi Nguyen-Thanh, Hung Nguyen-Quoc, Toan Pham-Bao, Hoang Truong-Viet, Hung Bui-Tien, Nhi Ngo-Kieu
abstract: Currently, most kinematic calibration models for serial robots are developed by differentiating the forward kinematics equations, which leads to a lack of clarity in defining the error and understanding its physical origin. To address this limitation, this study proposes a general error model for rigid body motion, in which the error is defined based on a clear separation between the actual and nominal motions. The model is linearized using the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff (BCH) expansion in the Lie algebra space se(3). Based on this foundation, a hybrid calibration framework is constructed by combining the Modified Denavit–Hartenberg (MDH) model with the Product of Exponentials (POE) method for serial robots. The error of each link is modeled locally in its own coordinate frame according to MDH conventions, then propagated along the kinematic chain and accumulated at the end-effector. The number of calibration parameters is reduced by exploiting the geometric properties and motion structure in the se(3) space, thereby improving computational stability. In addition, we formulate a method to reduce the general motion of a rigid body to that of three fixed points, while preserving all six degrees of freedom. This enables calibration to be performed by determining only the coordinates of these three points instead of the full pose, thereby simplifying the measurement setup and experimental procedure. The model is validated through simulations on the SCARA robot and the PUMA 560 robot. The results show fast convergence and significant improvement in end-effector positioning accuracy under large initial errors and high noise conditions. The proposed method can be extended to general multi-body mechanical systems.

title: Lightweight Audio-Visual Networks for Real-Time Lip-Sync DeepFake Detection
authors: Quoc-Dat Le, Vu-Hoang Tran, Viet-Dat Nguyen
abstract: Lip-sync DeepFakes, which manipulate lip movements to match tampered audio while preserving visual identity, pose significant challenges to digital content integrity due to their subtle temporal inconsistencies. Traditional detection methods focusing on spatial artifacts are often ineffective against these forgeries, while recent temporal correlation models, despite their accuracy, are computationally intensive and impractical for resource-constrained devices. This paper proposes a lightweight, real-time framework for lip-sync DeepFake detection, leveraging compact neural networks, temporal attention mechanisms, and knowledge distillation. Utilizing ShuffleNetV2x0.5 as the backbone, our model incorporates audio-visual temporal modeling and human-inspired perceptual cues, such as lip-speech synchronization, to achieve robust detection. Knowledge distillation transfers insights from a high-capacity teacher model to ensure high accuracy with a model size of only 18 MB and an inference speed of 20 FPS on standard CPUs, optimized for edge device deployment. Evaluated on the AVLIP and FakeAVCeleb datasets, our approach achieves 93.50% average precision on AVLIP and 99.23% average precision on FakeAVCeleb, rivaling state-of-the-art models while enabling real-time performance on edge devices. This framework is well-suited for applications like mobile video authentication, livestream monitoring, and content moderation, addressing the growing need for efficient and scalable DeepFake detection solutions.

title: Real-Time, Energy-Efficient Sobel Edge Detection on FPGA Using Approximate Carry-Lookahead Adders
authors: Ba-Loc Pham, Van-Khoa Pham, My-Phuong Doan Thi, Trung-Tin Nguyen
abstract: Real-time vision systems for autonomous vehicles, medical imaging and surveillance demand edge detectors that are both high-throughput and power-aware, yet the arithmetic intensity of the Sobel operator traditionally makes FPGA implementations resource-heavy. This study proposes an FPGA-accelerated Sobel filter in which each convolution adder is replaced by a configurable k-bit approximate carry-lookahead adder, synthesised in Vitis HLS and deployed on a PYNQ-Z2. A design-space sweep shows that a 3-bit approximation delivers the best trade-off, achieving 357 FPS at 125 MHz—1.6 × faster than an exact-adder FPGA and four orders of magnitude faster than a CPU reference—while processing 225 × 225 frames with 2.8 ms latency and requiring only 0.164 W of dynamic power, which translates to 2178 FPS/W energy efficiency. Image quality remains well within acceptable limits (PSNR ~ 22 dB, SSIM ~ 0.953) such as remote sensing transmission or embedded visual IoT applications, where small degradations in visual quality are tolerable, and hardware overhead is negligible, with LUT and FF counts increasing by less than 0.5 % and no additional DSP, BRAM or clock resources. These results demonstrate that modest, data-aware approximation unlocks substantial speed-and-power gains without perceptible edge-map degradation, positioning approximate arithmetic as a practical optimisation lever for embedded vision accelerators.

title: Extremely Scalable Distributed Computation of Contour Trees via Pre-Simplification
authors: Mingzhe Li, Hamish Carr, Oliver Rübel, Bei Wang, Gunther H. Weber
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th Symposium on Large Data Analysis and Visualization (LDAV)
abstract: Contour trees offer an abstract representation of the level set topology in scalar fields and are widely used in topological data analysis and visualization. However, applying contour trees to large-scale scientific datasets remains challenging due to scalability limitations. Recent developments in distributed hierarchical contour trees have addressed these challenges by enabling scalable computation across distributed systems. Building on these structures, advanced analytical tasks—such as volumetric branch decomposition and contour extraction—have been introduced to facilitate large-scale scientific analysis. Despite these advancements, such analytical tasks substantially increase memory usage, which hampers scalability. In this paper, we propose a pre-simplification strategy to significantly reduce the memory overhead associated with analytical tasks on distributed hierarchical contour trees. We demonstrate enhanced scalability through strong scaling experiments, constructing the largest known contour tree—comprising over half a trillion nodes with complex topology—in under 15 minutes on a dataset containing 550 billion elements.

title: DC-Link Capacitor-Less Inter-Line DC Power Flow Controller Enabled by Current-Source Dual Active Bridge and Novel CLC Resonant Circuit
authors: Hongyi Zhang, Miao Zhu, Pengfeng Lin
abstract: Inter-line DC power flow controller (IDCPFC) has garnered wide interest as an effective solution to improving controllability over power flows in meshed DC grids. Existing IDCPFCs rely on bulky DC-link capacitors for power flow regulation, which not only increases the volume of device but also compromises its overall performance. Enabled by current-source dual-active-bridge (DAB), this paper proposes a DC-link capacitor-less topology for IDCPFCs. A novel CLC resonant circuit is also tailored for the topology, presenting excellent performance for frequency modulation. Principles of operation of the proposed topology are detailed in this paper. On this basis, a closed-loop control strategy is developed to achieve seamless transitions between different operating modes. The effectiveness of the proposed topology and the correctness of analyses are verified via PLECS simulations.

title: Design of Subsystems in a Bidirectional Power Conversion Architecture
authors: Chun-Yu Hsiao, Zong-Kun Sun, Sen-Tung Wu
abstract: Recent advances in energy conversion and management technologies emphasize the need for efficient, intelligent power systems. This paper presents a bidirectional power-conversion architecture integrating propulsion and energy-storage functions. The system comprises a three-phase AC-DC rectifier, a PMSM drive, and a bidirectional DC-DC converter connecting the storage module and load. Supporting motoring, regenerative braking, and static power-supply modes, the architecture enables seamless bidirectional power flow. Advanced multi-mode control algorithms ensure efficient energy transfer among the source, load, and storage unit. Finiteelement and system-level simulations verify smooth mode transitions and improved overall efficiency. The proposed dualmode framework offers broad applicability in smart manufacturing, energy storage, and renewable-energy systems, contributing to smart grids and sustainable energy management.

title: From Sand to Screen: Virtual Beach Tourism for People with Mobility Impairments
authors: Halim Budi Santoso, I Kadek Dendy Senapartha, Matahari Bhakti Nendya, Gabriel Indra Widi Tamtama, Maria Kinanthi Sakti Ning Hapsari, Michael Wibisono, Clara Angelita Karunia Dewi, Roberto B. Figueroa, Lunchakorn Wuttisittikulkij
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Tourism is known to foster intercultural experiences and well-being. However, travelers with disabilities, particularly those with mobility impairments, often face physical and social barriers that limit their participation. This study explores the potential of Virtual Reality as an inclusive tourism tool to enhance accessibility, empathy, and awareness. Using focus group discussions with 28 participants with mobility impairments in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, key challenges in physical accessibility and social attitudes at tourism destinations were identified. Guided by these insights, this paper describes the development a dual-mode virtual beach tourism prototype allowing users to experience remotely. User testing with eight participants demonstrated that the disability mode heightened empathy and awareness among non-disabled users while offering accessible interaction for mobility-impaired users. Findings suggest that VR experiences can serve both as inclusive tourism alternatives and as educational tools to promote universal design and equitable tourism access.

title: A Novel Hybrid Machine Learning Model for Short-Term Load Forecasting: Optimizing Accuracy and Efficiency for Mechatronic Energy Systems
authors: Fareeduddin Mohammed, Ameni Boumaiza, Antonio Sanfilippo, Syed Qarnain
abstract: In energy management, short-term load forecasting (STLF) is vital for maintaining the balance between demand and supply and ensuring operational efficiency in smart grids. We propose a hybrid model combining Multi-Linear Regression (MLR), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and Feedforward Neural Networks (FFNN) to enhance forecast accuracy while maintaining computational efficiency. The model was validated on real datasets from Qatar and Panama City across 5-minute, 15-minute, 30-minute, and 1-hour resolutions. Compared to traditional hybrid models, it achieves significant improvements, including a 29% reduction in RMSE and 59% faster training times. These results demonstrate the model’s applicability for real-time STLF in dynamic power grids, with direct implications for energy-efficient mechatronic systems.

title: When Quantum Federated Learning Meets Blockchain in 6G Networks
authors: Dinh C. Nguyen, Md Bokhtiar Al Zami, Ratun Rahman, Shaba Shaon, Tuy Tan Nguyen, Fatemeh Afghah
abstract: Quantum federated learning (QFL) is emerging as a key enabler for intelligent, secure, and privacy-preserving model training in next-generation 6G networks. By leveraging the computational advantages of quantum devices, QFL offers significant improvements in learning efficiency and resilience against quantum-era threats. However, future 6G environments are expected to be highly dynamic, decentralized, and data-intensive, which necessitates moving beyond traditional centralized federated learning frameworks. To meet this demand, blockchain technology provides a decentralized, tamper-resistant infrastructure capable of enabling trustless collaboration among distributed quantum edge devices. This paper presents QFLchain, a novel framework that integrates QFL with blockchain to support scalable and secure 6G intelligence. In this work, we investigate four key pillars of QFLchain in the 6G context: 1) communication and consensus overhead; 2) scalability and storage overhead; 3) energy inefficiency; and 4) security vulnerability. A case study is also presented, demonstrating potential advantages of QFLchain, based on simulation, over state-of-the-art approaches in terms of training performance.

title: Privacy-Aware Transaction Fraud Detection With Low Communication Costs Under Joint Federated Learning_supp1-3647476.pdf
authors: Yubo Kong
abstract: Nowadays, cooperation between different organizations to form a cross-industry anti-fraud alliance by using federated learning (FL) is promising for transaction fraud detection. However, there are two challenges when building the federated learning-based fraud detection method. First, existing FL-based fraud detection methods cannot fully use participants' local data to better distinguish unknown types of abnormal fraud transactions. A lot of local data would be discarded due to the private set intersection process under the federated learning framework. Second, they mainly focus on the fraud detection performance but ignore the privacy and communication costs during the training of the fraud detection model. In response to the above challenges, we propose a privacy-aware (P) transaction fraud detection model with low (L) communication costs (C) under a vertical and horizontal joint federated learning framework in this paper, named PLC. Specifically, we merge horizontal federated learning and vertical federated learning to build a normal behavior model to improve the fraud detection performance for solving the first challenge. Meanwhile, we design a sparse factor-based SMC aggregation method to reduce communication costs without sacrificing detection performance for solving the second challenge. The experimental results show that the communication costs can be reduced by 46.7% and 55.4% under the ECC dataset and the Vesta dataset, respectively. The ablation experiment results show that our proposed method can provide good privacy protection performance with a small sparse factor. Our proposed fraud detection model can significantly improve the fraud detection performance under the joint federated learning framework.

title: Improved Diffusion Recursive Least Squares for Graph Signal Estimation on Distributed Network
authors: Yi Hua, Zhangfa Wu, Hongping Gan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing over Networks
abstract: Streaming graph signal (GS) estimation is common in various network systems. Several graph filter algorithms have been proposed for streaming GS estimation, but they still fail to reach optimal levels. To achieve optimal performance in both estimation accuracy and convergence rate, this paper adopts the recursive least squares (RLS) method in processing GS. When the RLS algorithm is directly combined with GS, its recursive mechanism causes the estimation performance to experience severe degradation. To address this issue, a graph RLS with non-cooperation algorithm and a distributed graph diffusion RLS (DRLS) algorithm, both following the fully recursive structure of the standard RLS, are proposed first. By analyzing these two algorithms, it is found that streaming GS and graph topology are complex and variable, so the previous recursive mechanism is not suitable. Therefore, a dynamic adaptive recursive mechanism is designed, and based on this, a distributed graph improved DRLS (IDRLS) algorithm is proposed. Convergence analysis confirms that the proposed algorithm achieves mean stability and mean-square convergence at a linear rate. Furthermore, we thoroughly examine the causes of performance degradation and demonstrate the superiority of the distributed graph IDRLS algorithm. Finally, experiments, conducted on two different graphs with different levels of sparsity and real-world dataset, verify that the proposed graph IDRLS algorithm can achieve the superior estimation performance and convergence rate and be more effective than the related graph algorithms.

title: Generalized Fast List Decoding of PAC Codes
authors: Wenbo Liu, Zhuolun Wu, Wei Zhang, Jianhan Zhao, Yaofeng Jiang, Yanyan Liu
abstract: Polarization-adjusted convolutional (PAC) codes are a recently proposed novel coding scheme that introduces a rate-one convolutional pre-transform before the polar transform, offering substantial performance gains, particularly when approaching the dispersion bound for PAC code (128, 64). However, achieving this performance advantage requires an extensive list decoding scale, substantially increasing decoding latency and limiting its practicality. In this letter, we propose generalized special nodes for PAC codes and provide a corresponding fast list decoding algorithm. The simulation results indicate that the proposed decoding algorithm offers superior parallel processing capabilities with negligible performance degradation. Specifically, the decoding latency for PAC code (128, 70) can be reduced by 31.75% compared to the current state-of-the-art work.

title: All-Dielectric Bandpass Filters for IEEE 802.15.3 d Terahertz Communications
authors: Linxi Chen, Weijie Gao, Mariam Abdullah, Jeffrey Hesler, Christophe Fumeaux, Withawat Withayachumnankul
publish: IEEE Transactions on Terahertz Science and Technology
abstract: As the demand for high-speed terahertz communications grows, bandpass filters become essential for managing the spectrum. However, the development of efficient planar bandpass filters for terahertz frequencies remains limited. This study introduces a new class of terahertz bandpass filters on an all-silicon, substrate-less platform. The design employs cascaded 2D and 1D photonic crystal structures with effective-medium claddings. The proposed approach allows for precise control of the center frequency and bandwidth, providing the flexibility to filter designs that can potentially cover all 69 channels in the IEEE 802.15.3 d standard between 252 GHz and 325 GHz. In this work, we demonstrate filter designs for four different channels, with two representative prototypes fabricated and characterized. Experimental results show low insertion loss better than 1.5 dB, high out-of-band rejection beyond 25 dB, flat group delay of 0.25 ns within the passband, and low group delay dispersion around 0.01 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\rm{ns}^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> . Communications experiments confirm the ability of the filter to reshape the terahertz spectrum, suppress out-of-band noise by 17dB, and improve channel isolation while preserving data integrity. This method provides a promising solution for scalable, high-performance filtering in future terahertz communications systems.

title: Trustworthy open set domain generalization network for unknown fault diagnosis under unseen conditions
authors: Zhenhua Fan, Bing Yan, Che Xu, Shixiang Lu, Kai Zhong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Advanced intelligent fault diagnosis methods based on domain generalization leverage multi-source sensor data to overcome the limitations the limitations of domain adaptation-based models regarding target data demand in the training stage, which resolves domain shift problems under unseen conditions in industrial instrumentation. However, previous studies primarily focused on the closed-set diagnosis with same label space shared by the training and testing data, which struggle to address the problem of new fault identification under intricate industrial dynamics. To overcome this obstacle, a trustworthy Evidential Open-Set Domain Generalization Network (EOSDGN) is proposed for open-set fault diagnosis under unseen conditions. In the EOSDGN method, an evidential deep classifier is constructed to quantify the uncertainty of predicted results, an evidential domain discriminator is employed to integrate the data from diverse source domains, and an evidential uncertainty calibration is established to reconcile the misleading evidence and class-based evidence assignments. The EOSDGN model effectively addresses both domain and label shift challenges by integrating domain-invariant features extraction and uncertainty quantification of the predicted probabilities, which enables efficient classification of known faults while simultaneously facilitating the identification of unknown faults. The effectiveness of the EOSDGN model has been substantiated using public and practical datasets. Experimental findings demonstrate that the EOSDGN model surpasses the performance of the state-of-the-art models.

title: DeepStep: A Deep Learning-Based Indoor Person Identification Framework Using Footstep-Induced Structural Vibration Signals_supp1-3643033.pdf
authors: Bodhibrata Mukhopadhyay
abstract: This paper introduces a large-scale, non-intrusive person identification framework using footstep-induced structural vibration signals. The increasing adoption of structural vibration analysis for person identification comes from its inherent non-intrusiveness and privacy preserving characteristics. However, existing methodologies are often constrained by the scarcity of extensive datasets, both in terms of the number of subjects and the temporal length of individual recordings, and frequently rely on supervised learning paradigms coupled with manual feature engineering. Consequently, the generalization capabilities of these approaches to broader populations are typically limited. To address these limitations, we have curated a comprehensive dataset of structural vibration signals acquired from 100 individuals. In addition, we have developed an unsupervised event detection method using features based on time, frequency, and wavelet analysis. Furthermore, we have developed DeepStep, a residual attention-based framework specifically designed for efficient feature extraction and classification of structural vibration signals. Experimental evaluation on our curated dataset demonstrates that the proposed approach achieves a Rank-1 accuracy of approximately 92% and a Rank-5 accuracy of approximately 96%.

title: Comparison of Open-Switch Fault-Tolerant Control Strategies for Three-Level NPC Inverters in Five-Phase Induction Motor Drives
authors: L. Vancini, M. Mengoni, G. Rizzoli, L. Zarri, A. Tani
abstract: In recent years, interest in multiphase converters has grown significantly, driven by the demand for higher efficiency and reliability in electric drives. Simultaneously, multilevel converter technology has matured, offering a practical solution for delivering high power from devices with limited voltage ratings. The integration of these two technologies, multiphase and multilevel converters, provides increased degrees of freedom, enabling the implementation of various fault-tolerant control strategies. However, the higher number of switching devices in multilevel converters also raises the likelihood of switch faults. To mitigate the effects of an open-switch fault, conventional strategies often aim to nullify the current in the faulty phase. Multilevel inverters, with their inherent flexibility, allow for more sophisticated fault-tolerant approaches. This paper presents a comparative analysis of four fault-tolerant control strategies for five-phase, three-level neutral-point clamped (NPC) inverters. Each method exploits the multiphase system's redundancy to reduce the impact of a single open-switch fault, focusing on minimizing voltage ripple across the DC bus capacitors within each switching cycle and throughout the fault duration.

title: On the Impact of Phase Errors in Phase-Dependent Amplitudes of Near-Field RISs
authors: Ke Wang, Chan-Tong Lam, Benjamin K. Ng, Yue Liu
abstract: This paper investigates mutual coupling between phase-dependent amplitudes (PDAs) and designed phase shifts within pixels of near-field (NF) reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) in the presence of phase errors (PEs). In contrast to existing research that treats phase shifts with errors (PSEs) and the PDAs separately, we introduce a remaining power (RP) metric to quantify the proportion of power preserved in the signals reflected by the RIS, and we prove its asymptotic convergence to theoretical values by leveraging extended Glivenko-Cantelli theorem. Then, the RP of signals passing through RIS pixels is jointly examined under combined phase and amplitude uncertainties. In addition, we propose four pixel reflection models to capture practical conditions, and we derive approximate polynomial upper bounds for the RP with error terms by applying Taylor expansion. Furthermore, based on Friis transmission formula and projected aperture, we propose a general NF channel model that incorporates the coupling between the PSEs and the PDAs. By using Cauchy-Bunyakovsky-Schwarz inequality and Riemann sums, we derive a closed-form upper bound on spectral efficiency, and the bound becomes tighter as the pixel area decreases. We reveal that as the RIS phase shifts approach the ends of their range, the RP under independent and identically distributed PEs is smaller than that under fully correlated PEs, whereas this relationship reverses when the phase shifts are near the middle of their range. Neglecting the PEs in the PDAs leads to an overestimation of the RIS performance gain, explaining the discrepancies between theoretical and measured results.

title: BAPTISM: A Robust Framework for Encrypted Malicious Traffic Identification with Low-quality Training Data
authors: Xiang Luo, Chang Liu, Gang Xiong, Gaopeng Gou, Zhen Li, Junzheng Shi, Li Guo, Binxing Fang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Machine learning (ML) is highly effective for accurate encrypted malicious traffic identification by using highquality training data. In fact, obtaining such data is costly and challenging. As a result, many ML-based models are inevitably trained on low-quality data and perform poorly. To enhance performance, some methods utilize various sample selection techniques to choose confident samples for model training. However, they often rely on a single metric for this selection, which restricts their adaptability across diverse datasets and noise conditions. In this paper, we propose a robust framework BAPTISM for identifying encrypted malicious traffic with low-quality training data. Particularly, BAPTISM selects a suitable base model for each task, and trains it with early stopping to generate traffic representation before overfitting occurs. Then, we devise an adaptive metric selection strategy to select confident samples. By employing two metrics (JSD and CSD) to assess the characteristic of traffic representation from distinct perspective, we find the more proper metric for each class and apply it for confident sample selection. According to the confident samples and selected metric for each class, we develop a label correction tactic which adapts to class nature to improve the quality of training data. Finally, we employ parallel training strategy to train the base model with the corrected data, further mitigating the impact of low-quality data. We conduct experiments across three real-world malicious traffic datasets with various noise settings. The results demonstrate that BAPTISM is compatible with different base models and outperforms across noise ratios ranging from 20% to 90%. Meanwhile, BAPTISM consistently selects the confident samples with the highest purity and volume under each setting.

title: Label Noise Robust Learning Approach for Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring based on Meta-Learning
authors: Bo Liu, Yanru Ren, Wenpeng Luan, Keke Li, Jinjiang Zhang, Wenqian Jiang
abstract: Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM) provides a solution for smart energy management in consumer electronics, enabling the monitoring of internal appliance operating statuses by analyzing the aggregated load data. Recently, various machine learning algorithms have been employed for NILM, however, their effectiveness largely depends on the availability of substantial high-quality labeled data. In practice, the manual and automatic labeling based on event waveform extracted from master meter data inevitably introduce the noisy labels, which impacts the performance of load identification neural network model. To this end, we propose a label noise robust learning approach for non-intrusive load monitoring based on meta-learning. On the basis of traditional teacher-student framework, multiple meta networks are generated by adjusting student network parameters using pseudo labels, which are derived from the noisy labeled data according to neighbor feature similarity. These meta networks further generate predictions, which are compared with the teacher network predictions to constitute the meta loss. The NILM model trained with meta loss can extract valuable information from noisy labeled data and avoid overfitting to incorrect labels. Comparison tests on two public datasets and one private dataset demonstrate that our method provides better performance under different noise rates.

title: Federated Learning-Based Credit Card Fraud Detection: Performance Analysis with Sampling Methods and Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: Fatima Muhair Alketbi, Fatih Kurugollu, Sebti Foufou, Isam Mashhour Al Jawarneh
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: Credit card fraud detection requires solutions that are accurate and also preserve privacy, given the sensitivity of financial data. This study examines the performance of three deep learning models: Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), across three learning frameworks: Federated Learning (FL), Split Learning (SL), and Regular Learning (RL). Four sampling approaches are used to mitigate class imbalance: SMOTE, Random Oversampling (ROS), Random Undersampling (RUS), and NearMiss Undersampling (NMU). Although accuracy, precision, and recall are conventional assessment measures, the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUC-ROC) functions as the primary performance metric. FL and RL robustness was further assessed through noisy client simulations. Experimental findings indicate that FL surpasses RL, demonstrating enhanced stability under certain adversarial scenarios. The proposed FL model achieved higher AUC-ROC performance than the Federated SDT model on the same dataset. This research advances the development of privacy-preserving and robust fraud detection systems, facilitating future enhancements in decentralized machine learning frameworks.

title: A Modular Pipeline for Context-Aware AI Assistance in XR Environments
authors: Phillip Vogler, Alexander Zoubarev, Louay Bassbouss, Stephan Steglich, Stefan Arbanowski
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: Integrating large language models into virtual environments opens the door for countless enhancement opportunities deemed computationally infeasible before the commercialization of AI. While this is the case, consumer hardware is still not equipped to deal with the processing requirements of local realtime 3D rendering and LLM inference. This paper presents a modular approach to building a computation pipeline designed to enable context-aware AI assistance in 3D environments, making use of remote rendering technology to offload computing to remote servers. The pipeline consists of a speech-to-text module, a text-to-speech module, and an LLM-based action system controlling a virtual agent. The architecture enables a composable approach to deploying immersive LLM assisted 3D environments that can be used in gaming and educational systems alike.

title: Digital Active Filters for Suppression of Predictable Common Mode EMI of Power Electronic Systems
authors: Maximilian Lemke, Jens Aigner, Tobias Doerlemann, Stephan Frei
abstract: In many new power electronic systems higher switching frequencies and steeper switching slopes could be realized, resulting in higher efficiency and power density. This leads to increased electromagnetic interference (EMI). Passive components for attenuating common-mode (CM) EMI often are bulky and heavy and reduce the power density significantly. For this reason, active EMI filters (AEFs) were developed for compensating the disadvantages of passive filters. Besides analog active EMI filters, digital active EMI filters (DAEF) have been introduced. Most active filters measure the EMI and generate a cancellation signal which is superimposed to the EMI to reduce it. The cancellation signal generation requires signal processing leading to delays. This results in a misalignment of EMI and cancellation signals, and the compensation performance is reduced. In some cases, a future noise signal can be predicted for a certain time. If the time that can be seen into the future is longer than the time required to generate the cancelation signal from a noise signal, the delay can be compensated. For example, periodic signals allow predictions of the future course. This paper discusses the predictability of the EMI and methods for synchronization between power electronic systems as noise source and DAEF. Selected methods for generating the cancellation signal are described and the filter performance is compared based on a motor inverter test setup. Advantages and disadvantages of the methods are discussed.

title: Single-Loop Model Predictive Speed Regulation for PMSM with Repetitive Disturbances Based on an Iterative Learning Observer
authors: Minrui Li, Haifeng Li, Yixiao Ding, Shihua Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Predictive Control of Electrical Drives and Power Electronics (PRECEDE)
abstract: This study investigates model predictive speed control for permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) under repetitive disturbances. A novel single-loop dual-layer MPC framework incorporating an iterative learning observer (ILO) is proposed. First, a discrete-time ILO is designed to estimate repetitive disturbances. By fully utilizing the repetitive characteristic, the ILO enables accurate estimation of harmonic disturbances while simultaneously providing a preview of their future behaviors. Second, the state reference trajectory and the control reference trajectory of the PMSM are derived by incorporating both the reference sequence and the previewed disturbance sequence. Finally, a single-loop MPC is developed to track the reference trajectories. Departing from existing MPC schemes, the proposed framework demonstrates three distinctive advantages: (1) exact tracking of references under repetitive disturbances, (2) preservation of structural simplicity, and (3) no requirement of explicit exogenous signal modeling. The stability of the proposed controller is rigorously analyzed. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing disturbance-observer-based MPC designs in steady-state speed fluctuation suppression capability.

title: Resilient Aviation Security: A Hybrid Approach Combining Facial and Appearance Recognition
authors: Ján Jevčák, Martin Kelemen, Jozef Mário Jusko
abstract: Facial recognition technology (FRT) is increasingly used in airports to improve security and efficiency, but its reliability is compromised by real-world variables and privacy regulations like GDPR. This study experimentally evaluates an FRT system’s robustness against facial occlusions, including masks, glasses, and headwear-under both daylight and poor lighting conditions, measuring its False Acceptance Rate (FAR) and False Rejection Rate (FRR). The results reveal that while the system performed perfectly in ideal daylight, its accuracy deteriorated significantly in poor lighting. The combination of multiple occlusions under these adverse conditions led to high error rates, reaching up to $15 \%$ FAR and $15 \%$ FRR. To address these vulnerabilities, a dual-layered security model integrating facial recognition with appearancebased person recognition is proposed. And experimentally validated. This hybrid approach enhances system resilience by using non-biometric identifiers for continuous tracking, thereby improving security without sacrificing data privacy principles.

title: Privacy-Preserving On-chain Permissioning for KYC-Compliant Decentralized Applications
authors: Fabian Piper, Karl Wolf, Jonathan Heiss
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Decentralized applications (dApps) in Decentralized Finance (DeFi) face a fundamental tension between regulatory compliance requirements like Know Your Customer (KYC) and maintaining decentralization and privacy. Existing permissioned DeFi solutions often fail to adequately protect private attributes of dApp users and introduce implicit trust assumptions, undermining the blockchain’s decentralization. Addressing these limitations, this paper presents a novel synthesis of Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI), Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs), and AttributeBased Access Control to enable privacy-preserving on-chain permissioning based on decentralized policy decisions. We provide a comprehensive framework for permissioned dApps that aligns decentralized trust, privacy, and transparency, harmonizing blockchain principles with regulatory compliance. Our framework supports multiple proof types (equality, range, membership, and time-dependent) with efficient proof generation through a commit-and-prove scheme that moves credential authenticity verification outside the ZKP circuit. Experimental evaluation of our KYC-compliant DeFi implementation shows considerable performance improvement for different proof types compared to baseline approaches. We advance the state-of-the-art through a holistic approach, flexible proof mechanisms addressing diverse real-world requirements, and optimized proof generation enabling practical deployment.

title: Unlocking On-Chain Intelligence: A Practical Framework for GenAI-Powered Smart Contracts
authors: Rabimba Karanjai, Yang Lu, Lei Xu, Weidong Larry Shi
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Generative AI and modern Machine Learning are rapidly transforming industries, creating new tools and use cases. As these models grow, there is an increasing need for reliable Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) to manage and deploy them. At the same time, demand is rising for smarter smart contracts and more complex on-chain computation. Our paper presents a new framework that brings GenAI inference directly onto the blockchain. Using the Cosmos SDK, Ethermint, and the ONNX runtime, we enable AI models to run on-chain across multiple blockchain nodes. We evaluate the system’s feasibility, performance, and portability, showing that it can support different AI engines and model types. By enabling GenAI inference on-chain, our approach expands what smart contracts can do, especially for data-driven DeFi, and opens the door to new applications in the future.

title: Demo: MedTech Chain 2.0 Integration of Homomorphic Encryption into a Decentralized Platform for Medical Device Data Research*
authors: Yavor Pachedzhiev, Andç Durmaz, Ege Yarar, Ivan Markov, Sinan Önen, Roland Kromes, Zekeriya Erkin
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Hospitals produce vast amounts of medical device data, making their protection and analysis crucial in Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) settings. MedTech Chain 1.0 allowed cybersecurity researchers to run queries for data analytics. Even if the platform applied differential privacy, data storage was in plaintext and certain analysis capabilities were still missing. To address these limitations, we propose MedTech Chain 2.0, a platform that integrates homomorphic encryption, and enhanced mechanisms for encryption key management, and expanded query support. These improvements strengthen data protection while enabling deeper insights, advancing in cybersecurity and CTI research.

title: Free Lunch in In Situ Visualization: Leveraging Idle CPU Resources to Mitigate GPU Contention
authors: Victor A. Mateevitsi, Andres Sewell, Jens-Henrik Göbbert, Mathis Bode, Paul Fischer, Joseph A. Insley, Ioannis Kavroulakis, Damaskinos Konioris, Yu-Hsiang Lan, Misun Min, Dimitrios Papageorgiou, Steve Petruzza, Silvio Rizzi, Ananias Tomboulides, Michael E. Papka
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th Symposium on Large Data Analysis and Visualization (LDAV)
abstract: In high-performance computing (HPC), in situ analysis and visualization avoid costly I/O by extracting insight during the simulation run. When these tasks execute on the same GPUs that drive the simulation, resource contention can degrade performance. We propose an asynchronous framework that offloads visualization to idle CPU cores and overlaps in situ work with simulation execution. The framework uses ASCENT for efficient data movement and rendering and applies core pinning. Evaluated with NekRS on Polaris and JUWELS Booster, it reduced end-to-end runtime by 21–40% for slice-based visualizations compared to inline GPU instrumentation. Slice outputs incurred little overhead and overlapped cleanly with the simulation. Heavier filters like isovolumes, multilevel contours, and volume rendering were "free" (i.e., visualization time was encapsulated by simulation time) only at lower node counts, consistent with a CPU-budget model: filter cost and output cadence must fit the cores available per node.

title: Push-Pull Resonant Converter with Wide ZVS Range
authors: Nian-Ci Chen, Min-Fu Hsieh
abstract: This paper proposes a push-pull resonant converter with constant off-time control, designed to achieve wide-range zero-voltage switching (ZVS) under varying input voltages and load conditions. Simulation results verify that the proposed converter achieves ZVS turn-on at input voltages of 53.6 V and 42 V, for both full-load (1 kW) and light-load (100 W) conditions.

title: Comparison of Graphs Based on the Formation of Heat Kernel Invariants
authors: Sergey Chukanov, Ilya Chernukha
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The structure of a graph can be characterized using the eigenvalue spectrum of its Laplacian matrix, which is intrinsically related to the heat equation. The derivative of the heat kernel with respect to time is determined by the Laplacian, and the heat content derived from the kernel can serve as a basis for graph comparison and recognition. In this work, the coefficients of the heat content power series are used to represent the structural properties of graphs as feature vectors. The relationships for determining the Mahalanobis (weighted Euclidean) distance between feature vectors—heat kernel invariants and elementary symmetric polynomials of graphs— are presented. This distance measure enables quantitative comparison of graph structures and can be applied in pattern recognition, computer vision, and signal identification tasks. The study also considers the use of Laplacian-based learning to optimize the Mahalanobis matrix for improved discrimination between graph representations. The obtained results demonstrate the feasibility of using heat content coefficients as invariant descriptors of graph structure.

title: A Framework for Dynamic VLAN Management in Legacy Network Infrastructures
authors: A. P. Matveeva, Yu. M. Monakhov, D. V. Krizhanovsky, S. N. Matveev
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The static configuration of Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs) in traditional corporate networks presents significant challenges for network management, including operational inefficiency, lack of adaptability to changing traffic patterns, and potential security vulnerabilities. While Software-Defined Networking (SDN) offers a solution, its widespread adoption is hindered by high costs and compatibility issues with existing traditional (legacy) infrastructure. This paper addresses this gap by proposing and implementing a prototype of a configuration management system for dynamic VLAN reconfiguration in legacy network environments. The core of the solution is an experimental testbed built within the EVE-NG emulation platform, integrating Ansible for network automation, Prometheus for metrics collection, and Grafana for visualization and monitoring. The prototype successfully demonstrates the automated execution of VLAN configuration changes on emulated Cisco devices via SSH, coupled with the ability to monitor the resulting network state through collected NetFlow data and system metrics. The developed framework serves as a foundational closed-loop system for managing network configuration, validating the practical feasibility of the approach. The results confirm functionality of the prototype and lay the groundwork for future integration of intelligent optimization algorithms for fully autonomous network management.

title: Resource-Efficient Nonlinear Model Predictive Control for Quadcopters: A Comparative Study of FMINCON and FORCESPRO
authors: Kaibo Li, Truong Quang Dinh, Kairui Yao
abstract: This study investigates the performance of two optimization solvers—FMINCON and FORCESPRO—when applied to nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC) for quadcopter trajectory tracking. A unified NMPC framework is developed and implemented using both solvers under identical system models and control configurations. The evaluation focuses on key performance metrics including computation time, memory usage, tracking accuracy, and input smoothness. A series of simulation-based experiments are conducted to benchmark solver behavior across different prediction horizons. The comparative analysis aims to assess the practical feasibility of each solver for real-time and embedded quadcopter applications. Results show that FORCESPRO achieves significantly better resource efficiency and tracking performance, particularly during transient flight phases, highlighting its suitability for onboard deployment in agile aerial platforms.

title: A 3-D Ionospheric Electron Density Reconstruction Method Based on Fusion of Multi-Source Data
authors: Yangqiang Yang, Xueqing Zhang, Lifen Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: The ionosphere is an ionized region of the Earth's upper atmosphere, and its variations significantly affect the reliability of radio communication and satellite navigation systems. The reconstruction methods of ionospheric electron density is mainly divided into three categories including tomography, data assimilation, and deep learning, and integration of multi-source data is the development direction of three-dimensional electron density reconstruction. This paper used spaceborne SAR data, ionosonde data, GNSS-TEC data, and IRI model data to construct the constraint conditions for three-dimensional electron density reconstruction, and then reconstructs the three-dimensional electron density of the ionosphere. The specific idea was as follows, the regional TEC is inverted from spaceborne SAR data, GNSS-TEC is used to calibrate the regional TEC baseline, the peak height and maximum electron density of the F2 layer are calibrated by ionosonde data, and finally the electron density profiled from IRI model was corrected to obtain the three-dimensional electron density profile. Simulation experiments showed that the three-dimensional electron density reconstruction method proposed in this paper can reconstruct high-precision three-dimensional electron density profile of the ionosphere, which might provide reference for further research and verification.

title: Adaptive-Parameter Enhanced VSG Control of MMC for MVDC Collection of Renewable Energy
authors: Hao Hu, Yuying He, Jingxin Hu
abstract: For medium-voltage DC aggregated renewable integration systems, this paper proposes an adaptive parameters control strategy for modular multilevel converters (MMCs). Conventional fixed-parameter virtual synchronous generator (VSG) exhibits insufficient dynamic response under power disturbances. The proposed method dynamically adjusts virtual inertia and damping coefficients based on real-time frequency deviations, achieving an optimal balance between response speed and stability. Simulations verify that adaptive control significantly enhances frequency stability and power response compared to fixed-parameter VSG. According to the simulation results, the adaptive-parameter algorithm reduces the active power overshoot by 47 percent and shortens the settling time by $\mathbf{2 0}$ percent during the power reference transition Compared to the fixed-parameter method.

title: Control and Experimental Verification of Unidirectional 3-Phase AC/DC Power Converter Using Single-Delta Bridge-Cell Converter
authors: Atsuya Suzuki, Makoto Hagiwara
abstract: This paper proposes a unidirectional three-phase to DC power converter that integrates a single-delta bridge-cell (SDBC) converter with a single-phase diode rectifier through a medium-frequency transformer operating at $\mathbf{1 5 0 ~ H z}$. The proposed configuration enables both active and reactive power control, thereby facilitating reactive power compensation while supplying substation auxiliary loads. As a result, it contributes to reducing the rated power and downsizing of the highvoltage line-frequency transformer required in substation facilities. However, unlike conventional SDBC-based systems, the nonlinear characteristics of the diode rectifier prevent cluster power balancing via circulating current control. To overcome this limitation, this paper introduces a novel method utilizing negative-sequence current for cluster balancing. The effectiveness of the proposed method is experimentally verified using a $100 \mathrm{~V}, 5 \mathrm{kVA}$ downscaled model.

title: A Flexible and Lightweight Watermarking Framework for Stable Diffusion Models
authors: Huixin Luo, Li Li, Xinpeng Zhang
abstract: The application of Stable Diffusion Models (SDMs) in Internet of Things (IoT) image processing raises significant ethical concerns, particularly regarding model copyright infringement and the dissemination of inappropriate Artificial Intelligence (AI)-generated images. Model watermarking technology has proven effective for copyright verification and tracing the source model of AI-generated content. While initial-noise-modification-based watermarking can provide provable security and achieve lossless embedding, existing methods rely on Denoising Diffusion Implicit Model (DDIM) inversion for watermark extraction, which suffer from inherent precision limitations that compromise extraction accuracy. More critically, most of the existing approaches of this type still rely on access to the original or a compatible SDM during watermark verification, which introduces considerable practical constraints due to the model’s size and computational demands. To address these limitations, an end-to-end flexible SDM watermarking framework is proposed that replaces the DDIM inversion process with a lightweight watermark extractor, thereby eliminating the dependency on inversion in conventional provably secure watermarking. Specifically, a universal watermark extractor across SDM V1/V2 variants is designed based on a Transformer and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) framework, complemented by fine-tuning a pre-trained watermark decoder, to directly recover watermark information from generated images. Experimental results confirm that our watermarking method yields superior performance in terms of fidelity and robustness. The lightweight extractor offers additional advantages of low computational cost and high transmission efficiency, providing an efficient and practical solution for watermark extraction in SDM-generated image.

title: RyNet: Multi-Level Attention for Rich and Complementary Feature Representation in CNNs
authors: Anouar Chahbouni, Imane Elmanaa, Khaoula El Manaa, Yassine Abouch, Badre Bossoufi, Mohammed El Ghzaoui, Rachid EL Alami
abstract: Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) excel at extracting spatial and channel-wise features, but reliance on final-layer activations often underutilizes intermediate representations and weakens hierarchical cues. We propose RyNet, a theoretically grounded, modular, and CNN-agnostic dual-attention framework that integrates dynamic channel refinement with multi-level feature fusion in a single backbone. RyNet aggregates low-, mid-, and high-level feature maps, applies channel squeezing with learnable channel-wise attention scores to promote selective activation, and fuses recalibrated features via a lightweight summation strategy. This yields stage-to-stage coupling with implicit spatial emphasis at negligible computational cost. RyNet achieves hierarchical complementarity without branch duplication or concatenation–projection stacks. Integrated into VGG16 and ResNet18, RyNet improves CIFAR-10 test accuracy from 89.90% to 90.84% (a relative improvement of 1.04%) and from 90.42% to 91.74% (a relative improvement of 1.50%), respectively, On the PlantVillage (tomato) dataset, a custom CNN-based model integrated with RyNet achieves 99.61% accuracy, representing a relative improvement of 1.54%. Under identical datasets and training conditions, RyNet consistently and statistically outperforms SE and CBAM, and beyond this, demonstrates superiority over recent CNN–Transformer hybrids and other state-of-the-art methods. Feature-space analysis reveals a 121.9% increase in inter-class separability, while visualizations and interpretability evaluations confirm the effectiveness of dynamic channel selection under multi-level fusion. These results provide strong theoretical, empirical, and statistical validation for the proposed design. Overall, RyNet emerges as a principled, lightweight, and easily integrable module for enhancing CNN representations in resource-constrained environments, with significant performance gains and improved model explainability.

title: Attentive Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory Model to Predict the Remaining Useful Life of Aircraft Engines
authors: Andréia Seixas Leal, Ravinesh C Deo, Salvin S. Prasad, Luis Carlos de Castro Santos, Mumtaz Ali, Lilian Berton
abstract: Accurate Remaining Useful Life (RUL) prediction for turbofan engines remains a challenging issue for the aviation industry due to operational condition variability, sensor noise, and the relatively complex degradation patterns of turbofans. To address this important research problem, we propose a new Bidirectional LSTM with Dual-Attention (BiLSTM-Attn) model that integrates (1) temporal attention (αt) for phase-aware degradation modeling mechanism, (2) feature attention (βj) via convolution for sensor importance weighting, (3) hybrid normalization for condition invariance, and (4) gated fusion of spatiotemporal contexts particularly to model RUL for turbofan engines. Evaluated on the NASA C-MAPSS, the proposed BiLSTM-Attn model achieves an average root mean square error (RMSE) of 16.0 across the FD001-FD004 dataset, thus outperforming the competing model (CNN-LSTM) by 10% accuracy measure while maintaining real-time inference speed. The interpretable attention weights of the proposed model also provide maintenance engineers with significantly useful actionable insights into critical degradation patterns, as demonstrated through case studies on FD003 failure mode datasets. This combination of relatively high accuracy (R2 = 0.82) along with the explainability of the proposed model makes it suitable for both offline analysis and onboard deployment actions in aviation health management systems.

title: Mutual Coupling-Enhanced Movable Antenna Arrays: Breaking Minimum-Spacing Constraints
authors: Junwei Zhu, Fei Han, Yuqing Guo, Ying Wang
abstract: The existing works concerning movable antenna (MA) arrays often stipulate a half-wavelength minimum antenna spacing to avoid mutual coupling (MC) between antennas. This letter unveils the potential performance improvement of MA arrays by strategically leveraging MC for the first time. Firstly, the impacts of MC are precisely characterized by the MC matrix, which is derived based on rigorous circuit and antenna theories. Upon this approach, the maximization of the sum rate is formulated as a problem, where the minimum-spacing constraints for antennas are naturally removed. Subsequently, a hybrid convex optimization and particle swarm optimization (CO-PSO) is proposed to tackle the proposed problem efficiently. Simulations results are provided to validate the robustness of our proposed CO-PSO algorithm. These results demonstrate that MC can enhance the spectral efficiency of MA arrays by approximately 1.75 bps/Hz, thus highlighting the potential of MC in improving the capacity of MA-assisted wireless communications.

title: Enhancing Light Utilization Efficiency of Dragon Fruit Canopies Using Bi-Directional Adjustable-Focusing LED Lighting System
authors: Qiannan Jiang, Qiaoyang Zhang, Haiyun Chen, Jiacheng Ruan, Wensong Wang, Tama Fouzder, Ji Wang, Hua Xiao
abstract: Commercial light-emitting diodes (LEDs) offer fixed lighting patterns with limited canopy coverage, creating a mismatch with dragon fruit's dynamic photosynthetic and phenological needs. To mitigate the inherent limitations of conventional unidirectional irradiance distributions, a bi directional emission LED system incorporating adjustable focusing mechanisms is engineered. Monte Carlo ray-tracing and numerical integration are employed to quantitatively analyze the influence of plant architectural complexity, LED positioning strategies, and angular emission profiles on canopy light distribution. Concurrently, three optimization algorithms— Simulated Annealing (SA), Genetic Algorithm (GA), and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO)—are comparatively evaluated for their efficacy in maximizing radiation efficiency (RE) and utilization efficiency (UE). The proposed method (1) achieves targeted photon delivery while minimizing light spillage between canopies, resulting in 39.39% and 206.67% higher UE compared with the other two schemes under the same static fixture at a height of 1.7 m and an emission angle of 50°, and (2) achieves high prediction accuracy, with RE and UE determination coefficients (R²) of 96% and 97%, respectively.

title: Gamma-Ray Induced Displacement Damage in Silicon Microvolumes: Single Defect Generation Rate and Random Telegraph Signal
authors: Vincent Goiffon, Clémentine Durnez, Antoine Jay, Ali Jouni, Vera Kharchenkova, Aubin Antonsanti, Valérian Lalucaa, Damien Lambert, Thomas Jarrin, Antoine Salih Alj, Richard Monflier, Nicolas Richard, Philippe Paillet, Anne Hémeryck, Daniel McGrath, Cédric Virmontois
abstract: Single displacement damage-induced defects created by 60Co gamma-rays are studied in silicon microvolumes using a state-of-the-art CMOS Image Sensor (CIS). The Dark Current Spectroscopy (DCS) technique used in this work enables spatial and temporal tracking of the identified defect generation rates with a single defect sensitivity. The generation rate, energy level, annealing temperature and quantity of expected point defects (including the divacancy V2 and the E-center As-V or P-V) are estimated. An isochronal annealing experiment up to 300°C highlights the creation of new defects at high temperature such as V2OH, VOH and VmOn complexes. This study also demonstrates that 60Co gamma rays can generate bulk defect-induced Dark Current Random Telegraph Signal (DC-RTS) with a very specific temporal and amplitude signature. A divacancy-impurity complex is suspected to be at the origin of this DC-RTS behavior.

title: Cooperative Vehicle Localization in VANETs Subject to Sensing and Transmission Failures
authors: Ge Guo, Zeng-Bo Li, Jiageng Liu
abstract: This paper investigates a cascaded robust Kalman filter framework for cooperative localization of vehicles subject to unreliable information from onboard sensors and vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs). Specially, an adaptive-threshold outlier-robust local filter is first introduced that using a machine learning-based dynamic parameter selection approach. Then, a three-stage weighting function, and K-means clustering to classify residuals into reliable and outlier sets, with the maximum residual from the reliable set used to adaptively determine the threshold. Finally, by employing a dual-statistics joint test to extract two-dimensional statistical features from residual matrices, an unreliable information isolation algorithm with low computational complexity is developed. Experimental results demonstrate that the method outperforms the state-of-the-art results with ensured accuracy and robustness for cooperative vehicle localization in urban environments.
