title: HySpeFAS: A Hyperspectral Face Anti-spoofing Dataset based on Snapshot Compressive Imaging
authors: Shijie Rao, Yidong Huang, Xueqian Zhang, Hao Fang, Ajian Liu, Jun Wan, Kaiyu Cui, Yali Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Face anti-spoofing, which aims to prevent the attacks of widely-used face recognition systems, is highly related to personal privacy and property security. However, existing benchmarks on face anti-spoofing mainly focus on RGB images, further challenged by consistently developed 3D high-fidelity (HiFi) masks. To facilitate the research on multimodal face anti-spoofing, we construct the HyperSpectral Face Anti-Spoofing (HySpeFAS) dataset. We introduce the newly-developed snapshot spectral imaging (SSI) technology to capture real and spoof faces, as well as identify unknown HiFi masks. Specifically, hyperspectral images (HSIs) acquired by SSI sensor contain rich information about the chemical composition of the targets, which can be used to effectively distinguish live human skin and various spoof materials. The HySpeFAS dataset contains 22,368 multimodal images (i.e., RGB, SSI, HSI) of 17 live subjects and 60 spoof subjects. Moreover, extensive experiments with baseline deep learning models validate the special features of the SSI images and the potential of SSI in FAS. By publishing the dataset as well as the baseline models, we encourage the community to foster the algorithm study associated with hyperspectral images and the development of SSI-equipped intelligent systems.

title: Digital Transformation, CEO Career Concerns, and Enterprise Green Mergers and Acquisitions
authors: Ruitao Zhao, Zhenbing Yan, Lei Zhao
abstract: Green transformation has become a global consensus, but enterprises often treat it as a symbolic strategy rather than a substantive commitment. While existing studies have examined how internal capabilities and external pressures influence enterprise green actions, few have explored how digital transformation enables external green strategies such as green mergers and acquisitions (M&A), or how CEO career concerns shape such decisions. This study examines the impact of digital transformation on green M&A among Chinese A-share listed enterprises from 2010 to 2023, with an in-depth analysis of the moderating role of CEO career concerns in this process. The results show that digital transformation significantly promotes green M&A, particularly when CEOs face external and prospective concerns, whereas internal career concerns weaken this effect. Heterogeneity analysis reveals that the digital–green relationship varies by CEO characteristics, industry type, and enterprise characteristics. The study enriches the understanding of sustainable strategic decision-making mechanisms in engineering management. It offers enterprises guidance on aligning incentives to promote the synergy between digital transformation and green transition.

title: Tailored to Fit Sepsis Individuals: Medical Knowledge Aware Reinforcement Learning Model Offers Optimized Therapeutic Strategies
authors: Xue Feng, Siyi Zhu, Luping Fang, Huaiping Zhu, Guolong Cai, Yanfei Shen, Gangmin Ning
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Sepsis is a life-threatening syndrome, with high morbidity and mortality. Timely treatments and precise interventions are crucial for improving sepsis patient outcomes. Reinforcement learning (RL) models have made promising advances in associating sepsis treatments. However, existing models face obstacles when applied to heterogeneous sepsis patients with an imbalanced distribution of disease severity, struggling to maintain optimal performance. To provide optimal therapeutic intervention strategies for sepsis with different disease severity, we proposed a novel treatment recommendation model named Medical ontology knowledge and disease diagnosis Position aware Transfer learning - Double Dueling Deep Q Network (MPT-D3QN). Through the attention mechanism, medical ontology knowledge and disease diagnosis positions were introduced to achieve a more accurate representation of patient states. Subsequently, an offline deep reinforcement learning algorithm was used to recommend therapeutic intervention strategies for a specific patient population. The transfer learning framework was responsible for the information transfer across patient groups in different domains. We trained and tested MPT-D3QN model on the Multi-Parameter Intelligent Monitoring in Intensive Care III (MIMIC-III) dataset. Compared with the reported strategies in present clinical practice, the MPT-D3QN model could obtain a higher expected return value (12.98 vs. 10.61) and reduce the estimated mortality from 13.20% to 6.15% in all test datasets. Moreover, the experimental test on an external dataset eICU Collaborative Research Database (eICU) further demonstrated the robust generalization capability of the model. Compared with the state-of-the-art models, the proposed model not only guaranteed higher expected returns but also generated optimal and interpretable treatment strategies for sepsis with different disease severity.

title: On Key Substitution Attacks against Aggregate Signatures and Multi-Signatures
authors: Yuuki Fujita, Yusuke Sakai, Kyosuke Yamashita, Goichiro Hanaoka
abstract: The most fundamental security requirement for signature schemes is unforgeability, which guarantees that no one can create a valid signature on a message without the secret signing key. However, in signature schemes, there are potential attacks in which a third party forges the message and verification key of a valid signature and “hijacks” the signature. Such attacks are referred to as key substitution attacks. Key substitution attacks obscure the ownership of a signature—that is, who actually created it—and therefore must be taken into account in practical applications. In this article, we investigate security against key substitution attacks of a wide range of aggregate signature schemes and multi-signature schemes: the Boneh-Gentry-Lynn-Shacham aggregate signature scheme, the sequential aggregate signature scheme by Lysyanskaya et al., the multi-signature scheme by Bellare and Neven, MuSig2, and the ordered multi-signature scheme by Boldyreva et al. Furthermore, if any of the schemes does not provide security against key substitution attacks, then we modify the scheme to become secure against the attacks. This paper also provides important insights for practical deployments of signature schemes. For example, MuSig2 is actually used in blockchain systems, but if key substitution attacks were possible, the authenticity of the block contents would be called into question.

title: Dynamic Diffusion Graph Convolutional Network with Scene-Guided Gating for Trajectory Prediction in IoT-Based Intelligent Transportation Systems
authors: Xiang Yin, Zhipeng Zhang, Yujie Huang, Hao Hu
abstract: Accurate trajectory prediction is crucial in IoT-based intelligent transportation systems. This task remains challenging due to the uncertainty of agent intentions and the highly stochastic social interactions between agents. Despite the promising progress, most existing studies overlook the impact of scene heterogeneity on driving behavior, thereby limiting the predictive performance of models across diverse scenes. Moreover, the highly stochastic social interactions between agents have not been fully explored, thus weakening the reliability of predictions. To address these challenges, a novel dynamic diffusion graph convolutional network with scene-guided gating is proposed in this study. First, a pioneering scene-guided gating is introduced to capture and leverage the impact of scene heterogeneity on driving behavior. This mechanism generates scene-specific non-shared parameters to selectively filter information, thus establishing scene-guided information bottlenecks to facilitate more socially-aware trajectory prediction. Then, a dynamic diffusion graph convolutional layer is formulated to comprehensively account for the highly stochastic social interactions between agents. It models social interactions as a diffusion process on a lane graph and employs bidirectional random walks on lane attention graphs to simulate the stochastic nature of social interactions. Finally, extensive experiments on the nuScenes benchmark demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed model.

title: TERM Model: Tensor Ring Mixture Model for Density Estimation
authors: Ruituo Wu, Jiani Liu, Bing Li, Anh-Huy Phan, Ivan V. Oseledets, Ce Zhu, Yipeng Liu
abstract: Probabilistic modeling is a core challenge in statistical machine learning. Tensor-based probabilistic graph methods address interpretability and stability concerns encountered in neural network approaches and allow tractable inference (e.g., marginal inference and conditional inference). In this paper, we introduce tensor ring decomposition for density estimation, which reduces the number of permutation candidates compared to existing methods, while simultaneously enhancing expressive power and maintaining tractable inference. Different non-negative strategies for density function results in two variants: Born TRDE offers simpler inference and sampling but with slightly lower accuracy, while Energy TRDE, though more complex, achieves superior performance. Furthermore, a mixture model that incorporates multiple permutation candidates with adaptive weights is designed, resulting in increased expressive flexibility and comprehensiveness. Unlike existing methods that focus on finding a single optimal permutation, our approach, inspired by ensemble learning, demonstrates that combining multiple suboptimal permutations can yield superior results. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach excels in estimating probability density functions and sampling, capturing intricate details with competitive or superior performance compared to existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) tractable density methods.

title: A Time-Certified Predictor-Corrector IPM Algorithm for Box-QP
authors: Liang Wu, Yunhong Che, Richard D. Braatz, Jan Drgona
abstract: Minimizing both the worst-case and average execution times of optimization algorithms is equally critical in real-time optimization-based control applications such as model predictive control (MPC). Most MPC solvers have to trade off between certified worst-case and practical average execution times. For example, our previous work wu2025direct proposed a full-Newton path-following interior-point method (IPM) with data-independent, simple-calculated, and exact O(n) iteration complexity, but not as efficient as the heuristic Mehrotra’s predictor–corrector IPM algorithm (which sacrifices global convergence). This letter proposes a new predictor–corrector IPM algorithm that preserves the same certified O(n) iteration complexity while achieving a 5× speedup over wu2025direct. Numerical experiments and codes that validate these results are provided.

Development of Nano-Particle Induced Room Temperature CH

authors: Bodhishatwa Roy, Saikat Jati, Tanushree Bala, Anupam Karmakar, Sanatan Chattopadhyay
abstract: The article demonstrates the performance of metal-nanoparticles (NPs) decorated SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> thin films for room temperature CH<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub> sensing in the range of 15 to 180 ppm concentration. The SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> films are deposited on glass substrate by thermal evaporation of CBD extracted SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> nano-powders. A simple cost-effective chemical reduction method is adopted for synthesizing Pd-, Au- and Pt-nanoparticles; which are then drop-casted on the SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> films for sensor fabrication. FESEM imaging confirms the formation of continuous SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> film along with the drop-casted NPs. The analyzes of XRD and PL spectra suggest the formation of orthorhombic SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> with inherent oxygen-vacancy defects which are exploited for CH<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub> sensing at room temperature. The highest response of ∼630% for 15 ppm of CH<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub> is obtained for PdNP decorated SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> film, significantly higher than that of AuNP and PtNP decorated SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> films. Moreover, the PdNP decorated SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> film also exhibits very fast response-recovery time of ∼12.3 s and ∼5.3 s respectively, with high selectivity towards CH<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub>; indicating its potential use as a CH<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub> sensor for environment monitoring and diseases diagnosis.

title: Social Commerce Live Streaming and Its Effect on Impulsive Purchasing Behavior: A Study of Indonesian Gen Z
authors: Naufalino Raihan Yudo Firmano, Calvin Valentino Sugianto, Cadelina Cassandra
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: The rapid growth of internet access in Indonesia has significantly influenced e-commerce and social media platforms, fostering new types of digital consumer engagement. Among these developments, live-streaming commerce has emerged as a particularly effective tool, enabling real time interaction, product demonstration, and a seamless shopping experience. This study aims to examine how various stimuli in live streaming environments such as promotion intensity, trustworthiness, streamer expertise, attractiveness, interactivity, and live room activities affect customer perceived pleasure and arousal, and how these emotional responses influence impulsive purchasing behavior. This study use the Stimulus-Organism-Response (S-O-R) model as the theoretical framework. Data were collected through an online survey and cleaned and analyzed 389 gen z respondent using quantitative methods. The results revealed that six out of seven key variables had a significant positive effect on either pleasure or arousal. The Strongest variables were attractiveness affected pleasure; interactivity and expertise affected arousal; and trustworthiness was weakest. Notably, streamer expertise significantly influenced arousal but had no significant impact on pleasure, suggesting that emotional engagement in live shopping is driven more by entertainment and interpersonal connection than by information provided by the streamer.

title: High-Efficiency Constant Power Point Tracking for Photovoltaic Generation Systems
authors: Han-Cheng Wu, Yu-Chuan Chen, Jen-Hao Teng, Chun-Wei Cheng, Rong-Ceng Leou
abstract: The duck curve phenomenon arises from the intermittent nature and increasing penetration of Photovoltaic Generation Systems (PVGSs), causing sharp fluctuations in grid demand. This variability requires advanced grid balancing and energy management strategies to ensure stability. One key technology addressing this issue is Constant Power Point Tracking (CPPT), which restricts the power output of a PVGS under changing conditions. Unlike traditional Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT), which maximizes instantaneous power, CPPT focuses on maintaining a stable and predictable power delivery. Therefore, this paper proposes a high-efficiency CPPT for PVGSs. The proposed CPPT estimates the solar irradiance and ambient temperature of a PVGS using two sets of voltage and current measurements, along with the Newton-Raphson method. The CPP can then be directly calculated to restrict the instantaneous power output of the PVGS. The proposed CPPT can also dynamically switch to MPPT if the estimated power output of the PVGS is lower than the restricted power output of the PVGS without extra measurement sets. Therefore, a high-efficiency CPPT can be realized meanwhile maintaining the potential maximum power output. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves the CPP or MPP in 3s with a tracking accuracy of 99.82% under a tracking interval of 1 s.

title: A Three-Port Bidirectional DC/DC Converter with DC-bus/ESS Power Control in DC Microgrids
authors: Ching-Ming Lai, Chao-Tang Chou, Yong-Zheng Chen, Shi-Qiang Liu, Tomokazu Mishima
abstract: This article presents a novel three-port bidirectional DC-DC converter (BDC) featuring an integrated inductor to enhance power density and reduce system cost. The proposed converter topology enables the integration of electric vehicles (EVs), energy storage systems (ESSs), and a DC-Bus. Under high power demand, energy can be dispatched from the EV or ESS to the DC-Bus. Conversely, when the DC-Bus reaches full capacity, excess energy can be stored in the ESS or EV. This bidirectional energy flow enhances the reliability and flexibility of DC-microgrids (DC-MGs) while reducing reliance on a single energy source. To improve performance, the lowvoltage ports utilize a two-phase interleaving technique, which effectively minimizes current stress and ripple. The highvoltage ports utilize a tapped-inductor winding configuration, allowing for a high voltage-gain through adjustable turn ratios. This study focuses on power control between a 400 V DC-Bus and a 60 V ESS, and includes analysis of operating principles and steady-state behavior. The system verification using a 1 kW prototype circuit confirms that the proposed converter achieves both high voltage-gain and stable bidirectional power transfer, demonstrating its practical feasibility.

title: An Investigation into Load-Pulling Effect of Active EMI Filter on Power-Electronic Converters
authors: Thattam Narksook, Achirawat Kaitkansiri, Surapong Suwankawin
abstract: Reducing the size of passive elements in EMI filter by using the active elements can achieve attenuation performance, and the active EMI filter using FeedbackVoltage Sensing Current Injection (FB-VSCI) topology is now commercially available. Nevertheless, the load-pulling effect from active EMI filters is overlooked, this paper investigates into this effect and introduces a heuristic analysis to comprehend such phenomenon. The correctness of the theoretical result is validated by simulation and experimental results.

title: LED Lifetime Prediction Under Weather Condition for Enhanced Semiconductor Reliability Using XGBoost Algorithm
authors: Mochamad Nizar Palefi Ma’Ady, Mohammad Yanuar Hariyawan, Eka Sari Oktarina, Muhammad Dwi Hariyanto, Naufal Zakariya
abstract: Light-emitting diodes (LEDs) require reliable lifetime prediction to reduce maintenance and improve system availability. This paper presents a compact and interpretable regression framework for predicting luminous-flux degradation using Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost). The study utilizes 249 hours of hourly measurements collected in a controlled environment, encompassing temperature, humidity, voltage, and current, with the addition of two temporal features representing hours elapsed and hour-of-day. All features undergo standardization, and a five-fold cross-validated XGBoost regressor is trained with 100 trees, maximum depth of 6, sub-sampling, and column sampling. The model achieves $R^{2}=0.8899$ on the full dataset with RMSE $=0.7185$ lux and MAE $=0.3744$ lux. Cross-validation yields mean $R^{2}=0.9065( \pm 0.0768)$, demonstrating strong generalization and low residual bias. Featureimportance analysis reveals that environmental drivers dominate predictive power, with temperature contributing $50.5 \%$ and humidity 32.73%, significantly exceeding electrical parameters. A 15,000-hour simulation projects approximately 6% luminous-flux reduction from 266.25 to 250.31 lux without reaching L70 under stable conditions. However, long-horizon extrapolation should be interpreted cautiously given the early-life training data and absence of accelerated-aging signals. The results support shortto mid-horizon forecasting and predictive maintenance with a minimal sensor set while emphasizing thermal and humidity management for enhanced reliability.

title: Using the Gray Level Co-Occurrence Matrix to Search for Anomalies in Images
authors: Ekaterina Zubova, Maksim Shamshin, Alexei Zakharov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The development of an algorithm for detecting surface defects in metal products using the Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) is considered in this paper. An open set of images from the NEU Surface Defect Database was used to evaluate the quality of the work. Modules for image preprocessing, GLCM construction, feature extraction, and results analysis were developed. The data obtained allowed to evaluate the use of the GLCM method for detecting various types of surface defects. The accuracy of detecting surface defects using the developed algorithm was 60–85%.

title: Comparison of Fundamental Sources for Creation of Legal Norms for Civil and State Aviation
authors: Peter Kontriš, Robert Klir
abstract: The fundamental aim of this research is to define and describe the relationship between regulations for civil and military aviation. The article begins by describing the main national and international bodies responsible for managing civil and military aviation. This is followed by a description of the methods used to create legal norms at the international and national level. A separate description is provided for civil aviation and another for state aviation. The final part presents the interrelationship between civil and military aviation legal norms.

title: Radar Human Action Recognition Based on CNN with Swin Transformer Embedded in Attention Enhancement Module
authors: Yuanchuang Geng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of insufficient feature extraction and global context-dependent modeling capability of traditional radar human action recognition methods, a network model combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and embedded Attention Enhancement Module (AEM) is proposed for recognizing human actions in distributed pulsed ultra-wideband radar data. Swin Transformer's network model for recognizing human actions from distributed pulsed ultra-wideband radar data. Local features are extracted from different spectra of multiple radars by a multi-branch CNN residual group convolution module, and then after feature fusion, the AEM is applied, which focuses on the action region through spatial attention, and filters the key features through channel attention, which is complementary to Swin Transformer's global contextual modeling capability, and thus significantly improves the quality of the features in the high-level semantic stage. The experiments use the publicly available dataset from Delft University of Technology for 5-fold crossvalidation, which proves that the method can effectively recognize 9 different types of human actions with a recognition accuracy of 98.06%.

title: BDS for Train Localization Optimization Based on LEO Augmentation
authors: Meng Yang, Zhengxiang Wang, Debiao Lu, Baigen Cai, Jian Wang, Jiang Liu, Wei Jiang, Chendong Zhang, Ling Liu, Juan Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Rail Transportation (ICIRT)
abstract: Since the late 1990s, the first Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite constellation named Iridium was established. Since then, LEO has progressively been employed to augment Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS). The train control system adapts GNSS for continuous train localization to deliver reliable distance between two trains. The more accurate and reliable the train location is, the more safe distance between two trains can be calculated and can be used as input for train control. LEO satellites that provide various information for the GNSS can deliver either more accurate ultra-rapid ephemeris or Doppler observations for end-user location calculation. This paper proposes a train localization method based on BeiDou Navigation Satellite System (BDS) ultra-rapid ephemeris augmentation utilizing LEO satellite observations.In order to carry out the experiments, a simulated LEO platform named DFZ is established,which includes a Trajectory Conversion Tool, a Scenario Editing Tool, and a Simulation Control Terminal. This approach employs the simulated LEO platform to acquire measurements from BDS satellites, enabling the generation of enhanced ultra-rapid ephemeris for the BDS constellation. We carried out experiments using the platform, generating GNSS signal as train moves along the track on the Beijing-Shenyang railway line, using the LEO satellites to generate ultra-rapid ephemeris.The simulated ultra-rapid ephemeris achieves an orbit determination accuracy of 5 cm and a clock offset precision of 3 ns. This augmented ephemeris data is then received and combined with observation files derived from a Beijing-Shenyang railway line. Positioning is implemented using a pseudorange-based least squares method. Comparative experiments demonstrate that, relative to positioning achieved using standard BDS broadcast ephemeris, this LEO-augmented method improves localization accuracy from 1.92 m to 1.44 m.

title: BEVTrack: Multi-View Multi-Human Registration and Tracking in the Bird's Eye View
authors: Zekun Qian, Wei Feng, Feifan Wang, Ruize Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: We handle a new problem of multi-view multi-human tracking in the bird's eye view (BEV). Different from previous works, we require neither the calibration among the multi-view cameras nor the actually captured BEV video. This makes the studied problem closer to real-world applications, however, more challenging. For this purpose, in this work, we propose a novel BEVTrack scheme. Specifically, given multi-view videos, we first use a virtual BEV transform module to obtain the BEV for each view. Then, we propose a unified BEV alignment module to fuse the respectively generated BEVs, in which we specifically design the self-supervised losses by considering both the spatial consistency and the temporal continuity. During the inference, we design the camera-subject collaborative registration and tracking strategy to make use of the mutual dependence between the multi-view cameras and the multiple targets, to achieve the desired BEV tracking. We also build a new benchmark for training and evaluation, the experimental results on which have verified the rationality of the problem and the effectiveness of our method.

title: A Multimodal Remote Sensing Method for Mangrove Species Classification Based on Sentinel-2 Imagery
authors: Haiwei Yuan, Shikuan Wang, Jianzhou Gong
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Intertidal mangrove communities present significant challenges for remote sensing classification due to tidal dynamics, intertwining canopies, and spectral confusion between species. These factors often lead to classification errors and indistinct species boundaries, primarily due to intraspectral variation and interspectral similarity, and also limit the capture of vertical structural features. To address these issues, we propose MSMNet, a specialised multimodal deep learning method for fine-grained mangrove species classification based on Sentinel-2 multispectral imagery. The model uses ResNet50 as its backbone architecture and integrates the Mamba state-space module to model long-range spatial correlations. MSMNet incorporates wavelet transform technology to enhance its ability to represent textures and uses three pathways to extract three key mangrove remote sensing modalities: morphological texture, spectral features, and vegetation physiological characteristics. The design of the multimodal dynamic fusion and enhanced multiscale integration modules supports cross-modal adaptive weight allocation and efficient cross-scale feature aggregation, leveraging complementary information across dimensions. It is demonstrated by experimental results that all baseline models are significantly outperformed by MSMNet with 73.80% mIoU, 84.47% F1 score, and 99.37% overall accuracy. Compared to the second-best approach, its metrics improved by 2.25%, 1.59% and 0.06% respectively. MSMNet notably demonstrated exceptional performance in classifying key mangrove species such as Rhizophora stylosa, achieving a 4.06% accuracy improvement and significantly reducing misclassification rates at species level. These findings confirm that multimodal feature fusion and multiscale information integration are crucial for improving the accuracy of mangrove species classification. MSMNet provides an efficient solution for precise intertidal mangrove mapping. Code and the dataset are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/WangShiK/MSMNet</uri>.

title: Breaking the Diffraction Barrier: A Hybrid Framework Combining Physical Modulation and Neural Diffusion for Sub-Diffraction Target Recovery
authors: Xuening Liu, Zengshan Yin, Chongbin Guo, Changhao Wu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Although most aircraft are equipped with active communication systems such as ADS-B and satellite links, these systems may fail in emergencies or when signals are lost. At this point, remote sensing, as a passive observation method that does not require a target response, can provide crucial visual information and effectively gaps left by traditional methods. With the support of existing remote sensing technologies, aircraft targets in remote sensing imagery can now be effectively identified and extracted through using image features. However, when reconstructing sub-diffraction-limited targets (e.g., aircraft registration numbers), key high-frequency information is irreversibly lost during imaging due to the optical system's inherent diffraction limit. This significantly restricts image interpretability. To address this limitation, we propose a new super-resolution reconstruction framework that combines physical optical modeling with deep diffusion models. Firstly, a parallel collimated light simulation system is constructed to model the degradation process due to diffraction and generate training samples that characterize the multi-level blurring effect. Secondly, the collected multi-frame training samples with varying degrees of blurriness are used as the conditional input to the diffusion model to enhance feature representation. Inspired by the principle of wavefront modulation and its compensation, we have designed two dedicated modules: the Selective Channel Attention Unit (SCAU) and the Spatial Gated Feature Enhancement (SGFE), which explicitly compensate for the high-frequency attenuation caused by diffraction. The experimental results demonstrate that this method outperforms existing methods on both public remote sensing datasets and self-collected real-world datasets. It is effective at reconstructing identity information, such as aircraft registration numbers, from aerial remote sensing images, expanding the range of identities detectable by current remote sensing satellites.

title: Simultaneous Temporal-Frequency-Variable Modeling for Power Forecasting
authors: Li Shen, Yangzhu Wang, Xuyi Fan, Huaxin Qiu, Wei Li
abstract: Smart grids, as a critical application of the Internet of Things (IoT), integrate diverse power generation sources while serving a vast number of energy consumers. Therefore, multivariate time series (MTS) forecasting methods are essential for power forecasting. The existing deep MTS forecasting models have already achieved remarkable performance. They deploy different architectures to analyze MTS features from the temporal, frequency and variable dimensions. However, tight combinations of three types of MTS features have rarely been explored, resulting in imperfect predictions, especially for power systems, wherein the variates are correlated mostly because of the close spatial locations of power plants and clients. To address this problem, a novel MTS forecasting model, SimTFV, that is capable of simultaneously modeling temporal-frequency-variable features is proposed in this work. SimTFV mixes temporal and frequency features via an enhanced instance normalization mechanism based on Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Moreover, SimTFV possesses multiple modified attention modules for simultaneously and efficiently extracting MTS features from the temporal and variable dimensions. Extensive experiments on three energy generation benchmarks and one energy consumption benchmark demonstrate the state-of-the-art performance of SimTFV. The code is released on https://github.com/OrigamiSL/SimTFV.

title: AI Agent for Task Assignment in End-Edge-Cloud Networks
authors: Hao Hu, Yin Zhang, Xiaoyan Huang, Ke Zhang, Fan Wu, Zhaolong Ning
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) agents empower end-edge-cloud networks with intelligent interaction and decision-making capabilities, in which Large Language Models (LLMs) provide strong global information processing and lightweight models offer rapid responses. The integration of diverse AI agents into networks enables the exploitation of global insights for strategic decisions. However, the heterogeneous devices in end-edge-cloud networks pose significant challenges for efficient task assignment. In addition, the redundancy of global information and the limitations of local information further complicate collaborative decision-making. To this end, we propose an end-edge-cloud network with AI agents, in which LLMs and lightweight models are deployed at different layers to enable collaborative decision-making. The collaboration of diverse AI agents across multiple layers enables rapid local responses while ensuring effective extraction of global features, thereby enhancing task assignment efficiency in end-edge-cloud networks. Simulation results indicate that the collaboration between LLMs and lightweight models facilitates efficient task assignment in end-edge-cloud networks, significantly increasing the total number of completed tasks.

title: Localized Intra- and Inter-Tumoral Heterogeneity for Predicting Treatment Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy in Breast Cancer
authors: Yinhao Liang, Wenjie Tang, Qingcong Kong, Ting Wang, Jianjun Zhang, Wing W. Y. Ng, Siyi Chen, Ying Li, Yuan Guo
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: This study proposes a novel method for extracting breast cancer tumor heterogeneity descriptors to non-invasively predict whether pathological complete response (pCR) can be achieved after neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC). These localized descriptors extract corresponding heterogeneity features for different radiomic features and are able to capture tumor characteristics at various localization levels. These descriptors also capture tumor heterogeneity both at the individual tumor level and across the whole dataset, providing decision-making models with features that are both more effective and interpretable. We validated the effectiveness of the proposed features with the Kolmogorov-Arnold network (KAN) across multiple centers, yielding an AUC of 0.92 when combined with pathological features and demonstrating good performance in external datasets (AUCs of 0.84 and 0.81). Additionally, we transform the best model into a symbolic formula to intuitively explain the machine learning model's prediction process, showing how factors such as age, HER2, Ki-67 and heterogeneity influence the prediction. The symbolized model is consistent with the experience of clinical experts, which enhances users' confidence in deep models. The experimental results show that our proposed features and method outperform classical heterogeneity features and end-to-end neural networks with a small additional computational cost.

title: Feature Selection-Based Machine Learning Framework for Birth Weight Prediction: Toward Intelligent Clinical Decision Systems_supp1-3647103.pdf
authors: Onur Kurt
abstract: Birth weight is a vital indicator of pregnancy progress and infant development. Accurate pre-delivery estimation is crucial, influencing both short- and long-term health outcomes. This study advances intelligent healthcare systems by proposing a hybrid stacked ensemble model for enhanced birth weight classification. Using a prospective dataset of 913 medical records—each with 18 features including maternal data and fetal ultrasound measurements—we address the challenge of reliable prediction in complex clinical data. Our computational approach incorporates (1) class imbalance correction via Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE), applied exclusively to training data; (2) mutual-information-based feature selection to identify key predictors; and (3) a hierarchical hybrid architecture uniquely combining support vector machines (SVM), k-nearest neighbors (k-NN), and bagged trees, with a logistic regression meta-classifier. Using 5-fold cross-validation, the hybrid model achieved a weighted-average accuracy of 99.29%, sensitivity of 99.27%, and F1 score of 99.24%, outperforming various standalone models—especially in predicting low birth weight (LBW) and high birth weight (HBW) classes. Results confirm the hybrid model’s value in developing robust, intelligent clinical decision support systems for birth weight classification.

title: Combined Effects of Transient Ionizing and Electromagnetic Pulse on Vertical NPN Bipolar Transistor
authors: Meiqing Zhong, Cui Meng, Yinong Liu, Lanfeng Yuan, Chicheng Liu, Bolun Feng, Maoxing Zhang
abstract: Combined effects of transient ionizing and electro-magnetic pulse on vertical NPN bipolar transistor were experimentally investigated under pulsed X-ray irradiation. Technology computer-aided design (TCAD) simulation method was also employed to explore the underlying physical mechanisms. The results demonstrate that the combined effect of a positive pulse injected into the collector (CEMP) and pulsed X-ray irradiation exceeds the linear superposition of their individual effects. Conversely, the combined effect of a positive pulse injected into the base (BEMP) and pulsed X-ray irradiation aligns closely with the results observed under BEMP acting alone. Mechanism analysis reveals that when CEMP and pulsed X-ray irradiation act simultaneously, there is a significant increase in both the drift photocurrent at the collector junction and the diffusion photocurrent near the collector junction. However, when BEMP and pulsed X-ray irradiation act simultaneously, these photocurrent components remain small, leading to a combined effect similar to the results observed when BEMP acts alone. These findings provide critical insights for the radiation-hardening design of bipolar circuits in harsh radiation environments.

title: The Wideband Operation of Miniaturized Four-Port Single-Junction Microstrip Circulator
authors: Rong Liu, Fan-Yi Meng, Zi-Jun Zheng, Shu-Zhong Liu, Hao-Yuan Wang, Chang Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Four-port single-junction circulators are widely employed in in-band full-duplex systems owing to their advantages in size and manufacturing cost. This article presents a broadband synthesis method for miniaturized four-port single-junction microstrip circulators. By applying multiple rotation mode (MRM) analysis to the design of the four-port single-junction configuration, the azimuthal characteristics of the internal modes within the cross resonator are effectively reconstructed. For the central junction with arbitrarily complex conductor geometries, a simple and effective method for extracting input impedance is proposed, and the reactance compensation principle of the central junction is analyzed in combination with the equivalent circuit. A folded transmission circuit is constructed via a compact impedance-matching network to achieve the miniaturization of broadband circulators. The proposed miniaturized four-port single-junction circulator prototype is fabricated and measured, with the measurement results demonstrating an excellent agreement with the expected performance. Measurement results indicate that the proposed circulator achieves a relative bandwidth of over 70% for 1-dB insertion loss, with return loss better than 17 dB. The isolation of S<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">31</sub> and S<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">41</sub> is better than 16 and 17.8 dB, respectively. The cross-sectional circuit dimensions of the miniaturized circulator are only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$11\times 11$</tex-math> </inline-formula> mm (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.39\lambda _{0} \times 0.39\lambda _{0}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>).

title: Performance Enhancement Using a Dynamic Scoring-Based Task Scheduling Algorithm for Heterogeneous Multicore Systems
authors: Aradhana Mishra, Subrat Kar
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Computer Society
abstract: Heterogeneous multicore systems, such as ARM's big.LITTLE architecture requires efficient task scheduling to balance deadline misses, energy consumption, and throughput. Traditional methods often assign tasks based on static classifications of computational or memory intensity, which do not fully utilize the dynamic nature of these systems. This paper proposes a scheduling algorithm called the Dynamic Scoring-Based Task Scheduling (DSTS) algorithm, which dynamically assigns tasks to cores by considering real-time processor states and task requirements. The algorithm uses task and processor scores, which account for computational needs, memory demands, and urgency, to ensure efficient task processor mapping and core utilization. The proposed approach significantly reduces energy consumption and improves system performance. The results show that DSTS reduces average energy consumption by 30.95 percent compared to four other leading schedulers, cuts missed deadlines by 26.92 percent, and increases throughput by 3.11 percent. These results demonstrate that DSTS effectively reduces energy use and improves deadline adherence, making it suitable for energy-critical applications such as mobile devices, cloud services, and embedded systems.

title: Distributed Prescribed-Time Unknown Input Observer for LTI Systems With Event-Triggered Communication
authors: Yuangui Bao, Dan Zhao, Yuezu Lv, Guanghui Wen
abstract: This article studies the event-triggered prescribed-time distributed observer network design problem of linear time-invariant systems subject to unknown input (UI), where each observer node has access only to partial output information of the target system. The issue of the prescribed-time distributed event-triggered state estimation has not been adequately addressed. To this end, a novel prescribed-time distributed unknown input observer (PTDUIO), featuring the periodic delayed terms and prescribed-time coupling gain, is proposed under the scenario of continuous-time communication. It is analytically proved that the constructed PTDUIO enables each observer node to reconstruct the target system's states in the prescribed settling time regardless of initial conditions, with completely eliminating the influence of UI. To reduce the communication frequency among neighboring nodes, an improved event-triggered mechanism with the triggering condition related to the prescribed-time function is designed. Such a design facilitates the simultaneous realization of prescribed-time convergence and event-triggered communication. In addition, the sufficient criterion is derived to achieve the practical prescribed-time distributed state estimation in the event-triggered communication fashion, and the Zeno behavior is excluded. Finally, numerical examples are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the designed PTDUIO.

title: Multi-Feature Fusion Radar Detection for Maritime Small Targets via Disentangled Representation Learning
authors: Zezhou Wu, Chen Pang, Guoqing Wu, Yongzhen Li, Shunping Xiao
abstract: This study addresses the problem of radar maritime target detection in scenarios characterized by low signal-to-clutter ratios (SCR) and out-of-distribution (OoD). The complex scattering characteristics of sea clutter are difficult to model precisely. Detection methods often exhibit mismatches between their modeled clutter scattering characteristics and the actual sea clutter, resulting in poor detection performance in diverse maritime environments. This study proposes a multi-feature fusion detection method, namely the multi-feature fusion detector (MFFD), that employs disentangled representation learning. The MFFD is designed to adapt to varying environments and comprehensively utilize information from radar data. Specifically, the MFFD first extracts polarization-Doppler and polarization time frequency features from raw radar echoes. These features are then encoded into disentangled representational vectors, which include target vectors, sea state classification vectors, and redundant vectors. Finally, the MFFD fuses target vectors using an attention mechanism. During training, the MFFD employs a multi-task loss function to ensure the accurate disentanglement of representational vectors. Furthermore, a method for filtering target label noise has been introduced to improve the quality of datasets, especially in instances where target occlusion occurs. The experimental results demonstrate that the MFFD achieves superior detection performance compared to several existing detection methods, thereby offering a promising solution for maritime target detection in challenging conditions.

title: A Transmitarray Generating Broadband Elevated-Order OAM Vortex Beams For High-Capacity Wireless Communication Systems
authors: Muhammad Ikram, Jinyao Zhang, Mazhar Islam, Junjie Zheng, Xuanming Zhang, Hassan Azeem, Chaoyun Song
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: The broadband elevated-order OAM vortex beams can greatly enhance wireless communication capacity, but challenges in bandwidth, gain, and mode purity limit their practical use. This letter proposes a symmetric transmit unit cell featuring three conductive layers interleaved with substrate layers, achieving full 360° phase coverage with -3 dB transmission loss and providing a uniform configuration suitable for dual-polarized applications. The fabricated transmissive prototypes were experimentally tested for elevated-order modes, and the results confirmed broadband vortex beam generation consistent with simulations. The overall mode purity is greater than 79% for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$l = +2$</tex-math></inline-formula> and 73% for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$l = +3$</tex-math></inline-formula> within the 26.5-37.5 GHz range, corresponding to 36.6% of the OAM bandwidth. Furthermore, maximum gains of 21.5 dBi and 20.3 dBi are achieved for modes 2 and 3, with corresponding aperture efficiencies of 11.2% and 8.5%, respectively. The proposed transmit arrays could enable next-generation wireless systems with higher capacity.

title: To Optimize Edge-Intelligent Cooperative Perception in Heterogeneous Vehicular Networks_supp1-3647708.pdf
authors: Kai Liu
abstract: Cooperative Perception (CP) has been a promising paradigm to enhance single-vehicle awareness by enabling perception sharing among connected vehicles. However, existing studies often overlook the impact of constrained and heterogeneous edge resources, leading to synchronization bottlenecks and limited deployment efficiency. To address these challenges, this paper proposes EI-Cooper, an Edge Intelligence (EI)-enhanced cooperative framework for adaptive and efficient CP in heterogeneous vehicular networks. The novelty of EI-Cooper is fourfold. First, we leverage key EI techniques including selective cooperation, model pruning and bandwidth allocation to jointly coordinate the perception, computation, communication within the CP pipeline. To the best of our knowledge, EI-Cooper represents the first attempt to extend CP with EI capabilities. Secondly, we formulate a <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</u>ynchronization-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">E</u>fficient <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">C</u>ooperative <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">P</u>erception (SECP) problem, which jointly determines edge selection, pruning ratios and bandwidths to balance end-to-end synchronization efficiency and perception accuracy. Thirdly, to tackle the closed-box nature and computational NP-hardness of SECP, we decompose it into two interpretable subproblems, respectively capturing macro-level spatial completeness and micro-level semantic retention. Finally, we develop a <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</u>wo-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</u>tage <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">H</u>ierarchical <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">O</u>ptimization (TSHO) algorithm, where the first stage maximizes coverage via submodular node selection with a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$(1-1/e)$</tex-math></inline-formula> approximation, and the second stage performs alternating optimization of pruning and bandwidth allocation under convergence guarantees. Extensive experiments on public datasets and a real-world prototype demonstrate the superiority of EI-Cooper.

title: Induction Motor Load Torque Observer Based on Kalman Filter
authors: O. A. Lysenko
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: Measuring load torque is required when testing asynchronous machines of varying power ratings to determine compliance with specified factory parameters. Existing methods for determining load torque involve the use of a torque sensor, which increases the weight, size, and cost of the test rig. A method for determining load torque based on a Kalman filter is proposed. This involves direct measurements of the electric motor stator current and voltage, recover the state vector using a Kalman filter, and calculating the current value of the load torque using angular velocity and electromagnetic torque values, averaging the value of the load torque over a sliding window. Using this method, it was possible to achieve a relative torque error of 1.6% in static conditions with supply voltage distortions and fluctuations, and 0.15% in the absence of supply voltage fluctuations and distortions. The proposed method for determining load torque does not require significant hardware resources and can be implemented on modern microcontrollers..

title: Analysis of the Influence of Geometric Parameters on the Diode Performance of a Vortex Hydrodiode Using Commercial CFD Code AnSys Fluent
authors: E. A. Pavlyuchenko, S. Yu. Kaigorodov, A. S. Pavlyuchenko, I. V. Tsvetkov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The paper presents a new technical solution for modernising a spur gear rotary pump by replacing the traditional valve-based fluid distribution with a hydrodiode distribution. A vortex hydrodiode is proposed as an alternative distribution element. The comprehensive analysis of the effect of geometric parameters on the diode efficiency of the hydrodiode was performed Using the commercial CFD code ANSYS FLUENT. It is established that the diameter of the nozzle tube holes and their number are of primary importance when optimizing the parameters of the hydrodiode. Based on numerical modelling, the optimal design option of a vortex hydrodiode with a maximum diode factor D = 1.618 was identified. The results obtained can be used to design this type of hydrodiodes.

title: Comparative Analysis of Low-Pass Filter Digital Models Frequency Responses for Electrical Systems Components
authors: E.I. Popov, V.A. Kopyrin, D.E. Chamin, M.A. Kochetygov, M.O. Permyakov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: The use of digital twins in electric drive control tasks is driven by ever-increasing requirements for the quality of transient processes. The digital twin of a dynamic system is a discrete model, the use of which always entails some loss of accuracy and the appearance of distortions in the frequency domain. Mathematical models of cable lines are characterized by relatively small time constants, which imposes conditions on the choice of sampling frequency in accordance with the requirements imposed by the Shannon-Nyquist theorem. However, in practice, the choice of sampling period is limited by the processing power of the digital signal processor. As a result, the purpose of the article is to determine the limits of applicability in the frequency domain of existing methods of transition to the Z-region using the analog prototype method by conducting a comparative analysis of the error in approximating the frequency characteristics of the analog prototype with digital models of the RLC low-pass filter for each of the methods. It has been established that an increase in the sampling period leads to a discrepancy between digital models and their analogue prototypes in an integral sense over the entire frequency range. In addition, this leads to the loss of information about such physical processes in a real system, such as resonance or a change in the phase of the signal at the output of a dynamic system. For most engineering problems, the Tustin method can be recommended under appropriate assumptions about the stationarity of the dynamic system. However, if signs of non-stationarity appear or increased requirements for the design of regulators, according to the authors, it is worth paying attention to analytical models of dynamic systems

title: Irradiance Forecast-Supported Energy Management and Controlling
authors: Péter Udvardy, Gábor Kánai, Tamás Jancsó, Bertalan Beszédes
abstract: This paper presents an extensive investigation into the integration of irradiance forecasts into photovoltaic (PV) energy management systems and the predictive maintenance controlling system. By combining numerical weather prediction (NWP) models, artificial intelligence (AI)-based learning techniques, and site-specific PV performance datasets, we propose a comprehensive methodology for enhancing grid stability through improved scheduling of distributed energy storage and electric vehicle (EV) charging which is supported by the regular predictive maintenance regime. The work spans theoretical background, algorithm design, case studies, integration scenarios and controlling. The results show that forecast-based optimization mitigates grid instabilities caused by solar overproduction, enhances self-consumption, and reduces the reliance on expensive grid reinforcement.

title: Task balancing of Private Pilot Training programs
authors: Jaroslav Juracka, Zuzana Hubnerova, Jaromír Hammer
abstract: This paper outlines the structure, sequence, and requirements of the Private Pilot License (PPL) training program in accordance with the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) standards and compares with the practical experiences of a flying school. The study focuses on the theoretical and mainly practical components of pilot training, the sequence of flight exercises, minimum flight hours, and assessment procedures. Official documentation from EASA, flight training organizations, and professional guidelines is used to provide a standardized, regulatory-compliant overview

title: Don’t Panic: Error Handling Patterns in Go Smart Contracts and Blockchain Software
authors: Luca Olivieri, Luca Negrini
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Issues in error handling may have critical consequences in blockchain software, ranging from silent execution with invalid states to denial of services due to unexpected crashes. This paper discusses the pitfalls of errors handling within blockchain frameworks written in Go such as Hyperledger Fabric, Tendermint Core (including its derivatives, e.g. CometBFT, Ignite), and other frameworks (e.g. Cosmos SDK), as well as the Ethereum implementation. Then, it explores how a static analysis approach can be applied for the automatic detection of such of issues, allowing to fix buggy code before deployment, i.e., when the code becomes difficult to patch being blockchain a trustless, distributed, and decentralized environment. Finally, we evaluate our analysis implementation within GoLiSA on a set of existing smart contracts and blockchain applications, empirically demonstrating the feasibility of the proposed approach.

title: AI-DeFi Systemic Risk: A Complex Adaptive System Framework
authors: Yunxiu Zhou, Orestis Papageorgiou
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is altering the systemic risk topology of decentralized finance (DeFi). While prior studies examine vulnerabilities in each domain, their intersection remains undertheorized. This paper frames the AI-DeFi ecosystem as a complex adaptive system (CAS) to identify three mechanisms by which AI reshapes systemic risk: algorithmic homogeneity, which synchronizes agent responses; dynamic network rewiring, which amplifies structural fragility; and emergent multi-agent behavior, which produces contagion without centralized intent. Together, these forces introduce endogenous, path-dependent failure modes opaque to reductionist analysis. This framework provides a foundation for empirical analysis and anticipatory governance in AI-mediated financial systems.

title: Output Quality Quantification for the Cascaded H-Bridge Converter based STATCOM
authors: Yu-Chen Su, Zhi-Wei Hu, Xin-Rui Du
abstract: The cascaded H-bridge (CHB) converter has been widely studied for STATCOM applications thanks to its modularity and satisfactory output quality. However, the output quality quantification for the CHB converter based STATCOM has not yet been undertaken. As the operating point changes, for example, from inductive to capacitive operation, the output performance of the CHB converter based STATCOM needs further investigation. In addition, the cascaded cell number may also influence the output performance. Therefore, this paper attempts to quantify the output quality of the CHB converter based STATCOM using the well-known flux-linkage ripples analysis. The analytical results show that the output quality varies with different modulation indices, and the comparative results show that a higher number of cascaded cells yields better output quality. The circuit simulation is also conducted to demonstrate the output performance agrees well with the analytical findings.

title: Design and Implementation of Electric Motor Emulator for Six-Phase PMSM
authors: Ying-Ren Lai, Peng-Xin Shen, Yaow-Ming Chen
abstract: This paper presents the systematic design and implementation of an Electric Motor Emulator (EME) for a sixphase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (PMSM). Unlike conventional motor test platforms that require physical motors, the proposed EME reduces cost, improves repeatability, and mitigates development risk. A six-phase PMSM model is established using the dual-DQ transformation, while the hardware architecture employs six half-bridge inverter modules with L-type coupling circuits. A digital signal processor (DSP)based controller with current-mode control is implemented to ensure real-time stability. For numerical computation, a trapezoidal-leapfrog integration method is adopted to simulate motor current dynamics efficiently. Both simulation and experimental results validate that the developed six-phase EME can accurately reproduce current and speed responses of the motor model under step response and four-quadrant operation. These findings confirm the feasibility and practical applicability of the proposed EME system for six-phase motor drive testing and development.

title: Evaluation of Gate Driver Losses in Boost Converters with Wide-Bandgap Semiconductors
authors: Wei-Tse Hua, Kun-Che Ho, Jia-Zheng Liao
abstract: This study evaluates the performance of gate drive technologies and power semiconductor devices in boost converters, with a primary focus on the impact of driver losses on converter efficiency. By measuring and analyzing key parameters such as drive power consumption, gate driver loss, and driver circuit efficiency, the study reveals significant differences in energy consumption and dynamic response among different driver architectures. The results indicate that electrically isolated drivers provide reliable gate signals while achieving lower drive power consumption and higher efficiency. Meanwhile, high-drive-capability architectures demonstrate advantages in reducing gate drive losses. Furthermore, compared to conventional silicon-based power devices, widebandgap semiconductors (SiC MOSFETs), combined with highefficiency gate drive strategies, not only enhance overall drive efficiency but also significantly reduce the total energy consumption of the driver circuit, highlighting their potential advantages in high-frequency and high-power-density applications. The findings of this study serve as a reference for optimizing power converter design and further advancing highefficiency power electronic systems.

title: A Fine-Grained Usage Prediction to Understand the Unique Needs of Carsharing in Rural Areas
authors: Sören Aguirre Reid, Pia Georgiew, Dennis Handt, Frank Kammer, Markus Siepermann
abstract: As a sustainable mobility solution, carsharing contributes to reducing energy consumption and CO2 emissions by complementing existing public transport services and addressing spatial and temporal service gaps through a selective and flexible mode of transport. However, only 8.5 % of German municipalities in rural areas and small towns currently have access to carsharing. Research on the unique requirements of rural areas is scarce. The goal of this paper is to understand the specific needs of rural areas and provide a granular planning map showing expected carsharing demand. Drawing on existing booking data, we develop a demand prediction model based on highly detailed sociodemographic, geographic, and public transportation data. To gain deeper insights into the underlying factors, the prediction model is analyzed using explainable AI methods. Our model achieved an average prediction deviation of 14 %. Feature analysis revealed that incorporating detailed public transport data, as opposed to relying solely on location data of public transport stations, substantially enhanced the model's explanatory power.

title: Optimal Placement of Remote Control Switch for Improving Reliability Indices
authors: Kandung Dwi Ridho Pangestu, M. Isnaeni Bs, Husni Rois Ali
abstract: As the demand for reliable power supply in Jakarta continues to increase, particularly in relation to the recovery speed of the Medium Voltage Network, the implementation of Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems has become increasingly critical due to their significant impact on operational resilience. However, financial and resource constraints make it impractical to install SCADA facilities in all distribution substations. This paper aims to determine the optimal locations for Remote Control Switches (RCS) within a single feeder by considering multiple decision criteria, including distribution substation load, number of customers affected by outages, number of priority customers, and travel time to the distribution substation. The Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) approach is used to prioritize the candidates for distribution substations with RCS based on the criteria mentioned above. The results of this study are expected to provide strategic recommendations on the number and optimal locations for RCS deployment, ensuring investment and operational efficiency. This study offers practical insights for PT. PLN (Persero) in selecting critical SCADA installation points to achieve faster network recovery, improve service continuity, and enhance key reliability indices such as System Average Interruption Duration Index (SAIDI) and System Average Interruption Frequency Index (SAIFI), affected by medium voltage network disturbances.

title: Friction dynamics in automotive braking operations and comparison of control techniques effectiveness
authors: Adolfo Senatore, Luca Grimaldi, Valentin Ivanov
abstract: Stricter environmental regulations are driving vehicle development toward improved safety, comfort, and sustainability. Recent studies highlighted the significant contribution of brake and tire wear to overall vehicle emissions. To mitigate this, regenerative braking has been adopted in pure electric and hybrid electric vehicles, reducing fuel consumption, emissions, and brake wear. However, traditional brakes remain necessary for low-speed and emergency braking, introducing new challenges. This paper presents a comprehensive vehicle model featuring an advanced braking system, including: an electro-hydraulic actuator with fluid compressibility and thermal and rheological effects; a lumped capacitance model for disc temperature; a friction coefficient model dependent on contact temperature, pressure, and sliding speed. The drag torque effect, caused by the pads not completely separating from the disc at the end of braking phase is also considered. For the tribological analysis, detailed models were implemented. Several wheel slip controls were also compared to identify optimal strategies. Simulations show that using variable friction coefficient (CoF) yields more realistic, albeit harsher, braking conditions, increasing pressure, stress, and wear, yet preserving vehicle stability. Only with variable CoF the brake fading is detectable. First Order Sliding Mode Control (FOSM) and Second Order Sliding Mode Control (Second Order SMC) proved more efficient and robust than the Proportional-Integral controller.

title: Integral Sliding Mode Steering Feel Feedback Controller for Steer-by-Wire Systems Using Co-Simulation Framework
authors: Hoang Quan Vo, Quoc Thanh Truong, Yoon Jongil, Bom Yun, Duc Thien Tran
abstract: To address the lack of road feeling feedback in Steer-by-Wire (SBW) systems, this paper presents the design and simulation of a steering feel feedback controller based on Sliding Mode Control (SMC) to reproduce the road reaction torque at the steering wheel. The reference feedback torque is calculated from the steering rack force, determined through vehicle dynamics simulations, and applied as the controller input. A torque feedback motor then reproduces the road feel at the steering wheel. A co-simulation environment integrating MATLAB/Simulink and CarSim was developed to support the design, simulation, and validation of the steering feel feedback controller using a high-fidelity vehicle model. CarSim provides detailed vehicle dynamics, including road reaction forces and steering system characteristics, while Simulink implements the control algorithm and models the steering wheel dynamics. This co-simulation setup enables a realistic evaluation of the proposed controller in a Simulation-in-the-Loop (SiL) framework under various driving scenarios. The proposed method is validated through different standardized driving tests based on ISO procedures, demonstrating its effectiveness in generating robust and realistic steering feel feedback for SBW systems. The results, derived from co-simulation, indicate that the proposed controller successfully generates a steering feel with stable torque tracking.

title: The Living Library of Trees: Mapping Knowledge Ecology in the Arnold Arboretum
authors: Johan Malmstedt, Giacomo Nanni, Dario Rodighiero
abstract: As biodiversity loss and climate change accelerate, botanical gardens serve as vital infrastructures for research, education, and conservation. This project focuses on the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University, a 281-acre living museum founded in 1872 in Boston. Drawing on more than a century of curatorial data, the research combines historical analysis with computational methods to visualize the biographies of plants and people. The resulting platform reveals patterns of care and scientific observations, along with the collective dimensions embedded in botanical data. Using techniques from artificial intelligence, geospatial mapping, and information design, the project frames the arboretum as a system of shared agency—an active archive of more-than-human affinities that records the layered memory of curatorial labor, the situated nature of knowledge production, and the potential of design to bridge archival record and future care.

title: A Single-Snapshot DOA Estimation Algorithm Based on Outlier Detection in Impulsive Noise*
authors: Bo Shang, Ruonan Pei, Jiyan Hu, Xiaoyu Lan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: In increasingly complex electromagnetic environments, single-snapshot direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation confronts growing technical challenges, particularly with non-Gaussian impulsive noise emerging as a critical factor that severely compromises estimation accuracy. This paper presents a single-snapshot DOA estimation framework that integrates Isolation Forest (IForest)-based anomaly detection with an enhanced sparse reconstruction algorithm to address the challenges posed by impulsive noise and local convergence. First, leveraging the impulsive noise's outlier characteristics, the IForest algorithm is applied to identify anomalies within single-snapshot observations, enabling effective mitigation of impulsive interference. Subsequently, to avoid the susceptibility of traditional non-convex optimization algorithms to local minima, an improved Focal Underdetermined System Solver (FOCUSS) is proposed by reformulating the objective function and refining the optimization strategy, thereby enhancing sparse signal recovery performance. Finally, the purified measurements obtained from the anomaly detection process are fed into the improved FOCUSS algorithm to achieve high-resolution and robust DOA estimation. Simulation results verify that under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions with impulsive noise contamination, the proposed approach significantly outperforms conventional methods in terms of estimation accuracy, interference suppression, and robustness, while exhibiting enhanced resolution capabilities.

title: Research on the Optimization of Low-Altitude Pollution Monitoring System Based on Multi-Source Data Fusion
authors: Fengming Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Addressing the environmental monitoring needs of inaccessible contaminated areas (such as chemical waste disposal sites and remote rivers and lakes), this paper proposes a multisource fusion solution utilizing visual sensors, ultrasonic range finders, gas sensors, and PM2.5 sensors, combined with a low-altitude drone platform to construct a monitoring system. By improving the weighted Kalman filtering algorithm to fuse multi-source data, the performance of the system is validated through simulations in MATLAB under ideal environments, strong noise conditions, and partial sensor failures. In the low-altitude environmental monitoring and inspection industry, this system can significantly enhance the efficiency and accuracy of environmental data collection in contaminated areas, providing strong support for environmental governance and risk early warning.

title: Graph Coloring-Based Risk-Aware Conflict-Based Search Algorithm for Multi-UAV Conflict-Optimized Path Planning
authors: Qiming Yang, Yanshen Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: With the rapid development of Urban Air Mobility (UAM), efficient multi-UAV path planning is urgently needed to tackle 3D airspace utilization and flight conflict mitigation. This paper proposes a hierarchical path planning framework with three core innovations: 1) A 3D airspace stratification strategy based on flight heading and mission requirements; 2) An improved risk-aware Conflict-Based Search (CBS) algorithm, which designs a safety-and-cost-balanced heuristic function to reduce search space and computational complexity under layer constraints; 3) A graph coloring-based dynamic conflict resolution mechanism for adaptive flight layer adjustment. In summary, the proposed hierarchical CBS algorithm integrating 3D airspace stratification and graph coloring effectively resolves UAV path conflicts in high-density airspace and enhances path planning efficiency and safety.

title: Research on Gyroscope Data Fusion Based on Quaternion and Kalman Filter in Attitude Control of Hexapod Robots*
authors: Fengrui Yang, Xinxuan Wang, Juncheng Yang, Qiyan Zhang, Rui Long, Mingjian Ma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that hexapod robots are prone to attitude instability in complex terrains, which restricts their applications in the fields of rescue and exploration, this paper proposes an integrated scheme that fuses attitude perception and gait control, and verifies it through Webots simulation and physical tests. The scheme adopts quaternions and the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) to fuse data from Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) gyroscopes, accelerometers, and magnetometers, effectively avoiding the gimbal lock issue.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[9]</sup> Meanwhile, it combines Forward Kinematics (FK) and Inverse Kinematics (IK) to achieve stable gait control. Specifically, in the hexapod robot model built in Webots, with the tripod gait as the core, the ikpy library is used to solve the inverse kinematics problem; the coordinate transformation matrix is employed to calculate the joint angle compensation value during the adjustment of the robot's body attitude; and forward kinematics is simultaneously utilized to plan the leg swing trajectory. Results from the simulation and physical tests show that this method can improve the accuracy of attitude estimation and control stability. It not only enables the robot to walk stably in complex virtual terrains but also allows the robot prototype equipped with MG996R and MG90S servos to maintain stable foot-ground contact in real complex terrains constructed with books, dumbbell plates, etc., verifying the effectiveness of the scheme in practical scenarios.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[2]</sup>

title: Research on the Development of Computing Power Network and Its Applications
authors: Deyun Yang, Tao He, Yunna Li, Haolin Li, Lu Peng, Qiuhong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: With the in-depth penetration of the digital economy and the accelerated evolution of intelligent industries, the computing power network (CPN), as a new-type infrastructure integrating computing and network resources, has increasingly prominent strategic value in improving the operational efficiency of the national economy and empowering industrial digital transformation. This paper first constructs a CPN system architecture centered on the "Computing-Network-Brain" framework, then deeply analyzes the challenges and solutions for key technologies such as computing power perception and measurement, and intelligent scheduling algorithms. It also summarizes the development patterns from basic connectivity to intelligent endogeneity growth through the three-stage evolution model of "ubiquitous collaboration-unified integration-integrated endogenous." Subsequently, by drawing upon practical application cases of computing power networks over the past two years, this paper analyzes the role of CPN in enhancing dimensions including cross-domain data interaction efficiency and the overall effectiveness of computing power resource utilization, as well as its contributions to strengthening system resilience and viability. Finally, looking forward to the future, this paper assesses that intelligent decision-making, resilient anti-destruction, and endogenous security are the key development directions of the CPN.
