title: Cyclic Regularization of Input Convex Neural Networks for Robust Voltage Regulation
authors: Jiaqi Wu, Jingyi Yuan, Erik Blasch, Yang Weng
abstract: Traditional centralized voltage regulation in distribution grids is typically formulated using the DistFlow model, which requires complete system knowledge, including topology and line parameters. However, due to limited observability, complete system information is often unavailable or unreliable at the grid edge. Previous works introduce data-driven approaches to overcome this problem, and input convex neural networks (ICNNs) have been applied to preserve convexity, enabling tractable optimization. However, discriminative learning models like ICNNs often overfit historical data, leading to poor generalization to unseen operating conditions. Overfitting may lead to biased control, particularly under shifting operating conditions caused by high penetrations of distributed energy resources (DERs). Challenges to regularizing such data-driven surrogates lie in the absence of a generative mapping from voltage states to control variables like power injections. To address these limitations, we propose a Regularized ICNN (RegICNN) incorporating a cyclic neural architecture for physics-based regularization. In RegICNN, we (1) enable a form of generative regularization to capture bidirectional mappings between voltage and power for unseen operation points; (2) further introduce a quadratic regularization term tailored to power flow physics; and (3) theoretically analyze the injection-voltage mapping under the DistFlow model, showing its convexity conditions and justifying the use of ICNNs as optimum data-driven surrogates for voltage control. Specifically, RegICNN learns a convex neural surrogate that approximates the injection-voltage mapping while preserving feasibility and global optimality for gradient-based control. Experiments on 3-, 12-, 116-, and 123-bus distribution feeders demonstrate that the RegICNN-based surrogate significantly improves modeling accuracy and control robustness when facing changes in operating points, making it a promising approach for data-driven voltage control in modern, dynamic distribution grids.

title: Compensation Strategy-Based Intrusion Tolerant Parameter Estimation for Quantized Nonlinear Hammerstein Systems under Replay Attacks
authors: Qingxiang Zhang, Jin Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: In Cyber-Physical Systems security (CPSs), replay attacks disrupt the temporal alignment between inputs and outputs. The dual nonlinearity of Hammerstein system and quantized measurements further increases the difficulty of parameter estimation. This paper investigates the intrusion tolerant (meaning the capable of maintaining performance despite attack interference) identification problem of quantized Hammerstein systems under replay attacks. On the attack side, an optimal attack strategy is formulated by maximizing estimation error under energy constraints. A closed-form solution is derived using quadratic optimization and projection. For the defense design, a sending mechanism based on stochastic intervals and binary detection sequences is proposed. By leveraging the statistical properties of the detection sequence, the mechanism compensates for estimation errors caused by attacks. The system’s nonlinear and quantized structure is reformulated as a solvable nonlinear system, enabling joint estimation of system parameters and attack probabilities. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that the estimators are consistent and asymptotically normal, and an optimal setting for defense factors is presented. Simulation examples validate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed approach in terms of identification accuracy and attack resistance.

title: Coupled Physics-Informed Neural Network for Multi-Physics Modeling in Additive Friction Stir Deposition_supp1-3646558.pdf
authors: Zhenyu Kong
abstract: Additive Friction Stir Deposition (AFSD) is an emerging metal additive manufacturing process gaining increased attention due to its solid-state processing nature, resulting in desirable mechanical properties and the capability of fabricating large parts. To understand the multi-physics nature of the process, modeling of thermal distribution and material velocity during processing is imperative, which can be addressed by solving the related partial differential equations (PDEs). However, complex coupled PDEs entail inaccuracies and slowness in utilizing the existing numerical methods, such as the Finite Volume Method (FVM). This work proposes a neural network-based method, coupled Physics Informed Neural Network (coPINN), as a fast and accurate mesh-free solution for predicting the thermomechanical states during the AFSD process. In the case studies, the proposed coPINN accurately predicts the velocity and temperature distribution for a steady-state non-linear coupled fluid dynamics-heat transfer model of the AFSD process faster than the existing FVM. Comprehensive comparisons with residual errors show the proposed method’s trustworthiness in handling coupled physics, non-linearity, and mixed boundary conditions. In addition, the solutions of our approach show better conformance with the actual experimental data than the FVM-based solver. Overall, this work shows more efficient neural network-based solutions of a PDEs-based model than a traditional numerical method.

title: Correspondence-Free, Function-Based Sim-to-Real Learning for Deformable Surface Control
authors: Yingjun Tian, Guoxin Fang, Renbo Su, Aoran Lyu, Neelotpal Dutta, Weiming Wang, Simeon Gill, Andrew Weightman, Charlie C.L. Wang
abstract: This paper presents a correspondence-free, function-based sim-to-real learning method for controlling deformable freeform surfaces. Unlike traditional sim-to-real transfer methods that strongly rely on marker points with full correspondences, our approach simultaneously learns a deformation function space and a confidence map – both parameterized by a neural network – to map simulated shapes to their real-world counterparts. As a result, the sim-to-real learning can be conducted by input from either a 3D scanner as point clouds (without correspondences) or a motion capture system as marker points (tolerating missed markers). The resultant sim-to-real transfer can be seamlessly integrated into a neural network-based computational pipeline for inverse kinematics and shape control. We demonstrate the versatility and adaptability of our method on two vision devices and across four pneumatically actuated soft robots: a deformable membrane, a robotic mannequin, and two soft manipulators.

title: Lessons Learned from the euROBIN Manipulation Skill Versatility Challenge at IROS 2024
authors: Xudong Han, Haoran Sun, Ning Guo, Sheng Ge, Jia Pan, Fang Wan, Chaoyang Song
abstract: Robotic automation in high-mix, low-volume settings often relies on structured workcells where fixtures, workpieces, and procedures are well defined, but tasks must be reconfigured quickly across variants. This paper presents the Design and Learning Research Group's solution to the euROBIN Manipulation Skill Versatility Challenge (MSVC) at IROS 2024, in which a standardized electronic task board is operated through a fixed sequence of subtasks. We deliberately adopt a simple, industry-style implementation: each subtask is taught by recording an open-loop Tool Center Point (TCP) and gripper trajectory in the task-board frame, a wrist-mounted depth camera is used once per run to localize the board and a few key features, and a web dashboard exposes the resulting motion primitives as reusable code blocks that can be reordered and reparameterized. With this pipeline, our system completes the benchmark in 28.2 s in the lab (37.2 s on-site), compared to a human baseline of 16.3 s and an average of 83.5 s for previous teams, closing a large part of the performance gap without advanced learning or feedback control. We further demonstrate limited skill transfer by retargeting the same subtask library to a smoke-detector battery replacement scenario required by the competition. Finally, we release our implementation as open source and discuss how competition design and benchmark structure influence the balance between simple engineered solutions and richer sensing and learning.

title: Online Scheduling With Trajectory Prediction for Collaborative DNN Inference in Vehicular Networks_supp1-3629759.pdf
authors: Ruiting Zhou
abstract: In recent years, deep neural networks (DNNs) have been extensively utilized to provide vehicular intelligent services. Given the limited computing capabilities of vehicles, collaborative vehicle-edge DNN inference has emerged as a promising approach. This method partitions the DNN, then distributes parts to the vehicle or the edge, e.g., roadside unit (RSU), for sequential inferences. However, determining the optimal DNN partition is challenging due to the uneven load distribution of DNN models and varying road traffic conditions. Moreover, vehicle movement can cause loss of inference results if vehicles leave the RSU signal coverage. To this end, we propose a novel online learning-based collaborative DNN Inference framework MCI. MCI utilizes multiple RSUs to assist vehicles with sequential inference and ensure reliable data transmission. To reduce learning cost, MCI designs a trajectory prediction to analyze vehicle context before making decisions. Then, MCI combines the classical EXP4 and LinUCB algorithms to learn system dynamics and make effective scheduling decisions. We prove that MCI achieves a sublinear regret bound of $O(T^{3/4} \sqrt {\log T})$ . Extensive experimental results show that MCI reduces latency by up to 68% and has a lower failure rate, compared to state-of-the-art algorithms.

title: Quantifying Firms' Innovation Ecosystem Orientation: Assessing the Impact on Innovation Performance and Triple Bottom Line Collective Benefits_supp2-3647232.docx
authors: Daniel Espinosa Saez
abstract: Innovation ecosystems (IE) have gained prominence as drivers of business and sustainable development. Given their importance for social and economic development, they help address the increasing competition in globalized markets, the scarcity of natural resources, and the overall complexity of the innovation process. Despite their growing relevance, existing literature is characterized by theoretical ambiguity and methodological diversity. To address this, we propose a refined approach to measuring firms' IE orientation and clarifying its impact on innovation and collective benefits. We first conducted a qualitative content analysis to conceptualize the IE orientation. These insights informed a quantitative cluster analysis that was used to derive a classification variable. We then empirically tested this variable using survey data from 287 innovation managers to assess its relationship with innovation performance and collective benefits across economic, social, and environmental dimensions — aligned with the triple bottom line (TBL). Our findings from Southern European firms present a nuanced understanding of how IE orientation not only fosters enhanced innovation capabilities but also generates significant TBL benefits. This study underscores the potential role of IE in driving sustainable development within similar institutional contexts. By bridging the gap between theoretical conceptualization and empirical measurement, the study provides a more systematic and actionable understanding of IE.

title: Structural Ambiguity Resolution in Indonesian-English Speech-to-Text Translation by Utilizing Prosodic Information
authors: Ruhiyah Faradishi Widiaputri, Ayu Purwarianti, Sakriani Sakti
abstract: Most speech-to-text translation (ST) systems overlook structural ambiguity in source speech, often resulting in inaccurate or ambiguous translations. To address this issue, this study introduces the first structural ambiguity-free ST system, which not only translates spoken language into text in another language but also resolves structural ambiguity by leveraging prosodic information of the input speech, resulting in non-ambiguous translations. Our contributions include (1) developing the first structural ambiguity-free ST corpus for Indonesian to English and (2) proposing structural ambiguity-free ST by modifying the cascaded and end-to-end approaches of standard ST so that it can utilize prosodic information in producing structural ambiguity-free output. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that our best-performing system achieves strong translation quality (BLEU 42.57, chrF++ 59.88, COMET 79.09) while effectively disambiguating input speech according to the intended interpretation with an accuracy of 85.17%.

title: Evaluating Range of Motion of Two Prominent Neck Support Devices for Daily Activities_supp2-3647266.pdf
authors: Haohan Zhang
abstract: Neck muscle weakness causes the inability to raise and move the head, leading to fatigue, neck pain, and a “head-on-chest” posture (dropped head syndrome) in severe cases, which significantly affects quality of life. Static neck collars are the current standard of care. However, these collars are passive, which cannot restore the head-neck movement necessary for daily tasks. Emerging robotic devices like powered neck exoskeletons were developed to enable head-neck movements. Previous laboratory tests showed improved patients’ ability to follow prescribed trajectories; however, the ability to assist with daily tasks of such a robotic device remains unknown. In this paper, the functional range of motion allowed by a state-of-the-art powered neck exoskeleton was compared to a clinic-standard static neck collar in healthy adults performing simulated daily tasks wearing these devices. Results showed a greater head range of motion and consequently less compensatory torso movements while wearing the neck exoskeleton in its transparent mode. Participants rated the neck exoskeleton more favorably than the static collar in terms of comfort and ability to perform the tasks. Results also revealed the range of motion limits of the current neck exoskeleton for these daily tasks. These results provided justifications for using neck exoskeletons to restore daily functions and offered critical insights into future refinement of this technology to enable head range of motion for critical daily activities.

title: Graph Neural Network of Multiple Diagonal Constraints for Sound Event Detection
authors: Kibae Lee, Jongkwon Choi, Keunhwa Lee, Chong Hyun Lee
abstract: Acoustic signals originating from distinct sources inherently exhibit diverse spectral and temporal characteristics. In this study, we propose a novel framework, termed the graph neural network of multiple diagonal constraints (GMDC), which is designed to learn class-specific representations of sound events within the graph domain. The proposed method initially encodes an input audio signal as a graph structure, which is subsequently extended into multiple class-specific graphs to enable the detection of overlapping sound events. To construct these class-specific graphs, the model learns a set of multi-graph structures represented by an adjacency tensor, which is derived based on temporal annotations for each sound class. The learning process is guided by two distinct loss functions: the first enforces diagonal constraints to emphasize features in event regions, while the second further refines this by suppressing off-diagonal activations in non-event regions. Furthermore, the GMDC framework integrates graph learning with event detection through both sequential and joint learning strategies, enabling more effective modeling of complex acoustic scenes. Experimental results on two publicly available datasets demonstrate that the proposed GMDC framework improves the F1-score by 8.0% to 12.1% and reduces the error rate (ER) by 0.02 to 0.04 compared to the baseline convolutional recurrent neural network (CRNN). Furthermore, on the synthetic underwater dataset, the GMDC consistently outperforms the CRNN baseline across various signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and signal-to interference ratio (SIR) conditions. Even under severely degraded conditions such as -12 dB SNR and SIR, the GMDC achieves improvements of 12.6% and 10.3% in F1-score and reductions of 0.16 and 0.21 in ER, respectively.

title: AC-BaaS: An Asynchronous Cross-Blockchain as a Service for the Internet of Things
authors: Lingxiao Yang, Xuewen Dong, Zhiguo Wan, Sheng Gao, Wei Tong, Yong Yu, Yulong Shen
abstract: Cross-chain techniques improve blockchain scalability and interoperability, providing decentralized exchange and cross-chain collaboration services for Internet of Things (IoT) data across various domains. However, current state-of-the-art (SOTA) solutions for cross-chain data exchange across multiple domains are constrained by synchronous networks, hindering efficient data exchange in intermittent network environments. Furthermore, there is a lack of research on asynchronous cross-chain transaction pool mechanisms, which are crucial for optimizing system utility. In this paper, we propose AC-BaaS, an <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</u>synchronous <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</u>ross-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">b</u>lockchain <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</u>s <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">a</u> <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</u>ervice framework tailored for the multi-domain IoT. Built upon a specially designed asynchronous sidechain architecture, the system leverages a committee to provide AC-BaaS for data exchange across multiple IoT domains. To fulfill the need for asynchronous and efficient data exchange, we combine the ideas of aggregate signatures and verifiable delay functions to devise a novel cryptographic primitive called delayed aggregate signature (DAS), which constructs asynchronous cross-chain proofs (ACPs) that ensure the security of cross-chain interactions. To ensure the consistency of asynchronous transactions, we propose a multilevel buffered transaction pool that guarantees the transaction sequencing. We further propose a heuristic for optimizing the utility of the buffer pool mechanism to strike a balance between performance and resource consumption. We also examine DAS delay size settings to trade-off security and efficiency. We analyze and prove the security of AC-BaaS, simulate asynchronous communication environments under various security levels, and conduct a comprehensive evaluation. The results show that AC-BaaS outperforms SOTA schemes, improving throughput by an average of 1.71 to 5.09 times, reducing transaction latency by 64.36% to 85.49%, and maintaining comparable resource overhead.

title: Suppressing High-frequency Resonance in MMC HVDC System Using Passivation Schemes based on Virtual Flux and Digital Differentiator
authors: Yiqi Liu, Yucheng Wu, Jiayi Liu, Hengke Zhang, Bo Zhao, Fangning Gu, Mingzhe Sun, Shangfu Teng, Zheng Zhao
abstract: Inherent control delays challenge the stability of the Modular multilevel converter-based high voltage direct current (MMC-HVDC) system, particularly inducing the high-frequency resonances (HFR) incidents in practice. Complex system operating conditions and poor stability margin have introduced new HFR risks, restricting the conventional suppression methods. Therefore, this paper provides two passivation schemes based on the virtual flux and digital differentiator to remove the influence of the time delay terms in control units, eliminating the negative damping risks. The realization methods of the integrator and differentiator in the passivation schemes are designed to facilitate practical implementation, with the fuzzy adaptive control method introduced to correct the control parameter. The passivation schemes have superior performance in HFR suppression amidst the changeable operation conditions and various MMC time delays, improving the stability and passivity. The effectiveness of the proposed schemes is verified through simulations and experiments of the MMC-HVDC system.

title: Low-Power System for Spatial Tactile Detection using a Self-Sensing Nanocomposite with On-Device Adaptive Regularization
authors: Julio Heredia-Lozano, Abraham Balam, Javier Vázquez-Castillo, Johan Jair Estrada-López, Zarel Valdez-Nava, Vincent Bley, Céline Combettes, Francis Avilés, Alejandro Castillo-Atoche
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Carbon nanostructured materials offer unique properties for spatial tactile sensors, but their inherent heterogeneous nature also presents challenges in signal processing to reduce hysteresis, enhance pressure-sensitive performance, and long-term stability. To address these challenges, a robust regularization technique using electrical mapping for implementation and evaluation within an embedded system is proposed. A low-power wireless sensing node is proposed to detect and classify the electrical response of a two-dimensional multiwall carbon nanotube/polypropylene (MWCNT/PP) tactile sensor using robust adaptive regularization and weighted order statistics methods. The location-dependent piezoresistive response of a MWCNT/PP square membrane is obtained from boundary electrical measurements and electrical mapping. The proposed system addresses the ill-posed inverse problem by implementing spatial tactile detection in a low-power microcontroller, thereby enabling the development of new Internet-of-Things (IoT) self-sensing integrated systems. Experimental results show a high accuracy of 93.94% for the spatial tactile detection, achieved with a low power consumption of 0.79 mW. The robust regularization coupled with the weighted order statistical classification and their implementation in a low-power microcontroller offers a promising approach to accurately detect spatial tactile responses.

title: Multi-Dimensional Optimization for STAR-RIS Aided NOMA Communications With Different Operational Protocols
authors: Yaxin Ren, Yang Zhang, Chao Wu, Lihua Pang, Minghao Shang, Pei Xiao
abstract: Simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface (STAR-RIS) has attracted considerable attention due to its ability to overcome the half-space limitation of traditional RIS and achieve full-dimensional wireless coverage. This paper investigates a STAR-RIS-assisted multi-user uplink non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) communication system, formulating a joint optimization problem to maximize the system sum-rate for different operational protocols of STAR-RIS, namely energy splitting (ES), mode switching (MS), and time switching (TS). The optimization variables comprise the active and passive beamforming, the deployment location of the STAR-RIS and the communication time allocation. In addition, we incorporate practical constraints, such as coupled phase-shift, discrete amplitude and phase settings and limited deployment regions. Given the non-convex nature of the problem due to multiple coupled variables and realistic constraints, we propose a low-complexity alternating optimization (AO) algorithm based on fractional programming (FP) theory. Specifically, the FP theory is employed to transform the optimization problem into a more tractable weighted sum form. Then, the optimization problem is decoupled into four subproblems, which are solved using specific methods tailored to each protocol. Finally, all variable blocks are optimized in an alternating manner until convergence. Numerical results indicate that the proposed algorithm achieves significant performance gains with low computational complexity and offers valuable guidance for the selection of the STAR-RIS deployment location and operational protocols.

title: CySIDER: Cybersecurity Situational Intelligence Framework for DER Networks
authors: Damilola Popoola, Souradeep Bhattacharya, Manimaran Govindarasu
abstract: The growing integration of Distributed Energy Resources (DERs) within the smart grid has increased its exposure to significant cyber-physical threats. Intrusion and anomaly detection systems (IADS) are employed to enhance situational awareness, but they often generate large volumes of low-level alerts with limited context, thereby reducing their operational value for security analysts. Additionally, current cyber situational awareness tools lack the depth to support DER cybersecurity, limiting the Security Operation Center’s (SOC) ability to detect, interpret, and respond effectively. This paper presents CySIDER, a real-time Cyber Situational Intelligence framework designed to strengthen cybersecurity visibility in DER networks. CySIDER integrates edge-based machine learning anomaly detection with cloud-level alert correlation and knowledge-graph reasoning to transform raw alerts into coherent high-level incident representations. The framework supports standardized threat mapping through the MITRE ATT&CK model and contextual analytics for rapid, informed response. The framework is validated within an experimental testbed environment using DER-specific datasets, achieving low prediction latency ($\approx 2 \mathrm{~ms}$) and high alert confidence ($\approx 96 \%$), with high alert reduction and correlation rates. This framework is protocol-agnostic and IADS-platform independent, making it a scalable and practical solution to secure next-generation DER networks.

title: A Digital Twin Framework for Human Organs modeling and forecasting in the Metaverse
authors: Sarfraz Ahmed, Joannes Sam Mertens, Laura Galluccio
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: Digital Twins (DTs) have emerged as essential tools for representing physical systems and their interactions within virtual environments. In healthcare, DTs enable new possibilities for real-time visualization, monitoring, and prediction of physiological and biological processes. Integrating the Metaverse with DTs redefines human–computer interaction by seamlessly blending physical and virtual reality. In this paper, we propose an immersive digital twin framework for human organs that integrates real-time bio-signal data. We design a DT framework by creating 3D models of the heart and lungs organs in Unity, targeting Virtual Reality (VR) platforms, such as the Meta Quest. These models animate dynamically in response to live sensor streams (e.g., smartwatch-derived heart rate). Additionally, we enhance the framework with machine learning models that forecast short-term physiological trends and can also detect anomalies in the patterns. The proposed system supports real-time interaction, visualization, and prediction, offering applications in remote healthcare, continuous monitoring, medical training, and patient education. Our approach demonstrates the potential of combining immersive environments with bio-signal-driven machine learning to create intelligent, interactive, and adaptive healthcare systems with application sin surgery and medicine, in general.

title: Disconnecting Users from Virtual Worlds with a Single Packet: an Unreal Untold Story
authors: Hugo Bertin, Ilies Benhabbour, Marc Dacier, Yérom-David Bromberg
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Metaverse Technologies &amp; Applications (iMETA)
abstract: Online worlds, with online games at the forefront, have become ubiquitous in our lives. In 2024, the gaming industry worldwide revenue was estimated at US$455 billion [1]. Yet, this industry is facing a growing number of cheating actors and techniques.We introduce new attacks targeting multiplayer games based on Unreal Engine (UE), such as Fortnite, PUBG, and Valorant. These attacks disconnect players from ongoing game sessions against their will. Cheaters can launch them as a Denial-of-Service against opponents with very few packets (sometimes only one) to steal the victory from the target without exposing themselves as fraudsters.This paper shows how such issues present in a single game engine can spread widely across several games produced by different editors, focusing on Unreal Engine, whose source code is publicly available. UE is also commonly found in digital twins, virtual reality, and other Metaverse solutions. We present our analysis of the design and implementation choices made within Unreal Engine. We cover how to exploit UE networking protocols and discuss how to defeat some common countermeasures used on the Internet against IP spoofing. We propose some mitigation strategies for video game developers.

title: CNN-Mamba Hybrid Network for Efficient Hyperspectral Image Compression
authors: Lei Zhang, Jiaqi Wang, Lixin Zhao, Wenlong Xia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Hyperspectral images (HSIs) contain vast amounts of data. The limitations imposed by available communication bandwidth make achieving lightweight compression and high-quality reconstruction under low compression ratios particularly challenging. Although widely utilized in hyperspectral image processing, Transformer remains constrained in practical remote sensing applications due to its considerable computational burden. In response to this issue, this paper propose a CNN–Mamba hybrid (CMH) architecture-based compressed sensing (CS) network (CMCSN). As the core of feature enhancement, the CMH block effectively combines the local modeling capability of CNN and the global representation power of Mamba, achieving efficient feature representation while maintaining linear computational complexity. Considering the strip-based data acquisition characteristics of push-broom hyperspectral sensors, we propose the SSHF module to extract vertical spatial features at multiple scales and progressively fuse spectral information. To meet the low computational complexity requirements of satellite platforms, a lightweight encoder is designed using strip convolutions, effectively reducing resource consumption on edge devices. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a slight performance improvement over CNN-Transformer mixture architecture-based compressed sensing network (CTCSN) under a 1% sampling rate, while simultaneously reducing the computational complexity and the number of parameters by approximately 25%. The code is available at https://github.com/haideshiwo/CMCSN.

title: Negative Sample Learning based Surface Defect Detection for Lithium Battery Tabs
authors: Yongtao Yu, Chao Liu, Linlin Zhu, Jiaxu Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Lithium battery is the core energyy component of modern electronic devices, the quality of lithium battery tabs directly affects the battery performance and safety; therefore, detecting surface defects on the tabs is a key link in production. However, automated inspection faces the challenges of industrial image complexity and scarcity of abnormal samples. In order to improve the detection efficiency and accuracy as well as to solve the problems of sample imbalance and data scarcity, this paper utilizes the PatchCore algorithm based on negative sample learning for lithium battery tabs surface defect detection. Experiments show that the WideResNet50 model has the best detection effect among various ImageNet pre-trained networks. In order to further optimize the model, the experiments introduce the CBAM attention mechanism and the image reconstruction network structure, which enhances the ability to extract anomalous features. The comparison experiments verify the effectiveness of the optimized method and show that the proposed method can provide an efficient and accurate solution for the detection of defects in lithium battery tabs.

title: Enterprise Architecture Design Using TOGAF ADM on Bank XYZ Employee Training Information System
authors: Antonius Wahyu Sudrajat, Abdul Rahman, Muhammad Abdul Azizul Hakim, Moh Lutfi Al Ghuntur Aji
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Digital transformation in the banking industry demands robust information systems and enhanced human resource competencies to address dynamic challenges. This study aims to design an integrated enterprise architecture using The Open Group Architecture Framework (TOGAF) Architecture Development Method (ADM) as a strategic solution to support the digitalization of employee training systems at Bank XYZ. A qualitative case study approach was employed, involving observations, interviews, and document analysis. The architectural design encompasses phases from Preliminary to Opportunities and Solutions, yielding a blueprint and roadmap for implementing a Learning Management System (LMS) that aligns business processes with technological capabilities. The proposed architecture leverages an application server as the central processing unit, protected by a firewall, connected to a database server, and complemented with a Virtual Private Network (VPN) and monitoring system to ensure security, efficiency, and optimal performance. Evaluation through Focus Group Discussions (FGDs) confirms that the architecture design meets organizational needs and supports the achievement of digital transformation goals. The findings indicate that TOGAF ADM is an effective approach for designing strategic information systems in the banking sector.

title: A CISO Perspective on Board-Level Involvement in Information Security Governance
authors: Sara Nodehi, Tim Huygh, Remko Helms, Laury Bollen
abstract: The rising frequency of cyberattacks, data breaches, and regulatory pressures has increased the importance of board-level involvement in Information Security Governance (ISG). While prior conceptual research has defined six fundamental board roles, how these roles are understood and enacted in practice remains unclear. To address this gap, this study investigates board-level ISG involvement through twelve semi-structured interviews with Chief Information Security Officers (CISOs). Using an inductive thematic analysis followed by deductive interpretive mappings of the six conceptual board roles, the study provides empirical insights into their actual manifestations. Although many aspects of conceptual role definitions align with practice, important nuances emerged, including the reactive and compliance-driven nature of board engagement. In addition to refining theoretical understanding, the paper analyzes board-level responsibilities, challenges, and contextual influences; identifies key barriers to implementation; and proposes future research directions to reduce the gap between boards' theoretical responsibilities and practical activities.

title: Integrated Wheelie-Traction Controller for Maximum Acceleration in High Performance Electric Motorcycle
authors: Ihsan Mert Muhaddisoglu, Andrew McGordon, Quang Truong Dinh
abstract: In motorcycles, traction control is an essential feature for both performance and safety. A traction control strategy usually focuses on keeping the slip of the driving wheels in a stable region. One unique phenomenon for motorcycles is the wheelie, which hasn’t been addressed for electric motorcycles. In this paper, an Integrated Wheelie-Traction Control System (IWTCS) is designed to accelerate the motorcycle as fast as possible. The proposed IWTCS consists of a classical Proportional-Integral control algorithm for traction control and a Wheelie Detector (WD) that uses a Kalman-Filter for wheelie intervention. The developed IWTCS is analyzed in the Quarter Mile scenario and compared against a controller based on synthetic user behavior with zero delays to wheelies and a TCS without Wheelie Control. The results demonstrate that the IWTCS can match the synthetic user behavior performance in quarter mile scenario and reduce both the wheelie duration and keep body pitch angle stable to improve safety and comfort. When compared to the TCS without Wheelie Control, the IWTCS, improves average acceleration by ~3% and significantly reduces both body pitch angle and total wheelie duration.

title: Psychomare: A Psychoanalytic and XR-Based Artistic Exploration into Nightmare Visualization
authors: Jiayang Huang, Joshua Nijiati Alimujiang, Kang Zhang, David Yip
abstract: Psychomare is an artistic research project that explores the visualization of nightmares through a psychoanalytic and XR-based performance methodology. By treating dreams as symbolic data and nightmares as distortions of subjective recognition, the project translates psychological fear into tangible visual forms. Utilizing AI-driven imagery, embodied dance performance, and virtual production technologies, Psychomare creates an immersive dream-scape where the dancer confronts surreal nightmare entities derived from personal and collective dream memories. Drawing on Lacanian theory, the work proposes that nightmares emerge from a mis-recognition of the self—a mirrored distortion of unconscious desires and fears projected onto dream imagery. This symbolic mis-recognition becomes the conceptual core of the project, guiding its aesthetic and choreographic strategies. Feedback from the dancer, audience, and a psychoanalyst reveals strong emotional resonance and aesthetic depth, suggesting that the visualization of nightmares can foster self-reflection, emotional confrontation, and collective empathy. This project offers a new model for integrating immersive art, psychoanalytic theory, and technological mediation as a path of collective care.

title: A pedestrian target detection method based on the improved YOLOv12n lightweight model
authors: Xinjun Zhang, Yu Chen, Da An
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: In order to solve the problem of dense pedestrian targets and large number of object detector parameters in pedestrian detection, a pedestrian detection method RJK-YOLO based on star convolutional network StarNet and lightweight detection head was proposed. Firstly, StarNet was introduced as the backbone of RJK-YOLO to extract image features. Secondly, StarNet's StarBlock is used to enhance C3k2. Finally, a new lightweight detection head based on group normalization and shared convolution is proposed to further improve the detection efficiency and accuracy of the model. By introducing the shared convolution mechanism, the detection head effectively reduces the number of parameters of the detection head, and enhances the global information fusion ability between the feature maps, ensuring that the detection accuracy can be maintained even in complex and changeable dense pedestrian scenes. In this method, the ablation experiment was carried out on the dataset Widerperson, and the model size was reduced by 31%, the number of model parameters was reduced by 32%, and the number of FLOPs was reduced by 26%, which effectively reduced the computational cost of pedestrian detection in a dense pedestrian environment.

title: Emotion Recognition Based on Multi-Modal Physiological Signals
authors: Ziyang Gong, Chang Choi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Emotion recognition has significant applications in mental health monitoring, intelligent human-computer interaction, and medical diagnostics. However, single-modality physiological signal methods often encounter limitations such as low accuracy and instability. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a multi-modal emotion recognition framework integrating Electroencephalogram (EEG), Electrocardiogram (ECG), and Photoplethysmography (PPG) signals. An innovative cross-modal attention mechanism is adopted to effectively facilitate information interaction and fusion across different modalities. Experiments conducted on the publicly available ECSMP datasets show that our proposed method significantly improves emotion recognition accuracy compared to single-modality approaches, achieving an overall accuracy of 89.2%. This study provides a novel multi-modal fusion strategy for the field of emotion recognition, demonstrating substantial theoretical significance and practical applicability.

title: Multi-objective Beamforming Algorithm for RIS-assisted Backscatter V2I Communication System
authors: Yi Dong, Peng Xu, Zebang Zhu, Wenting Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: In this paper, a multi-objective beamforming scheme which jointly optimize the BS beamforming vector and reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) phase shift matrix is proposed for the distributed RIS-assisted backscatter vehicle to infrastructure (V2I) communication system. Firstly, a multi-objective optimization framework balancing energy efficiency (EE) and spectral efficiency (SE) is established using the linear weighting method. Secondly, the optimization problem is transformed into a strictly convex problem by quadratic transformation and Weighted Minimum Mean Square Error (WMMSE) method. Then, an alternating optimization (AO) approach is employed to decouple the original problem into the problem of the BS beamforming vectors and RIS phase shift matrices, and iteratively solve them to convergence. The simulation results show that the proposed algorithm enhances the incident power at backscatter device (BD) while significantly improving vehicle data collection volumes under energy efficiency considerations.

title: Design and Simulation of a Multilevel Boost Converter
authors: Chun-Yu Liao, Kai-Jun Pai
abstract: This study proposes a high-gain boost converter design based on the Cockcroft-Walton voltage multiplier (CW multiplier). By increasing the number of multiplier stages, the proposed topology achieves high voltage gain without modifying the main switching circuit structure or control strategy. The use of a single-switch topology effectively reduces voltage stress on the power switch while delivering high voltage conversion. Additionally, the design integrates a traditional boost converter with a single-stage voltage multiplier and operates under discontinuous conduction mode (DCM), which simplifies the control strategy and reduces conduction losses, thereby improving overall efficiency and system stability. The paper elaborates on the operating principles of the voltage multiplier circuit based on the boost converter. It adopts the NCV8873 controller to implement pulse width modulation (PWM) and voltage regulation, ensuring stable output voltage. To validate the feasibility of the proposed converter architecture, simulation analysis is carried out using Power Simulation (PSIM) software, confirming the accuracy of the developed model and the effectiveness of the PWM control scheme.

title: Seamless Mode Transition Method Considering Voltage-Second Balance of Magnetic Component Between Transition to Reduce the Voltage Stress for Wide Output Voltage Range of Full Bridge Resonant Converter
authors: Chien-Yu Chen, Yen-Shin Lai
abstract: A full-bridge LLC resonant converter with a multi-mode control strategy is developed to support wide output voltage applications, such as electric vehicle (EV) charging. The control scheme integrates half-bridge pulse-frequency modulation (HBPFM), full-bridge pulse-frequency modulation (FBPFM), and full-bridge phase-shift modulation (FBPSM) across a 350 V to 835 V output range. State-plane trajectory analysis is employed to determine optimal transition points, ensuring volt-second balance and suppressing resonant current overshoot during mode changes. By minimizing frequency variation, the method enhances system stability and dynamic performance. Experimental results using an 800 V input prototype confirm reduced voltage stress on power switches, improved mode transition behavior compared to conventional techniques.

title: Delay Effect of Switch-Level Current Limitation in Islanded-Mode dVOC Inverter
authors: Hung-Chih Lin, Pei-Yui Yu, Yaow-Ming Chen
abstract: Grid-Forming (GFM) inverter has become an important research topic in recent years, and dispatchable virtual oscillator control (dVOC) is one of the control methods that shows the characteristic of GFM and has many other advantages. However, the overcurrent protection is one of the major challenges to overcome. This article discusses the effects of different kinds of time delays on dVOC inverter with the switch-level current limitation. Computer simulations with MATLAB/Simulink are shown to validate the ability of the current limitation with time delays. A prototype of dVOC inverter with the current limitation is also built and shown a similar result as the simulations present. The values of the current ripple under different conditions are also discussed and compared with experimental results.

title: Hybrid Architecture Based on Siamese U-Net for Few-Shot Image Segmentation of Nanomaterials
authors: Mikhail Savelev, Alexei Zakharov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This work investigates an approach to training neural networks under few-shot learning conditions for segmenting nanomaterial images. A hybrid architecture is proposed that combines a Siamese network and U-Net, which makes it possible to increase the accuracy of segmentation even in conditions of heterogeneous image structure. The architecture uses metric learning to compare pairs of images (support and query), providing sustainable learning and generalization with only 5–50 labeled examples. The results of experiments that demonstrate high values of Intersection over Union (IoU), Dice coefficient, precision, and recall are presented. A comparative analysis of modern low-resource learning methods, including MAML, Transfer Learning, GANs and VAEs, with a description of their key features and limitations, is also performed.

title: Design of a Material Transport Cart for a Factory in the Aviation Industry
authors: Samuel Dubovský, Samer Al-Rabeei, Michal Hovanec, Volodymyr Tymofiiv, Hana Pačaiová, Martin Venceľ
abstract: This paper focuses on designing a transport cart to improve material handling within a manufacturing company in the aviation industry. The objective is to enhance the efficiency and safety of transporting specific components by optimizing handling operations, increasing transport capacity, and improving workplace ergonomics. In addition, the paper investigates the economic effects and the positive impact of reduced noise pollution associated with higher transport capacity in aviation factory applications. The theoretical section includes an analysis of the current transportation system within a selected production facility. It evaluates the strengths and weaknesses of existing solutions and identifies areas for improvement. Based on this assessment, a new cart design tailored to operational requirements will be developed using Autodesk Inventor, along with complete technical documentation and visualizations. In the practical section, the proposed design is tested using Tecnomatix Plant Simulate software to evaluate its impact on material flow, logistics capacity, and handling efficiency. The thesis concludes with an assessment of simulation results, focusing on economic benefits, ergonomic improvements, reduced noise pollution, and recommendations for implementing the solution in real-world production.

title: Environmental and Economic Assessment of Aircraft Noise and Emissions in Flight Trajectory Optimization
authors: Sebastián Cikovský, Patrik Šváb, Peter Dzurovcin, Peter Korba, Naqibullah Daneshjo
abstract: This research investigates the comparison of actual flight trajectories obtained from ADS-B data with simulated and optimized routes (GNSS and RNAV) on the scheduled service between Vienna and London. The objective was to quantify differences in fuel consumption, emissions (CO2, $\mathrm{NO}_{\mathrm{x}}, \mathrm{CO}, \mathrm{SO}_{2}$), and aircraft noise, and to evaluate their impact on the efficiency and environmental footprint of air transport operations. The analysis showed that optimized trajectories can achieve fuel savings of $\mathbf{7}-\mathbf{9 \%}$ compared to real flights, leading to both lower emissions and reduced noise exposure along selected segments of the route. The findings provide valuable input for the economic assessment of aviation’s negative externalities and highlight the role of trajectory optimization as a tool for mitigating emissions, noise, and operational costs.

title: In-orbit experience from VZLUSAT-2 mission: From freely rotating to nadir pointing CubeSat
authors: Dávid Hriadel, Petr Svoboda Jerie, Filip Rak, Vladimír Dániel, Robert Lászlo
abstract: VZLUSAT-2 is a nanosatellite dedicated to X-ray measurement with secondary goals of high-resolution Earth observation and advanced attitude control. Building on the heritage of VZLUSAT-1, the 3U CubeSat integrates a fully three-axis Attitude and Orbit Control System (AOCS) with custom reaction wheels, magnetorquers, and fine Sun sensors. Due to supplier delays, key hardware and all control software were developed in-house, enabling flexible on-orbit commissioning through a $\mu$ Python framework. This paper presents the design, verification, and in-orbit commissioning of the AOCS, including equipment calibration and system parameter estimation performed in flight. Nadir pointing demonstrations confirmed sub-degree attitude accuracy, while operational limitations caused by higher-than-expected inertia and residual magnetic dipole are discussed. The results provide practical guidance for small-satellite missions requiring precise yet cost-efficient attitude control.

title: Dynamic Modeling and Robust Cascade Control of Feed Drives
authors: Ngo Hong Nam, Vo Lam Chuong, Tran Thuy Uyen Phuong, Ha Le Nhu Ngoc Thanh, Truong Nguyen Luan Vu
abstract: This paper proposes a lumped parameter modeling approach for the dynamic analysis and control design of feed drive systems utilizing ball-screw nut mechanisms. The proposed model integrates key physical parameters such as equivalent inertia, structural stiffness, and friction to accurately represent the mechanical behavior of the drive system. Based on this model, a cascade control structure is developed, consisting of an inner velocity loop and an outer position loop. The velocity loop is regulated by a PI controller designed using the Internal Model Control (IMC) methodology, which enables a systematic selection of control gains to ensure fast, stable, and robust tracking. Meanwhile, the outer position loop is governed by a Sliding Mode Controller (SMC), which is well-known for its robustness against parameter variations and external disturbances. Simulation results from MATLAB/Simulink demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme in achieving high-precision position tracking, improved disturbance rejection, and enhanced control stability under varying load conditions. This integrated modeling and control strategy provides a practical and scalable solution for precision motion control applications, such as CNC machine tools and industrial automation systems.

title: In-Network Recovery of Delayed and Missing PMU Measurements using Programmable Switches
authors: Eva Casto, Xiaoyu Guo, Yanfeng Qu, Dong Jin
abstract: Phasor Measurement Units (PMUs) provide time-synchronized, high-resolution measurements essential for real-time monitoring and control of modern power systems. However, PMU networks are vulnerable to data quality issues such as missing and delayed measurements, often caused by cyberattacks, synchronization failures, or hardware malfunctions. These disruptions can compromise cyber resilience for critical functions by degrading the accuracy of essential grid applications, including state estimation, fault detection, and stability assessment. To address this challenge, we present a decentralized, in-network PMU data recovery framework using P4-programmable switches. Our system detects and recovers missing and delayed data directly within the communication infrastructure, reducing dependency on centralized processing and enabling faster, more resilient responses. We implement the recovery scheme on P4 software switches and evaluate its performance using real-world PMU data from a campus microgrid. Results show that incorporating delayed data into the recovery process significantly improves accuracy, achieving a 20.69% reduction in magnitude mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) and a 28.6% reduction in average phase angle error. In the 5% missing PMU data scenario, the proposed approach maintains a low magnitude MAPE of 0.0279% and an average phase angle error of just 0.0272 degrees, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving data recovery accuracy.

title: Surface Finish of the Burnished Mold Steel after Plasma Nitriding
authors: Fang-Jung Shiou, Wei-Cheng Gao, Sun-Peng Lin
abstract: The objective of this study is to present a novel polishing tool suitable for a CNC machining center to improve the surface roughness of a burnished mold steel. The design of a new polishing tool incorporates features such as low oscillation, low vibration, high replaceability, and safety devices equipped with wireless pressure sensors and protective detectors. For flat test samples, various processes were conducted prior to the polishing process, including fine milling, burnishing, and plasma nitriding hardening. In the burnishing process, referring to the optimal combinations of burnishing parameters from previous studies, the surface roughness of the flat specimens was reduced from Ra 0.22 um to Ra 0.056 um. For the plasma nitriding hardening process, after conducting experiments using the Taguchi method, the optimal parameter combination for the nitriding hardening was determined These parameters increased the hardness after burnishing from 40 HRC to 49 HRC, an improvement of 22.5%. Through matrix polishing experiments, the optimal parameter combination for polishing was determined. This parameter combination reduced the surface roughness of the hardened specimens from Ra 0.15 um to Ra 0.08 um, improving surface roughness values by 47%.

title: Trajectory optimization of 6-DOF upper limb rehabilitation robot using Genetic Algorithms
authors: Quoc Thanh Trinh, Minh Hoang Nguyen, Quoc Thanh Truong, Kyung Sin Kwak, My Ha Le, Kyoung Kwan Ahn, Duc Thien Tran
abstract: This paper presents a trajectory planning implemented on a rehabilitation robot with boundary condition optimization. The proposed method uses a quintic polynomial with boundary constraints on position, velocity, and acceleration to determine the coefficient of freedom to generate a motion trajectory for a 6-degree-of-freedom (6-DOF) robotic system designed for upper limb rehabilitation. Firstly, the movement trajectory is divided into multiple segments connecting predefined waypoints, representing typical motions in upper limb rehabilitation exercises. The quintic polynomial ensures smooth transitions in position, velocity, and acceleration across all trajectory segments. Second, the Genetic Algorithm (GA) is applied to determine the polynomial coefficients to generate a trajectory that follows the desired path within the robot’s workspace. The coefficients obtained through the GA are implemented within the workspace to generate the motion path for the rehabilitation robot. To evaluate the performance of the developed approach, simulations were conducted in MATLAB SIMULINK to perform motion planning for the robot. The results produced an optimal trajectory with the determined polynomial coefficients, playing a crucial role in planning movement trajectories for patient rehabilitation.

title: Hybrid Cryptographic Architecture for Multi-Platform Blockchain Document Signing: Technical Innovation and Cross-Chain Interoperability
authors: V. A. Pasenchuk, T. N. Demchenko
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This paper presents a novel hybrid cryptographic architecture for blockchain-based document signing that addresses fundamental interoperability challenges across heterogeneous blockchain platforms. The proposed system introduces technical innovations including a unified cryptographic protocol combining classical ECDSA signatures with post-quantum Dilithium algorithms, biometric authentication mechanisms, and zero-knowledge proof systems. The architecture enables seamless document signing across Ethereum, Hyperledger Fabric, and Solana networks through standardized smart contract interfaces and novel cross-chain verification protocols. Key technical contributions include mathematical formalization of hybrid signature schemes, implementation of privacy-preserving verification using NIZK proofs, and design of platform-agnostic verification mechanisms that maintain cryptographic security across different consensus architectures while achieving sub-second verification times.

title: Methods for Mathematical Model Construction of Squirrel Cage Induction Motor in Discrete Time
authors: M. A. Kochetygov, V. A. Kopyrin, E. I. Popov, D. E. Chamin, M. O. Permyakov
publish: 2025 Dynamics of Systems, Mechanisms and Machines (Dynamics)
abstract: This article describes some methods of mathematical model construction for a squirrel-cage induction motor in discrete time. The relevance of this research is widespread induction motor using in digital controlled electric drives of oil and gas industry. The discrete time models are used to develop and analyze control algorithms. We compare the accuracy of models based on the bilinear transform (Tustin’s method), the forward difference method, and the backward difference method. The research results help to select the most suitable method of discrete time in IM models according to the required accuracy, computational resourced, and modeling objectives. Discrete time models are derived by using of the forward and backward difference methods; and these models show a larger absolute error throughout the simulation time in comparison to the real time model of the induction motor. The calculated integral relative error transient processes quantitatively express quantitatively, such as no load startup, load application, and load shedding. We find some facts that the state variable plots of the discrete time models are based on the forward and backward difference methods and they are mirrored relative continuous time of IM model’s state in variable plots.

title: The impact of conflict situations on the workload of air traffic controllers during simulator training
authors: Jiri Ulvr, Ondrej Mach, Vladimir Smrz, Petr Michenka, Tomas Pechacek
abstract: This article focuses on the impact of conflict situations, defined as loss of separation, on the deviation between planned and actual workload of air traffic controllers during simulator training. Data were collected from realistic scenarios with 14 novice ATCO trainees, with workload recorded at one-minute intervals. Workload deviation was compared between conflict and non-conflict intervals using the Mann-Whitney U test, with effect size quantified by rankbi-serial correlation. Results show that the mean deviation was nearly twice as high in conflict intervals compared to non-conflict intervals (35.2 vs. 15.2; $\mathbf{p} \lt 0.001; \mathbf{r} \_{\mathbf{r b}}=0.449$), corresponding to a medium effect size. These findings confirm that conflict situations significantly increase ATCO cognitive load. The results have practical implications for adaptive scenario management and early detection of workload overload in training, thereby reducing the risk of errors in critical phases of air traffic control.

title: Exoskeletons in Aircraft Industry: Overview of Available Knowledge and Implementation Experience
authors: Denisa Charvátová, Slavomíra Vargová, Petr Adolf Skřehot, Juraj Sinay
abstract: The aircraft industry includes physically demanding tasks such as overhead assembly, maintenance and ground handling, which expose workers to a high risk of musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs). Exoskeletons have been proposed as an ergonomic solution to reduce biomechanical load; however, most existing studies originate from the automotive sector, with limited evidence available for aviation. This review analyzes peer-reviewed studies and documented pilot deployments from Scopus, Google Scholar and industry sources (2018-2024) to evaluate the effectiveness and limitations of exoskeletons in aerospace environments. Evidence suggests that shoulder exoskeletons can reduce deltoid and trapezius muscle activity by 15–64% during overhead tasks, with partial improvements in perceived exertion. Real-world trials from Airbus, Boeing and Lufthansa Technik confirm potential benefits but reveal challenges related to user acceptance, contamination, maintenance and certification under standards. The review identifies a critical research gap in long-term evaluation and regulatory integration, emphasizing the need for targeted, task-specific implementation strategies.

title: ChainFedTwin: A Blockchain-Based Federated Learning Framework for Secure, Explainable Digital-Twin Collaboration
authors: Nasim Nezhadsistani, Kasra Sohrabati, Seyed Mojtaba Hosseini Bamakan, Burkhard Stiller
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Federated Learning empowered Digital Twins may potentially provide a high-fidelity, privacy-preserving vision of distributed assets. However, verifiable trust, auditability, and interpretability at scale are difficult. This article presents ChainFedTwin, a seven-layered framework that tightly integrates federated learning with blockchain-supported governance and a multi-modal Explainable-AI layer. ChainFedTwin improves current DT frameworks by proposing advanced cryptographic methods, safe bias detection and protection mechanisms, and smart contract-based governance to realize security, privacy, and fairness upgrades. The XAI layer integrates SHAP and LIME for end-to-end interpretability and contains embedded bias detection per aggregation step with fairness validation services. Experimental evaluation on the NSL-KDD dataset proves that ChainFedTwin outperforms the baseline FedAvg algorithm substantially. Specifically, ChainFedtwin achieved a final test accuracy of 94.1% while FedAvg was 91%, an improvement of 3.1 percentage points. Apart from that, it converged to 90% accuracy in 48 iterations, a 47% iteration decrease from FedAvg’s 91 iterations, reflecting enhanced convergence speed and stability at the lower end final loss. While it causes about a 15% communication overhead due to privacy and auditing requirements, this is an acceptable compromise for increased security, trustworthiness, and interpretability in mission-critical DT applications.

title: Simulacra Naturae: Generative Ecosystem driven by Agent-Based Simulations and Brain Organoid Collective Intelligence
authors: Nefeli Manoudaki, Mert Toka, Iason Paterakis, Diarmid Flatley
abstract: Simulacra Naturae is a data-driven media installation that explores collective care through the entanglement of biological computation, material ecologies, and generative systems. The work translates pre-recorded neural activity from brain organoids, lab-grown three-dimensional clusters of neurons, into a multi-sensory environment composed of generative visuals, spatial audio, living plants, and fabricated clay artifacts. These biosignals, streamed through a real-time system, modulate emergent agent behaviors inspired by natural systems such as termite colonies and slime molds. Rather than using biosignals as direct control inputs, Simulacra Naturae treats organoid activity as a co-creative force, allowing neural rhythms to guide the growth, form, and atmosphere of a generative ecosystem. The installation features computationally fabricated clay prints embedded with solenoids, adding physical sound resonances to the generative surround composition. The spatial environment, filled with live tropical plants and a floor-level projection layer featuring real-time generative AI visuals, invites participants into a sensory field shaped by nonhuman cognition. By grounding abstract data in living materials and embodied experience, Simulacra Naturae reimagines visualization as a practice of care, one that decentralizes human agency and opens new spaces for ethics, empathy, and ecological attunement within hybrid computational systems.

title: Analysis of Underwater Target Detection by UAVs Using Airborne Magnetic Sensors
authors: Xinyu Dong, Honglei Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: This study aims to enhance the detection performance of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) for underwater targets by optimizing a detection probability model that incorporates precise modeling of the target's magnetic anomaly field. The Finite Element Method (FEM) is utilized to set up a detailed model of the target’s magnetic anomaly field, which is then integrated into a detection probability model. Through detailed simulations, the influence of various UAV flight parameters on detection probability is evaluated. The results indicate that detection probability is notably improved by lowering flight altitude or by adjusting flight direction. This research significantly contributes to the field by proposing an advanced method for UAV detection probability analysis grounded in an enhanced magnetic anomaly field model of underwater target.

title: Graphical Approach for Sub-Optimal Unity Power Factor Control of Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor Drives
authors: Chi-Yang Chang, Jun-Hong Lin, Mi-Ching Tsai
abstract: This paper presents an effective computational method for achieving sub-optimal unity power factor control (UPFC) in interior permanent magnet synchronous motor drives. Traditional UPFC methods that involve solving complex fourth-order polynomial equations related to motor parameters, will be challenging to implement in real-time controllers. The proposed graphical method approximates the optimal UPFC current trajectory using geometric constructions of the dq-axis currents. This approach aims to reduce computational complexity and hence allows for adaptability to parameter variations in real-time. Simulation and hardware-in-the-loop experiments demonstrate that the proposed method maintains a power factor above 0.99 during load transitions.

title: A Study on Circuit Technologies for Improving the Efficiency of Active Cell Balancing
authors: Seok-Jin Na, Kang-Moon Park, In-Ho Cho
abstract: Conventional active cell balancing circuits require many components depending on the balancing objectives, such as Pack-to-Cell balancing and Cell-to-Pack balancing, and are limited to unidirectional energy transfer, thereby limiting their flexibility for diverse balancing strategies. Also, the balancing efficiency can decrease due to component losses and dependent balancing conditions, requiring approaches to address these existing limitations and improve efficiency. Therefore, this paper comprehensively analyzes approaches to improve the efficiency of conventional active cell balancing circuits, including components reduction, bidirectional energy transfer, and enhanced switching control algorithms. Based on this analysis, we propose a high-efficiency active cell balancing circuit and switching control algorithm. Through validation of the proposed circuit technology, it is confirmed that the proposed circuit provides three times faster balancing speed compared to conventional active cell balancing circuits under the same balancing conditions.

title: Evaluation of Voltage-Offset Resistive Control for Photovoltaic Panels in Solar Electric Vehicles
authors: Jian-Yu Ju, Katherine A. Kim
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) systems installed on the roofs of solar electric vehicles (SEVs) are emerging as an approach to increase range and reliability of EVs. However, when SEVs move past buildings or nearby objects, they experience significant irradiance fluctuations and should be controlled to continually maximize PV energy generation. Conventional maximum power point tracking (MPPT) control methods are not optimized for rapid and repeated irradiance changes, and such changes can temporarily drop the output power to zero. To solve this problem, an control called voltage offset resistive control (VRC) is utilized along with experimental shading test to develop an adaptive VRC MPPT strategy. This adaptive VRC approach reduces the power loss caused by rapid changes in shading and shows potential for the effective integration of photovoltaic cells into SEVs.

title: Sensorless Control of IPMSM Using Sliding Observer Based on Model for Realizing MTPA Control
authors: Hiroto Yoshida, Yuto Yamamori, Mutuwo Tomita, Atsushi Matsumoto, Masaru Hasegawa, Shinji Doki
abstract: A position sensorless control technique for interior permanent magnet synchronous motors (IPMSMs) has been developed using a full-order observer based on a simplified motor model that omits the q-axis inductance $L_{q}$. This simplified model also facilitates the implementation of maximum torque per ampere(MTPA)control. However, designing the full-order observer is complex owing to the four-dimensional nature of its error equation. To address this limitation, this study proposed a sliding mode observer based on the simplified IPMSM model. In this method, the error equation is reduced from four dimensions to two by sliding mode control, making it easier to analyze the pole assignment problem compared with the full-order observer. This advantage makes enables the design the observer pole assignment for robust flux estimation in the presence of velocity estimation inaccuracies, which is a parameter of the observer, and provides a clear solution to the pole placement problem. The simulation result demonstrates that the proposed pole assignment for the sliding observer is effective, and that MTPA control can be implemented in position and velocity sensorless control of IPMSM.

title: Output Power Feedback Control for DC-DC Converter Utilizing Singular Auxiliary Chopper Circuit
authors: Nour A.K. Hamdan, Makoto Hagiwara
abstract: This paper focuses on the implementation of output power feedback control for a non-isolated dc-dc converter with a single auxiliary chopper circuit, intended for railway applications. The conventional chopper circuit typically requires large and heavy inductor to reduce current ripple, which is undesirable on-board moving train cars. To solve this problem, this paper proposes a non-isolated dc-dc converter with a single auxiliary chopper circuit, which transfers power using a triangular ac inductor current, allowing the inductor mass and volume to be reduced. This paper presents the basic operation principles and a control method that regulates output power using feedback control. Simplified theoretical expression of the output power is derived and verified through comparisons with both simulation and experimental results. Furthermore, the proposed control method is validated using a downscaled experimental setup, where the output power was observed to be stable under dynamic conditions.

title: Decentralized and Secure AOI Framework Using Smart Contracts on Jetson Devices
authors: Zi Yi Lim, Chien-Chia Huang, Yi-Da Chiang
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: This study presents a novel decentralized and secure Automatic Optical Inspection (AOI) framework utilizing blockchain technology and smart contracts deployed on Nvidia Jetson edge computing devices to address integration complexities, security vulnerabilities, and excessive energy consumption in traditional AOI systems. The proposed architecture leverages Jetson devices as both processing units for image analysis and blockchain nodes, creating a decentralized network where inspection results are recorded through smart contracts. This approach ensures data immutability, transparency, auditability, and system resilience through decentralization. Experimental evaluation across three Jetson device models (Nano, Xavier NX, and Orin Nano Super) demonstrate that blockchain operations consume minimal resources. With the newer hardware Jetson Orin Nano Super showing average CPU usage of only 5.35% during blockchain operations (including ordering service), significant computational capacity remains available for AI-driven image inspection tasks. This enables the simultaneous execution of computer vision and AI recognition, as well as secure blockchain data recording, on a single edge device. The research implementing blockchain technology in resource-constrained edge devices proves the feasibility of blockchain-secured AOI in manufacturing environments.

title: Sentiment Analysis of User Feedback on Generative AI Tools
authors: Li-Hua Li, Agus Cahyo Nugroho
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: DeepSeek, an AI-powered application, has captured public attention due to its capabilities, though user opinions remain diverse. This study conducted a sentiment analysis of DeepSeek based on user review data sourced from Google Play. By utilizing natural language processing (NLP) techniques, researchers classified user sentiment into positive, neutral, and negative categories. According to experimental results, tree-based models like XGBoost (XGB) (0.7937) and Random Forest (RF) (0.7903) performed worse than classic machine learning models, especially Support Vector Machine (SVM) (0.8103) and Logistic Regression (LR) (0.8064). This suggests that the dataset is well-separated in linear space. The analysis provides insight into common user issues, feature preferences, and overall satisfaction, highlighting key aspects that influence user experience. The findings offer valuable input for developers to enhance DeepSeek’s functionality and improve user engagement.

title: Implementation of Nonlinear Flux Linkage Model for PMSM in Electric Motor Emulator
authors: Liu Hung Jiun, Yaow-Ming Chen
abstract: Nonlinear flux linkage models of PMSMs offer superior accuracy compared to linear models in capturing the electromagnetic behavior of permanent magnet synchronous motors. However, their real-time implementation is often constrained by memory limitations, as large lookup tables are impractical. This paper proposes a stepwise regression approach to approximate the nonlinear flux linkage using a compact mathematical model, significantly reducing memory requirements while maintaining high precision. Designed specifically for electric motor emulator systems, the proposed method ensures efficient real-time performance, making it well-suited for advanced motor drive testing applications.

title: Real-Time Disturbance Magnetic Field Observation Method Based on Multiple Sensors to Enhance the Directionality of Active Disturbance Suppression in MCG Systems
authors: Shengjie Qiu, Jiqiang Tang, Pengtao Tian, Fengwen Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Active magnetic compensation is commonly combined with passive magnetic shielding structures in magnetocardiography measurements to suppress environmental magnetic disturbances and improve the signal-to-noise ratio. Accurate measurement of the disturbance field in the target region is essential for control decisions. Active compensation systems that rely on a single reference sensor often suffer from inaccurate disturbance estimation and degradation of the target signal signal-to-noise ratio. In this work, a computationally efficient magnetic field observation method based on two-dimensional spherical harmonics is proposed. By exploiting the spatial correlation differences of signals, a Kalman filter is designed to suppress random noise and target signal components in the reference sensor while interpolating the disturbance field in the target region. Validation experiments were conducted on a prototype magnetocardiography system equipped with a barrel-shaped magnetic shielding structure. The results demonstrate that the proposed observation method can effectively guide the active compensation system to suppress disturbances in the target region, with the suppression rate improved from 43.05% using a single sensor to 84.14%. This disturbance observation approach provides valuable insights for the development of multi-channel active compensation systems and magnetocardiography devices operating without passive magnetic shielding.

title: Coupled Mode Theory Inspired Design of Ultra-Sensitive Planar Bio-Sensor Based on SIW Resonator
authors: Xinyue Song, Guy A. E. Vandenbosch, Sen Yan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper proposes a highly compact and ultra-sensitive microfluidic sensor based on the cavity resonator for biofluids. Aiming at the problem that cavity sensors under planar channels have difficulty achieving high sensitivity, a simple and efficient design method based on coupled mode theory(CMT) is proposed, and a highly miniaturized device is optimized based on the proposed concept. Instead of the drilled channel of a typical substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) cavity with a top and bottom metal layer, the proposed resonator is based on a planar integration of the channel. An additional patch resonator is introduced in the cavity center for establishing a coupled resonator system. The high sensitivity is obtained by mode splitting generated from the strong coupling of the SIW resonator and the introduced patch resonator. The miniaturization strategies of folded SIW and spiral complementary split ring resonator (CSRR) are applied to the two coupled resonators, respectively, to put the channel position at maximum field levels. The highly miniaturized device reduces the amount of necessary fluid during testing while maintaining the performance. The sensor is operational in the frequency range 0.6-1.7 GHz and has a size 0.21 × 0.21 λ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at 1.7 GHz. The proposed sensor has been verified with sodium chloride solutions to emulate the concentration range of sweat under physiological conditions. The results demonstrated that the sensor provides excellent resolution, thereby confirming its suitability for biological fluid analysis.
