title: Flexible Piezo-resistive Strain Sensors Using Ternary Conductive Hybrid Nanocomposites Integrated Into Wearable Smart Gloves For Human-Machine Interface
authors: Mohd Farman, Sk. Masiul Islam, Gaurav Purohit, Sumitra Singh
abstract: We report flexible piezo-resistive strain sensors containing poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) polystyrene sulfonate (PEDOT:PSS), graphene nanoplatelet (GNP), and polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS)-based ternary conductive hybrid nanocomposites as an active sensing layer fabricated using a simple solution-processed technique. The sensors have been fabricated on flexible PDMS substrate which is patterned using emery papers having grit size of 80 and 100. The electrical characterization have been undertaken in PDMS-based flexible devices mounted on smart gloves with structures PEDOT:PSS/GNP/PDMS. The microscopic study of the microstructured PDMS is done using field emission scanning electron microscopy. The size of PDMS microstructure based on 80 grit and 100 grit emery papers is found to be in the range of 165–196 um and 121–148 um, respectively. FTIR peaks at 677 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup>, 930 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup>, ~1000–1110 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup>, and 1519 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup> signify the C—S, S—O, Si–O–Si, and C=C stretching, respectively. From XRD, the diffraction peak at 26.60° corresponds to 002 facets of GNP, whereas PEDOT: PSS showed no distinct peaks of PEDOT:PSS film indicating amorphous nature of the polymer. The gauge factor of the sensor based on 80-grit emery paper is determined to be 601.3 within the strain ranging from 0–46%. The sensor shows highly reproducible response over 2100 bending and stretching cycles suggesting long-term durability. Response and recovery time of the fabricated sensor is calculated to be 140 and 155 ms, respectively. The developed smart glove integrated flexible strain sensor is capable to detect human pulse, monitor the real-time human motions and therefore it may find a great promise for application in smart wearable electronics and human-machine interface.

title: FedGSE: Gradient-Based Submodel Extraction for Resource-Constrained Federated Learning
authors: Genlang Chen, Yabo Jia, Haozhao Wang, Chaoyi Pang, Wenchao Xu
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a pivotal paradigm for multi-client collaborative learning, primarily due to its inherent capability to safeguard privacy. Nonetheless, the heterogeneity among FL clients, characterized by their disparate resource capabilities and not independent and identical (NonIID) local datasets, presents a significant challenge. Specifically, low-resource clients, such as edge devices, grapple with the inadequacy to accommodate the entire model parameter set for training purposes. To mitigate this issue, preceding research has ventured into devising methodologies that entail extracting sub-models from the overarching global model, tailored to the specific communication, computational, and memory constraints of individual clients. Despite these advancements, prevailing sub-model extraction techniques, which predominantly hinge on pre-established rules, overlook a crucial factor: the impact of NonIID local data on the trajectory of neuron update dynamics. This oversight can amplify discrepancies between the practical local updates inferred by the sub-model and those anticipated via the entire model, thereby undermining overall performance. In this paper, we introduce FedGSE, an innovative Gradient-based Neuron Selection methodology designed explicitly for FL environments. This methodology aims to curate sub-models that significantly reduce discrepancies in local updates, enhancing alignment with the global model's learning trajectory. Central to the FedGSE approach is a sophisticated algorithm that handpicks critical neurons for sub-model construction. These neurons are identified through their pronounced gradient magnitudes, resulting from the training of the global model on a dataset mirroring the client's data distribution. Consequently, the sub-model's induced local gradient updates closely emulate those derived from directly training the client's data on the full global model, fostering enhanced alignment and performance. Extensive experiments over diverse datasets and tasks demonstrate the superiority of FedGSE over existing baselines.

title: Integrated Magnetic Structure to Improve High Power Region Efficiency for Dual Active Bridge Converter
authors: Siddhesh Shinde, Gautam Rituraj, Gautham Ram Chandra Mouli, Vishnu Mahadeva Iyer, Pavol Bauer
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Industrial Electronics
abstract: In dual active bridge (DAB) converters, series inductor and transformer functionalities are integrated into a single magnetic core structure to improve efficiency or power density. Allowing independent tuning of this integrated series inductance and magnetizing inductance gives higher design flexibility. However, the existing integrated magnetic methods often lower magnetizing inductance, compromise the transformer winding coupling, require complex custom core designs, or cannot effectively decouple transformer and inductor fluxes in the case of separate transformer and inductor windings. To overcome these problems, this paper proposes a unified core structure that allows independent tuning of series inductance without the abovementioned limitations. To demonstrate the performance of the proposed integrated structure, a DAB converter for a DC-DC electric vehicle charging application is built, and the proposed integrated structure is compared with discrete transformer and inductor structures under identical core volume and thermal steady-state conditions. It is experimentally validated that for the proposed structure at a high output voltage and high load conditions of 450 V and 9 kW, the magnetic power loss reduction is 8.8%, whereas, at a low output voltage and high load conditions of 250 V and 7 kW, the magnetic power loss reduction is 13.0%. Furthermore, the paper presents an iterative design methodology based on the derived reluctance and analytical models to systematize the design process.

title: Privacy-Preserving Sketches for Securely Estimating Intersection Cardinality Over Distributed Data Sets
authors: Yitong Liu, Pinghui Wang, Zhicheng Li, Xiaolong Lin, Rundong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Computing the number of distinct elements (i.e., cardinality) in the intersection of two sets is a fundamental task in various distributed systems, including measuring origin-destination flows in wide-area networks and data synchronization in distributed databases. Due to the enormous data scale, lightweight probabilistic methods, such as FM sketch and HyperLogLog sketch, are extensively used in these systems to estimate the set intersection cardinality, with memory efficiency, high accuracy, and low communication costs. However, if a set's sketch and the hash functions used to construct the sketch are disclosed to an untrusted third party, the privacy of the set's sensitive elements may be compromised. Applying the differential privacy mechanism directly to safeguard the sketch's privacy may incur significant estimation errors. To address this challenge, we propose a novel private sketch, SetXor, for securely estimating intersection cardinality for static sets. Specifically, we incorporate the randomized response noise into the constructed sketch to achieve local differential privacy while ensuring our SetXor sketch is mergeable. We establish a concrete probabilistic model to mitigate the estimation error caused by the noise and theoretically analyze the variance. We further propose a novel sketch SetXorDyn enabling intersection cardinality estimation for streaming sets where elements appear sequentially and contain duplicates. We employ a sampling-like method to eliminate the impact of different parities of element occurrences, allowing us to handle all elements without bias. We conduct extensive experiments on synthetic and four real-world datasets. The results demonstrate that our methods reduce the Average Absolute Relative Error (AARE) of state-of-the-art baselines by up to $110\times$ on synthetic datasets and $80\times$ on real-world datasets, while achieving up to $18.7\times$ speedup under the same settings.

title: You Only Look One Step: Accelerating Backpropagation in Diffusion Sampling with Gradient Shortcuts
authors: Hongkun Dou, Zeyu Li, Xingyu Jiang, Hongjue Li, Lijun Yang, Wen Yao, Yue Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Diffusion models (DMs) have recently demonstrated remarkable success in modeling large-scale data distributions. However, many downstream tasks require guiding the generated content based on specific differentiable metrics, typically necessitating backpropagation during the generation process. This approach is computationally expensive, as generating with DMs often demands tens to hundreds of recursive network calls, resulting in high memory usage and significant time consumption. In this paper, we propose a more efficient alternative that approaches the problem from the perspective of parallel denoising. We show that full backpropagation throughout the entire generation process is unnecessary. The downstream metrics can be optimized by retaining the computational graph of only one step during generation, thus providing a shortcut for gradient propagation. The resulting method, which we call Shortcut Diffusion Optimization (SDO), is generic, high-performance, and computationally lightweight, capable of optimizing all parameter types in diffusion sampling. We demonstrate the effectiveness of SDO on several real-world tasks, including controlling generation by optimizing latent and aligning the DMs by fine-tuning network parameters. Compared to full backpropagation, our approach reduces computational costs by $\sim 90\%$ while maintaining superior performance.

title: SAM-FuseNet: Segment Anything Guided Multi-Modal Fusion for RGB–Thermal Aerial Robotic Perception
authors: Chenyang Zhu, Jierui Wang, Lanlan Zhang, Jia Liang, Qianxiao Su, Baihua Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Multi-modal semantic segmentation with RGB and Thermal (RGB–T) inputs is critical for robust aerial robotic perception, yet existing methods face challenges in effectively adapting pretrained representations and balancing complementary cues under variable illumination.To overcome these challenges, we introduce Segment Anything Guided Multi-Modal Fusion Network (SAM-FuseNet), a novel RGB–T framework that leverages modality-specific encoders built on the Segment Anything Model 2 (SAM2) Vision Transformer (ViT) backbone, enhanced with Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) modules for efficient modality-specific fine-tuning without full model retraining. Cross-modal fusion is achieved via a pixel-wise spatial attention mechanism combined with channel recalibration, allowing adaptive weighting of contributions from each modality. A dual-pathway segmentation head further improves prediction quality: the first pathway progressively refines coarse-to-fine masks under SAM2 guidance, while the second pathway performs hierarchical feature fusion to capture long-range contextual information. Extensive experiments on the Caltech RGB–T and PST900 benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of SAM-FuseNet, achieving improvements of up to 3.93% in mean Intersection-over-Union (mIoU) while reducing the trained model parameters by more than 50%. Qualitative results further demonstrate sharper boundaries, robustness under underexposed conditions, and resilience to modality degradation.

title: Integrated Sensing and Communication with Index Modulation over Pinching Antennas
authors: Min Liu, Yue Xiao, Jiangong Chen, Shuaixin Yang, Xia Lei, Ming Xiao
abstract: Pinching antennas, as a novel class of low-cost and flexibly controllable antenna systems, offer a promising solution for next-generation wireless applications. In this paper, we propose a pinching antenna-assisted integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) framework, where index modulation (IM) is employed for efficient data transmission. Simultaneously, the user leverages the line-of-sight (LoS) component to estimate its position, thereby enabling the ISAC functionality. Furthermore, to address the inherent computational challenges, the proposed scheme invokes variational inference for approximating the joint posterior distribution of user location and transmitted symbols. Meanwhile, the prior knowledge of the user’s spatial constraints is incorporated through a turbo-type iterative update mechanism, which significantly enhances the estimation accuracy. Finally, simulation results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in terms of both localization precision and detection reliability.

title: ANHP: Adaptive Neural Hawkes Processes for Causal Structure Learning on Event Sequences
authors: Yongjian Chang, Duxin Chen, Yujin Cai, Wenwu Yu
abstract: Causal structure learning on event sequences is essential in critical systems such as communications, transportation, and industrial monitoring, where precise modeling of causal dependencies among event types significantly impacts tasks like root-cause alarm localization. Existing approaches often rely on Hawkes processes augmented with static network topology to eliminate the independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) assumption, yet their dependence on predefined fixed structures and manually chosen kernels limits adaptability to dynamic network systems. The key challenge is to automatically infer accurate causal graphs from event sequences where both temporal evolution and network topology change over time, while accounting for nonlinear dependencies. To address this challenge, we propose Adaptive Neural Hawkes Processes (ANHP), a novel neural point process framework comprising three core modules: (1) Adaptive Event-Graph Learning, which constructs dynamic topology directly from event embeddings; (2) Neural Topological Hawkes Process, which replaces traditional linear excitation kernels with neural parameterization to capture nonlinear, time-varying conditional intensities; and (3) Masked Sparse Causal Structure, which balances likelihood maximization and model complexity via kernel-parameters masking and Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) penalization to suppress redundant edges. Experimental results on real-world communication network alarm datasets from Huawei Shennong Intelligent Maintenance and Operation Center (IMOC) and synthetic datasets demonstrate that ANHP significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in accuracy, robustness, and scalability. The code is available at https://github.com/ChngYJ/ANHP.

title: Energy-Efficient Transmission Scheduling with Uncertainty-Aware Data Imputation for mHealth
authors: Weihua Chen, Zonglin Xie, Feng Liu, Ruipeng Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing over Networks
abstract: Transmission scheduling plays a critical role in energy conservation in wireless sensor networks (WSNs), particularly in mobile health (mHealth) systems that rely on multiple distributed sensing modalities. Although recent studies have proposed approaches to balance transmission efficiency and timeliness such as periodic sleep scheduling to reduce power consumption, these strategies often result in data loss which can severely degrade real-time diagnostic accuracy. To address this issue, this paper integrates transmission scheduling with data imputation. We propose an energy-efficient software-hardware co-designed framework for mHealth systems, and investigate a Wasserstein Generative Adversarial Imputation Network (WGAIN) to recover missing data. Specifically, the WGAIN model captures heterogeneous inter-sensor correlations, temporal dependencies, and missing-data patterns through a divide-and-conquer learning strategy. Furthermore, we incorporate a dropout-based uncertainty approximation method into the imputation framework and demonstrate its theoretical equivalence to Gaussian processes under variational inference. In addition, a reinforcement learning-based algorithm is developed to dynamically schedule transmissions across heterogeneous sensing modules, with the objective of minimizing overall uncertainty at a target service time. Extensive experiments conducted on the MIT-BIH dataset, together with evaluations on a real-world system prototype, have demonstrated that our approach consistently outperforms existing methods.

title: ITALYSIG: Open and High Fidelity I/Q Signal Database with Tutorial and Applications for Wireless Research
authors: Lorenzo Maria Monteforte, Luca Chiaraviglio, Hina Tabassum, Sadeq Bani Melhem, Pierpaolo Loreti, Daniele Franci, Settimio Pavoncello, Stefano Salsano, Giuseppe Bianchi, Nicola Blefari-Melazzi
abstract: High-fidelity in-phase and quadrature (I/Q) signal traces are critical for a variety of wireless network applications, including spectrum monitoring, interference detection and mitigation, radio-frequency (RF) fingerprinting (RFFP), smart jamming detection, anomaly identification, and modulation classification. However, the number and scope of publicly available I/Q datasets are currently limited, as most datasets are either restricted to a single frequency or wireless technology, or collected in controlled laboratory environments. This paper introduces ITALYSIG, a comprehensive, high-definition, open-source I/Q database of diverse real-world radio signals, including cellular, radar, and other wireless technologies. ITALYSIG provides I/Q captures with up to 100 MHz bandwidth, collected across diverse urban and rural environments in Italy. The I/Q signals are stored in multiple formats, including raw binary files, standardized VITA Radio Transport (VRT, VITA-49), and visual formats such as Portable Network Graphics (PNG) and JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) for broader applicability. The data-acquisition setup is based on a CRFS RFeye SenS Portable recorder at the front end, which enables automatic long-term I/Q recordings on the order of hours, multi-terabyte storage, and real-time signal processing. In addition to releasing the dataset, this article provides a comprehensive overview and qualitative comparison of state-of-the-art datasets in terms of measurement setup, data format, wireless technology, frequencies, and time duration. Furthermore, this article provides a tutorial on the end-to-end measurement setup for automatic I/Q acquisition, multi-format export, and back-end storage, as well as real-time analysis via the DeepView software. Finally, we provide guidelines for integrating I/Q traces into deep learning pipelines and highlight specific use cases of the dataset.

title: InsDD-YOLO: Detection of Transmission Line Insulator Damage Based on The Improved YOLOv13 Model
authors: Phat T. Nguyen, Duy C. Huynh, Loc D. Ho, Ha T. Tran, Matthew W. Dunnigan
abstract: Amidst the rapid global expansion of smart grids, ensuring the safety and reliability of power transmission systems has become paramount. Insulators are critical components of high-voltage transmission lines, providing both electrical insulation and mechanical support. However, their exposure to electrical, mechanical, and environmental stressors renders them vulnerable point within the system. Defective insulators are a major cause of failures in power transmission systems. Consequently, the early and accurate detection of these defects is pivotal for maintaining the integrity and reliability of the power grid. To address this challenge, this study proposes InsDD-YOLO, a novel object detection architecture enhanced from the YOLOv13 framework. The model incorporates a suite of strategic enhancements, including an improved DSConv (IDSConv) module for robust feature extraction, a streamlined Neck architecture augmented with a feature stream from a shallower layer (B2) to improve small-target detection, and a direct Head connection mechanism to maximize the preservation of fine-grained details. Experimental results demonstrate that InsDD-YOLO achieves superior performance, reaching an mAP0.5 of 90.1% and an mAP0.5:0.95 of 46.4%, outperforming the baseline YOLOv13 model by a significant 5.0% in mAP0.5. With an inference time of just 5.4 ms, the proposed model not only establishes a new benchmark for accuracy but also demonstrates an effective trade-off between performance and speed, underscoring its significant potential for deployment in real-time, automated power grid monitoring systems.

title: Exploiting Expertise of Non-Expert and Diverse Agents in Social Bandit Learning: A Free Energy Approach
authors: Erfan Mirzaei, Seyed Pooya Shariatpanahi, Alireza Tavakoli, Reshad Hosseini, Majid Nili Ahmadabadi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems
abstract: Personalized AI-based services involve a population of individual reinforcement learning agents. However, most reinforcement learning algorithms focus on harnessing individual learning and fail to leverage the social learning capabilities commonly exhibited by humans and animals. Social learning integrates individual experience with observing others’ behavior, presenting opportunities for improved learning outcomes. In this study, we focus on a social bandit learning scenario where a social agent observes other agents’ actions without knowledge of their rewards. The agents independently pursue their own policy without explicit motivation to teach each other. We propose a free energy-based social bandit learning algorithm over the policy space, where the social agent evaluates others’ expertise levels without resorting to any oracle or social norms. Accordingly, the social agent integrates its direct experiences in the environment and others’ estimated policies. The theoretical convergence of our algorithm to the optimal policy is proven. Empirical evaluations validate the superiority of our social learning method over alternative approaches in various scenarios. Our algorithm strategically identifies the relevant agents, even in the presence of random or suboptimal agents, and skillfully exploits their behavioral information. In addition to societies including expert agents, in the presence of relevant but non-expert agents, our algorithm significantly enhances individual learning performance, where most related methods fail. Importantly, it also maintains logarithmic regret.

title: A Novel Multi-scale Residual Active Deep Q-learning Network for Intelligent Bearing Fault Diagnosis with Small Training Data
authors: Chao Chen, Wenhui Sun, Hui Wang, Haobo Yang, Liling Han, Wei Fan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In bearing fault diagnosis (BFD), deep reinforcement learning (DRL) offers a promising solution by applying rewards to optimize fault decision-making strategies. However, the lack of sufficient training data as well as the ability to explore more comprehensive fault representation of key samples will draw limitations on DRL-based diagnostic model. To tackle these aforesaid issues, this study proposes a multi-scale residual active deep Q-learning network (MRADQN), which can not only select high-value samples from unlabeled candidates for expanding the number of training samples, but also extract local and global features from these newly-reconstructed samples. Specifically, MRADQN consists of an active deep Q-learning (ADQN) module and a multi-scale residual convolutional neural network (MRCNN) module. To pick out the most beneficial samples, ADQN designs a new state and action strategy based on entropy and cosine distance to calculate the uncertainty and similarity of samples, respectively, with the aim of quickly and accurately selecting the most significant data for labeling. For improving the ability regarding feature learning, a multi-scale residual block is designed in MRCNN to obtain rich feature representations. The experimental analyses show that MRADQN has strong fault detection capabilities, exceeding 99% diagnostic accuracy. And compared with many methods, MRADQN attains superior results when facing limited training data.

title: Asynchronous Unsourced Random Access in Cell-Free Wireless Communication Systems
authors: Gangle Sun, Mengyao Cao, Wenjin Wang, Wei Xu, Shi Jin
abstract: Cell-free techniques and unsourced random access (URA) are promising solutions for accommodating massive numbers of users. However, varying transmission distances between users and access points in cell-free systems introduce inevitable asynchronous transmissions, which degrade URA performance. To address this challenge, this paper investigates the impact of asynchronous transmissions on URA in cell-free systems and designs two efficient asynchronous URA receivers. Specifically, we first model the impact of transmission delays as phase shifts on URA codewords and expand the URA codebook to simplify the codeword detection problem formulation. To efficiently detect codewords, we propose a deep unfolding forward-backward splitting algorithm that estimates transmitted codewords while automatically training algorithm hyperparameters via machine learning. Additionally, we introduce a coordinate descent-based URA codeword detector integrated with a convolutional neural network, which leverages prior information on channel large-scale fading and delay probabilities to enhance detection performance. Extensive simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed asynchronous URA receivers.

title: State Machine Implementation for Safe Shutdown Strategies of Dual Active Bridge Converters
authors: Bonaventura Riko Kumara Datta, Yohan Fajar Sidik
abstract: The dual active bridge (DAB) converter has become a preferred topology for isolated bidirectional DC-DC converters in medium-to-high voltage applications due to its high efficiency and compactness. However, the fast-switching nature of SiC MOSFETs introduces challenges during shutdown events. While prior research has focused primarily on hardware-level protection, less attention has been given to converter-level control strategies that can manage shutdown transitions more gracefully. This research proposes a state-machine-based shutdown control for DAB converters using two safe shutdown strategies: multistage shutdown (MSSD) and zero-current detection (ZCD). Simulation results in PLECS show that both methods effectively suppress current and voltage stress during open switch and short circuit faults. The leakage inductor current is reduced to $\mathbf{5 8 - 6 4 \%}$ of uncontrolled fault levels, and shutdowns are complete within $117 \mu \mathrm{~s}$, respectively, without voltage overshoot. Both methods maintain current within the SiC MOSFET’s safe operating area.

title: Verification of Frequency Multiplying Inverter by Cascaded H-Bridge for Wireless Power Transfer
authors: Seiya Kobayashi, Sari Maekawa
abstract: In recent years, magnetic resonance wireless power transfer systems in the MHz band have been studied. However, higher operating frequency makes it difficult to achieve compatibility with higher output power due to limitations of components, such as switching devices and gate drivers. To address this issue, frequency multiplying circuits have been studied, which generate voltage at a switching frequency lower than the output frequency. We have proposed a frequency multiplying inverter based on a cascaded H-bridge. This paper verifies the feasibility of applying the proposed inverter to a wireless power transfer system through simulation and experimental evaluation. It also provides design insights for loss reduction and expansion of the operating range.

title: Phase-Based High-Sensitivity Metal Object Detection for Electric Vehicle Wireless Charging
authors: Hao Chen, Zhecheng Zhang, Yuanpeng Chen, Yue Hui, Jiande Wu, Xiangning He
abstract: To address the safety risks caused by metal foreign objects (MOs) in wireless electric vehicle charging (WEVC), this paper proposes a high-sensitivity metal object detection (MOD) method based on phase detection. The system injects a high-frequency excitation signal into an array of detection coils and monitors the real-time phase of the coil currents. Through impedance modeling of the detection coils, it is demonstrated that phase-based detection exhibits superior sensitivity compared to conventional amplitude-based techniques, especially for small-sized MOs. A high-resolution phase detection circuit, incorporating analog switches and a high-speed coil scanning mechanism, is designed to enable efficient multi-channel detection. A 3.3 kW WEVC prototype compliant with the SAE J2954 standard is developed to validate the proposed method. Experimental results show that the system can detect metallic objects as small as $1 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$ anywhere within the $\mathbf{7 5 0 ~ m m} \times \mathbf{6 0 0 ~ m m}$ power transmitting coil, achieving a minimum detectable phase variation of $\mathbf{1 2 ~ m r a d}$ and completing a full scan in only 0.48 seconds.

title: Power Flow Analysis of Hybrid Solar-Grid Shore Power Systems for Emission Reduction
authors: Wahyu Ardi Santosa, F. Danang Wijaya, Yohan Fajar Sidik
abstract: Ports worldwide face critical energy and environmental challenges due to diesel generator dependency, with growing electricity demand from operations exceeding capacity, requiring sustainable shore power solutions for netzero targets. Microgrid implementation, integrating renewable energy sources such as photovoltaic arrays and energy storage, represents a promising solution for reducing fossil fuel dependency while enhancing operational resilience and efficiency. This research focuses on power flow simulation and emission analysis of a hybrid photovoltaic and grid electricity system featuring a rooftop PV installation at Tanjung Emas Port, with a capacity of $6,250 \mathrm{kWp}$. The simulation examines normal operational conditions and photovoltaic intermittency scenarios to assess system performance. It confirms that voltage levels remain within the IEC 60038 range of 0.90 to 1.10 per unit under both conditions. The islanded PV system successfully supplies outlet boxes at both terminals and office buildings despite minimum irradiance. This solar-powered shore power system achieves emission reduction of 61.39% compared to diesel-based systems, providing a technical foundation for advancing Tanjung Emas Port toward becoming an international smart port.

title: Application of Active Cell Balancing Techniques for Electric Vehicles
authors: Minh-Quang Nguyen, Van-Phuc Le, Van-Thai Nguyen, Van-Phong Vu, Huu-Thai Pham, Hoai-An Trinh
abstract: In response to the increasing demand for safe and efficient energy storage systems, especially in electric vehicles and renewable energy applications, this paper presents the design and simulation of a Battery Management System (BMS) based on a Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) platform. While lithium-ion batteries are widely used for their high energy density and long cycle life, issues related to cell imbalance and system safety remain critical challenges. To address this, the proposed system employs Typhoon HIL software for real-time modeling and simulation. A digital signal processor (DSP) TMS320F28069 is programmed with an active cell balancing algorithm and integrated with the HIL404 hardware. The system adopts a bidirectional converter topology to redistribute energy dynamically between unbalanced cells, with real-time monitoring through the HIL SCADA interface. Simulation results under both charging and discharging conditions demonstrate the algorithm's effectiveness in reducing voltage and state-of-charge (SOC) deviations, thereby improving overall battery performance and operational safety. This work provides a cost-effective, real-time testing framework for validating BMS strategies, offering practical insights for future deployment in electric mobility and smart energy storage systems.

title: Research on Fast Backprojection Algorithm for TOPS SAR Imaging
authors: Haolin Li, Tao He, Deyun Yang, Zengzeng Jia, Yuzhe Sun, Shuo Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: The fast backprojection algorithm has been proposed for more than 20 years, but it has mainly been used for spotlight SAR imaging, and rarely for TOPS SAR imaging. In this paper, we first conduct an in-depth analysis of the two key factors that constrain the application of backprojection. These factors are the integration aperture constraints and the angular domain sampling constraints. Then, we propose a fast backprojection algorithm and processing workflow tailored for TOPS SAR imaging, which maintains the computational accuracy and operational efficiency of the fast backprojection algorithm. Finally, we validate the effectiveness of this method through simulation experiments.

title: A Comparative Study of Metaheuristic Algorithms for Coverage-Aware Multi-UAV Path Planning in Complex Threat Environments
authors: Jiachen Cui, Xiang Wei, Zhi Wang, Jiyuan Tan, Wei Li, Xiaobin Hao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Aerospace Information Perception and Intelligent Processing (AIPIP)
abstract: Multi-UAV cooperative route planning is a key technology for enhancing regional detection efficiency, with its core challenge being the solution of high-dimensional optimization problems under complex constraints. For cooperative detection scenarios involving multi-level threat zones and complex terrain, we propose a solution based on multi-algorithm comparative optimization. To evaluate algorithm performance, a simulation environment was established featuring six tier-3 threats, seven priority search areas (PSAs), and digital elevation terrain. A weighted cost function was constructed with objectives including path length, threat cost, altitude cost, smoothness cost, and detection reward. Four meta-heuristic algorithms—SFOA, GJO, MVO and ZOA—were systematically compared. Results indicate that (SFOA) demonstrates optimal overall performance in solving this problem, exhibiting superior convergence speed, solution quality, and stability compared to other algorithms. It can plan cooperative flight paths for UAV swarms that balance high detection efficiency with high safety. This study provides an effective basis for algorithm selection and solutions for multi-UAV collaborative mission planning in complex environments.

title: Intelligent Mobile Robot Fall Detection System Integrating Pose Estimation and YOLO
authors: Yu-Yong Luo, Chia-Hsin Cheng, Tzu-Yuan Chiu
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: This article presents a fall detection and alarm system based on human pose estimation integrated with an autonomous vehicle. The aim is to monitor and track the safety status of elderly residents at home. The system is capable of rapidly alerting caregivers in the event of a detected fall, ensuring timely assistance for the elderly. Regarding the fall detection methods, three approaches are proposed in this thesis: pose estimation-based method, YOLOv5-based method, and the combination of YOLOv5 and pose estimation. Using pose estimation or YOLOv5 alone for fall detection might be limited by the diversity and quantity of training data, leading to suboptimal recognition performance. To address this issue, the thesis proposes a method that combines YOLOv5 and pose estimation. This combined approach effectively reduces false alarms from individual methods, consequently enhancing the accuracy of the fall detection system. By leveraging the strengths of both methods, this approach comprehensively considers the pose features within the image and the positional information of the target objects, thus improving the effectiveness of fall event detection.

title: Design and Evaluation of a Secure Coding Approach Based on Static and Dynamic Testing in Compliance with ISO 27001:2022 Standard
authors: Warsun Najib, Antonius Daiva Prabawisesa, Dani Adhipta
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Software vulnerabilities remain a critical challenge, with many security flaws introduced during development due to insufficient integration of security testing into coding workflows. This paper presents an automated secure merge workflow that integrates Static Application Security Testing (SAST) and Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST), aligned with the ISO/IEC 27001:2022 standard. The workflow leverages Semgrep for SAST and OWASP ZAP for DAST to enable early vulnerability detection, automated scanning, detailed reporting, and conditional merge control. Evaluation against the OWASP Benchmark dataset shows that Semgrep achieved a recall of 88.20%, while OWASP ZAP reached a precision of 97.77%, confirming their complementary roles. Beyond tool performance, the workflow demonstrates how ISO/IEC 27001 controls can be operationalized in practice, providing auditable evidence of secure coding and vulnerability management. While the pipeline alone cannot fulfill all principles of the standard, it strengthens compliance assurance and offers a practical model for integrating security into modern development pipelines.

title: Desaturation Function Blanking Time Design Considering Parasitic Circuit Parameters
authors: Sheng-Tsung Tsai, Yaow-Ming Chen
abstract: This paper presents an estimation method for the blanking time. Generally, typical desaturation (DESAT) circuits require design associated with gate driver ICs, including blanking time design, which is referred to the datasheet of gate driver ICs. However, the design method of the datasheet is under the ideal case. In practice, the tolerance, based on experience, is added to the blanking time under the non-ideal case caused by the parasitic inductance of the power switch. However, it is difficult to quantify the appropriate blanking time. Therefore, this paper proposes an estimation method based on the turn-on transient behavior of the MOSFET to improve the design procedure under the non-ideal case. Finally, simulation results are presented to verify the performance of the proposed estimate method.

title: Experimental Evaluation of a Regenerative Test System for Power Devices Under Soft-Switching Conditions
authors: Yusuke Nishibori, Ryosuke Ota, Keiji Wada, Kazuyasu Takimot, Makiko Hirano, Yushi Koyama
abstract: This study presents a regenerative test system based on an LLC converter that enables device evaluation under soft-switching conditions. The test system employs a passive circuit configuration that achieves power regeneration through a transformer, without the use of voltage or current sensors or a closed-loop controller. Compared to conventional systems using resistive loads or back-to-back configurations, the proposed method achieves reductions in volume, weight, and power consumption. Experimental verification using the prototype under conditions of 100 V voltage and 4 A peak current confirmed that power consumption was limited to 9.33 W. These results demonstrate that the proposed system can simultaneously achieve both soft switching and power regeneration, thereby establishing its suitability as a testing system optimized for soft-switching circuits.

title: A Grid-Forming Inverter with Virtual Damper Winding
authors: Chen-Kai Lee, Jian-Je Hung, Che-Wei Hsu, Jiann-Fuh Chen
abstract: This paper proposes a damping power control method in Virtual Synchronous Generator (VSG) control technology. Incorporating virtual damper winding was introduced to the inverter equivalent output impedance for emulating the damping power of synchronous generators. For demonstrating the effect, a three-phase, three-level neutralpoint clamped (NPC) inverter configuration was implemented, with an input DC bus voltage of 800 V, grid phase voltage of 220 Vrms/ 60 Hz, switching frequency of 50 kHz, and rated power of 6.6 kVA. Experimental results showed the total harmonic distortion of voltage (THDv) of $\mathbf{1. 5 4 \%}$ at rated power in off-grid mode. In grid-connected mode, the total harmonic distortion of the current (THDi) was 2.54% when operating at 3.3 kW. After adding the virtual damper winding, the settling time decreased approximately 40% when the grid frequency suddenly drops to $\mathbf{5 9. 9 5 ~ H z}$.

title: Innovative Approach to Non-Destructive Diagnostics of UAV Components Using Integrated Sensors
authors: Jaroslav Kessler, Jozef Novotňák, Zoltán Szőke, Adam Polakovič
abstract: The development of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and their increasing deployment bring new requirements for the reliability and safety of structural components. A particular challenge is the area of non-destructive testing (NDT), which is complicated by the use of additive manufacturing. This technology allows the creation of components with a heterogeneous internal structure, often combining solid and hollow segments, which reduces the effectiveness of conventional inspection methods. Components, such as multicopter arms, are exposed to high dynamic stress during operation, with landing being a particularly critical phase. Hard landings can lead to the formation of microcracks, which are difficult to detect by standard methods such as thermography or ultrasound. The limitations of these approaches are the layered surface, material texture and increasingly complex geometry optimized by evolutionary algorithms. The article aims to present an innovative approach to NDT, based on the integration of sensors directly into the design of UAV components. This system is designed for off-line diagnostics, i.e. pre-flight and in-flight inspection of critical points, without compromising the integrity of the structure. The presented solution represents a promising path to more reliable monitoring and extending the service life of UAVs manufactured using additive technologies, thereby contributing to higher operational safety and efficiency of their deployment. (Abstract)

title: Military Aviation Regulations and their Interaction with Civil Aviation Regulations
authors: Robert Klír, Peter Kontriš
abstract: The primary objective of this research is to conduct a comparative analysis of civil and military aviation regulatory frameworks. The initial part of the study presents an overview of the methodology and findings, focusing on the structural and content-related aspects of military aviation regulations. The comparative assessment was conducted using the aviation regulatory systems of the United States Air Force (USAF) and the Russian Federation Air Force (AFoRF), two of the world’s largest and most influential military air powers. The results obtained were subsequently compared with the regulatory environment of the Slovak Republic. Special attention has given to the interoperability of military and civil aviation regulations as well as to cross-comparisons between different military regulatory frameworks. Findings indicate that, while civil and military aviation regulations share several common principles, they also exhibit significant structural and procedural divergences. One of the most notable distinctions lies in the fact that each country maintains its own military regulatory system. They often differ in organizational hierarchy, document classification, and operational procedures when compared to civil aviation standards.

title: Poster: Applying a Distinguished Framework to Ensure Privacy-by-Design and Composability in a Regulated Tokenized Multi-Asset Network
authors: Rodrigo Gonçalves Bueno, André Luiz de Souza Carneiro, João Paulo Aragão Pereira
publish: 2025 7th Conference on Blockchain Research &amp; Applications for Innovative Networks and Services (BRAINS)
abstract: Adoption of DeFi, Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC), and Tokenized Multiassets necessitates new security architectures for Regulated Tokenized Multiasset Networks (RTMNs). Traditional approaches are insufficient for the distributed nature of decentralized finance, and Zero Trust models face compliance and efficiency challenges in financial networks. This paper proposes a novel framework for diverse use cases, guarantees composability, atomicity, settlement finality, and enforced compartmentalization, sharing minimal necessary information, enabling privacy-by-design. A detailed analysis of the framework’s application in RTMNs is presented, evaluating its characteristics in the context of tokenizing government securities.

title: A New Three-Port DC-DC-AC Converter with Single-Phase Buck-Boost AC Output
authors: Hafiz Furqan Ahmed, Alireza Lahooti Eshkevari, Ashraf Ali Khan
abstract: This paper presents an innovative topology of a three-port DC-DC-AC converter, along with its modulation strategy, aimed at seamlessly integrating DC energy sources and storage systems within (hybrid) DC and AC microgrids or feeding DC and AC loads. The converter combines the functions of two separate circuits (DC-DC and DC-AC) into a unified topology, reducing component count, implementation costs, conversion stages, and related power losses. Compared to counterparts, this new circuit requires only five switches, fully shared between the DC and AC ports; offers a broad range of buck-boost voltage operations, making it ideal for connecting with series-connected DC sources, such as a string photovoltaic system, where the input voltage may vary both above and below the DC and AC output levels; all three ports of the proposed converter support bidirectional current flow, enabling battery bank charging, while this bidirectional flow in the DC and AC ports allows for power sharing between the two microgrids, acting as an interlink converter; and incorporates 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">nd</sup> order LC filters at each port, ensuring a continuous and low-ripple current flow for both the DC and AC ports. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the topology, modulation method, operational performance, and comparative assessments, all of which are validated by experimental tests, achieving a peak efficiency of 96.6%.

title: Remote Sensing Single Image Dehazing With Histogram Degradation Representation Learning
authors: Zhongmin Zhu, Tianyu Song, Yusi Huang, Weitao Han, Xinghui Xia, Ling Ma
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Haze severely degrades the visual quality of remote sensing images, resulting in the loss of fine details and reduced reliability in subsequent tasks. Although Transformer-based approaches have recently achieved notable progress in image dehazing, most existing methods mitigate computational complexity by constraining self-attention to channel interactions or fixed spatial regions. This design inevitably restricts their capacity to capture long-range spatial dependencies, which are crucial for effectively modeling haze distributions. To address this limitation, we propose a Histogram-guided Remote Sensing Image Dehazing Transformer (HRSformer). The framework is built upon two key components: a Histogram Degradation Representation Block (HDRB), which dynamically selects spatial feature ranges and collaboratively processes distant pixels with similar degradation patterns to suppress global haze interference, and a Multi-Expert Modulation Block (MEMB), which employs a mixture-of-experts strategy to adaptively capture multi-scale and multi-granularity contextual features in a sample-specific manner, thereby improving the reconstruction of fine local textures. Extensive experiments on multiple public remote sensing dehazing benchmarks demonstrate that HRSformer consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both quantitative metrics and visual quality, validating its effectiveness and superiority.

title: Heterogeneous Multirobot Team: Maritime Inspection and Intervention in Global Navigation Satellite System-Denied Scenarios
authors: Barbara Arbanas Ferreira, Antun Ivanovic, Marijana Peti, Luka Mandić, Matko Batoš, Jakob Domislović, Goran Vasiljević, Juraj Obradović, Fausto Ferreira, Frano Petric, Antonella Barišić-Kulaš, Marko Car, Jurica Goričanec, Natko Kraševac, Marko Križmančić, Ivan Lončar, Lovro Marković, Robert Milijaš, Dario Stuhne, Matko Orsag, Stjepan Bogdan, Nikola Mišković
abstract: Autonomous robotic systems play an increasingly important role in overcoming complex maritime challenges, where the environment requires high adaptability, robustness, and precision. Marsupial robotic systems, combining aerial systems and surface vessels, offer a powerful solution for coordinated missions in Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS)-denied scenarios, leveraging the unique capabilities of each robot to form a versatile team. This article presents a system integrating advanced sensor fusion, localization, mission planning, and communication to enable seamless collaboration between unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and autonomous surface vehicles (ASVs). The focus is on optimizing the vehicles’ interaction to efficiently locate, retrieve, and transport objects from a target vessel in an adverse sea environment. This article provides a complete system overview, including the hardware setup, algorithms used, implementation details, and field trial results. The results analysis demonstrates the advanced capabilities of the developed ASV‒UAV system in complex real-world maritime operations, underscoring its potential for coordinated multirobot tasks in environments where traditional navigation systems are unavailable. Notably, this system was developed by the team that secured first place in the Mohamed Bin Zayed International Robotic Challenge (MBZIRC), proving its excellence in challenging conditions.

title: Microwave Acoustic Device Integration for In-Band Full-Duplex Applications
authors: Jack Guida, Chuan Tian, Kenneth E. Kolodziej, Siddhartha Ghosh
abstract: Simultaneous transmit and receive, or in-band full-duplex (IBFD), holds significant promise for radar and wireless communication systems using time-domain cancellation at radio frequencies. These systems rely on precise control of group delay to effectively mitigate self-interference. Piezoelectric-based traveling microwave acoustic wave devices provide a compact, passive means to implement such delays with high fidelity. This work explores the integration of piezoelectric acoustic delay lines to enhance self-interference cancellation (SIC) performance through precise group delay control and demonstrates SIC with such devices for a single tap demonstration.

title: Data-Driven Methods of Distributed Control to Multi-Input Linear Systems
authors: Zongyuan Sun, Jiachen Qian, Zhisheng Duan, Zhongkui Li
abstract: This article investigates data-driven methods for distributed cooperative control of multi-input linear systems. In model-free scenarios, designing cooperative control laws is particularly challenging due to strong dynamic coupling and limited communication between neighboring agents. We consider both partially known and completely unknown system models, and propose corresponding direct and indirect data-driven procedures for distributed controller design. For systems with partially known models, we develop several algorithms tailored to different cases of unknown system matrices. For completely unknown systems, we adopt an indirect data-driven framework, reformulating the system identification process as a distributed optimization problem. The problem admits a unique optimal solution which accurately represents the system model, with the uniqueness guaranteed by the distributed design of control inputs. A practical algorithm is proposed to obtain this optimal solution, and the communication load with neighbors is independent of data length and system size, demonstrating favorable scalability. To enhance the practicality of the proposed methods, several acceleration techniques with mild approximations are incorporated, significantly reducing communication and computation costs. Moreover, we also provide discussions on the effect of data quality and noise on the identification performance. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms are validated through numerical simulations.

title: MarkingVLM: Vision-Language Model for Few-Shot IC Marking Detection
authors: Zhongshu Chen, Zhenghua Chen, Lin Zuo, Yu Liu
abstract: Integrated circuit (IC) marking detection faces critical “Triple C” challenges: compact marking scales, complex multidirectional layouts, and costly annotation requirements. Traditional models struggle with data scarcity in dynamic manufacturing environments where fine-grained labeled data are expensive and time-consuming to obtain. This work presents MarkingVLM, a specialized vision-language model designed for IC marking detection with exceptional few-shot learning capabilities. MarkingVLM adapts cross-modal understanding from Contrastive Language-Image Pre-training (CLIP) through unique innovations: 1) dual-granularity detection combining patch-level semantic alignment with pixel-level visual decoding; 2) layout mirror module enabling efficient multidirectional text flow recognition through feature-level augmentation; and 3) enhanced prompt engineering with learnable contexts for effective domain adaptation. Extensive experiments across two IC marking datasets with distinct characteristics substantiate superior performance: 94.2% precision and 96.5% recall on Dataset-1, and 89.6% precision with 92.6% recall on the more challenging Dataset-2. Most significantly, MarkingVLM achieves 92.7% precision with 32 training samples and maintains over 80% recall with merely 8 samples, demonstrating notable data efficiency improvement over conventional methods. Results establish a new paradigm for industrial text detection by bridging open-domain vision-language knowledge with specialized manufacturing requirements.

title: Synergistic Resource Allocation with Key Genera-tion and Consumption Matching in Quantum Secured Multicore Fiber Optical Networks
authors: Chuan Xie, Yongmei Sun, Yaoxian Gao, Fengkai Sun, Yuting Wang, Yuefeng Ji
abstract: Integrating quantum key distribution (QKD) with multicore fiber (MCF) optical networks to build large-capacity and high-security networks is a promising method to meet the traffic and security demand in the future. In this paper, an innovative algorithm named QKD Transceiver Planning for Key Generation and Consumption Matching (QTP-KGCM) is proposed to solve the problem of mismatch between key generation and consumption. On demand of achieving synergistic transmission of classical and quantum signal, a heuristic resource allocation algorithm named Classical and Quantum signals Layered Interleaved (CQLI) is proposed. Furthermore, this paper pro poses the Deep Q Network based Synergistic Resource Allocation (DQN-based SRA) algorithm in response to the limited effective ness, which is a common issue in heuristic resource allocation algorithms. Simulation results show that QTP-KGCM algorithm can ensure that secure key rate of generation exceeds consumption rate 94.7% of the time in real-time key consumption scenario, while secure key quantity of generation exceeds consumption 99.5% of the time in cumulative key consumption scenario. Compared with existing conventional channel allocation algorithm, CQLI algorithm achieves a maximum increase of 0.485 in synergistic degree. DQN-based SRA algorithm demonstrates superior synergistic degree performance, achieving a maximum improvement of 0.213 and 0.198 in synergistic degree compared with the CQLI algorithm and existing synergistic core and wave length allocation algorithm, respectively.

title: Adaptive Collaborative DNN Inference via Heterogeneous Graph Attention in Edge Environments
authors: Chuxuan Shi, Bo Jiang, Hong Xu, Jinhui Xie, Chenglong Wang
abstract: Deploying deep neural networks (DNNs) in dynamic edge environments is challenging, as scheduling decisions must consider both the topological complexity of the DNN model and the variability of dynamic edge resources. Existing methods often fail to balance this trade-off, resulting in suboptimal performance. In this study, we introduce Heterogeneous Graph-Attention-Network-Based Collaborative Inference (HANCI), a framework designed to minimize end-to-end inference latency using an intelligent, context-aware scheduling approach. This framework employs a decoupled feature extraction architecture based on a heterogeneous graph attention network. It independently extracts high-quality features from static DNN computational graphs and dynamic edge environments. This decoupling allows HANCI to generate comprehensive, interference-free state embeddings. These embeddings support a hybrid decision-making strategy that combines a learned partitioning policy with a heuristic-guided placement mechanism, making the complex scheduling problem tractable. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that HANCI considerably outperforms baseline methods. It reduces inference latency by 21.6% for lightweight models and by up to 78.1% for complex architectures. This study provides a robust and adaptive solution to the challenge of collaborative DNN inference in edge environments.

title: Prediction of Long-term Prognosis in Infantile Epileptic Spasms Syndrome of Unknown Etiology based on Hypsarrhythmia by Self-Attention Autoencoder_supp1-3647091.xlsx
authors: Koichi Fujiwara
abstract: Infantile epileptic spasm syndrome (IESS) is developmental epileptic encephalopathy occurring in childhood. It is often difficult to predict long-term seizure outcomes at the time of onset, particularly in patients with unknown etiology. Predicting long-term seizure outcomes from electroencephalograms (EEG) at onset may be helpful for decision-making on therapeutic strategy by clinicians and families. This study included twenty-two patients with IESS of unknown etiology with a median follow-up period of 11 years (range 5-14 years). We categorized patients diagnosed with IESS of unknown etiology into good and poor outcome groups according to the presence or absence of seizures at the time of the last follow-up. Fifteen patients were categorized into the good outcome group, and the rest into the poor outcome group. A machine learning (ML) model was developed using scale EEG data during sleep to identify patients in the poor outcome group. A self-attention autoencoder (SA-AE), which is an anomaly detection method for time-series data, was adopted because the numbers of patients in the poor and good outcome groups were unbalanced. The ML model achieved a sensitivity of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.00\pm 0.05$</tex-math></inline-formula>, specificity of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.88\pm 0.11$</tex-math></inline-formula>, and accuracy of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.95\pm 0.06$</tex-math></inline-formula>. In addition, the AUROC was <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.91\pm 0.09$</tex-math></inline-formula>. Thus, the SA-AE model under development enabled highly accurate prediction of long-term prognosis in patients with IESS of unknown etiology. We confirmed that trained attention among the EEG channels could be explained from the viewpoint of pathophysiology of IESS. This study contributes to the determination of appropriate treatment for patients with IESS of unknown etiology.

title: PointFormer: A Spatiotemporal Data-Guided Algorithm for Aircraft Type Recognition
authors: Jinjin Zhang, Yunzhou Zhang, Fawei Ge, Tengda Zhang
abstract: Spatiotemporal trajectory data’s sparsity, irregularity, and fine-grained nature pose significant processing challenges. To address this, we introduce PointFormer, a deep learning framework. We demonstrate its efficacy through aircraft type identification, a quantifiable task that requires mining distinct flight patterns of different types from large-scale historical flight trajectories. At the first stage of our work, we employ Grad-CAM to demonstrate that points within trajectory sequences exhibit uneven contributions to predictions. Motivated by this, we propose the point-to-dynamic-voxel mapping and resampling (PMR) module, which dynamically merges redundant points by mapping clustered neighbors into sequence-specific voxels and employs farthest point sampling (FPS) to retain discriminative points. This generates a structured key-point sequence, thus enabling small-batch parallel training while ensuring no loss of critical information. Furthermore, to directly address irregular point dispersion, we design multi-scale consistent point embedding (MSCPE) using three distinct sliding window scales. PointFormer achieves significant and consistent gains, with PMR, MSCPE, and their combination delivering +14.9%, +7.2%, and +19.2% average improvements respectively, across varying aircraft type combinations.

title: Pulse Density Modulation for Active Rectifiers above 500 kHz in EV Chargers
authors: Thuong Ngo-Phi, Nam Nguyen-Quang
abstract: The growing demand for high-power-density electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure is accelerating the adoption of power converters operating at ultra-high switching frequencies. However, conventional modulation techniques such as PWM and SVPWM face increasing limitations at high frequencies, including narrow pulse issues, sampling inaccuracies, wide-bandwidth current sensor requirements, and high complexity in real-time control algorithms. This paper proposes and implements Pulse Density Modulation (PDM) as an alternative control strategy for the three-phase six-switch current source rectifier (CSR6SW) in fast EV chargers under 400 VDC. The proposed PDM technique is based on an offline modulation architecture, enabling enhanced resolution by adjusting the number of modulation blocks and switching pulses per cycle. LTspice simulation results at various frequencies (38.4 kHz, 172.8 kHz, and 691.2 kHz) demonstrate that PDM can synthesize near-sinusoidal input currents with low total harmonic distortion (THDi) and high power factor (PF > 0.99), requiring no real-time feedback. Notably, at 691.2 kHz, the system achieves THDi = 1.29% and PF = 0.9985, outperforming SVPWM in both waveform quality and control hardware simplicity. The proposed PDM approach shows strong potential for next-generation fast EV chargers employing current source rectifiers, centralized DC distribution, and high-efficiency isolated DC-DC converters - especially when combined with SiC/GaN power devices.

title: Optofluidic Lab-On-a-Chip System for Biometric Characteristics of Staphylococcus aureus Using Monte Carlo-Based Light Extinction Modeling
authors: Wen-Chien Chuang, Quoc-Thinh Dinh, Dang Khoa Tong, Cheng-Yen Kao, Cheng-Yang Liu
abstract: This study presents the first microfluidic system integrated with Monte Carlo simulations for biometric identification of Staphylococcus aureus suspensions. The system employs three microchannels with optical path lengths of 6 mm, 12 mm, and 18 mm to analyze photonic behavior, including transmission, scattering, and absorption. Experimental results demonstrate that transmission decreases with increasing optical path lengths and bacterial concentrations, consistent with light extinction theory. For nominal concentrations of 125 ppm, 250 ppm, and 500 ppm, the system estimates concentrations with deviations of -8 percent, -6.4 percent, and -9.4 percent, respectively. The bacterial radii are measured with high accuracy, showing deviations of 1.8 percent, 3.3 percent, and 4.3 percent around the nominal size of 1 µm. This microfluidic system offers real-time analysis, reduced sample volumes, and high precision, providing a groundbreaking platform for Staphylococcus aureus detection and characterization in biological diagnostics and environmental monitoring.

title: Adaptive Four-RBF-Based PID–SMC for Precise Trajectory Tracking of Piezoelectric Actuators
authors: Nguyen Thi Thu Hang, Nguyen Ngoc Son, Ho Pham Huy Anh
abstract: In this paper, an adaptive RBF based PID sliding mode control (RBF-PID-SMC) is proposed for piezoelectric actuator (PEA). In this approach, three radial basis function (RBF) neural networks are employed to estimate the PID sliding surface parameters, while an additional RBF network is designed to approximate the hysteresis characteristics of the PEA. The closed loop stability of the system is strictly analyzed and proven using Lyapunov theory. Simulation results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method in achieving high precision tracking control.

title: Identifying Validator Alliances by Voting Similarity in PoS Blockchain Governance via Visual Analytics System
authors: Jaeheon Kwak, Jaeuk Lee, Hyoji Ha, Haewon Kim, Hyunwoo Han, Kyungwon Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th Symposium on Large Data Analysis and Visualization (LDAV)
abstract: We present a visual analytics system to increase proposal approval likelihood in Proof-of-Stake(PoS) blockchain governance. The proposed system introduces the Contextual Alliance Index(CAI), a similarity metric reflecting contextual information based on proposal voting data. Through heatmaps and bubble heap graphs, users can explore alliances among validators and support comparison and prioritization of persuadable validators. Furthermore, a case study illustrates an analytical process for understanding voting patterns for each proposal, and for identifying alliances and the prioritization of persuadable validators when drafting new proposals. This study is expected to contribute to the in-depth analysis of proposal patterns and the development of effective proposal strategies by identifying validator alliances in PoS blockchain governance.

title: Wireless Power Transfer Receiver Side Charging Regulator with Synchronous Buck Converter for Smart Farming Robot
authors: Gervasius Geovan, Marojahan Tampubolon, Aryadharma Sudhartio, Ahmad Syahril Muharom
abstract: The Modern era has changed conventional farming into smart farming that uses various robots for monitoring or doing mechanical jobs. To support the autonomous function of the robot, a method of battery charging that is fully autonomous is required. The wireless charging method or wireless power transfer (WPT) can be applied to overcome this problem. Li-Po batteries are often used in robots and need a charging system that is fast, safe, and protects the battery’s life. This study proposes a synchronous buck converter used as the WPT receiver side for a battery charging controller using the constant current-constant voltage (CC-CV) method. A digital proportional integrator (PI) controller was implemented to regulate the charging process, maintaining a constant current of 3 A in CC mode and a 12 V constant voltage in CV mode. The converter has successfully developed and achieved 91.8% maximum efficiency under the CC mode. It has also successfully charged a 3-cell, 5000 mAh Li-Po battery within 1 hour, achieving an average efficiency of 85%.

title: An Explainable EEG Framework for Alzheimer’s and Frontotemporal Dementia Diagnosis Using Pairwise CSP and Random Forest
authors: Md Jewel Rana, Most. Nusrat Tasnim Ria, Shabbir Mahmood, Nakib Aman, Abu Saleh Musa Miah, Najmul Hassan, Yoichi Tomioka, Asai Nobuyoshi, Jungpil Shin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Alzheimer’s and frontotemporal dementia are generally recognized as common brain diseases. These serious diseases frequently change the brain’s connections and functions. They significantly impact well over 100 million people worldwide, and the number is growing. This study introduces an innovative technique for analyzing complex brain signals. This unique method is officially named Pairwise Common Spatial Pattern or PCSP. PCSP significantly enhances the accuracy of classification for EEG signals. Six different classifiers were rigorously evaluated. Random Forest demonstrated the highest overall precision, achieving an accuracy of 97.75%. Explainable AI (XAI) techniques were employed, with SHAP and LIME effectively identifying critical features and relevant EEG channels. These metrics are highly beneficial for this classification. The entire system definitively demonstrated rapid processing, completing in about 1.07 ms per sample. This speed indicates its potential use in accurate real-time applications. This novel approach establishes an efficient method for accurately diagnosing healthy individuals. It also facilitates earlier diagnosis for patients with devastating Alzheimer’s and frontotemporal dementia.

title: Hybrid DBSCAN-SMOTE with Attention-Augmented MLP for Detecting Low-Frequency DDoS Attacks in Imbalanced Network Traffic
authors: Rissal Efendi, Teguh Wahyono, Indrastanti Ratna Widiasari
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology (iCAST)
abstract: Traditional detection system struggle with Low-frequency Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks because of subtle behavior and underrepresented in network traffic data. A hybrid preprocessing framework is presented in this study, leveraging Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) to detect anomalies and Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) to balance the class distribution which is followed by an attention-augmented Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) classifier. By identifying low density region, DBSCAN effectively removes outliers, while SMOTE addresses class imbalance by generating synthetic samples of minority class. The attention mechanism enhances the MLP’s ability to focus on critical features, improving detection accuracy for rare attack instances. Experimental results on a benchmark DDoS dataset show improvements in F1-Score (0.929) and PR-AUC (0.956) compared to baseline models. The proposed method proves effective in detecting low-frequency DDoS attacks, while maintaining low false-positive rates in imbalanced network environments.
